HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Notes and Bills Decline

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury notes and bills fell yesterday on continued concerns over the impact of the bankruptcy of Orange County, Calif.
The market is concerned that some Wall Street firms may sell the government securities they hold as collateral for their loans to Orange County. 
 Prices of short-term Treasury securities fell 5/32 , while the declines in intermediate maturities ranged from 1/16 to 5/32 , according to Telerate Inc. The price of the two-year note fell 1/8, pushing its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, to 7.49 percent, from 7.43 percent on Wednesday.
The long end of the market, however, was stronger. The price of the 30-year bond rose 9/32 , to a price of 9528/32 , for a yield of 7.86 percent, down from 7.89 percent on Wednesday.
Despite the worries over Orange County, the municipal market steadied after a sharp drop on Wednesday.
Analysts said there was very little selling of California issues, with traders choosing to wait for further developments. John C. Mooney, a portfolio manager on the municipal side at SunAmerica Asset Management, said, "What bidding there was on California paper was limited and cautious, with few takers." He said the bids on shorter-maturity paper improved yesterday to 70 cents on the dollar, compared with 60 cents the day before.
The average yield to maturity in the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively trade municipal issues rose to 7.08 percent, from 7.06 percent on Wednesday.
The Treasury market initially extended its losses in early trading on persistent concern over the Orange County losses and Federal Reserve policy. On Wednesday, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, hinted strongly in testimony before the Congressional Joint Economic Committee that the Fed would soon raise short-term interest rates again, saying that the economy was continuing to grow briskly.
Hugh A. Johnson, chief investment strategist for the First Albany Corporation, said Mr. Greenspan's testimony left the impression that the Fed was likely to raise short-term interest rates for the seventh time since Februrary on either Dec. 20 or Jan. 31, when the Federal Open Market Committee, the central bank's policy-making committee, meets.
"It is my expectation that the central bank will raise the Federal funds target rate to 6 percent from its current 5.50 percent," Mr. Johnson said. "The assessment is short-term rates will be raised enough to slow the economy significantly and begin to ease concern of future inflation. At that point, we should begin to see indicators that lead inflation to abate."
In later trading yesterday, long bond prices drew some support from a firmer dollar in the currency markets. A stronger dollar means that dollar-denominated investments like Treasury securities become more attractive to foreign investors.
The Treasury auctioned $17 billion of new one-year bills, with the average rate at auction 6.75 percent, up sharply from last month, when it was 6.09 percent. A year ago it was 3.47 percent.
The following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of one-year bills:

HEADLINE: Dow Plunges 49.79 Points, To 3,685.73

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
The stock market, after three sessions of shrugging off news about Orange County's bankruptcy and the prospect of another interest-rate increase by the Federal Reserve, dropped sharply yesterday in unusually heavy trading, in part because of resurgent fears of a recession, some analysts said.
Other analysts attributed the fall to more technical factors, such as traders buying and selling stocks in their portfolios in advance of the expiration of quarterly options and the end of the year, when quarterly profits and losses are recognized. 
 Whatever the explanation, the Dow Jones industrial average fell throughout the day, but at 3:15 P.M. set off the so-called circuit-breaker rules designed to slow down high-speed computer-guided trading.
The Dow fell 49.79 points, to 3,685.73, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 5.78 points, to 445.45. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index fell 15.15 points, to 719.12.
Volume was unusually heavy throughout the day on the New York Stock Exchange but peaked in the last hour of trading, accelerating the selloff. A total of 362.8 million shares changed hands, about 25 percent more than this year's daily average of 288 million shares.
It was a curious session in which bond prices rallied but stock prices fell, a break from this year's pattern in which the fate of stocks and bonds has run almost parallel.
But the Dow, and also the S.& P. 500 and Nasdaq, fell from the beginning of the session, while bond prices were flat until 1 P.M. when they rallied strongly. Gold, which traders buy as a hedge against inflation, fell yesterday after prices had been flat for three sessions.
"This is the classic recession scenario," said Tracy Herrick, chief investment strategist for Jefferies & Company in Los Angeles. "Bonds rally, stocks drop, especially cyclical stocks, and nobody buys gold. The markets are saying that a recession could occur far sooner than anybody thinks."
Moreover, the yield curve of bonds is flattening, which means that short-term bonds pay almost as much as bonds with maturities of a decade or more. A wide variety of fixed-income securities are therefore attractive and could coax money into Treasury bills and notes and out of stocks.
For example, the one-year Treasury bond yesterday paid an interest rate of 7.17 percent, a five-year bond 7.75 percent and a 30-year bond 7.86 percent.
"The yield curve has had so many contractions that it's about to give birth," said Dirk van Dijk, equity strategist for C. H. Dean & Associates in Dayton, Ohio. "And the birth just might be recession. The Fed is walking close to that line when it says it will continue to raise interest rates."
Other analysts were less certain. "None of us in the market really knows where the trigger comes in," said Richard E. Meyer, managing director of institutional trading at Ladenburg, Thalmann. "The market has been fighting negative news for three days. It was just a buildup and, like a thunderstorm, it just happens."
Some stocks rose. AT&T rallied strongly, after falling for nearly a month, to rise 1 3/8, to 48 5/8. Prudential Securities and other brokerage firms raised their assessments of the company. Seneca Foods gained 3 1/4, to 34 1/2, after Grand Metropolitan contracted the processing of its Green Giant vegetables to Seneca.
Most stocks were down. National Semiconductor fell 1 3/4, to 17 3/8, after reporting second-quarter earnings that only matched Wall Street expectations.
And Hewlett-Packard, like a variety of other high-technology stocks that have been consistent winners throughout the year, fell 3 1/4, to 92 5/8.

HEADLINE: Wholesale Inventories Up

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8

 BODY:
Wholesale inventories increased for a fourth straight month in October, the Commerce Department said today, and sales increased moderately.
The steady rise in stocks of goods on hand during the fall indicates that wholesalers expected strong holiday sales prospects. 
 In a separate report that also showed a continuing strong economy, the Labor Department reported that the number of Americans filing new claims for state unemployment benefits for the week ended last Saturday came in below Wall Street economists' expectations of 325,000. Initial claims climbed by 6,000, to 322,000, from a revised 316,000 the week before, which included the Thanksgiving holiday. New claims for jobless benefits typically go down in a holiday week.
In the inventory report, the Commerce Department said inventories held by merchant wholesalers grew six-tenths of 1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $230.13 billion, following a revised five-tenths of 1 percent rise in September.
During October, wholesalers' sales increased three-tenths of 1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $174.93 billion, after falling in September by a revised five-tenths of 1 percent.
The additions to inventory in October were entirely at the durable goods level, as stocks of products like automobiles and furniture increased 1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $148.15 billion.
In the jobless report, the Labor Department said that the number of people filing continued claims for the week ended Nov. 26, the latest week for which the figures were available, edged back up from a five-year low the prior week.
The closely watched four-week moving average, which irons out weekly fluctuations and is considered a more accurate indicator of jobless trends than the weekly totals, dipped in the week ended last Saturday.
The average fell by 2,750, to 323,000, from a revised 325,750 a week earlier.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains on Speculation Fed Will Raise Rates Again

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against other leading currencies yesterday as dealers speculated that the Federal Reserve would soon raise interest rates again.
Expectations that United States interest rates would rise intensified after the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, told members of the Congressional Joint Economic Committee on Wednesday that the economy was still growing briskly, even though the Fed has raised rates six times since February. Higher rates make dollar deposits more attractive. 
 "Greenspan opened the door for another rate increase, and that's helping the dollar," said Jerry Egan, managing director of foreign exchange at MTB Bank.
In New York trading late yesterday, the dollar rose back above 100 Japanese yen, to 100.55 yen, from 99.95 yen on Wednesday. The dollar rose to 1.5773 German marks from 1.5677 marks,
The Fed last raised the two short-term interest rates it directly controls on Nov. 15, by a bigger-than-expected three-quarters of a percentage point each. The Fed's discount rate on direct loans to banks, which sets the floor for other rates, is 4.75 percent, compared with 4.5 percent in Germany and 1.75 percent in Japan. The difference means that traders give up interest payments when they sell dollars for marks and yen. More rate increases would make dollar purchases even more attractive.
"People would rather be long of dollars than short," given the outlook for United States rates, Gary Sakamoto, vice president at National Westminster Bank, said. "The question now is whether the Fed raises rates before the end of the year."
Concerns about the impact of the bankruptcy filing by Orange County, Calif., abated in the currency market, dealers said.
In other currency trading, the Australian dollar rallied to a three-year high against the United States dollar as copper and other commodity prices rose. The Australian currency often strengthens when commodity prices rise because the country is the world's sixth-largest copper producer and one of the world's largest exporters of raw materials.
The Australian dollar rose as high as 77.40 United States cents, its highest level since December 1991. In New York, it was last quoted at 77.35 United States cents, up from 76.99 cents on Wednesday.
The dollar was stronger against most European currencies, rising to 1.3366 Swiss francs, from 1.3255 francs on Wednesday. The British pound slipped to $1.5651 from $1.5632.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
Examining Women's Studies Programs

BYLINE: By MICHIKO KAKUTANI 

 BODY:

PROFESSING FEMINISM
 Cautionary Tales From Inside the Strange World of Women's Studies
 By Daphne Patai and Noretta Koertge
 235 pages. A New Republic Book/Basic Books. $24.
Toward the end of their chilling new book, Daphne Patai and Noretta Koertge draw some rather unflattering analogies between contemporary feminism (or at least feminism as they say it's being taught in many women's studies programs today) and religious cults, experimental communes and creationist science. 
 Like many religious sects, they argue, women's studies programs have grown increasingly dogmatic, increasingly obsessed with conformity and increasingly intolerant of deviant beliefs. Like many experimental communes, they say, these programs tend to evince a "bunker mentality" that regards the outside world with a mixture of hostility and disdain. And like creationists, they assert, many teachers in these programs dismiss traditional science and intellectual inquiry as biased, while trying to replace these methods with alternative systems of their own.
In fact, as Ms. Patai and Ms. Koertge see it, the brand of feminism promulgated by many university programs today is not simply about equal rights for women or the study of gender and sex. "Feminism aspires to be much more than this," they write. "It bids to be a totalizing scheme resting on a grand theory, one that is as all-inclusive as Marxism, as assured of its ability to unmask hidden meanings as Freudian psychology, and as fervent in its condemnation of apostates as evangelical fundamentalism. Feminist theory provides a doctrine of original sin: the world's evils originate in male supremacy. It regards the male's (usually: the white male's) insistence on maintaining his own power as the passkey that unlocks the mysteries of individual actions and institutional behavior. And it offers a prescription for radical change that is as simple as it is drastic: reject whatever is tainted with patriarchy and replace it with something embodying gynecentric values."
Ms. Patai, a professor of Spanish and Portuguese at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst, and Ms. Koertge, a professor of the history and philosophy of science at Indiana University, are both longtime veterans of women's studies programs, and they identify themselves as feminists who have become disillusioned with the direction that feminism has taken in recent years. Many of the arguments they set forth in this volume will be familiar to readers of such recent books as "Who Stole Feminism?," by Christina Hoff Sommers, "The Morning After," by Katie Roiphe, and "Illiberal Education," by Dinesh D'Souza.
Once again, we are treated to laments about feminism's insistence on depicting women as victims in need of self-esteem. Once again, we are shown some absurdities resulting from feminism's efforts to police the English language. Once again, we are given a litany of horror stories meant to illustrate the dangers of political correctness.
In "Professing Feminism," Ms. Patai and Ms. Koertge cite cases in which students are chastised for failing to toe the party line and are charged with "resistance." They recount the story of a woman who is accused by her colleagues of exhibiting "masculinist categories of thought" because she happens to be an economist and another story about an "art project" exhibited on a University of Maryland campus that "listed as 'potential rapists' male names pulled randomly from a student directory."
Such examples are indeed disturbing, but because of the highly arbitrary nature of this book, they are not entirely persuasive: Ms. Patai and Ms. Koertge note in a prologue that they have based "Professing Feminism" on interviews with 30 women from around the country (many of whom did not even want their real names or affiliations mentioned), supplemented with material culled from letters, memos, journal entries and computer forums. Given this improvisatory method on the part of the authors, the reader is inclined to take their examples with a grain of salt and disinclined to accept them as representative of the state of women's studies as a whole.
When it comes to analyzing the basic tenets of radical feminism and their practical consequences in academia, however, Ms. Patai and Ms. Koertge are decidedly more convincing. "It is ironic, and tragic as well," they write, "that feminism, which originally denounced traditional education for its failures to act in accordance with its self-proclaimed precepts of justice, fairness, equality and dispassionate evaluation, has so enthusiastically trashed the very principles on which its early (and, on the whole, warranted) denunciations rested."
Indeed Ms. Patai and Ms. Koertge repeatedly illustrate in these pages the unfortunate tendency of radical feminism to replicate some of the very unfairnesses and stereotypes feminism once decried. They point out that women's studies programs tend to reinforce the simplistic theory that associated intellect and logic with men, and sentiment and emotion with women.
The new feminists, they say, have simply reversed the traditional hierarchy of values associated with these identifications: subjective, "female" impressions are now supposed to be more valid than logically constructed, "male" arguments. Stereotypes of women as weak, infantilized creatures, Ms. Patai and Ms. Koertge suggest, are similarly ratified by radical feminists, who not only insist on blaming men for all of humanity's ills, but who also promulgate a view of the world as a threatening, male-dominated realm.
Ms. Patai and Ms. Koertge argue that because these views are promoted by teachers of women's studies with such fervor, because many of these teachers use "their classrooms as sites for the recruiting and training of students to be feminist activists," a clash with the traditional values of liberal education becomes inevitable. In fact, they suggest that there will always be an inherent contradiction in the dual agenda of women's studies: educational (the study of women and gender) and political (the correction of social injustice); academic (implying freedom of inquiry) and ideological (implying indoctrination).

HEADLINE: AT THE MET WITH: Hans Haacke;
Peering at a Wide World Beyond Works on a Wall

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN 

 BODY:
HANS HAACKE first achieved a measure of fame in 1971 when he did not have a show at the Guggenheim Museum. One had been planned. Then the museum's director, Thomas Messer, discovered that Mr. Haacke wanted the show to include documentation of the real-estate holdings of New York City slumlords. The Guggenheim wasn't the place for "active engagement toward social and political ends," Mr. Messer proclaimed. He canceled the exhibition, and its curator, Edward Fry, was dismissed.
Seen today in the lobby of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Mr. Haacke doesn't look fearsome. He's friendly, if a little cautious. He has only one stipulation about touring the museum: no photographs of him. "I don't want to push myself as a person into the foreground," he says. "The foreground should be my work. And also the image can be a fetish, a fetishization of the artist, which I don't want." For the record, the 58-year-old German-born Mr. Haacke is balding, bearded and of medium height, and on this day he is dressed casually in a black leather jacket. 
 His desire is to visit one corner of the Met: its galleries of 19th-century art and a nearby exhibition, "Origins of Impressionism," which examines painting in France in the 1860's. As you might expect, Mr. Haacke doesn't go through the museum as other people tend to do. He's almost as interested in the labels, the architecture, the lists of donors and exhibition sponsors -- the infrastructure and apparatus of the museum -- as he is in the art. But he's unpredictable: he stops to admire something on the wall for its sheer beauty. When he says, before starting out, that he has just a couple of ideas in mind, you know he's underplaying his hand. But though he chooses the works he wants to talk about, not to mention his words, very carefully, he's also a close listener, willing to acknowledge that his idea about something isn't the only, or the best-formed, one.
He sets out toward the 19th-century galleries. On the way, he makes a stop to look at photographs. One of them is a 1928 work by August Sander, "Unemployed Man, Cologne." The man's pose is demure, touching, and Mr. Haacke notes how, unlike many of Sander's models, he looks modestly away from the camera.
Mr. Haacke once based a painting, of the German chocolate manufacturer Peter Ludwig, on a Sander photograph of a pastry maker. Sander extensively photographed Cologne before and after World War II, when Mr. Haacke was a child there. Sander also saw his art as having a social, not just esthetic, purpose, which is another obvious explanation for Mr. Haacke's interest in him.
Mr. Haacke settled in New York City in the 1960's. At a time of Minimalism and Process and environmental art, his early works involved biological references: one, "Ant Co-op," consisted of an ant farm. Mr. Haacke's aim was to explore socialization among the ants.
In a sense, it wasn't all that big a leap from the ant work to the political works he began to do by the late 60's: these explored the dynamics of human relations, in particular the relations between corporations and individuals, governments and citizens, museums and museumgoers. Mr. Haacke's metier became a territory more familiar to investigative reporters than artists: one project he planned for a museum in Cologne involved tracing the backgrounds of the donors of a Manet, including one who turned out to have been a high official at the Deutsche Bank in the days of Hitler (that museum, like the Guggenheim, declined to show Mr. Haacke's work).
Over the years, Mr. Haacke has become the dean of political artists, and scores of followers have tried to imitate his blend of reportage, visual bite and wit. In turn, he is heir to figures like Bertolt Brecht, George Grosz, Hannah Hoch and John Heartfield. He has constructed sculptures and installations and done photographic pieces and paintings aimed at companies like the Swiss arms manufacturer Oerlikon-Buhrle, American Cyanamid, Mobil Oil and the advertising firm of Saatchi & Saatchi, and also at individuals like Margaret Thatcher, Ronald Reagan and George Bush. Often his goal is to document how art and art institutions are tied up with politics.
Sander had an interest in documentation, too: he undertook to photograph people from all parts of German society, dividing them into peasants, businessmen, the insane and so on. His accomplishment was to suggest the coherence of such categories while maintaining the individuality of each of his subjects. An initial selection of pictures in this vast, encyclopedic enterprise, which Sander called "Citizens of the 20th Century," was published in 1929, but the Nazis suppressed the book and no further parts of the project were published until after Sander's death in 1964.
What does Mr. Haacke make of the idea of cataloguing human types? "Cataloguing has dangerous overtones," he says. "But the Nazis tried to present specimens. There were the ideal types that they wanted to promote, and we all know the consequence of that. And then they had rogues' galleries. Sander was cataloguing as a sociologist might do."
 
Courbet and Cabanel
 The Met's recently redesigned galleries for its 19th-century European painting and sculpture collection are decorated in a Beaux-Arts fashion. From the entrance to them, at the end of a long columniated vista, is Courbet's "Young Ladies From the Village," a painting of the artist's sisters gathered in a valley near his native Ornans. "I am always struck by the sense of light, as if there is a spotlight on the women," Mr. Haacke says.
Then he turns to the Met's architecture. "Disneyland," he says. "The claim that this recreates the environment in which these paintings were first shown is not credible."
"The Paris Salons didn't look like this," he continues, referring to the giant annual state-sponsored exhibitions in Paris. It was in part by breaking with the traditions of the salon that avant-gardists defined themselves. "Paintings in the salons, as we know from photographs, were stacked from floor to ceiling. So this is fake. We can visit here on Sundays. But it's like slumming in the past.
"It would be great if one could arrive at a presentation that convicts, so to speak, the salon paintings, the official paintings, on their own terms. But it's not easy. And I admit I cannot offer a scheme."
Mr. Haacke's opinions aren't pat. About much of the so-called political art today, he says, "I am often impatient with all the well-intentioned stuff that doesn't turn me on visually." He volunteers that while he sympathized with the idea behind the last Whitney Biennial, with all its political art, the show depressed him. And the preachy, humorless tone of museum wall labels that try to link art with politics gives him "stomachaches -- not the principle behind them but their execution."
Still, Mr. Haacke looks especially closely at the wall labels accompanying the works on view, which typically give the title, name the artist and donor, and sometimes include an explanatory comment. He mostly finds them lacking.
He notes a label for the academician Alexandre Cabanel's "Birth of Venus," the famous image of a glassy female nude reclining on the crest of a wave. It lists the work's donor as John Wolfe. He was the cousin and art adviser of Catherine Lorillard Wolfe, one of the Met's first major patrons. "The picture was part of the bedrock of the Met's early collection," Mr. Haacke says, "which tells you something of the outlook of the founders of the museum. The salon was their model, in every sense of the word salon."
The label doesn't say enough about what the scene depicts, Mr. Haacke says: "The label should put us in the context of Cabanel's period. Also, a naked woman appears in the painting. I would talk about this somehow in the label: what it meant in Cabanel's time, what implications it has, how this subject is still our subject today."
Mr. Haacke expands: "When works of art are presented like rare butterflies on the walls, they're decontextualized. We admire their beauty, and I have nothing against that, per se. But there is more to art than that.
"Museums are managers of consciousness. They give us an interpretation of history, of how to view the world and locate ourselves in it. They are, if you want to put it in positive terms, great educational institutions. If you want to put it in negative terms, they are propaganda machines. They're both. This is something usually not acknowledged and there's probably a good reason why: because if this were in one's consciousness, then one would be a bit more immune to brainwashing, assuming brainwashing is the intent. Although I wouldn't go so far as to say that it is. That would be a little paranoid."
 
Paint and Passion
 "Origins" is around the corner. Within it, Mr. Haacke settles on Cezanne's "Madeleine," a big, grossly painted image, in the overheated manner of that artist's early work.
"This is a god-awful painting," Mr. Haacke says. "But it is one of the most interesting in the show. Not only is the imagery something we see later with Expressionism, but also the application of paint is so outrageous for its time. Paint is applied, to put it in fancy terms, to be a signifier for distress."
"Compared to the late, mature Cezannes -- they are great paintings, no question -- this one has energy behind it," he says. "It is painted with passion. The later ones are more staid."
Renoir's "Young Boy With a Cat" is a few feet away. It depicts a naked adolescent from the rear, standing, his legs crossed, his head turned back toward the viewer. The cat he leans over to cuddle sits on a tall piece of furniture covered in white silk. "Look at the way the cloth is pleated, soft, and how it contrasts with the figure next to it," Mr. Haacke says. "The folds, of course, are full of sexual connotations. I don't know of another painting off the top of my head of a young boy seen naked from the back. Obviously there's affection on the part of Renoir toward the boy. It's a homoerotic image. The boy is looking out at us in a very strange way -- as if there's some unspoken drama going on."
The Renoir is in a part of the show devoted to nudes. The centerpiece of it is Courbet's "Woman With a Parrot." Mr. Haacke sees a connection not only between its image of a reclining nude and Cabanel's "Birth of Venus" -- an obvious link -- but also, less obviously, with Marcel Duchamp. "The Courbet reminds me of that late Duchamp in the Philadelphia Museum of Art," he says, referring to "Etant Donnes," the famous work involving a peephole through which one sees a naked woman splayed on the ground. "The hair, the posture, the raised arm that in this case holds the bird and in the Duchamp, a gas lamp. The fuzzy background: a waterfall in Duchamp, here a vague landscape. And of course, they're both erotic images."
Courbet painted "Woman With a Parrot" around the same time that he did "Origin of the World," a close-up shot of a woman's genitals. Mr. Haacke sees those two paintings and the Duchamp as forming "a triad."
"It's important when we see something on exhibition that we think not only in terms of where it comes from, but also where it leads to," he says.
 
Manet the Reporter
 Around the corner, in a room of marine pictures, hangs Manet's "Battle of the Kearsarge and the Alabama." Mr. Haacke positions himself in front of it. The picture depicts a scene from the Civil War that occurred in French waters: the Confederate steam-driven corvette Alabama lost to the Union steam sloop Kearsarge outside Cherbourg harbor on June 15, 1864. The painting shows the Alabama sinking under a cloud of smoke into a dark green sea, the Kearsarge in the distance on the horizon and, in the foreground, a small French sailboat occupied by spectators. As the label says, the picture is "not simply a marine but also a reportage of a significant contemporary event."
Mr. Haacke points out how "carefully constructed it is, with this long diagonal from the sailboat in the lower left to the Kearsarge in the upper right, and the way the tips of the sails of the small boat line up with the Alabama."
"But it's also a curious composition," he continues, "because in the foreground, there's this huge expanse of mostly nothing, just water, of relatively uniform color and little detail. While at the back you have the opposite: very minute details, with all the ships and flags."
"A standard line, promoted by people like Clement Greenberg," Mr. Haacke goes on, referring to the late American art critic, "is that politics contaminates art, and Manet is often cited as an example of art for art's sake." Mr. Haacke overlooks the last quarter-century of Manet scholarship when he says this. Still, he has a point to make: "But here Manet is acting like a reporter and commentator. Aside from the fact that it's a beautiful painting, the reason I'm excited about it is because it's a precedent for making current political events a subject matter of art."
Manet was a trenchant social commentator, Courbet a revolutionary. Mr. Haacke next wants to look at a Courbet in the following room, "Oak Tree in Flagey, Called the Oak of Vercingetorix." Again, the politics behind the image intrigue him. In Courbet's day, the people of Burgundy and of the artist's native Franche-Comte region were in heated dispute over the site of Alesia, the ancient capital of Gallic resistance to Julius Caesar. Particularly in the 1860's, when Napoleon III ruled France, Alesia became a symbol of anti-imperialism. The giant oak, Courbet said, represented the Alesian site in Franche-Comte where Vercingetorix, the Gallic general, battled the Romans. The oak was a kind of surrogate portrait of the general by Courbet. It was also, maybe, a reference to the trees planted during the French Revolution as emblems of liberty.
"The tree is very strong," Mr. Haacke says. "The whole thing's painted with a palette knife, so there is a thick texture to the pigment. No trompe l'oeil." It reminds him of Brecht: "Brecht wanted his actors to present themselves to the audience as actors, in contrast to pretending that they are the people they portray."
He also sees a connection between the Courbet and a well-known work by the German Romantic painter Caspar David Friedrich, "Sea of Ice," in Hamburg. Friedrich is more of a political artist than people think, Mr. Haacke contends. "Sea of Ice" is an image of a shipwreck in frozen waters. Wood fragments protrude from the ice. Most people interpret them as shards of the ship's broken mast. Mr. Haacke says they are tree trunks, their branches cut off, representing trees of liberty like Courbet's oak. "Trees for Friedrich represented Germany," he says, "and that image expressed his disappointment at the failure of the democratic movement there."
The Friedrich, in any case, has a direct connection to Mr. Haacke's art: his installation at the German pavilion of the 1993 Venice Biennale, which consisted of a shattered stone floor, mimicked the broken ice in the Friedrich. "I'm a Romantic in many ways, like Friedrich," Mr. Haacke says, "though many people may not believe that."
 
Rediscovering Degas
 In the show's last room is Degas's enigmatic painting called "Interior (The Rape)." The image is of a woman seated in a room with her back to a man leaning against a closed door. On the small table between them is an open valise and a lamp that lights the scene. "Walking around the Met recently I rediscovered Degas, whom I didn't particularly care for," Mr. Haacke says. "I couldn't get excited about all those women in tutus. But I've come to believe his relationship to women was much more complicated and sympathetic than I had thought."
He wants to find a room of Degas sculptures back in the 19th-century galleries. On the way there he can't avoid the objects in the show's gift shop, like a locket modeled after one in a Manet. "I don't mind catalogues, books, postcards," he says. "I don't even mind calendars. But when the images are extracted and turned into merchandise, that's an insult to the artist."
Mr. Haacke also notes a sign that says the sponsor of "Origins" is Philip Morris. This leads him on a tangent: he says he isn't surprised that Philip Morris has recently tried to get cultural institutions to which it has given money to campaign on its behalf against anti-smoking legislation. The company asked them to get in touch with the New York City Council to stress how important the company is to the arts here.
In 1990, Mr. Haacke recalls, he created a giant cigarette package, modeled after Philip Morris's Marlboro brand, with "Helmsboro" where the word Marlboro would be. A picture of Senator Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican, was placed within the Philip Morris insignia. And the words "Philip Morris funds Jesse Helms" were printed on each of the cigarettes, a reference to contributions by the company to the Senator's re-election campaign at a time when Mr. Helms was vigorously campaigning against the National Endowment for the Arts.
Mr. Haacke's SoHo gallery, John Weber, got a letter from a Philip Morris lawyer who had seen an announcement card for the show. The lawyer objected to the use of the Marlboro design, and Mr. Haacke had reason to believe from the letter that the gallery would be sued if the show went on as planned. (The lawyer insists he was only trying to stop the gallery from using the design on the card.)
"We ignored it," says Mr. Haacke. "But in most cases, the gallery would have said to the artist, 'We love you, but we don't have the money to fight this.' "
 
Women and Work
 Mr. Haacke is still looking for Degas. He arrives on the way at a Rodin of a headless nude woman with her legs spread. "Here's something that Jesse Helms would object to and also his complement, Catharine Mac Kinnon," he says, referring to the feminist lawyer and writer. "I don't think the truncation was intended as amputation. It's not pornographic. Rodin's references are probably to the venerated fragments of classical sculptures."
Degas's sculptures are crowded together in a small gallery nearby. They're difficult to see behind glass in bulky cabinets. "I want to show you this one of a pregnant woman," Mr. Haacke says. He points to a sculpture almost hidden in a corner. "This is the reason why my ideas about Degas and women have changed: it seems to me rather sympathetic and caring."
Mr. Haacke says his recent work designing sets for a ballet in Berlin has given him a new outlook on Degas's sculptures of dancers, too. "They're not nudes presenting themselves to a voyeur," he says. "They are working women, dancers. I've gone to rehearsals and watched the dancers, and their physical strength and control, and the use of their bodies as a means of expression, is unbelievable. You see that in Degas."
He is struck in particular by Degas's famous bronze of a 14-year-old ballerina wearing an actual muslin tutu and a silk ribbon around her hair. "The bronze figure pretends to be a real human while the tutu and ribbon are, in fact, the real stuff," Mr. Haacke says. "I don't know how to express it perfectly, but the relationship between reality and representation becomes complicated. The real world and the fictive world mingle. It's the precursor to the collages of Picasso and to the Dadaist ready-made."
The mingling of art and the real world has an obvious relevance to Mr. Haacke's work. "There is a tendency to sequester, to ghettoize art, to separate it from the world that we actually inhabit," he says. "But Degas, here, is breaking down the barriers."

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
Another Day in Battle Of the Blazing Faxes

BYLINE: By JOE LAPOINTE 

 BODY:
Day 69 of the National Hockey League lockout passed without further negotiations, but the two sides kept busy by firing up their fax machines for another bout of battling memos.
Bob Goodenow, the executive director of the N.H.L. Players Association, sent a letter to Commissioner Gary Bettman yesterday, reiterating the union's opposition to a payroll tax of any kind and its belief that sufficient concessions had been made on other issues to make the tax unnecessary. 
 The league, meanwhile, circulated communication among its teams indicating that the union either misunderstood or was misrepresenting its latest proposal.
The league formally canceled the All-Star Game, which was supposed to be held on Saturday, Jan. 21, in San Jose, Calif. So far, it has canceled 24 games of each team's 84-game schedule. To salvage at least a 40 or 50-game season, they need an agreement around the end of December.
No further negotiations are expected before the league's Board of Governors meets on Monday in New York. Until then, everyone can keep busy by reading from the blizzard of literature that is gushing from N.H.L.P.A. headquarters in Toronto and from league headquarters in Manhattan.
Although the union missive was sent by Goodenow to Bettman yesterday, it is likely to find its way to the desks of owners, either through Bettman or through union representatives on the respective teams who also were sent copies.
There are some on the union side who feel Bettman hasn't kept owners fully informed on union concessions because they feel Bettman is too committed to a luxury tax that would function as a salary cap. There also are some on management side who feel Goodenow has kept his membership less informed than it needs to be about management needs and demands.
In five pages, the union letter restates what the union calls concessions it made regarding free agency, arbitration and a rookie salary cap during recent weeks of bargaining. It repeats the union's opposition to a salary cap in any form, including a luxury tax on payrolls or a "contribution," as Bettman called it when he presented it to the union on Tuesday in Chicago. That presentation led to the latest recess in the talks.
"I am writing to express our concern over your decision to derail the progress we have made," Goodenow said in the letter. He said the other concessions were made to create a "drag" on salary inflation as an alternative to a "tax/cap system" Bettman seeks.
Yesterday's management letter, sent by the senior vice president Jeffrey Pash to all teams, said the union "is either misrepresenting the proposal or does not understand it, neither of which is encouraging," according to people who have seen the letter.
Referring to a Wednesday union memo, which was widely circulated in hockey circles, Pash wrote, "The exaggerated attack on the new proposal contained in the union memorandum ignores key elements of our proposal and appears to be a scare tactic to prevent a reasoned analysis of the plan."
Pash said that the impact of the tax is less than that claimed by the union.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Player Proposal to Seek Partnership

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Dec. 8

 BODY:
The emphasis in the new proposal the players will present to the owners on Saturday is on cooperation between the two sides, people familiar with the plan said today.
"We certainly can use that," one management official said. 
 But with the owners less than a week away from the new date for setting into motion their impasse/ implementation strategy, the No. 1 question about the players' proposal is will the owners abandon their hard stance on player salaries and opt for cooperation over instant economics.
"This proposal addresses the owners' stated concerns," Craig Fenech, an agent from New Jersey, said after the union's meeting with agents. "It should provide a basis for satisfying them. But I think they have an agenda. A number of owners want to try replacement players. I expect they're going to implement. I think we're headed to a last-man-standing scenario."
Union officials again declined to disclose details of the proposal they will unveil to the owners Saturday in Rye Brook, N.Y. Others have said the proposal contains a tax on club payrolls. One agent emerged from the four-and-a-half-hour meeting and said the agents were told the tax would be a scale of 4 percent to 6 percent. Two other agents said they were not given specifics. They also said union officials told them not to disclose what they were told.
At that level of tax, the players moved well off the approximately 1.5 percent tax they had proposed in September that the owners quickly rejected. The owners didn't bother finding out, but the union at the time did not seem prepared to go beyond 2 percent.
But their new rate is still worlds away from the owners' tax proposal, the alternative they presented to the salary cap they really want, that calls for a limitless tax and this year, had it been in full effect, would have cost the Detroit Tigers 77 percent of their top-rated payroll, or nearly $44 million.
The players, however, prefer to emphasize the value of a cooperative effort between them and the owners. They believe such a venture would generate enough revenue for the clubs to make them forget about restraining salaries.
Approximately $70 million of the money generated by the players' proposal would be distributed among the lower-revenue clubs the owners want to help financially. That's the amount the owners targeted in the revenue-sharing plan they adopted last January. To reach that $70 million figure, the union would determine what tax rate would be necessary to apply to the clubs' payrolls.
Other money, an agent said, would be used to finance the cooperative venture in such areas as licensing and marketing, international enterprises and local promotion.
"There are aspects of cooperative endeavors," Donald Fehr, the union head, acknowledged after the meeting.
The plan would not necessarily mean the players would join in the selection of a commissioner or serve on committees negotiating such matters as a national television contract. But they would have some input into some decision-making.
Tony Attanasio, a California agent, applauded the "partnership attitude" reflected in the proposal.
"For those who have a preconceived notion of implementation, I don't think it will do anything," said Attanasio, who earlier in the talks was one of the agents talking behind the scenes with owners. "But it shows the degree of imagination and intelligence needed to run this game as a business. It clearly and absolutely satisfies the suggestion that the players don't want to work with the owners for the betterment of the game."
Alluding to the three-fourths vote the owners need to ratify an agreement, he added: "If there are among the owners 21 people who have enough intelligence to see the philosophical modifications, to the extent they will see them, there should be a deal struck. If there are not 21 people, it would shock me that there are 21 dumb owners."
But again, Attanasio was talking philosophy and the owners have been talking economics. Would the players' proposal put a "drag" on salaries?
"I can assure you," the agent said, "the players' proposal will serve to satisfy, to a degree, what the owners have asked for and talked about for months."
Besides hearing about the proposal, in however specific or vague the terms, the agents discussed with union officials contract-signing both before and after implementation.
Attanasio said the union's view on having players sign before implementation is to consider each deal on its merits. Attanasio and Fehr said that post-implementation has to be discussed further by the union and the agents. "It was not resolved," Fehr said.
Unless negotiations are proceeding toward a settlement, the owners are scheduled to meet in Chicago next Thursday to act on declaring an impasse in the talks and implement their salary-cap proposal.

HEADLINE: Mostly Mozart And Its Players Reach Accord

 BODY:
Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts and a committee of musicians from the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra agreed on a three-year contract on Wednesday evening. The contract lays to rest the musicians' fears that Lincoln Center planned to kill Mostly Mozart, although the festival has been reduced to four weeks from seven. The contract must still be ratified by the orchestra.
The contract gives the musicians increased wages, benefits and seniority pay, as well as health and pension benefits. Neither the union nor Lincoln Center would discuss the details of the increases, but under the last contract the musicians' minimum weekly pay was $1,165 for a total of nine rehearsals and concerts per week. The contract also provides for the orchestra to continue post-season concerts in Tokyo and for special concerts during the year. 
 Mary Landolfi, the vice president of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, which represents the orchestra, said that although the new contract guaranteed the musicians less work than the previous contract, the union considered the new guarantees firmer, since in the past Lincoln Center was obligated to pay only supplementary unemployment benefits if the festival was shorter than six weeks.
The 1995 festival -- the 29th season of Mostly Mozart -- is scheduled to run from July 24 through Aug. 19.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Nobody's At Home

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
In the month since the election we have been waiting to see whether Bill Clinton could recover from the defeat and emerge a stronger person and President. As of now, the answer looks to be no.
Weakness and vacuity are what we see in the Clinton Administration. It moves from day to day, empty of vision, a Government without a design. Mr. Clinton himself seems more and more like Herman Melville's Bartleby the Scrivener, a dwindling, haunting presence in the White House. 
 There was a telling example of the way things are in the Administration's change of policy last week on Bosnia. It gave up the effort to have NATO press the Serbian aggressors by serious attacks, giving way to British and French objections.
The New York Times published a detailed report on how the decision came about. It was proposed in a memorandum by the President's national security adviser, Anthony Lake, the story reported, and "formally embraced at a meeting of the President's top advisers that neither Mr. Clinton nor Vice President Al Gore attended."
Mr. Clinton had approved the Lake memo, the report said, but he "was at his Camp David retreat and had been involved only sporadically in the Bosnian issue." So he hardly participated in the discussion of a decision that has fateful implications for resistance to aggression and genocide in Europe and for the future of the Western alliance.
And then Secretary of State Christopher, at a NATO meeting in Brussels, proclaimed that the alliance was in wonderful shape. "NATO is going to make itself relevant to the future," he said. It had stronger structures that would "help deal with crises like Bosnia at an earlier stage." Sure.
The truth is that the Clinton Administration has no meaningful policy now on Bosnia, or on the other religious-ethnic-nationalist conflicts that menace Europe. And its policy on Russia, once its proudest boast, has been undone by President Yeltsin's increasingly nationalist stance.
All this is not just a bad patch for Bill Clinton in foreign policy. It is a frightening absence of American strategy and American will: the two factors that kept the peace in Europe for nearly 50 years.
On the domestic side there is a similar sense of emptiness. Does anyone count on President Clinton to lead the fight against mean-spirited actions by the Republican leadership in Congress? Can anyone detect in him commitment to a set of political values? There are values to defend at this time, Lord knows: values just as traditionally American as the ones the Republicans talk about. A commitment to civil liberties, for one. A concern for the underdog, for the stranger at the gates.
Immigration is a crucial example. A growing nativism is using legal and illegal immigrants as scapegoats for economic troubles. Many Republicans in Congress are talking about a Federal version of California's Proposition 187.
Last week The Washington Post carried a powerful article decrying the anti-immigrant movement. Was it by a Clinton Administration official or some other leading Democrat? No, it was by William J. Bennett, the conservative Republican. During the week another important voice opposed Proposition 187 on the Federal level: Senator Alan Simpson, the conservative Republican from Wyoming.
Since the election Mr. Clinton has made no effort to counter the radical Republican line that government is evil -- no effort to remind Americans how much they need government. To the contrary, he has mimicked Republican ideas on budget-cutting and spending more on defense.
To write critically about the President is not easy for me. He has done many good things, from Haiti to GATT, and has not had the credit he deserves. He has been savaged by a brutal opposition and by a press that even Newt Gingrich says has been "very tough on the President and on Mrs. Clinton."
But Bill Clinton faces a fundamental test now, and he is not meeting it. After the election commentators said he might rally to smite the enemy like Harry Truman; how unlikely that prospect seems today. If he is going to be President, he has to pull himself together and make some major changes in his Administration. I think he has no more than a month or two to convince us that he can govern.

HEADLINE: More Mexicans, More Profit

BYLINE: By Lydia Chavez; Lydia Chavez teaches journalism at the University of California at Berkeley.

DATELINE: SALINAS, Calif.

 BODY:
Like the rest of the state, Monterey County favored Proposition 187, which denies education and health services to undocumented workers and their families. The clear message of the vote statewide, pundits say, is that we need to do something about illegal immigration.
But as seen from Salinas, the only thing clear is that political leaders like Gov. Pete Wilson, who offered Proposition 187 as a solution, are hypocritical at worst and wrongheaded at best. They actually send a different message, one that puts food on the table: "Hay trabajo en Salinas" -- there's work in Salinas. Keep trekking across the border and up through the Central Valley; at the end of the journey, si, hay trabajo. 
 Everybody knows that the fields of lettuce, broccoli, mustard greens and grapes are filled with illegal laborers. Farm workers put the number at 40 percent, the growers at 33 percent.
Voters would think Governor Wilson wanted to get rid of some of these Mexican workers, but in an appearance at the Heritage Foundation in Washington on Nov. 18 he supported the idea of inviting even more into the country as part of a guest worker program. "It makes sense -- it has in the past, it may well continue to do so in the future," he said, explaining that only workers but not their families would be allowed in.
Instead of penalizing a multibillion-dollar industry that hires undocumented workers, he supports it and picks on schoolchildren instead. Now, Newt Gingrich, the next Speaker of the House, and others say they will support similar legislation in the G.O.P.-controlled Congress.
Proposition 187 doesn't matter to the illegal workers picking lettuce in Fresno and oranges near San Diego. They come north not for health care or the schools but for jobs, and Proposition 187 does nothing to prevent employers from hiring them. As long as there's work, they'll stay; family and friends will follow, even if they are denied services.
Growers say with a straight face that they hire illegal workers unwittingly, that they are easily fooled by fake Social Security cards. But no one is likely to discover the fraud: only one Immigration and Naturalization Service official in San Jose is in charge of checking up on employers in a four-county area.
Never any problems in Salinas, said Ed Angstadt, president of the Grower-Shipping Vegetable Association of Central California. Everyone turns a blind eye. The immigrants keep coming. Why not? Hay trabajo.
Mr. Wilson blames the Feds for failing to enforce the law -- an easy out. If he was serious about controlling immigration, Proposition 187 would have focused on the employers.
"We need all those people," said Mr. Angstadt, explaining that the growers' association kept silent on Proposition 187. "You can't take a position against people you rely on to work for you. On the other hand, you don't want to offend the Governor."
It's easy to see why. As a Senator, Pete Wilson made sure the Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986 made it easy for foreign workers to become citizens. Now he proposes adding to their numbers.
"All those people" Mr. Angstadt cites keep wages down. A field worker gets $1.23 for picking 24 heads of lettuce -- some 15 percent less than the piece rate 10 years ago. Growers sell that box of lettuce for $8 to $10. Imagine how profit margins will widen even further if we invite more Mexicans into the fields.
"All those people" make it impossible for unions to organize for better wages and working conditions. Too many field workers fear that supporting a union will get them deported, and union contracts are nearly as scarce as immigration agents.
Mexican-Americans must compete for jobs with "all those people" who are their desperate brothers from the south. As a result, unemployment here has increased; to no one's surprise, crime has followed.
Last year, the voters in Salinas and elsewhere started looking around for someone to blame for crime and unemployment. There are too many people here, a beleaguered Mr. Wilson told them, and his ratings jumped. But instead of trying to cut off the lure of jobs, he chose to throw children out of school and turn the sick away from doctors.
Proposition 187 provides no answer to real concerns about immigration, but it did provide a banner under which politicians like Pete Wilson can advance their careers. While they play on the fears of frustrated Americans, Mexicans will choose reality: hay trabajo en Salinas.

HEADLINE: Plans to Trim Government Reach Deep Into Benefits

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7

 BODY:
Leaders of a Federal panel studying the cost of Government benefit programs have suggested far-reaching changes, including an increase in the age at which people qualify for Social Security and Medicare, reductions in Social Security payments to affluent people and new limits on tax deductions for the wealthy.
 These and other options are to be discussed at a meeting of the panel on Friday. The panel, created by President Clinton in November 1993, is headed by Senators Bob Kerrey, Democrat of Nebraska, and John C. Danforth, Republican of Missouri. 
The proposals are not intended to balance the Federal budget, but seek to hold the budget deficit to its current share of the nation's economic output, 2.3 percent, through the year 2030.
 Mr. Kerrey, the chairman of the commission, and Mr. Danforth, the vice chairman, are trying to muster support for their ideas among the other 30 members of the panel. The proposed changes are so broad and so politically explosive that the Senators appear unlikely to win support from a majority of the commission for the entire package, but they are finding support for many elements.
 Clinton Administration officials have been briefed on the proposals. Without endorsing any specific option, Mr. Clinton's budget director, Alice M. Rivlin, said today: "The Kerrey commission is playing an extremely useful role. It's focusing attention on the big problems of the next century."
 The panel, the Bipartisan Commission on Entitlement and Tax Reform, will submit its final report to the President and Congress by the end of this month, just in time to influence deliberations in the next Congress, which convenes on Jan. 4.
 Mr. Clinton and Republican leaders of Congress have said they will not touch Social Security next year, though many experts say some changes are needed to shore up the finances of the program over the next 35 years. Robert E. Denham, the chairman of Salomon Inc., who is a member of the commission, said the necessary changes would be far more painful if Congress deferred action.
 Ninety percent of the proposed reductions in the Federal budget deficit would be achieved through cuts in the growth of Federal spending. The remainder would come from higher taxes.
 To make the plan politically palatable, Mr. Kerrey and Mr. Danforth propose cutting the pensions for members of Congress by 40 percent. But the commission includes five people who are retiring from Congress, so this proposal may encounter opposition.
 The plan also includes these options, for which Mr. Kerrey and Mr. Danforth are seeking support:
 *Gradually increase the age at which workers may qualify for Medicare and may retire with full Social Security benefits.
 *Reduce Social Security benefit payments to more affluent retirees by changing the formula used to calculate benefits. The commission says this would make the formula "more progressive."
 *Establish a test of financial need for all Government benefit programs except Social Security and Medicare. This could reduce farm subsidies, unemployment compensation and some veterans' benefits for recipients with high incomes.
 *Impose new limits on the value of itemized tax deductions that may be taken by people in the higher income brackets. This would raise taxes for couples with incomes exceeding $92,000 a year.
 Another proposal would let workers take part of their current payroll taxes and invest it in a private retirement plan. These people, presumably those with average and above-average incomes, would receive lower Social Security benefits in the future, reducing outlays from the Social Security trust fund.
 The panel said that Government benefits like Social Security, Medicare, Medicaid and food stamps now accounted for 47 percent of all Federal spending and would account for 58 percent in the year 2003. These figures do not include interest on the Federal debt, an irrevocable commitment that accounts for 14 percent of all Federal spending.
 Commission members generally praised Mr. Kerrey for his efforts. One, Thomas J. Downey, a former Democratic Representative from Long Island, said, "Kerrey should be given credit for reaching out and offering some bold initiatives."
 Another member of the panel, Robert Greenstein of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, an expert on antipoverty programs, said, "The package as a whole includes so many controversial elements that I doubt you could get a majority for it on the commission."
 But many of the proposals are worthwhile, Mr. Greenstein said, adding, "It's not an all-or-nothing proposition."
 Mr. Kerrey's recommendations on Social Security are similar to those made in April by Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee. Mr. Rostenkowski, an Illinois Democrat, lost his bid for re-election last month, but is still a member of the commission.
 Workers may now retire with full Social Security benefits at the age of 65. This "normal retirement age" will rise gradually under current law, reaching 67 for people born in 1960 or later. The commission is considering proposals to accelerate this increase and perhaps to raise the retirement age even further, to 68 or 70.

HEADLINE: Johannesburg Journal;
Corporate Foe of Apartheid Finds Reward Elusive

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 8

 BODY:
After a decade of corporate homage to the anti-apartheid movement, Pepsi-Cola expected to enter South Africa in political and commmercial triumph -- the liberation soft drink.
 Unlike its arch-competitor Coca-Cola, which kept its brand in the South African market during years of trade sanctions against white domination, Pepsi pulled out in 1985 and stayed away until this year, when the black majority won the right to elect its own Government. 
When Pepsi returned, it came as a paragon of black economic power.
 The majority shareholders in the franchise are African-American celebrities like Whitney Houston, Danny Glover and Shaquille O'Neal, who plan to transfer ownership to black South Africans gradually. The company, called New Age Beverages, is managed by South African blacks. The work force is predominantly black, and the delivery men are all black drivers who have set themselves up as independent contractors with loans from Pepsi.
 But rather than being lionized as a hero of the struggle, Pepsi has become its latest target. Every day since September, hundreds of protesters have assembled outside the new bottling plant in Germiston, a Johannesburg suburb, demanding jobs that Pepsi says are already filled.
 The protesters have blocked delivery trucks and clashed with the police. They have stormed the property, on one occasion stampeding into a barbed-wire fence. Several protesters were injured in that incident, and the demonstrators say one woman died of her wounds.
 The job-seekers have been unbudged by the entreaties of local officials, who fear the attacks on Pepsi will alarm other companies contemplating a return to South Africa.
 Besides the obvious causes of the protest -- that South Africa has a black unemployment rate of about 50 percent, that a culture of protest has flourished in the absence of normal democracy -- the managers of the company draw another, bitter lesson: that a social conscience confers no immunity.
 In fact, said Monwabisi P. Fondeso, president of New Age Beverages, the company may be a victim of its own political correctness. By trying to identify so closely with the cause of South Africa's blacks, he says, Pepsi may have created an impression that it sees itself as a social program rather than a business.
 The job-seekers say they initially gathered because they heard -- through Pepsi's own saturation promotion campaign -- that a big, well-paying international company was opening shop.
 At first, Pepsi played along, meeting with representatives from the factory gate and even allowing the protesters to fill four of its $2.65-an-hour jobs by plucking identity cards, lottery style, from a cardboard box.
 But the swarm of job-seekers grew, and the demands became more insistent. The company said the job-seekers at the gate could submit applications like anyone else.
 The protesters' angriest indictment of Pepsi is that the company has been "poaching" experienced workers from Coca-Cola and other beverage companies, rather than hiring unskilled workers and training them.
 "The company was not creating jobs for the unemployed," said Norman Nxasano, chairman of an impromptu job-seekers' committee. "It was a relocation of workers from one place to another place."
 The company replies that it needs skilled bottlers to regain a foothold in a $1 billion market that is virtually a Coke monopoly. While Pepsi disappeared from South Africa, Coca-Cola licensed a South African company to continue selling its brand, and opened a plant in neighboring Swaziland to supply the market.
 Mr. Fondeso said that Pepsi, as a black-owned company, is supposed to be "more humane, understanding. We're supposed to be perhaps more empathetic."
"I think we are all these things," he added, "but we are also, first and foremost, a business."
 Mr. Nxasano said the jobless know of Pepsi's efforts to promote black control, but they expect more.
 "To prove that they are a good company, they must prove that here in South Africa," he said. "As we are here, the company must employ us."
 To job-seekers like Colbert Mkhabele, out of work for more than two years, the months-long vigil outside the Pepsi gates makes perfect sense. Prior to Pepsi's return, he said, he spent his days drifting from factory gate to factory gate without hope. Pepsi seems like a better gamble.
 For one thing, he said, the job-seekers do not believe that Pepsi has no more jobs. But even if it is true at the moment, the company will probably expand. Pepsi, after all, had a third of the cola market when it pulled out nine years ago. And by the protesters' logic of fair play, those who showed up first at the gate are entitled to preference.
 "We must stay here until we get a good result," Mr. Mkhabele said.
 William Rankwe, another supplicant at the Pepsi gate, added, "If they don't compromise, well, there are many ways to kill a cat."
 As for other companies considering investments in South Africa, the protesters say, they are welcome -- as long as they play by the new rules. The job-seekers, who are trying to link up with other organizations of the unemployed, say they want a Government code of conduct that would include a mandate to hire the neediest people and train them.
 "If other companies from the West come and they don't do what Pepsi has done, then no problem," said Alfred Maruapula, another of the job-seeking throng. "As long as they can hire people from the gate, there won't be any problem."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Unemployed South Africans demanding jobs protested outside the Pepsi-Cola bottling plant in Germiston, near Johannesburg, last month. (Themba Hadebe)

HEADLINE: Link Sought In Sicknesses At 2 Colleges

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 8

 BODY:
Hundreds of college students have fallen ill with nausea, diarrhea and vomiting at Dartmouth College and Harvard University, and Federal epidemiologists are trying to discover if there is any connection between the two outbreaks.
 The first illnesses were reported last weekend at Dartmouth, in Hanover, N.H., when more than 100 students were afflicted. It came at the worst possible time for many of them, during last weekend before final examinations. 
A similar sickness struck many freshmen here at Harvard on Tuesday night. Since then more than 200 students have complained of vomiting, nausea, diarrhea and dehydration.
 Two doctors from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta came to Harvard Yard to investigate possible causes of the outbreak.
 Doctors and health officials at both colleges are trying to learn whether the symptoms were brought on by a common source, like food poisoning or contaminated water, or by a highly contagious virus.
 They are also trying to determine if there has been any recent contact between Harvard and Dartmouth, like intramural sports.
 So far, said Joe Wrinn, a spokesman for Harvard, "We haven't been able to establish any link."
 Harvard sent written surveys to its students. At Dartmouth, where every student must have a computer, the medical surveys were sent out via electronic mail.
 No common origin of illness has been found at either college. Investigating the possibility that the illness was caused by food poisoning, Harvard temporarily closed the Freshman Union, where many freshman eat, and sent samples of 40 different kinds of food to laboratories for testing.
 Michael Luo, 18, a freshman at Harvard, went to the Freshman Union on Tuesday night and ate pork chops, fusilli, a grilled cheese sandwich and some milk. Later that night he woke up sick.
 "It was really violent," Mr. Luo said. "It wasn't a pleasant experience."
 Many of Mr. Luo's classmates missed their economics test the next day.
 Doctors and nurses worked through the night at Harvard's Stillman Infirmary, which treated more than 150 students.
 When Shirin Sinnar, a 17-year-old freshman, arrived at the infirmary on Wednesday morning, there were no beds left. She spent the day on a cot in a nearby library. Ms. Sinnar said that many sick students did not eat at the Freshman Union.
 "We had all eaten at different places," she said. "One of us ate at the Union, one of us ate at Hillel, and one of us skipped dinner."

HEADLINE: Western Europeans Cast A Cautious Line Eastward

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ESSEN, Germany, Dec. 8

 BODY:
Smarting from their setbacks in Bosnia and Russia's criticism of overtures to the east, leaders of the 12 nations in the European Union will offer Eastern European countries a tentative road map to membership at a two-day summit meeting that begins here on Friday, diplomats say.
 With their meeting overshadowed by recent discord with the United States over the failed United Nations peacekeeping mission in Bosnia, the European leaders are expected to try to avoid open disputes. 
There are differences among them nonetheless.
 Chancellor Helmut Kohl, who sought $8.5 billion in grants and loans over the next five years to help central and eastern European countries prepare for membership, had to settle for $6.6 billion, officials said.
 France, supported by Spain, Portugal and Italy, was unwilling to accept the higher sum unless the group also increased aid to North African and Mediterranean countries to $6.6 billion, more than the Germans and other northern Europeans wanted to provide.
 The split reflects growing anxiety in France that the European Union, which will expand to 15 members next month when Finland, Sweden, and Austria join, has been dancing too much to Germany's tune.
 Germans view instability in Eastern Europe as the greatest threat to security; France and other southern European countries are more anxious to prevent the spread of Islamic fundamentalism in North Africa.
 The president of the European Union's executive commission, Jacques Delors, called NATO's decision last week to spell out terms for prospective members by the end of next year premature.
 NATO allies agreed that it would be years before any Eastern European countries could qualify for membership, and reaffirmed their desire to develop relations with Russia to avoid "new lines of partition." But the Russian Foreign Minister, Andrei V. Kozyrev, and President Boris N. Yeltsin denounced the overture nevertheless as a threat to Russian interests.
 Mr. Delors said the European Union would be more cautious, but impatient Eastern Europeans view it as too slow.
 Only at the last minute was Mr. Kohl able to obtain French approval to invite leaders of six Eastern European countries here on Saturday. The six countries, Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Bulgaria and Romania, have "association" agreements with the European Union.
 These six countries will be offered a "structured dialogue" as the union spells out guidelines for transforming their formerly Communist economies to become part of the free market. The six will be free to trade with Western Europe in the meantime, though there will be limits on how much steel, coal, textiles and clothing -- their most competitive products -- they can sell.
 Richard Portes, director of the Center for Economic Policy Research in London, said he would be "very surprised" if any eastern countries were admitted before "several years" after 2000.
 "Platitudinous statements about how we love them all very much and want them in very much" will be more common at the summit talks than concrete proposals to get them ready, he said.
 Mr. Portes and five other leading European economists proposed a European Union secretariat for the six associate members, a suggestion rejected by officials of the group as a needless layer of bureaucracy.
 France and then Spain will hold the rotating six-month presidency of the union next year, and they are not expected to push the issue of membership for the Eastern Europeans.
 Mr. Delors said he also wanted the leaders to adopt a five-point plan here to combat unemployment; more than 17 million people in the 12 countries are out of work.
 His proposals to allow the group to issue bonds to finance vast road and rail projects were rejected by finance ministers last week.
 Most members agree in principle that the best way to reduce unemployment is to cut back on the social benefits that make it highly expensive for employers to hire workers in Western Europe. But all have found it difficult to get labor unions and legislatures to agree on cuts.
