HEADLINE: On Eve of Miami Summit Talks, U.S. Comes Under Fire

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Dec. 8

 BODY:
As they began arriving here today for a huge summit meeting, President Clinton and other Latin American leaders were no doubt relieved that negotiators had resolved a series of sharp disagreements over how quickly to establish a vast liberalized trade zone in the Western Hemisphere.
 But despite general agreement about the desirability of lowering barriers to trade, which is to be the centerpiece of the first Western Hemisphere summit meeting since 1967, there were plenty of signs already that Latin American officials remain skeptical of United States intentions on trade. 
Only after heavy Latin pressure, for example, did the United States agree to set a date for concluding talks for a free trade pact for the Americas -- and the date was 2005, well into the future. In addition, the target date was for finishing the talks, not for actually lowering the trade barriers themselves.
 For years, Washington has beseeched Latin American countries to open their markets to American products, and in the last few years they have. In the last decade, Latin American nations have slashed trade barriers and made the region the fastest growing United States export market in the world.
 It used to be that Latin American leaders were wary of Yankee free traders. Today they suspect that it is the United States that is losing its historical free trade zeal and is more interested in protecting its own markets from such imports as Costa Rican garments, Colombian flowers, Argentine steel and Brazilian orange juice and shoes.
 "Instead of signing a declaration of generalities, we should be setting a date to start the hemispheric free trade zone," said Bolivia's American-educated President, Gonzalo Sanchez de Lozada.
 American trade policy is crucial to Latin America because the United States is the largest trading partner for every nation in the area except Cuba.
 American companies have doubled sales in a decade, making Latin America the only region where the United States enjoys a trade surplus. By the end of the 1990's, the United States expects to export more to Mexico than to Japan, and more to Latin America than to Western Europe.
 But the opening has exacted a price. In two years, Latin America's global trade deficit has doubled to $20 billion. Latin leaders complain that the Clinton Administration is dragging its feet in opening United States markets in keeping with its pronouncements in favor of free trade zones.
 "The Latin leaders feel in a way that they have been double-crossed," said Sebastian Edwards, a Chilean who is the World Bank's chief economist for Latin America. "The trade liberalization has been the most traumatic in history. But these guys opened up in exchange for nothing."
 Clinton Administration officials retort that few issues have drawn the President's attention as free trade. In the last year, he has won Congressional approval of the vast global trade pact known as GATT and of the North America Free Trade Agreement with Mexico and Canada, and has set a goal of a free trade zone in the Asia-Pacific region by the year 2020.
 Before arriving here this evening, Mr. Clinton signed legislation to approve GATT. "Some say the answer is to try to just hunker down within our borders," Mr. Clinton told reporters in Washington. "That is clearly not an option. No country can escape the global economy."
 This weekend, Mr. Clinton and 33 leaders of the region are to issue a declaration resolving "to begin immediately to construct 'the Free Trade Area of the Americas' in which barriers to trade and investment will be progressively eliminated." Looking at the open-ended timetable, some Latin Americans joke, "Engaged -- without a date for the wedding."
 This week, economists reported the impact of Latin America's largely unilateral tariff cuts, amounting to 80 percent over the last decade. In November, Brazil recorded a trade deficit of imports over exports of $600 million, its first monthly trade deficit since 1987. In the first nine months of 1994, Argentina's trade deficit hit $4.3 billion, more than double last year's level.
 On the defensive, Administration officials say they have not lost the free trade faith. "From the U.S. side, we feel that we opened unilaterally a long time ago," Jeffrey E. Garten, Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade, said in an interview. "The U.S. is by far the most open economy in the hemisphere."
 Without waiting for the United States, Latin America's free traders have been so zealous that some say that New Year's Day could be renamed Latin America Free Trade Day.
 Starting Jan. 1, trade is to be duty free for 90 percent of commerce among Brazil, Argentina, Uruguay and Paraguay. Known as Mercosur in Spanish, this "market of the south" covers two-thirds of South America's economic activity. For most of the other third -- Venezuela, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru and Bolivia --Jan. 1 marks the start of common external tariffs, ranging from 5 to 20 percent.
 Inside Mercosur, trade is already largely duty free.
 Jan. 1 also marks the start of a third free trade group -- Mexico, Colombia and Venezuela. Known as the Group of Three, this group will erase all tariffs and quotas over the next decade.
 By next June, Latin diplomats plan to wind up talks for fusing the Southern Cone and Andean groups, creating a South America trade zone. By the end of the next year, Mercosur and the European Union are to start formal talks on a trade liberalization pact.
 "Converts often have more passion in any religion," said Elliott Abrams, who served as the top State Department official for Latin America in the Reagan years. "The Latin Americans are going gangbusters on free trade. There has not been one step back."
 Last year, Vice President Al Gore announced the Miami summit meeting in the heady days following Senate ratification of the free trade treaty with Mexico. But, critics charge, a year has seen the Administration retreat into generalities.
 No rules have been drawn up on joining the Nafta club. Sensing protectionist winds in Congress, the Administration withdrew legislation to give the President fast-track authority to negotiate free trade agreements and legislation to extend Nafta trade benefits to 15 Caribbean countries.
 "It's up to the United States to set the rules of Nafta accession," said Peter Hakim, president of the Inter-American Dialogue, a Washington-based policy forum on hemispheric relations. "Without a date, it's flat."
 This Sunday, Mr. Clinton is expected to invite Chile to start negotiations about joining Nafta.
 So far, for the Latins, the primary benefits of their trade openings have been more efficient economies and a boom in intra-regional trade. Growing twice as fast as Latin exports to the United States, intra-Latin trade has tripled, growing from 10 percent of regional trade a decade ago to 25 percent today.
 In an odd convergence of interests, American protectionists play into the hands of Brazilian manufacturers.
 With Latin America's largest manufacturing base, Brazil wants to emerge as a kind of queen bee of a South American free trade zone. This year, for the first time, Brazil is exporting more to Latin America than to the United States. Eighty percent of Brazil's exports to Latin America are manufactured.
 Profiting from shorter shipping distances and shorter letters of credit, Brazilian manufacturers believe that delays in expanding Nafta will give them more time to establish supply lines, credit lines and consumer loyalties throughout South America.

HEADLINE: A Message to Bosnians;
Allied Talk of a U.N. Withdrawal Warns The Combatants They Risk All-Out War

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ZAGREB, Croatia, Dec. 9

 BODY:
The highly publicized plans for a big NATO operation to withdraw United Nations troops from Bosnia carry a blunt message to the belligerents: Stop fighting a buffered, low-level war or risk an all-out war.
But any withdrawal of the more than 24,000 United Nations troops in Bosnia is almost certainly several months away. "The watershed will be next spring," Yasushi Akashi, the top United Nations official in the Balkans, said today. 
 Thus, rather than an announcement of an imminent withdrawal, the short-term goal of American and French statements this week about having tens of thousands of boys in green tanks ready to rescue the boys in white tanks has been to focus the minds of the nationalist politicians who destroyed Yugoslavia and took their people to war.
The presence of the United Nations force has almost certainly contributed to extending the Bosnian war. It has done so by keeping movements of front lines to a minimum, providing basic sustenance and offering Balkan politicians an instrument to maneuver beneath the avid gaze of the world's networks and newspapers.
The United Nations force account for 6 percent of the Croatian economy and most of the virtually nonexistent Bosnian economy. Remove the more than 35,000 United Nations personnel in Bosnia and Croatia, and the area's politicians may have a different agenda. To begin with, they will have to feed people.
The question now is: What calculations will these politicians bring to bear on the virtual ultimatum that has been presented?
The Serbs do not want NATO to come into Bosnia to help the evacuation of the peacekeepers. They fear that to get United Nations troops out of the protected eastern Muslim enclaves of Zepa, Srebrenica and Gorazde, the NATO forces would have to carve out corridors, possibly with assistance from United States troops. Those corridors would come from Serb-held land. NATO might not be in hurry to give them back.
"If NATO or the United States want to assist the United Nations, then they should not approach Serbian territory," Radovan Karadzic, the Bosnian Serb leader, said today in an interview with Reuters. "We would not attack them, but if they approach Serb territory and are hostile to us, there would be a big war between us. There will be another Vietnam."
The Serbs are also concerned that they would also be more exposed to a NATO attack if they could no longer use peacekeepers as a shield.
To stop NATO from coming, the Serbs would therefore seem more likely to seek a minimum understanding with the United Nations forces. United Nations hostages are likely to be released; many have been already, and 67 more were freed today. The Serbs also allowed an aid convoy to reach Bihac for the first time in nine weeks.
At the same time, the Serbs may well maneuver to secure a permanent cease-fire and reopen talks on carving up Bosnia. They have 70 percent now and are said to be prepared to settle for about 50 percent, provided the map offered by the five-nation "contact group" is redrawn.
The Muslim-led Bosnian Government has mixed feelings about the departure of United Nations forces. On the one hand, they fear that a withdrawal would expose them to Serb attack. On the other, they would welcome NATO troops, provided they come to stay for a while and not merely to evacuate the United Nations troops.
Despite Bosnian hopes, Defense Secretary William J. Perry stressed today that the United States remained determined to avoid entanglement in the war. The Bosnian Government is aware of this. It also knows, as Mr. Perry said, that without the peacekeepers on the ground, "there would be more flexibility in the future for applying military leverage."
But the Bosnian Government would also pay a heavy price for a United Nations departure.
The eastern enclaves and Sarajevo would be acutely vulnerable. The Government has scant resources to feed its people. The army would put up a strong fight but would still face, at least initially, a huge Serbian superiority in tanks and artillery.
That is why the Bosnian Prime Minister, Haris Silajdzic, said this week, "We asked the United Nations force to come, and we want them to stay." The statement was a victory of analysis over anger: the reluctance of United Nations commanders to call in NATO air power has repeatedly enraged the Bosnian Government.
But with NATO waiting in the wings, and the politics of the Republican Congressional leaders Bob Dole and Newt Gingrich offering not-too-distant hope, is the Bosnian Government worried enough about a United Nations departure to compromise?
Mr. Akashi hopes the answer is yes. But the compromises would be formidable.
The Government would have to accept the reopening of negotiations on the "contact group" map, the virtual independence of a Serbian entity within Bosnia, and the abandonment of its desire to inflict a battlefield defeat on Mr. Karadzic, who sent his militias to kill and evict several hundred thousand Muslims.
It is widely expected that there will now be great pressure on the Government from the United States to accept such compromises: financial incentives, promises of military support for the peace, and so on. Croatia, Bosnia's conduit for arms but its ally only up to a point in fighting the Serbs, is also seen as likely to push for a settlement.
Such pressure may carry the day. But it appears just as likely that the Muslim-led Bosnian forces will want to fight on. If so, the time will come when the United Nations threats, and the NATO plans, will have to be executed.
What then? "If we leave," Mr. Akashi said, "the suffering of civilians, particularly in the Muslim enclaves and in Sarajevo, may be of such tragic proportions that there would be a cry for a reintroduction of an international force, whether dressed in green or white."
He continued: "The conflict would sharpen and may spill out of Bosnia. Cleavages between the United States and Russia would be exacerbated. There would be a major destabilization of Europe."
A grim warning. But the slow agony of Bosnian over the last 32 months has also been grim and has suggested, increasingly, that if the United Nations stays, a half-hearted war may drag on for decades.

HEADLINE: For Guantanamo Refugees, Hope Fades as Time Passes

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: GUANTANAMO BAY NAVAL STATION, Cuba, Dec. 8

 BODY:
About once a week, one or two Cubans housed in refugee camps here attempt an escape back to the Cuban side, either by diving into a cove and swimming to the border or by sprinting for it.
Having risked their lives to leave their country in August by taking to the sea on flimsy rafts and boats, at least three refugees have already died trying to return. 
 Two drowned; the third detonated a land mine.
"I'm destroyed," said Ruben Martinez, 29, who has tried to escape twice to get back to his wife and 5-year-old daughter in Havana but was caught by American troops both times. "I've had time to think about my family and to realize there is nothing more important."
Although this American naval base has not experienced a disturbance as big or as violent as the one that injured more than 200 American soldiers in refugee detention camps in Panama today, it still houses large numbers of refugees desperate to return to normal lives after months in limbo, even if that means giving up dreams of going to the United States.
The Cuban refugees fled their country in boats and rafts last summer, many escaping worsening economic conditions; many Haitians who are also being housed here fled the relentless violence in their homeland. As Christmas approaches, many have become increasingly anxious as they realize, despite some encouraging signs, that they may remain in the camps indefinitely.
Five Cubans made their way into the base this week, asking for asylum, but more than 350 have sneaked out in recent months.
There are now 22,574 Cubans and 5,712 Haitians in Guantanamo but thousands have already left.
More than 15,400 Haitians, most of whom fled their country in July, returned to Haiti after the return of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide in October. About 300 of them went back as "public safety volunteers" after receiving three weeks of training in crowd control and other police functions from the Justice Department.
"It's time for me to go," said Lucianor Phanord, 22, who is in another group of 250 Haitian trainees who are to leave on a Coast Guard cutter this month. "I want to go back and help my country."
Among the Cubans, about 8,000 people, including 2,700 to 3,000 children, are being interviewed by Immigration and Naturalization officials for possible release.
The screening began this week after Justice Department officials announced in a policy change that families with children would be individually reviewed to determine whether they should leave the camps on humanitarian grounds.
The first two families were released on Thursday and taken to Florida. Since October, more than 430 young, elderly or seriously ill Cubans have been admitted to the United States on humanitarian grounds. A small number of Haitians have been allowed to enter on similar grounds.
During a two-day visit to the camps by reporters this week, parents expressed frustration with the pace of the immigration process; only about 30 families had been interviewed by Thursday. Priority is being given to sick children, infants and pregnant women, said Maj. Rick Thomas of the Army, a spokesman at the base.
But many families recognized that their patience has paid off. Ania Rodriguez, 25, said she never lost hope: not when she boarded a boat to leave home with her two-month-old baby girl and 43 others, not when the Americans said absolutely no one held at Guantanamo would be allowed into the United States, not while waiting since Aug. 22 for some breakthrough.
While her situation is better than that of other refugees -- she has an air-conditioned room with a sink in a cinder-block house for pregnant women and mothers with infant children -- she still must bathe outdoors, dry baby clothes on concertina wire and live separated from her husband and her parents, who stay in tents and can only visit.
"Even if I'm the last one of the 14 mothers in the house to leave, I am relieved that something is happening," said Mrs. Rodriguez, who broke into tears while relating the story of her exile. "We could never return to Cuba. We left our home. We would have even less than we had before."
The policy changes in Washington have given hopes to others, making them stay put and wait for the United States, where most have relatives, or any other country to take them. Conditions in the camps have slowly improved, and in many of them there is a sense of permanence.
At three camps for single Cuban men, a recreation area with volleyball courts, a bowling alley and a theater stage has sprung up from the dust. A central tent shelters an exhibition of drawings and paintings, and a boisterous game of bingo, with cigarettes as the winnings.
There and elsewhere refugees spend their days listening to transistor radios, talking on the telephone with relatives in the United States (collect) and working. Jobs include handling refugees' mail, teaching in makeshift schools or seeing patients in health clinics.
Javier Martinez, 22, a car mechanic who starts his days jogging with the Marines, says he will stick it out for as long as it takes.
In the meantime, he works out and takes English classes. He sleeps in a tent with 15 other men, next to a night table made of cardboard and decorated with photographs from a Victoria's Secret lingerie catalog.
"There are fewer and fewer of us left," he said. "The Cubans in Miami think our situation will be resolved soon."
In the two remaining camps for Haitians, the population has dwindled but continues to defy expectations that President Aristide would draw all of the refugees back to Haiti.
Conditions at these camps are starker than in some of the Cuban camps -- women with infants sleep on cots under tents and recreational services are few -- and more than 200 unaccompanied minors have not been allowed to enter the United States.
But many of those left say they are willing to endure the camps indefinitely. Some say they feel Mr. Aristide's term is too short and fear worse when he is gone. Most doubt assurances that it is safe to return.
While the Haitians are being encouraged -- some of them say forced -- to go home, there are long-range plans that assume a long stay for the Cubans.
Brig. Gen. Raymond P. Ayres Jr., who oversees the camps, said there are plans for centralizing schools, installing a sewage system and replacing tents with sturdier structures made partly of plywood and with electricity.
It currently costs the United States Government about $15 million a month to run the camps, he said.
Despite improvements, the camps are tough on many of the refugees. There have been 14 suicide attempts among the Cubans. Parents say their children have become aggressive and undisciplined, fighting with others and disobeying orders.
At Camp November, where about 260 men and 3 women who want to return to Cuba wait, there are threats of a mass escape if their pleas to leave are ignored. Of 1,000 Cubans who asked to be repatriated, only 203 have been allowed to go.
The American officials say the Cuban Government has been slow in processing the refugees. But Cuban officials in Washington said they need to check their identities.
The refugees say they never thought the United States would not welcome them, having accepted so many refugees in the past. Many say they feel deceived and want nothing to do with Americans.
"This has been a huge blow," said Ruben Martinez as he plotted his third attempt to escape through minefields. "I'm only 29 years old, and I will never believe anything anyone ever says again."

HEADLINE: Hemisphere Trade Talks Open; U.S. Hedges Its Hopes

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Dec. 9

 BODY:
President Clinton tonight opened the first summit meeting of Western Hemisphere nations in nearly three decades, asking leaders of 33 nations to become "true partners for prosperity" with the United States.
But even as he and other leaders dined at the historic Biltmore Hotel here, Administration officials conceded that the United States was unable to get many other nations to agree to take far stronger collective action against money laundering, drug trafficking and threats against democratic governments. 
 American officials said that when the final communique is issued on Sunday by the 22 presidents and 12 prime ministers, it would not include language that Washington had sought committing the nations to "act as one" to "preserve and if necessary restore democratic rule." Many of the largest countries in Latin America declined to join the United Nations-authorized force sent to Haiti two months ago to oversee the transfer of power from military rulers to the country's elected President, Jean-Bertrand Aristide.
The final communique also will not include a call to require financial institutions to report large transactions, which would help investigators spot drug traffickers. Instead, Washington settled for language saying governments will encourage banks to cooperate with investigators.
But despite these setbacks, Mr. Clinton and his huge delegation, which includes roughly half the Cabinet, argued today that the meeting marks a watershed in both economic and political cooperation.
In a speech today to Miami's business and political leaders, Mr. Clinton declared that "the so-called lost decade of Latin America is a fading memory" and that the region, with the exception of Cuba, had "freed itself from dictatorship and debt, and embraced democracy and development."
President Fidel Castro was the only leader not invited to the meeting, and Mr. Clinton got his longest applause today -- from an audience that included many Cubans -- when he said he hoped that at the next summit meeting, "a leader of a democratic Cuba will take its place at the table of nations."
But Mr. Clinton's aides were less forthcoming when they were asked why Cuba was the exception to the Administration's policy of "commercial engagement," under which it has pressed for broadened economic ties with countries like China and Indonesia that have also repressed dissent.
Michael D. McCurry, the State Department spokesman, told reporters that "Castro has put himself out of the summit" by refusing to make "permanent and lasting change," and said the Cuban leader had to "get with the program."
Most of Mr. Clinton's speech today, however, was a defense of his trade programs even as many Democrats are warning that the President is losing a key political constituency in blue-collar workers, who, polls show, feel that free trade is costing them jobs. Mr. Clinton argued that his strategy is the only one that will ultimately raise wages for American workers, saying those who produce export goods earn 17 percent higher wages than others.
Mr. Clinton acknowledged that past efforts to link the hemisphere economically had failed, most recently after the 1967 talks in Uruguay, when President Johnson and a score of other leaders talked about a less ambitious customs union. It never happened, but Mr. Clinton argued that with the arrival of democracy, attitudes had changed.
"People have talked about free trade in this hemisphere for years," Mr. Clinton said. "It's been talked about and talked about. The difference is, here in Miami we have a chance to act, and we're going to take it."
Administration officials tried today to play down the muting of the communique, saying that the 34 nations had gone further than ever before in agreeing to cooperate on a number of issues -- from terrorism to the environment. "The true meaning of this is that the countries have agreed to make what used to be domestic issues a legitimate subject of international concern," a senior Administration official said tonight.
Nonetheless, the most recent draft of the communique restores the language used by the members of the Organization of American States, calling for "due respect to the principle of non-intervention."
Mr. Aristide, however, is one of the stars here. The Haitian President stopped today at an elementary school in the Little Haiti neighborhood of Miami and quickly attracted a crowd of 300 people, who came to cheer him and hear his message of reconciliation in Haiti.
When the working sessions begin on Saturday, members of Mr. Clinton's Cabinet will discuss more specific issues with their counterparts. Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said earlier this week that he would use his talks to strengthen joint efforts against money laundering.
On economic issues, Mr. Clinton comes to Miami with far more leverage than he enjoyed last month, when he met Asian leaders in Indonesia for talks intended to set up a free trade area around the Pacific: For each of the major countries in Latin America, the United States is the No. 1 trading partner.
"The fact of the matter is that three-quarters of the countries here would join Nafta tomorrow morning if they could," one of Mr. Clinton's top economic aides said today, referring to the North American Free Trade Agreement signed last year with Mexico and Canada. "But we do not think they are ready."
Mr. Clinton said today that the talks here could not have happened without Nafta, and on Sunday he is expected to announce that talks will begin next year to admit Chile to the accord.
Argentina is also eager to join, but a senior Administration official said "we're telling them that they have a ways to go" before the Argentines open their markets and improve labor and environmental laws sufficiently to gain the same preferential access to the United States market that Mexico and Canada now have.

 Nynex should be allowed to offer cable programming in New York and New England, a Federal judge in Maine ruled. [39.]
Tyson Foods is being investigated as part of the independent prosecutor's inquiry of Mike Espy, the Agriculture Secretary. [1.]

Foote, Cone & Belding is planning a number of changes, including a new name and a joint venture with a multimedia company. [41.]
The F.A.A. banned two models of propeller planes from flying in icy conditions. The order affects planes operated by the commuter divisions of Delta, Continental, T.W.A. and American. [1.]
Two pager companies spurned a three-way deal with Metrocall, which had offered to buy the two, USA Mobile and Premiere Page, for $384.3 million in stock and assumed debt. [41.]

 Blue-chip stock indexes gained, but the overall market was weaker in heavy trading. The S. &P. 500 index rose 1.51 point. [40.]

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Viacom Drops Plan for Florida Sports Park

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: MIAMI, Dec. 9

 BODY:
Viacom Inc. canceled plans today to build Blockbuster Park, a $1 billion entertainment and sports complex on the eastern edge of the Everglades.
The park would have become the home of two professional sports teams owned by the Blockbuster Entertainment Corporation's founder, H. Wayne Huizenga. Its economic potential had been praised by civic leaders but environmentalists said it would hurt the nearby wetlands. 
 The decision came nearly two and a half months after Blockbuster was acquired by Viacom, which said the 2,500-acre entertainment complex did not fit its corporate strategy as a media company.
The company cited the project's high financial and management costs and a complex regulatory process involving Dade and Broward Counties and the City of Miramar.
"Personally, I'm disappointed the project will not be developed," Mr. Huizenga said. "I believed this was good for Blockbuster Entertainment Corporation and good for South Florida, but I appreciate the broader strategic context for this decision."
There has been speculation for weeks that Viacom would not proceed with the park. Viacom has about $10 billion in debt after buying Blockbuster and Paramount Communications this year. To pare that debt, the company is selling Madison Square Garden in New York and some cable television systems.
The plans for Blockbuster Park included sports arenas, a theme park, film and music studios, a virtual-reality amusement center, theaters, restaurants and retail stores.
The Florida Panthers hockey team and the Florida Marlins baseball team -- both owned by Mr. Huizenga -- would have played their home games at the park.
Viacom announced the cancellation of the project after the stock market closed. Its class A shares ended trading unchanged at $39.
The Blockbuster Park management team will now seek another use for about 1,000 acres already purchased for the park. "Hopefully, something could be salvaged from this project," Mr. Huizenga said.

HEADLINE: Giuliani Suggests Privatizing of Airports

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
Having broken off negotiations with the Port Authority over renewing its leases at Kennedy International and La Guardia airports, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he would explore turning the operation of the airports or the land under them to private hands.
 Mr. Giuliani, who as a candidate often raised the idea last year, said a decision to privatize the city's two airports had become more likely after months of negotiations to rewrite the leases to increase the city's revenues from the airports proved fruitless. 
 The Mayor's proposal won an important ally yesterday when Governor-elect George E. Pataki expressed support for selling the airports out from under the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. Mr. Pataki said the leases contributed far too few revenues to the city.
 Mr. Giuliani's threat to privatize could be partly an attempt to pressure the authority to renegotiate its leases with the city on more favorable terms. Even as the Mayor raised the issue during an impromptu news conference in the hallway at City Hall, the authority's executive director, Stanley Brezenoff, called Deputy Mayor Peter J. Powers to schedule a meeting next week to restart the stalled lease negotiations.
 So far, neither the Mayor nor the Governor-elect, who since the election has often been at odds with his fellow Republican, have formed detailed proposals on how to privatize the city's airports. Such proposals could take the form of selling the land now owned by the city outright or turning over the operations to a private company once the Port Authority's leases expire in 2015.
 As Governor, Mr. Pataki will appoint 6 of the authority's 12 commissioners -- with the other six named by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey -- and will thus have considerable influence over the authority's leases with the city.
 "My personal view is the Port Authority has been shortchanging the taxpayers of the City of New York for years," Mr. Pataki said in an interview. "I think the Mayor is 100 percent right."
 Negotiations between the city and the Port Authority collapsed two weeks ago with the Port Authority, a quasi-public interstate agency, refusing to agree to a number of proposals to increase the amount it pays the city for the use of the land under the airports in Queens.
 Under the terms of the lease, in effect since 1965, the payments vary according to the authority's profits, which derive from terminal rentals, parking revenue and flight fees. Over the last decade, the authority has paid the city nearly $600 million, but since last year the payment has dropped to the minimum amount specified in the lease, $3.1 million a year. With the authority undertaking sweeping renovations at the airports, however, the payment is not expected to increase much until the lease expires in 20 years.
 Mr. Giuliani called the $3 million "scandalously low" for the right to use two of the nation's busiest airports. In the city's budget, Mr. Giuliani proposed increasing the payment to $75 million a year.
Before the talks broke off, officials familiar with the negotiations said, the authority offered to accept a 50-year extension that would increase the payment to an average $55 million for each of the next five years, though the figure would drop significantly after that. The city, the officials said, insisted on larger payments in a shorter lease.
 The idea of selling the land under Kennedy and La Guardia has arisen before. In 1992, the City Council commissioned a study that suggested the city could raise $1.2 billion by selling the property outright.
 Barry Weintrob, the authority's chief financial officer, disputed the Mayor's remarks. He said the authority's payments had dropped because of the vast improvements now under way. He also said the benefits of privatization were overrated.
 "We've concluded it doesn't make economic sense," he said.
 Once the authority's lease expires, the buildings on the land -- and all the improvements to them over the years -- revert to the city's ownership. The threat of losing its lease could pose serious difficulties for the authority's long-term bonds, which are supported by the revenues from the airports.
 Echoing the Mayor and his aides, Mr. Pataki said he favored privatizing the airports even over renegotiating the leases with the Port Authority. He said a private owner would give the city a sizable purchase price, contribute to property taxes the authority does not now pay, and pour private resources into maintaining the terminals.
 Mr. Pataki said he and Mr. Giuliani had discussed the possibility at their breakfast meeting last week and would discuss it further. He said he also raised the issue of privatizing the authority's other airport, Newark International, with Governor Whitman.
 A spokesman, Carl Golden, said that Governor Whitman had not taken a position on a sale, but that a committee formed to study privatization in myriad areas would issue a report as soon as next week.

HEADLINE: South America's Big Trade Strides

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 7

 BODY:
Spurred by free trade pacts at home, South American businesses are making giant strides toward transforming their continent into a single seamless market by the end of this decade.
Business ventures are growing across borders, as Latin American executives design regional strategies for banking, manufacturing, transportation and generating electricity that could present opportunities as well as obstacles for competitors from the United States. 
 As President Clinton meets with 33 Latin American leaders in Miami to discuss a timetable for liberalizing trade from Alaska to Argentina, free trade within South America is fast becoming a reality, shaking up more than the region's long-protected companies. South America's own emerging free trade zones have given Brazilian manufacturers a head start over North American exporters in the race to sell to one of the world's fastest-growing regions.
Consider Brahma, a Brazilian brewery that already sells half the beer drunk in Brazil. "The Brahma brand is too strong to remain bottled up inside Brazil," Marcel Herrmann Telles, Brahma's director general, said last week when he inaugurated a $100 million brewery in Argentina. In the last two years, the company has bought other breweries in Chile and in Venezuela.
"Our idea is to concentrate on Latin America," Mr. Telles said.
In the old, Balkanized South America, markets stopped at the frontier because government red tape, high tariffs, nationalism, bad roads and lack of communications prevented companies from expanding. While border delays endure, both governments and businesses increasingly are thinking regionally.
Starting Jan. 1, 90 percent of trade will be duty free within the four southern countries, Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay. This Common Market of the South -- Mercosul in Portuguese and Mercosur in Spanish -- accounts for two-thirds of South America's economic activity.
Most trade is already duty free among the Andean Pact nations of Venezuela, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru and Bolivia. On Jan. 1, the five are forming a customs union by adopting common external tariffs, averaging about 14 percent. Negotiations on merging the two pacts into one, tentatively called the South American Free Trade Association, could be completed within six months.
Some North American businessmen say the transformation offers them an opportunity to focus on the broader Latin American market, rather than expend time and money on a single country.
"American companies down here are all developing Mercosul strategies," said Dolph Johnson, senior vice president for the Sao Paulo office of Spencer Stuart, a Chicago-based executive search firm. His own company set up in Argentina two years ago and plans to expand to Chile next year.
In September, General Motors inaugurated a $100 million plant in Argentina to build 25,000 Chevrolet pickup trucks for the broader Mercosul region. Regional manufacturing of Toyota, Mazda and Mercedes- Benz trucks is also to be concentrated in Argentina.
Within the four member countries of Mercosul, trade has already tripled since 1990 to $10 billion this year. Other South American nations are riding the free trade boom. Since 1988, Colombia has quintupled its trade with its two Andean Pact neighbors, Ecuador and Venezuela.
The most dynamic activity has been conducted between the two largest economies in South America, Brazil and Argentina, thanks to their common market. Last year, Brazil displaced the United States as Argentina's largest trading partner.
In the last four years, 320 Brazilian companies have set up offices in Argentina, investing a total of $1.5 billion. A Brazilian construction company, Encol, is building apartment buildings in Buenos Aires. A Brazilian paint company, Tintas Renner, is making paint in Argentina and in Uruguay.
In turn, Brazil, which used to rely on grain from the United States and Canada, will buy 70 percent of Argentina's wheat crop this year.
Bankers have been following businessmen across the borders. Last week, Banco Itau, one of Brazil's largest private banks, won permission from the Argentine Government to set up a banking affiliate called Banco Itau Argentina. In Brazil's first major foray into overseas retail banking, Itau plans to open in July with 35 agencies and 10 electronic banking centers, mostly in Buenos Aires.
"The Argentine market opened to foreigners at a time of extraordinary economic expansion," Roberto Egydio Setubal, Itau's president, recently told Gazeta Mercantil, Brazil's leading business newspaper.
Three Chilean banks have also announced plans to buy Argentine banks. Chile's largest private pension fund, AFP Provida S.A., is investing in pension funds in Argentina, Colombia and Peru.
In a region of crackling phone lines and garbled faxes, some South American nations are also starting a multibillion-dollar fiber optic network. Last month, telephone company officials inaugurated the first leg, Unisur, which connects Brazil, Argentina and Uruguay. Capable of handling 25,000 simultaneous conversations and data transmissions, the 1,068-mile cable was furnished by a consortium formed by AT&T, Alcatel and Pirelli.
South American nations are also integrating their road, rail and energy networks.
In October, Brazilian authorities opened a $58 million energy conversion plant that will reconcile different electrical systems in Brazil and Argentina, allowing the two countries to swap power according to seasonal demand. Uruguay plans a similar $30 million plant next year to swap its own power with Brazil. And Chilean companies recently bought 30 percent of the electrical distribution network in Buenos Aires.
"Twenty years ago, when Chile and Argentina almost went to war, the Argentines were afraid that the Chilean Air Force would bomb El Chocon," Mr. Johnson recalled, referring to an Argentine hydroelectric project. "Now, the Chileans won't bomb it, because they own it."

HEADLINE: Mixed Day For Prices Of Treasuries

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Government securities were generally mixed yesterday, with the longest maturities unchanged.
Despite the uncertainty still surrounding the bankruptcy of Orange County, Calif., Treasury prices firmed as the market looked ahead to next week and a new supply of inflation data. Prices of notes and bills fell sharply on Thursday as traders feared that some Wall Street firms might sell the government securities they hold as collateral for their loans to Orange County. 
 The municipal market was quiet yesterday in thin volume, with traders noting some firming of prices that had been soft for days.
Michael S. Appelbaum, a senior vice president and municipal bond specialist at Paine Webber Inc., said, "The tone was better as prices moved up slightly, with much emphasis still on year-end tax planning, as some investors engage in swapping on maturities, taking loss in the transaction to later realize a profit at maturity."
The average yield to maturity in the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal issues fell to 7.04 percent yesterday from 7.08 percent on Thursday. Yields and prices move in opposite directions.
Although some analysts and traders have said there has been little trading of California issues since Orange County filed for Chapter 9 bankruptcy, Skeets Dunn, managing partner of J. C. Bradford & Company in Del Mar, Calif., said there had been many bids since the county's announcement. "For instance, general triple-A rated debt was bid at a price to yield 6.85 percent on Tuesday," he said. "On Wednesday, it was bid back to 7.15-20 percent and today we've seen trades, some of which were through 7 percent."
Mr. Dunn said there had also been activity from institutional investors in the buying of insured triple-A debt at the depressed prices.
The prices of some rated issues tied to Orange County, like the Irvine Ranch Water District, have risen in the last few days. For example, Mr. Dunn said, an 8 1/4 percent water district debenture due 2023 was at 99 3/4 yesterday, up from the high 80's on Wednesday and low 90's on Thursday.
In the Treasury market, the 30-year bond was unchanged yesterday at 9529/32 for a yield of 7.86 percent. A week ago the yield on the long bond was 7.91 percent.
Much of the bond market's early advances yesterday were generated by losses coming from the stock market and the strength of the dollar overseas.
But prices retreated later in the day as the market focused on familiar concerns about a pickup in inflation ahead of new inflation data next week. The Labor Department reports on producer prices in November on Tuesday and on consumer prices on Wednesday.
Worries about inflation were revived yesterday after a report from the University of Michigan showed consumers feeling more optimistic about the economy than at any time in nearly six years. In a preliminary report, the university's consumer confidence index, traders said, surged to 97.7 in December from 91.6 in November -- the highest reading since January 1989.
Although some economists say consumer confidence has only a weak correlation to consumption spending, combined with strength in the labor market and income growth, yesterday's data reinforced expectations that the Federal Reserve would raise soon raise short-term interest rates for a seventh time since February.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar, Generally Steady, Slips Against Yen and Mark

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar was steady in subdued trading yesterday, slipping slightly against the Japanese yen and the German mark.
The dollar rose on Thursday, and some traders took profits yesterday. 
 In New York late yesterday, the dollar eased to 100.11 yen from 100.55 yen on Thursday. It was quoted at 1.5770 marks from 1.5773 marks.
"It is a Friday during December, and the market is very thin," said Richard Vullo, vice president at Hypobank. "We had some long dollar positions from yesterday. People took some profits today."
 The dollar climbed on Thursday as investors speculated that the Federal Reserve would soon raise short-term interest rates for the seventh time since February. Higher rates tend to attract dollar buyers by offering a better return on securities denominated in the currency.
 "There is an overall optimism in the U.S.," Mr. Vullo said."There is a sense of confidence in the Fed, and that is helping the currency because people are moving into U.S. assets again."
 Some currency dealers predict that the Fed will increase short-term interest rates by at least 50 basis points -- equal to a half percentage point -- at the Dec. 20 meeting of its policy-making committee.
 Traders said those hopes helped keep the dollar from slipping through the psychologically significant levels of 100 yen and steady above 1.5750 marks yesterday.
In other currency trading, the Canadian dollar weakened despite efforts by the Bank of Canada to prop it up by purchasing the Canadian currency for United States dollars.
The Canadian dollar has been weighed down this year by the heavy debt load of the country and the relative value of its securities to investments in the United States. Yesterday, there were rumors that major rating agencies would lower their ratings on the Province of Quebec.
 "Any time attention is drawn to debt, the Canadian dollar comes under pressure," said Amy Smith, an analyst for the consulting firm IDEA. "The Canadian dollar would get hurt because you would see a lot of selling of Quebec's debt."
The Canadian dollar slipped to 72.27 United States cents, from 72.38 cents on Thursday.
The British pound fell to $1.5595, from $1.5651 on Thursday. The dollar edged up to 1.3370 Swiss francs from 1.3366 Swiss francs.

HEADLINE: HOW THEY DO IT;
Financial Survival in Tokyo

 BODY:
John Harlow (pictured right), a senior vice president with Korn Ferry, an international recruiting firm, recently returned to San Francisco after a four-year stint in his company's Tokyo office. Before he went, he had to consider the financial impact as well as the changes in quality of life for his wife, Carole, and his sons, John Junji, 11, and Ben, 10.
 Tokyo is an extremely expensive city. When he moved there is 1990, the cost of living was 79 percent higher than in the San Francisco area. To compensate, his company gave him a raise and agreed to pay many of the family's expenses. 
 Still, unpredictable exchange rates proved to be a problem. The value of the dollar fell by nearly a third during his stay in Tokyo. Substantial performace bonuses helped make up the difference, but if he had stayed any longer, he said, he would have sought an increase in pay.

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
Bargains Now Abound In Closed Equity Funds

BYLINE: By Francis Flaherty 

 BODY:
EXXON is trading just above $61. Would you jump to buy it at $51? Or what if Merck, now about $37, could be had for $32?
Sorry, these deals are just pipe dreams. But closed-end funds offer the nearest thing. The funds, whose shares trade on exchanges like any stock, offer the diversification and management of regular mutual funds. But while the latter issue an unlimited number of shares priced at the portfolio's net asset value, closed funds issue finite shares that often trade at premiums or discounts to that value. 
 And, thanks to rising interest rates and year-end selling for tax purposes, discounts in the 535 closed funds are as common as Christmas trees. Not just in popular municipal-bond and single-country funds, either; many stock funds, foreign and domestic, look cheap. Yesterday, domestic stock funds had an average discount of 10.38 percent; in January, it was 4.5 percent.
"We recommend buying with both hands," said Peter Madlem, a money manager in Santa Barbara, Calif., and the editor of Cappiello's Closed-End Fund Digest (monthly, $200, 805 565-5651). Domestically, he likes Bergstrom Capital, a general equity fund selling for $84 a share -- an 11.16 percent discount to its $94.55 portfolio value. Internationally, he favors Templeton Dragon, a new Asia fund with a 15 percent discount.
But, he and others warn, do not just grab bargains. Be selective.
"Buy only if the discount is about 5 points more than its average" in past months, said Thomas Herzfeld, editor of Investor's Guide to Closed-End Funds (monthly, $325, 800 854-3863). Blue Chip Value's 12 percent discount exceeds its 1994 average of 5 percent, for example; it also surpasses similar funds' current average discount of 10.38 percent.
And view discounts through the lens of fund expenses, said Albert J. Fredman of California State University. Adams Express, a domestic equity fund, keeps expenses very low at 0.32 percent of assets. The fund's 12.7 percent discount, divided by the expenses, produces a "discount life" of 39.69. In a fund with the same discount and 1.5 percent in expenses, that value is 8.47.
Other things being equal, annual expenses would not eat up the discount on the first fund for nearly 40 years, compared with fewer than 9 years for the second. Mr. Fredman's rule: "More than 10 is good."
Most important, realize that investors can get burned by fire-sale prices. "If you buy a mediocre fund with a great discount and it stays mediocre, you're stuck," said Catherine Gillis, editor of Morningstar Closed-End Funds (twice a month, $195, 800 876-5005). Worldwide Value, a foreign equity fund, sells at a 19.6 percent discount for good reason, she said. Its net asset value has gained just 0.01 percent a year for five years.
The lesson? "Put the discount to the side, and ask first if it's a good fund," said Maria Scott of the American Association of Individual Investors. "If you're in for 10 or 20 years, even big discounts won't mean that much. And remember you may have to sell at a discount, too."
Mr. Madlem has fused the two variables of closed funds -- share price and net asset value -- into one rule. "If the current discount is high compared to the average discount, and the N.A.V. is improving, buy."
Ms. Gillis added that a discount's importance depended on one's aims. The discount on the Growth Fund of Spain, now 18 percent, has held fairly steady. But -- despite Spain's recent woes -- the well-managed fund has gained an average 4.7 percent in net asset value for three years. "Even if the discount stays constant, you'll do well long term if the N.A.V. keeps rising," she said.
For short-term profits, though, funds with volatile prices make more sense -- however their net asset values may behave.
No matter the goal, closed funds have their merits. They are the sole way to invest in some countries, Mr. Herzfeld said. His recent buys include Korea Equity (34.7 percent premium in February, 11 percent discount now) and the Austria Fund (13 percent premium in February, 11 percent discount now).
And some closed funds mirror open-end mutual funds -- except for the discounts. Templeton Developing Markets and Templeton Dragon are both run by the noted manager J. Mark Mobius -- but Dragon sports a 15 percent discount. Charles Royce, Barton Biggs and other open-fund managers also tend closed funds.
But closed funds can be dangerous. Never buy a fund's initial offering; it is usually overpriced. Avoid steep premiums. Be wary of thinly traded funds; prices can be volatile. To skirt taxes, do not buy this year until after fund distributions.
And realize that closed funds have two ways to win -- and two ways to lose. They are also hard to track. While share prices are listed daily with other equities, current discounts appear just weekly in a few papers. Only specialty sources list average discounts. And while closed funds issue quarterly and annual reports like companies, they issue prospectuses only for new shares.

HEADLINE: Pardon Me, Do You Have A Place to Buy a Rolls?

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON 

 BODY:
This may be more than some stuck-in-the-tunnel motorists can take: soon there will be no one to borrow mustard from. The only Rolls-Royce dealer in New York City is closing.
 The dealer, Michael Schudroff, says that he is shutting down his showroom on East 61st Street near First Avenue after 25 years, a victim of the recession, "the pricing of these cars" -- in the $150,000 to $315,000 range -- and what he calls astronomical overhead. 
 "Rent, over a million a year," he said. Plus $60,000 a year for employee parking across the street, unquestionably a Rolls-sized dent in the budget. Plus the difficulty of taking customers out on test drives. "These cab drivers, they don't care if it's a truck or a beautiful piece of art like a Rolls," he said. "No respect. And the doors on a Rolls dent easily because they're aluminum."
 Also, demand for Rolls-Royces isn't what it used to be. In 1990, some 1,200 Rollses were sold in North America. But the worldwide market for Rollses and Bentleys declined precipitously in 1991 and 1992. In 1993, 355 cars were sold in North America; according to Robert Wharen, the managing director for Rolls-Royce for North and South America, this year's total should be slightly up at 375 cars.
 Mr. Schudroff expects to sell 35 cars this year in Manhattan. "Last year, I was No. 1 in America with 65," he said. "I used to sell close to 200. The business is just not there anymore."
 Mr. Wharen said, however, that he intends to find another franchisee for Manhattan.
 Mr. Schudroff's first step in leaving Manhattan was to hire Sotheby's to sell his 45-car private collection of Rollses, Bentleys, Mercedeses, Jaguars and one Chevrolet -- a 40-year-old red Corvette that the auction house predicts will go for between $20,000 and $30,000 when the bidding begins at 2 P.M. today. That is modest compared with the six-figure estimates for five of Mr. Schudroff's Rollses and a 1956 Bentley S1 whose original owner was the actor David Niven.
 "Smell this car," Mr. Schudroff declared one morning recently, easing the long-nosed coupe into traffic on First Avenue. "Smell it." He was right: even though it is 38 years old and has a dinosaur of a radio -- AM only and vacuum tubes that seem to take forever to warm up -- it has that new-car smell.
 So does a 1961 Rolls Silver Cloud II, a coupe with 27,825 miles. "I remember this car in the showroom in 1961," he said. "I was 16 years old. Now I own it."
 But not after today. Sotheby's expects the Bentley to go for $100,000 to $125,000, the Silver Cloud for $125,000 to $150,000 and a 1966 Rolls Phantom V State Landaulette for $250,000 to $350,000. The '66 is one of only five such Rollses in the world and one of three with the steering wheel on the right -- the other two are left-side-drive cars. "Rolls-Royce would only build you one if you were a head of state," Mr. Schudroff said. This one rolled off the assembly line with the Emir of Bahrain's coat of arms on it.
 "It's like a house inside," Mr. Schudroff said, but it has options not found in most houses, let alone most cars. There is a grip rail on the partition behind the driver's head, "so you could stand up and wave to the people," he said.
 There is also a backseat that can be raised at least 12 inches, so a passenger can sit down, wave to the people and still be seen. And there is a cocktail cabinet with Waterford glasses and decanters that will suffer no damage should the car be overturned in a protest. And it would take a strong people to do that: the car weighs more than 6,000 pounds, Mr. Schudroff said.
 To talk about Rolls-Royces, whether an emir's or a mere heiress's, is to talk about cars with debonair charm and mannerly flourishes -- and to learn the British name for automotive anatomy. The hood is the bonnet, the fenders are the wings, the trunk is the boot.
 But somehow, Mr. Schudroff has never lost his New York accent. He was born in Flatbush, Brooklyn, and started restoring cars at 14: Triumphs and Austin Healeys, mostly, until he saw the advertisement he says changed his life, two or three lines of type in the classifieds for a Rolls-Royce that needed restoration -- "$4,400 or trade for sailboat."
 "I had neither," he said. "I scraped together the $4,400 from friends and relatives. I remember selling it later for $8,900."
 Less than 10 years later, he had his dealership at 407 East 61st Street, and customers who had showrooms of their own. Mr. Schudroff said one buyer kept his Rolls in a room with plate-glass walls, right next to his living room.
 Mr. Schudroff insists that he is not giving up the Ghost, Silver or otherwise. When he closes early next year, he intends to sell Rollses in Greenwich, Conn., where he already has a showroom and where he used to have a Rolls franchise. Mr. Wharen said the company has not yet decided to let him have it back.
 Despite a few close scrapes, only once in Mr. Schudroff's 25 years in Manhattan did he suffer every car dealer's ultimate nightmare, an accident on a test drive.
 "A cab hit us broadside," Mr. Schudroff said. "If you ever had to be in an accident, you'd want to be in one of these cars. The man felt so bad he bought it anyway."

HEADLINE: House Democrats Face Painful Choices

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9

 BODY:
House Republicans scaled back their plans to reduce committee sizes today to accommodate Democrats, but still left the minority party with a serious problem: deciding whom to kick off major committees.
 Women, blacks and Hispanic lawmakers would suffer disproportionately if Democrats followed seniority and dropped the members who were last to join the panels. 
 But any effort to bypass seniority to maintain diversity in the committees would anger members whose positions would be sacrificed, and would be likely to upset the already restive conservatives in the party.
 Democrats, far from being soothed by Republican gestures, complained that no member should have to leave a committee, even if that required committees to be expanded, not shrunk. Reducing committee sizes has long been advocated by outside students of Congress, who contend that smaller committees would be more efficient.
 Democrats complained bitterly that the ratios Republicans had imposed were unfair and were "smothering the voice of the American voters," as Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, who will be minority leader in January, put it.
 Representative David E. Bonior of Michigan, the No. 2 House Democrat in the new Congress, said, "We don't want to start off the session in a negative way, but if our caucus decides that these ratios are piggish on their part, then we may have to go to the mat."
 In fact, majority parties always give themselves an edge, though the Republicans went a little further beyond their 53 percent share of the incoming House than the Democrats did in exceeding their 59 percent share of the old House.
 On Appropriations, which controls spending, Republicans are taking 57 percent of the positions, while Democrats had 62 percent. On Ways and Means, which handles taxes, Republicans are taking 58 percent; Democrats had taken 63.
 Mr. Gephardt and Mr. Bonior spent the day on the telephone, talking to dozens of representatives whose committee positions were threatened. They planned to hold a series of meetings next week to decide how to propose handling the problem when the full Democratic caucus meets later in the week.
 The Republican decision on committee sizes was announced today by Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the incoming Republican majority leader. Along with abolition of the committees on the District of Columbia, Merchant Marine and Fisheries and Post Office and Civil Service, with a total of 82 positions, the Republican plan would take 35 slots away from the remaining 20 committees.
 The original Republican plan would have cut those committees by 81 positions. Of those that were restored, 33 will go to Democrats. Mr. Armey said the numbers had been revised "out of consideration for the minority's need to be able to fill committee slots." He said the Republicans did so because, as a former member of the minority, he had "seen the kind of tension that is created when the needs of the minority are not given consideration."
 He also boasted that in making their committee assignments, Republicans had shown special consideration for freshmen. He said newly elected Republicans got 7 out of 11 open Republican seats on Appropriations, 3 of 10 on Ways and Means and 9 of 10 on Commerce.
 Freshmen are at the heart of the Democratic problem, too, but they are the freshmen from the outgoing Congress. The class elected in 1992 included 21 women, 16 blacks and 6 Hispanic lawmakers. Democrats used the diversity of that class and its immediate predecessor to change the makeup of several major committees.
 On Ways and Means, Democrats have 24 members. Five left through retirement or defeat, but another four must leave to get down to the 15 slots in the next Congress. The four junior members include two of the committee's five blacks.
 On Appropriations, Democrats have 36 members. Five will not be back, because of defeat or retirement, and the allocations announced today will give them 24 positions in the next Congress, requiring seven Democrats to surrender that plum assignment.
 The lowest seven in seniority include two of the committee's three Hispanic Democrats, two of its five Democratic women and one of its three blacks. The committee's most junior member, Representative Carrie Meek of Florida, who is black, has urged that diversity be made a consideration in deciding how to handle the reductions.
 While plans for handling the issue will be earnestly discussed when Democrats meet to organize next week, it is likely that the only concession junior members will get from the caucus is the assurance that they will be first in line to get back on the choice committees if Democrats regain control of the House or other members are defeated.
 Mr. Bonior said that no decisions had been made and that he hoped Republicans would reconsider. During his tenure in the House, he said, Democrats had always adjusted committee ratios and made committees bigger so that no member would have to get off. But none of those shifts were as big a change as occurred when Republicans won control of the House.
 Thomas E. Mann of the Brookings Institution said Mr. Bonior's idea of expanding committees so that no one would be forced out was "good for the individuals and bad for the institution."
 "Over the last couple of decades," Mr. Mann said "there has been a real inflation in committee size. Large committees are harder to operate as units, by and large. Over time it leads to a ballooning of the total number of assignments and the total number of conflicts and the frenetic pace of the institution."
 The other major problem the Democrats confront is how to deal with members of the three committees Republicans are abolishing. Republicans allowed their members to transfer to whatever committee picked up the jurisdiction of the extinct committee, and to take their seniority with them. But Democrats are divided on that question.

The plan is subject to a formal vote ratifying it on Jan. 4, and it could still be changed in minor ways.

HEADLINE: Pentagon to Cut $7.7 Billion in New Weapons Programs

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9

 BODY:
The Pentagon announced today that it would cut $7.7 billion in new weapons programs over the next six years to help combat readiness by paying for increased salaries and improved living conditions for American troops.
Coupled with President Clinton's decision last week to add $25 billion to the military's budget through 2001, the announcement today reflects a concerted effort by the Administration to increase combat readiness and to support military personnel. 
 The decision to shift money from hardware to readiness, at least in the next few years, also underscores the efforts by the White House to blunt criticisms from Republican lawmakers that American forces are stretched too thin. The Pentagon conceded last month that 3 of 12 Army divisions were below peak readiness levels.
"We believe that these adjustments are acceptable, they protect our technology base, and they allow important force-modernization programs to continue at a rate that we can afford, and they do provide the necessary savings which help us increase funding for readiness," Defense Secretary William J. Perry told reporters today.
But Republicans countered that the Administration's financing decisions underscored a lack of vision. "It's an ad-hoc defense policy," said Senator John McCain, an Arizona Republican on the Armed Services Committee. "It's becoming bizarre as they lurch from one idea to another."
In a widely publicized memorandum in August, Deputy Defense Secretary John M. Deutch ordered the Army, Navy and Air Force to prepare plans to cancel or delay as much as $20 billion in new weapons systems in development. The President's decision to pour more money into the Pentagon coffers reduced the size of the necessary cuts.
The plan announced today includes the following:
*Canceling a radar-evading missile system developed by the Northrop Grumman Corporation, called the Tri-Service Standoff Attack Missile. Ending the program will save $2.1 billion in the next six years, but cost 1,700 Northrop Grumman jobs in Southern California.
*Revamping the Army's Comanche armed reconnaissance helicopter program, developed by the Boeing Company and the Sikorsky division of the United Technologies Corporation, to build only two prototypes. The savings will be $2.1 billion over six years.
*Reducing the number of new Navy Aegis destroyers, built at the Bath Iron Works in Maine and the Litton Industries shipyard in Mississippi, to 16 from 18. The savings will be $1.5 billion over six years.
Military contractors said they still needed to see details of the plan before they could judge its consequences. Some even held out hope that future Administrations or Congresses could change today's decision. "These issues have a way of changing year to year," said Jack Satterfield, a spokesman for Boeing. "Obviously, this is the first step in a very long and detailed review process."
Before the White House came up with the extra money, the armed services had been bracing for even deeper cuts. Some Air Force officials feared that the purchase of 422 F-22 fighters, the service's most-prized new weapons system, could be delayed for up to four years. Instead, the Pentagon shaved only $200 million in research and development from the program's overall $70 billion program.
In addition, the Pentagon opted to leave largely untouched the Marine Corps' V-22 Osprey, an aircraft that takes off like a helicopter and flies like an airplane, and is being developed by Boeing and the Bell helicopter unit of Textron Inc.
"These cuts, we believe, are prudent," Mr. Perry said, "and they will not interfere with our efforts to develop the new wave of weaponry needed for the 21st century."
The Administration has concluded that the end of the cold war offers an opportunity to cancel or significantly delay several costly weapons that were designed to fight the Soviets, and shift that money into readiness accounts. Mr. Perry plans eventually to replace older equipment using savings from base closings and streamlined Pentagon purchasing practices.
Moreover, about $15 billion of the $25 billion the White House added to the Pentagon budget is earmarked for weapons modernization in the fiscal years 2000 and 2001.
Senior Pentagon officials insisted that the decisions of the past week made up virtually all of a $49 billion shortfall the Defense Department faced over the next six years. Lower-than-expected inflation costs had dropped the shortfall to $37 billion. The extra $25 billion from the White House pared it to $12 billion.
Today's announcement brought the shortfall to about $4 billion, pocket change in the Pentagon's $1.5 trillion long-term budget that Mr. Deutch said would be eliminated through budgetary nips and tucks.

HEADLINE: Attacks Begin on Plan to Cut Social Programs

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9

 BODY:
In a taste of battles likely to dominate American politics for the next decade, labor unions and spokesmen for the elderly today attacked proposals from a panel advising President Clinton on how to slow the growth of Social Security, Medicare and other Government benefit programs.
 After three hours of debate, the chairman of the panel, Senator Bob Kerrey, Democrat of Nebraska, admitted that he had only four or five votes of the 20 needed to win an official endorsement of his recommendations. The 32-member panel, the Bipartisan Commission on Entitlement and Tax Reform, is scheduled to hold its final meeting on Wednesday, with no consensus in sight. 
 As part of a comprehensive plan to control the cost of Federal benefit programs, Mr. Kerrey and the vice chairman of the commission, Senator John C. Danforth, Republican of Missouri, proposed raising the eligibility age for Medicare and the normal retirement age, at which full Social Security benefits become available, to 70, from the current 65. They would also reduce Social Security, Medicare, unemployment insurance and certain veterans' benefits for people with high incomes.
 Critics immediately denounced the proposals, just as Mr. Kerrey had predicted. Thomas R. Donahue, secretary-treasurer of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., said, "These measures would destroy the retirement income and health system that Americans have enjoyed for 60 years." He asserted that "there is no crisis in the Social Security retirement program."
 Robert M. Ball, a former Commissioner of Social Security, said that Mr. Kerrey's proposals, taken together, would mean a 44 percent reduction in benefits for workers who have earned average wages over the course of their lives. "Raising the normal retirement age to 70 would reduce benefits not only for early retirees, but also for those who wait until age 70 to retire," Mr. Ball said.
 It is unclear whether Senator Kerrey, who expressed impatience with his critics, will engage in the lengthy discussions and negotiations that will be needed to forge agreement within his panel. It is also unclear whether his proposals will improve or worsen the political climate for members of Congress who want to curb the growth of Social Security and Medicare.
 Horace B. Deets, executive director of the American Association of Retired Persons, said he was stunned by Mr. Kerrey's proposals because they would require older people to "bear, not share, the burden of deficit reduction." The proposals, he said, are not balanced; two-thirds of the proposed savings would come from Social Security and Medicare.
 Martin A. Corry, director of Federal affairs at the association, said: "Only a small proportion of workers retire at 65. The average retirement age is now 61 1/2, though some retirees return to the labor force for part-time or seasonal work."
 Workers can now collect Social Security retirement benefits at ages as low as 62, but the benefits for early retirees are reduced, and the reduction is larger for people who retire earlier.
 Thomas R. Margenau, a spokesman for the Social Security Administration, said: "Fifty-one percent of the people who apply for Social Security retirement benefits do so at the age of 62. Only 25 percent wait till age 65."
 Richard L. Trumka, a commission member who is also president of the United Mine Workers of America, said Mr. Kerrey seemed to be operating on the premise that "we must destroy these programs in order to save them."
 "The means-testing of Medicare would, in effect, redefine it as welfare," Mr. Trumka said. "And we all know the level of public support for welfare programs."
 Mr. Kerrey said such hostile reactions suggested that Americans could not deal with serious problems until they turned into a crisis.
 Several commission members expressed support for Mr. Kerrey's approach. Among them were Robert E. Denham, the chairman of Salomon Inc.; Peter G. Peterson, chairman of the Blackstone Group, an investment bank, and two Republican Representatives, C. Christopher Cox of California and J. Alex McMillan of North Carolina.
 Some members of the commission said they needed more time to analyze and discuss Mr. Kerrey's proposals, so they would understand how the changes affected people at different income levels.
 One commission member, Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming, said the critics of Mr. Kerrey's plan were trying to whip up "raw political fear" by using inflammatory words like "cut, slash, chop, destroy and dismantle." In fact, he said, people over the age of 50 will not be much affected.
 Wade J. Henderson, director of the Washington office of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said the proposals would have disproportionate effects on blacks and "could exacerbate racial divisions." For black males born in 1992, he said, the life expectancy is 65 years, so many of them will not live long enough to receive Social Security benefits if the retirement age is increased to 70.
 One of Mr. Kerrey's proposals would reduce the Social Security payroll tax for employees. Workers would have to invest the extra money they received in private savings plans or individual retirement accounts.
 Asked whether this was a first step toward "privatizing Social Security," Mr. Kerrey said: "Yes. But private retirement benefits are not destructive of Social Security."
 Under Mr. Kerrey's proposal, elderly people could stay in Medicare, but they could also get Government vouchers to enroll in private health plans. In addition, he would limit the tax deductions that employers may take for the cost of employee health benefits. Under current law, there is no such limit.

GRAPHIC: Photo: No sooner had the head of a panel advising the President on how to slow the growth of Government benefit programs made his suggestions than opponents attacked them. The chairman, Senator Bob Kerrey, talked about his proposals yesterday before a hearing of the panel. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: U.S. Hasn't Become Stumbling Economic Giant

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "The G.O.P. Contract Is Too Timid" (Op-Ed, Dec. 3): Paul Craig Roberts's diatribe against a United States "welfare state grown soft and fat" suffers from flawed logic, inaccurate insinuations and fatuous conclusions about America and its place in the global economy. 
 Rather than the stumbling giant hobbled by an undisciplined population and crushing taxes that Mr. Roberts portrays, recent studies indicate that the United States has a work force that is among the most productive and competitive in the world, and an overall tax burden lower than that in most of its economic rivals.
The insinuation that China's economy will surpass that of the United States because of the Chinese leadership's truer commitment to capitalist principles ignores the fact that, given the size of the Chinese population, even modest increases in per capita income will produce enormous growth in China's gross domestic product.
Mr. Roberts's denunciation of the American legal system conveniently ignores that until very recently a system where people had "different rights based on their status" already existed -- except women and minorities were the victims of inequality.
The claim that United States law "now demands advancement by race and gender quota" is insupportable by the evidence. To condemn changes that will bring into the economy a pool of talent and energy so long prevented from full participation is curious, given Mr. Roberts's concerns.
Advocacy of a "return to the small-government era" of the 19th century, whose implications Dickens described so well, is more romanticism for an idealized past than a clear-eyed vision of the future.
Reforms in health care, welfare and the role of government are desirable for a number of reasons, but to pose the issue in such an apocalyptic fashion neither clarifies the available choices nor provides feasible alternatives.
 
VINCENT A. AUGER
Clinton, N.Y., Dec. 3, 1994
 
The writer is an assistant professor of government at Hamilton College.

HEADLINE: U.S. Hasn't Become Stumbling Economic Giant;
Post-Welfare Vacuum

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Paul Craig Roberts bemoans that "The G.O.P. Contract Is Too Timid" (Op-Ed, Dec. 3). But his discourse is equally vague and mischievous. 
 Mr. Roberts holds the view that Social Security and health care should be privatized. He would abolish welfare and end "taxation of human and physical capital."
Can welfare be abolished with social peace assured and intact? Will private charity fill the void? What of the effect on innocent children? Will they be required to pay for the "sins" of their parents?
Will tasks be shifted to states and localities? How will the taxation of human and physical capital be discontinued without detriment to the indispensable flow of government revenues? Will Social Security and health care accounts owned by individuals be free from raiding? If not, shall stern and harsh riposte declare that the sick, infirm and needy be left to their own devices?
Mr. Roberts urges a "return to equality before the law" in the United States, as if all Americans have been subjected to social and economic circumstances that are a constant on a level playing field. However, it is his rugged individualism that invites regression to "feudal times." While a freer world marketplace does vouchsafe greater equality of status than did feudalism, when the issues of civil rights and discrimination in America are raised, Mr. Roberts would be wise to avert attempts at comparisons.
Neither the Republicans' "Contract With America" nor Mr. Roberts's unfettered libertarianism are serious platforms for a domestic political undertaking or a national program for competitiveness in the 21st-century global economic contest.
 
ELLIOTT A. COHEN
New York, Dec. 3, 1994
