LENGTH: 1317 words

HEADLINE: Finger-Pointing in Orange County Fiasco

BYLINE: By SALLIE HOFMEISTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 9

 BODY:
The search for people to blame for the Orange County, Calif., bankruptcy fiasco reached beyond county officials today to include some of the Wall Street firms that sold Orange County bonds to investors.
The Securities and Exchange Commission, widening its investigation of the county's loss-plagued investment fund, subpoenaed at least two brokerage firms, including Merrill Lynch & Company. Meanwhile, owners of bonds issued by the county sued county officials and Merrill Lynch and Smith Barney, contending that the brokerage firms concealed "reckless investment practices" of the investment pool. 
 The county, in turn, followed through on its threat to sue Wall Street firms that sold securities after its filing on Tuesday for bankruptcy. The securities were used as collateral to support borrowing by the investment fund, which disclosed last week that its $20 billion value had fallen by at least $1.5 billion because of ill-fated bets on interest rates.
The circle of local governments affected by the bankruptcy widened as well, with the small city of Montebello in Los Angeles County disclosing that it might have to file for bankruptcy because it has more than 60 percent of its $77.2 million investment portfolio frozen in the Orange County pool.
But so far, the county's financial crisis has not interrupted payments to employees of local governments, school districts and county agencies in Orange County. Nor have payments to pensioners been affected by the county's failure on Thursday to pay holders of a $110 million pension bond that was backed by the liquidity of the Orange County investment pool.
Merrill Lynch, which underwrote $600 million in bonds last summer for the investment pool, confirmed that it was subpoenaed yesterday by the S.E.C. "We plan to cooperate fully with the S.E.C. investigation," said Richard Silverman, a spokesman for Merrill Lynch in New York. He did not disclose any details about the Federal agency's request.
Rauscher Pierce Refsnes Inc., a small Dallas firm, was also subpoenaed. Rauscher Pierce has advised Orange County in the past and had been retained to sell a coming bond issue for the county.
The S.E.C. would not comment on the investigation, but lawyers close to the case said the regulators were looking at whether the firms that sold bonds to investors during the summer knew the risks faced by the Orange County investment pool. The bond offering statements did not disclose any losses in the investment pool, whose value began falling in February after interest rates started to rise.
The S.E.C. is also expected to look at what are known as reverse repurchase agreements, or reverse repos, used by Orange County to turn $7.8 billion in money from 187 county agencies, school districts and cities into a portfolio worth $20 billion. Under these agreements, nearly a dozen Wall Street firms lent the county about $13 billion and took as collateral fixed-income government securities worth about $13.5 billion.
When Orange County defaulted on one of those loans, for $2 billion, with CS First Boston on Tuesday, the county was forced into bankruptcy. Since then, all but two of the firms with repurchase agreements with the county have liquidated $11.5 billion in collateral, according to David Kiff, a spokesman for the county. Those two are Merrill Lynch, which has $2 billion in collateral against loans, and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, with $100 million.
Repairing the damage at the troubled Orange County investment fund will take at least a year, according to Thomas W. Hayes, the former California state treasurer who was named Thursday to manage the fund after Robert L. Citron, the former county treasurer, resigned.
A protege of Gov. Pete Wilson of California, Mr. Hayes is expected to have wide power to clean up the mess in the fund, whose collapse is putting political pressure on Thomas F. Riley, the chairman of the five-member board of supervisors. Mr. Hayes and Mr. Riley are Republicans, while Mr. Citron is a Democrat.
Orange County, a largely suburban county just south of Los Angeles, has a population of 2.3 million and is one of the wealthiest counties in the nation.
 Today, the county filed a lawsuit against Nomura Securities charging that the firm violated the county's bankruptcy protection by liquidating $900 million in bonds that it held as collateral.
In a statement today, Nomura called the lawsuit "baseless and without merit" and said, "We intend to defend ourselves vigorously in this matter."
Other firms that sold collateral, including Prudential, Smith Barney, First Boston and Morgan Stanley, are expected to be sued by the county.
The lawsuit, filed in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Santa Ana, Calif., asks the judge to void the sale or require Nomura to replace the bonds or give the county the proceeds from the sale. But many bankruptcy lawyers say repurchase agreements are exempt from the law that freezes all assets in a bankruptcy.
The Wall Street investment houses that helped the county sell bonds and lent it money are being seen by some investors as the deep pockets in the case.
Investors in those bonds, it was disclosed today, have filed a class action suit in Federal District Court in Santa Ana against Orange County officials who managed the fund, as well as Merrill Lynch and Smith Barney. The suit -- filed by Leetate Smith, trustee for the Smith Family Trust, which purchased $15,000 worth of county bonds, -- contended that investors were not informed that the county's investment pool was at risk of collapse.
The suit, the Merrill Lynch spokesman said, is without merit. "It's unfortunate, but predictable," he said. " We will contest the lawsuit vigorously."
A spokesman for Smith Barney also dismissed the suit, saying such suits are "filed all the time" in such situations.
Meanwhile, the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, which represents about 1,000 bus drivers and mechanics who work for the county, said it was also considering legal action. "The fingers are pointed at Merrill Lynch," said Bart Naylor, a spokesman for the union. "They sold the derivatives to Orange County, they shaped the risky strategy that got them into trouble, they underwrote the bonds to meet collateral calls."
In a recent case involving a huge loss in a municipal investment pool, Wall Street firms paid heavily.
After the investment fund of San Jose, Calif., lost $60 million as a result of the same kind of borrowing and interest-rate plays that got Orange County into trouble, San Jose sued 13 brokerage firms, including Merrill Lynch, Smith Barney, Paine Webber, E. F. Hutton and Prudential- Bache. Eleven of them settled the case for a total of $12 million; Hutton and Paine Webber were ordered to pay the city $13 million after a six-month trial that ended in June 1990.
"For this to happen again so close to the last time is a horror," said Melvyn I. Weiss, a partner at Milberg Weiss Bershad Hynes & Lerach in New York, who represented San Jose. He said he had been consulted by investors in the Orange County pool, but he declined to name them. "The brokers know these problems and have lived through them once before," he said.
In addition, the teamsters' union, in a letter to Arthur Levitt Jr., chairman of the S.E.C., asked the agency to investigate political contributions made by three Merrill Lynch employees to Mr. Citron's re-election campaign for county treasurer.
Merrill Lynch said today that the contributions were legal.
The teamsters contend that the $1,000 given by each of the three brokers, including Michael Stamenson, the San Francisco salesman who made millions of dollars in commissions on Orange County business, was in violation of rules recently approved by the S.E.C. that bar securities firms and their employees from seeking underwriting contracts from politicians whose election they helped finance.

HEADLINE: The Echoes Of Piaf In Paris

BYLINE: By FREDERICK TURNER; FREDERICK TURNER has frequently written about Paris for The Times.

 BODY:
AMONG the enduring icons of Paris is Edith Piaf, the tiny singer who burned herself out more than 30 years ago but who remains for Parisians, and for the French generally, the embodiment of some cherished values: a gritty romanticism, a profligate willingness to give everything for love and art, and a love of Paris that embraces equally its squalor and splendor. "My heart," she sang, "is at the corner of a street/And often rolls into the gutter."
And it was almost in the gutter of the 20th arrondissement, legend inaccurately claimed, that Edith Gassion was born in 1915 when her father failed to get a doctor in time and Edith's mother gave birth on a policeman's cape on the steps of 72 Rue de Belleville. Fifteen years later, and long since abandoned by her mother, Edith left her father to begin a career as a street singer in the district's Belleville-Menil montant neighborhood. 
 Later she would describe the years 1930 to 1935 as an "endless walk." This was the depths of the Depression, and Edith and her companion Simone Berteaut were just two of a hungry, shifting crowd of singers, jugglers, beggars and mimes who worked the city's streets, courtyards and squares, hoping to hear the ring of coins on the cobblestones. When a passing cabaret owner heard Piaf in 1935, he was astonished by a voice that seemed to fill every inch of her body and by an almost alarming intensity of delivery. He dubbed her "Mome Piaf" -- the Little Sparrow -- took her off the streets and put her on the road to stardom.
And yet in important ways Piaf remained to the end a person of the streets, closely identified with the working-class neighborhood of Belleville-Menilmontant. Speaking of her impoverished beginnings there, of that endless walk that would begin again each morning with the thin and dirty teen-ager gargling coffee to loosen her vocal cords, she said, "I wouldn't be Piaf if I hadn't gone through all that."
Seeking to help an American writer understand the roots of Piaf's genius, Simone Berteaut told him to go to the 20th arrondissement and poke about its old streets, alleys and cul-de-sacs. There, she told him, "You'll understand what it was like for us." Even though the area has undergone a piecemeal and esthetically unhappy urban renewal, you can still act on Berteaut's advice, for there is plenty of the old neighborhood left. And when you do go up to the 20th, you'll encounter a sector of a city that never ceases to surprise, constantly repaying a traveler's spirit of inquiry.
The best days to wander the 20th are Tuesdays and Fridays, when a huge, vibrant open-air market is in session along the Boulevard de Menilmontant and the Boulevard de Belleville. You can get there from the Menilmontant or Belleville Metro stop, although I prefer the former because emerging from the latter, you're confronted with a McDonald's.
At either stop, a double row of canvas-covered stalls stretches as far as you can see. Between them, a dense throng slowly pulses. Here's a tray of wristwatches; there are bins and bags of bulk spices, many of them used in the cuisines of the Levant and North Africa. Glistening cutlery is displayed next to a blind beggar with his bowl. At the corner sits a turbaned man selling dates and grains. Farther along are meats, fish, poultry strung up by the feet, great feathery mounds of untrimmed garlic, jagged pyramids of green beans and mangoes from the Ivory Coast.
Step aside from this brilliant display to the street edges, where knots of men sit in the cafes and gesture at each other in animated conversation. Stop at one -- say, Chez Jeannot, which advertises Tunisian snacks -- and have a bite or a cup of coffee, in order to simply sit and watch. "This is a Jewish-Tunisian restaurant," said a young man behind Chez Jeannot's counter who gave his name as Yossi. He was putting together what he said were "fricassees," a sandwich of tuna in a bun, garnished with potato slices, capers, olives and pickled peppers. "You have a lot of Jews up here in the 20th," Yossi told me. "Before, they were in Algeria." He insisted I try a fricassee and made one up that I took out to the tables on the sidewalk. Across the broad boulevard and above the awnings, laundry hung from the windows of the scabrous old apartment buildings and women leaned on sills looking down at the shoppers. A great many things have changed since Paris sprawled eastward in the last century, engulfing the villages of Belleville and Menilmontant and transforming them into working-class neighborhoods, but this section is still working class, though its ethnic composition has changed since Piaf walked its streets.
She was part Algerian herself, and as Yossi had pointed out, Algerians are still a force here. But now there are other North African nationalities here as well as brilliantly robed people from farther south in the continent and an increasingly large populace of Asians -- Thais, Malaysians and Chinese.
As the clock creeps toward the market's closing at 1 P.M., the vendors' cries rise to a keening chant. Time to turn off the market street onto the Rue Crespin-du-Gast and the Musee Edith Piaf, having beforehand made a telephone appointment with its proprietor, Bernard Marchois. Mr. Marchois speaks no English, but he understands perfectly the nature of your mission and obligingly shows you through the two rooms that are cluttered with Piaf artifacts.
While recordings flood you with the singer's tight vibrato, you inspect the photographs, letters, shoes, one of the black dresses Piaf always wore on stage, even the huge teddy bear that was a constant companion to a star who, like so many others, was always lonely except when performing. A life-size cutout of Piaf against a wall allows you to appreciate the phenomenon of so small a body housing so large a voice.
Up the steep slope of the Rue de Belleville, once the village's main street, past the bars, tabacs, Laundromats and Chinese groceries and restaurants, is number 72, the legendary birthplace. Three years after her death in 1963, when Maurice Chevalier unveiled the plaque that adorns this very ordinary doorway, a crowd choked the street all the way back to the Boulevard de Belleville. But few of the assembled knew that in fact Piaf had been born a few blocks away at the Hopital Tenon (it's still there). By then the legend had become far more important than the facts.
Coming back down the Rue de Belleville, a left turn on a street called the Rue Piat and on to the top of the hill will give a panoramic view of the city, including the partial renewal of Belleville-Menilmontant.
If you've bought picnic supplies at the market, you might want to put them to use in the sparkling little Parc de Belleville. If not, there are two good restaurants right here on the Rue des Envierges, both operated by the same family. I like the cozier feel of Bistrot-Cave des Envierges, but in good weather you can't beat the view from the terrace of A La Courtille with a breeze flapping its long awning and the smudged Impressionist clouds flowing overhead.
Part of what you see here has the bleak sterility associated with Georges Pompidou's makeover of Paris in the 1970's, but this neighborhood was originally built up without undue concern for the health or comfort of its residents and the "improvements" that might strike the American traveler as impoverished in character are probably experienced by the current inhabitants in quite another way.
AND in any case, there is still evidence of the neighborhood of Piaf's youth. Inside A La Courtille are some wonderful Willy Ronis photographs that show Belleville-Menilmontant as it was before renewal. A few blocks away, at 87 Rue de Menilmontant, a Century 21 real-estate office has a storefront display of the area as it was during World War II. And you can get an immediate sense of it by walking down the cobbled slope of the Rue du Transvaal just behind the restaurants. Here you find those narrow, beguiling alleys that Simone Berteaut recommended to the American writer, such as Villa Castel and Passage Plantin.
On the electrical boxes of the latter I saw scrawled messages that might have been written by Piaf herself: "L'amour est amer" (love is bitter) one of them read. At the bottom of the Rue du Transvaal you come to a knot of little streets in an area utterly unretouched. It's a good place to get creatively lost; wandering about, you see the truth of the architectural historian Francois Loyer's observation that the old architecture of this neighborhood is chaotic and unplanned but also intensely alive.
The Rue des Cascades, one short street off the eastern end of the Rue du Transvaal, embodies the divided nature of the 20th: on one side anonymous high rises, on the other a huddle of old buildings, some of which were photographed by the great Atget. Next to the Club Niagara, which advertises Friday-night jazz, is the studio of Raul Velasco, president of the local artists' association. There are more than a hundred artists' studios clustered in the neighborhood, he told me, and every May they hold an open-studio celebration to promote their work.
"When I came here from Mexico in the early 80's," Velasco said, "there were still a few people around who had known Piaf, and it was easy to have a conversation about her. There were two old women who used to speak of her, but both are dead. This area is changing very much, as you see, and the younger people moving into the flats, they don't have that memory of her."
Wind your way south, down through the Passage des Soupirs (Lane of Sighs), to the Rue Orfila, where Cafe de l'Esperance (Hope Cafe) offers a look at the sort of place fast disappearing in Paris: a tiny zinc bar, billiard table and coffee machine. The blonde woman behind the bar said with some asperity that when Piaf had lived hereabouts she had been entirely unknown. "Now everybody knows her name." Farther along, at 105 Rue Orfila is the building where Piaf and Berteaut lived for some months; then it was called the Hotel of the Future. You couldn't make up these heartbreaking names.
It isn't far along the Rue Pelleport to Place Edith Piaf on the Rue Belgrand, and to get there you pass Hopital Tenon. At the square is a small monument to Piaf unveiled in 1981 by Mayor Jacques Chirac. Behind the square is a jewelry store, La Vie en Roses, a takeoff on Piaf's signature song.
From there to Piaf's portion of Pere-Lachaise Cemetery is but a few steps farther, emphasizing how closely Piaf remained tied to her old neighborhood. There, surrounded by others who gave much for art -- Gertrude Stein, Modigliani -- is Piaf's black marble tomb. The first time I visited, it was covered with sprays of white flowers, and I thought it must have been some sort of anniversary. It wasn't. The tomb has been similarly bedecked on every visit since.
It will be when you visit, too: If the newcomers to the 20th lack the memory of the Little Sparrow and her rise from these streets, there are a great many others who do remember, who continue to make the pilgrimage, bearing their bouquets of devotion.
 
 
 
WALKING IN PIAF'S FOOTSTEPS, WITH NO REGRETS
 The Musee Edith Piaf is at 5 and 7 Rue Crespin-du-Gast and is open Monday to Thursday from 1 to 6 P.M., by appointment only. Bernard Marchois, the proprietor, is also the secretary general of the Friends of Edith Piaf, which runs the museum.
Visitors must call Mr. Marchois to get instructions on how to enter the building. He does not speak English, so you might want to ask your hotel concierge to speak with him at 43.55.52.72. There is no admission fee.
Ateliers d'Artistes de Belleville, the artists' cooperative of the 20th Arrondissement, is at 48 Rue Ramponneau, 46.36.44.09.
For a tour of Pere-Lachaise, one of the best guidebooks is "Permanent Parisians: An Illustrated Guide to the Cemeteries of Paris," by Judi Culbertson and Tom Randall (Chelsea Green, paperback, $15.95). Piaf's tomb is in Section 97.
 
Where to Eat
Prices are in dollars, at 5.25 francs to $1, and are for one person with wine.
The Bistrot-Cave des Envierges is at 11 Rue des Envierges, 46.36.47.84; open Wednesday to Saturday, noon to 2 A.M., and Sunday noon to 8 P.M. It is a wine bar serving traditional French cooking. Lunch is about $13 and dinner about $27.
A La Courtille is at 1 Rue des Envierges, 46.36.51.59. It offers complete meals featuring the cuisine and wine of particular regions of France. A full meal is about $34. Open noon to 2 P.M. and 8 to 10:45 P.M.
Two other convenient restaurants are next to Pere-Lachaise. Le St.-Amour backs up to one of the cemetery's walls at 2 Avenue Gambetta and 32 Boulevard de Menilmontant, at Place Auguste Metivier, but is nonetheless a cheerful spot for a good lunch.
The restaurant specializes in the cuisine of the Auvergne region. The sandwiches are fresh, the prices are moderate and the service is brisk and friendly. A dinner menu, including appetizer, entree, cheese and dessert is $23. Also recommended is their St.-Amour wine. Open 7 A.M. to 9 P.M. Tuesday to Sunday; call 47.97.20.15.
Across the square at 44 Boulevard de Menilmontant is Aux Becs Fins, a seafood restaurant with Perigord and Breton specialties, such as bouillabaisse and white-bean stew with goose. A full meal with wine, dessert and coffee is about $45. Unlike Le St.-Amour, which caters to tourists, this is a neighborhood restaurant, and while casual enough, it offers more serious meals. Call 47.97.51.52. Open noon to 2:30 P.M. and 7:30 to 9:30 P.M.

HEADLINE: Commuting at the Edge of the Exurb Belt

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

DATELINE: MILFORD, PA.

 BODY:
THE sky is coal-black, dawn still a time zone to the east, when Mona Clausen boards the 5:35 bus to Manhattan in front of the Old Tyme Pharmacy in this quaint village in the hilly northeastern reaches of the Poconos not far from the point where the borders of New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania fit like pieces of a jigsaw puzzle.
Mrs. Clausen's trip to her office at a midtown Manhattan bank takes two hours door-to-door; she won't see daybreak this time of year until the bus nears Newark. She commutes this way four or five times a week. 
 "You get used to it," she said. "I guess I'm just a morning person."
About 60 miles due south, Rick Goodwin makes a similar run each morning from Buckingham, Pa., in the heart of Bucks County's bosky countryside, to his Manhattan office, also in midtown.
Mr. Goodwin's trip takes, on a good day, two hours and 15 minutes by car and, from Trenton, Amtrak train. (On a bad day, he could fly to the Caribbean in the same amount of time.) He has been traveling to and from work this way each weekday for two years. He hasn't gotten used to it; he's not a morning person.
"I figured out I'm spending 54 days a year commuting," he said.
Eastern Pennsylvania has long been a second-home haven for people who are residents of the New York City region. Some are well-to-do owners of weekend homes and hobby farms in Bucks County. Others are the proud possessors of inexpensive cabins and cottages in the Poconos.
In recent years, though, the five counties north of Philadelphia along the western bank of the Delaware River appear to have become a permanent home for an increasing number of ex-New Yorkers and commuters who, lured in large part by comparatively cheap housing prices, work in Manhattan or northern and central New Jersey, particularly the Princeton area.
"A lot of people live over there and commute across the bridge into Jersey," said Ellen Hodges, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the Princeton Area. "In the last 10 years, it has really developed as the Princeton area has developed."
This slow in-migration of full-time residents -- along with a local economy that wasn't damaged as much by the recent recession as other parts of the Northeast -- has helped cushion real-estate prices and sales volume from the steep declines suffered in many parts of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut since 1988.
"We are becoming the fourth state in what has always been known as the New York, New Jersey and Connecticut region," said Davis R. Chant, the chairman of a real estate brokerage in Milford that bears his name.
"We're the next frontier," he added. "We're the only place in the region that is still growing significantly -- the only place around New York where there are many more people moving in than moving out. Why? We're clean, safe, affordable; we have good schools. Need I go on?"
Statistics precisely gauging the growth of eastern Pennsylvania as home for New York and New Jersey commuters or New Yorkers with second homes do not exist. There are, however, several measures that seem to show a rise in recent years, at least for permanent residents who either work in New York and New Jersey or take new jobs in Pennsylvania. In a 1988 study, for example, 10 percent of all home sales in Northampton and Lehigh Counties were to people who previously lived in ZIP codes in New Jersey and New York. Most of those buyers bought homes in the Easton area.
Kamran Afshar, an economist who conducted the study, said that the migration was spurred in large part by the completion of Interstate 78, which made travel to New York much faster.
BUS and train ridership to and from Pennsylvania has also increased over the years. About 51 people each weekday morning use Metro-North's Port Jervis, N.Y., station, about 10 miles north of Milford, for a two-hour ride into the PATH station in Hoboken, N.J., about twice as many as 10 years ago.
"If you look at the license plates in the parking lot, you'll see that about a third to half of them are from Pennsylvania," said Daniel Brucker, a spokesman for Metro-North. "They come from the Poconos and Pike County."
To the south, Bieber Bus Company in Allentown has expanded to 12 daily runs from the Allentown-Reading area to New York since it started business in 1971, when it had only three runs. "We're growing all the time," said Carl Bieber, president of the company. "Some are going to shop, but some are going for work."
Mrs. Clausen noted that there were several Milford-to-New York commuters who rode with her each day; she uses the Mahwah-based Short Line, which is faster but more expensive than taking Metro North from Port Jervis; it also goes directly to mid-town Manhattan rather than Hoboken.
"I'd say that there are five of us, altogether," she said. "Most of us came from New York and Long Island. I came from Bay Ridge, in Brooklyn."
Mrs. Clausen said that the main reason she endured the daily commute so well was because she loved the home she bought in downtown Milford for $200,000 in October 1993: a Greek Revival village house that was built in 1810. She had been living in a co-op apartment with her husband, Robert, a retired computer-systems manager.
"We had driven through the area, and thought it was very charming," she said. "We looked in Long Island and Connecticut, and didn't care for it too much -- it was overbuilt. Besides, we couldn't duplicate there what we have here. Our house in Westfield, N.J., for instance, would cost $400,000."
She also said she doesn't find the commute to New York, where she works as an executive assistant, daunting. "On weekends, it's only an hour and a half from the Lincoln Tunnel," she said.
But Mr. Goodwin described his commute as a "real shock, especially when you are used to getting to work in 15 or 20 minutes." "I have been doing a lot more reading than I had been," he said. There are also problems like treacherous roads in the winter.
Mr. Goodwin's 85-mile trip starts with a 40-minute drive to the train station. "A lot of people commute into the city from Yardsley, which is only about 10 minutes from the Trenton station," he said.
The additional transportation costs can be considerable, too. For example, an Amtrak pass from Trenton to Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan costs $265 a month. Parking at the station costs Mr. Goodwin $125 a month, though less expensive spaces are available.
As with Mrs. Clausen, who pays about $320 a month for her bus passes, what has made the commute bearable for Mr. Goodwin is his home: a 1,200-square-foot, 190-year-old two-bedroom with barn and stream on4.5 acres that he and his companion, Kirk McKend, a graphic designer and artist, bought two years ago for $305,000.
The small size of the building didn't faze Mr. Goodwin; he had been had been living in a 400-square-foot, rent-stabilized -- the rent was $475 a month -- one-bedroom apartment in a brownstone on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. Mr. Goodwin, the editor-in-chief of Unique Homes magazine, and Mr. McKend also intend to make about $175,000 in renovations to the house.
"WE first went to look at the Hamptons to see what we could get near the water," he said. "We spent weekends looking in the Sag Harbor area and decided that we didn't like it too much -- the traffic was unbearable -- and the kind of home we wanted was in the $350,000 to $400,000 range."
He was already acquainted with Pennsylvania because he and a group of others had bought a 10-room Victorian house on 14 acres in Honesdale, near Milford, in 1982 for $47,000. "It was a lot more house than you could get in the Catskills," he said. "Taxes on the house were something like $300 a year. The area also wasn't full of New Yorkers on weekends, which meant that you really got away."
He heard about Bucks County from friends; the Honesdale house was sold this past summer for $170,000.
"It was attractive, the land had nice rolling hills, I became enchanted with it," he said of his new house. "I also love old architecture -- I love the feel and history of it. So, I thought why not commute. You look at the train schedule and the map, and you say to yourself, 'It's not that bad.' For a while, at least."
Though buyers like Mr. Goodwin and Mrs. Clausen have helped stimulate the housing market in eastern Pennsylvania, the growth shouldn't be overstated, particularly for 1994. In Monroe County, in the heart of the Poconos, for example, the average home sale price fell by 3.7 percent to $93,581 this year from $97,188 a year ago. In Pike and Wayne Counties the estimated average price of a home has declined this year by 3.4 percent to $103,180 from $106,836 in 1993.
These prices may seem low, but there are numerous upscale and luxury properties on the market, too.
Seven years ago, Ron Parker, a Manhattan art dealer, bought a 640-acre spread outside Milford, in Pike County; he uses as a sort of hunting preserve. "I wanted my son to grow up with nature, like I did," he said.
He also bought a Mediterranean villa, an oddity in downtown Milford, which is dominated by Victorian architecture. "I had a home in the Hamptons, and I gave it to my ex-wife in a divorce," he said. "I came out here because I wanted peace and quiet and tranquility. I wanted to be as far away as possible from everything New York and the Hamptons stand for."
Because of inclement weather early in the year and rising interest rates, sales volume as well as sales prices also slid this year in most of northeastern Pennsylvania. In Wayne County, the number of homes sold fell by 18.8 percent, to 812 as of Nov. 30 from 1,001 for all of last year. In Pike County, the number fell 23.6 percent over the same period to 860 from 1,127. In Monroe, however, the number increased, by 14.8 percent to 1,061 from 924.
In Northampton County, where the data are less reliable, sales prices have been relatively flat over the last few years with a slight increase this year, according to local real estate brokers. The number of sales for 1994 is expected to fall slightly short of 1993's levels.
The ongoing job reductions by the Bethlehem Steel Co., however, have not had a significant impact on the local real estate market. "We are in an active market, and we are pretty optimistic," said Janet Rispoli, a broker with Patt, White Company, Better Homes and Gardens in Bethlehem. "We have so much other industry coming in here."
The strongest current market may be in Bucks County, where both home sales and volume and average prices have been relatively flat for several years after declining slightly in 1989 and 1990.
That may not sound like much to cheer about, but the area was also been spared the 30 percent declines in prices and the sharp drop in sales that struck many parts of Connecticut and New York in the late 80's and early 90's.
"We didn't have the steep climbs or as steep a fall," said George H. Wells, a broker with Elizabeth James Country in Doylestown, Pa. "In the past few years, prices have stopped falling, but they are not really starting to climb, either."
Home construction has been flat or slightly declining in most of the five counties, with the exception of Bucks County, where home starts are expected to increase by 3 percent this year following similar increases the previous two years. In some parts of the county, new developments are being built, a sight not seen in many parts of the New York region since the 1980's.
"The location has charm and natural beauty, and it is also convenient to corporate centers in New Jersey, Montgomery County, Philadelphia and Lower Bucks," said Perry DeSiato, vice president for sales and marketing for DeLuca Enterprises of Newtown, Pa., which is building the Peddler's View development in Solebury Township, just outside of New Hope in Bucks County.
The development is projected to include 215 homes, priced from $194,000 to $242,900. Forty-five homes have been completed and sold so far; another 15 are under construction. "Buyers like the setting and are impressed by the value offered in these homes," Mr. DeSiato said. "In an area of estate homes, single-family homes priced below $200,000 are very appealing."
TO be sure, the five Pennsylvania counties are different culturally; Monroe County probably has more of the schmaltzy heart-shaped-bathtub honeymoon ambiance for which if Poconos is beloved by some and and ridiculed by others.
More rural Pike and Wayne Counties distance themselves from this image and bill themselves as northeastern Pennsylvania rather than the Poconos. "We don't run away from the label, but we don't use it either," Mr. Chant said.
Northampton County is a largely working-class region dominated by Easton and Bethlehem. Bucks County is a bucolic upper middle class suburb of Philadelphia that emphasizes its relative sophistication and artsiness.
"I didn't want to live in the immediate suburbs," Mr. Goodwin said. "I like the sense of country, even though it's getting less and less like country with all the construction going on."
Mr. Goodwin's move to Buckingham has worked out so well that he has recently given notice to his employer, and is going to stay in Pennsylvania, where intends to free-lance. He partly blamed the commute for decision.
"It got to the point where I didn't feel like I was living where I was sleeping," he said.
"I've been told there are some people who have been doing this for years," he said. "But really, this is a bit much."

HEADLINE: Hartford Business Misses Its Hockey

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH 

 BODY:
ABOUT 100 people were lined up outside Coach's Bar and Grille, waiting to get in before a recent Friday night basketball game between the University of Connecticut and Yale at the Hartford Civic Center. After the game, business was even brisker at the establishment on Allyn Street near the Civic Center.
Two nights later, business was considerably lighter at the restaurant and bar of which Jim Calhoun, the Connecticut men's basketball coach, is a part owner. Had the Hartford Whalers scheduled game against the Boston Bruins been played on that Sunday night a week ago, "we would have been packed," said Mike Moreau, another of the four owners of the establishment that opened last March. 
 Coach's Bar and Grille, along with many other restaurants, bars and other businesses in and around the Civic Center, have been severely affected by the suspension of the 1994-95 National Hockey League season. As the prime tenant -- and only major league franchise in the state -- the Hartford Whalers are counted on to draw customers on game nights.
But this season the Whalers have yet to play a regular season game at their home arena and, with negotiations at a virtual standstill, the outlook for a settlement of the labor dispute that has wrecked the season is bleak. So much so that three Whaler players have gone to play hockey in Europe, while most of the others have returned to their homes, mainly in Canada.
Through yesterday, 17 of the 41 Whalers games scheduled for the Civic Center had been postponed. And even if the dispute is settled, it is unlikely that any of those games would be made up.
The Whalers averaged 10,492 spectators at their home games last season, and their absence weighs heavily on local businesses. It also has deprived approximately 225 part-time employes of income derived as ushers, concession workers and other jobs at the Civic Center Coliseum, where the Whalers play.
"It's like night and day," said John France, the assistant manager at Margaritas, a restaurant and bar inside the Civic Center. "We do at least 50 percent more business on a Whalers game night," he said. "And when they play the Boston Bruins or the New York Rangers, we do even better."
At Gaetano's Ristorante in the Civic Center Plaza the impact has been even more severe, said Carl Carbone, one of the owners. "We're packed on game nights; we'll serve about 200 dinners," he said. "But when the Whalers are playing, we'll serve as many as 500. And there are spinoffs since some of the money my waiters make on tips will be spent at shops in the Civic Center."
The impact is felt often. "The Whalers were scheduled to play three games last week, and our business would have doubled each of those nights," said Jay Rule, the manager of Challenges Sports Cafe on Ann Street, near the Civic Center.
Mike Seaver, the owner of both Chuck's Steak House and Margaritas in the Civic Center, said, "Where the lack of hockey hurts us is in the bar scene."
Mr. Seaver said that the absence of Whalers games had been felt more during the week than on weekends. "On weekends," he explained, "the loss of Whaler fan business is made up by people who come in from out of town for dinner. A lot of them wouldn't come in on game nights because they don't want to buck the traffic. But they'll come in when there isn't a game."
That's good news for parking lot operators who have also been affected by the hockey lockout. "The loss of business is significant," said Mike Kuziak, one of the owners of Laz Parking, which operates 25 lots and garages in Hartford, many of which serve the Civic Center. "We figure that on a Whalers game night about 5,600 vehicles park in lots and garages, so the total loss on a game night is about $255,000, which is substantial."
"But in a warped way the loss of business on game nights is probably healthy for Hartford because it shows what life would be like without the Whalers," Mr. Kubiak said.
In recent years there have been rumors that the Whalers might leave Hartford, largely because of declining attendance, which many attribute to the team's poor performance. But under an agreement reached in late last summer, the Whalers are assured of remaining in Hartford for at least 20 years.
Under the arrangement the state has agreed to spend $30 million in bond money and Connecticut Development Authority money to eliminate the team's debt. Further, it agreed to spend $10 million for improvements to the Civic Center, which is regarded as the cornerstone of downtown Hartford. As part of the arrangement, the Whalers no longer pay rent to use the Civic Center, although the team does have to pay operating costs. Since the agreement was reached, the Whalers principal owner, Richard Gordon, sold the club to three Michigan businessmen.
Without the Whalers, the main tenant in the Civic Center Arena is the basketball team the Hartford Hellcats, who are in their second season in the Continental Basketball Association. But the Hellcats, who play 28 home games this season, only average about 4,000 fans a game. And many, if indeed not most, of their spectators consist of families who come solely to see the Hellcats play. "They're not a major draw like the Whalers," Mr. Carbone of Gaetano's Ristorante said.
Far and away the biggest per-game attraction in the arena is the nationally ranked UConn basketball team, which usually plays before capacity crowds. This season, the Huskies, currently ranked 10th by the Associated Press, are scheduled to play 10 home games at the Civic Center. "We do better with UConn games than with the Whalers, particularly bar-wise," said Mr. France of Margaritas. "Business more than doubles."
Not only restaurants, bars and parking garages benefit from Whalers and UConn games.
Barbara Lerner, the owner of the Honore Gallery, a jewelry store inside the Civic Center, said "People will stop in the store on the way to a game or look in the window, see something they like and come back. On a night when UConn is playing, we can be packed before the game starts."
But 10 home games is not a lot, so the Civic Center depends on other attractions. This winter and spring there will be two Boston Celtic basketball games (the Celtics have been playing some of their games at the Civic Center for years), several ice shows, the Harlem Globetrotters, the Ringling Brothers Barnum & Bailey Circus and a World Wrestling Federation Fan Festival, plus Wrestle Mania XI, from March 31 through April 2.
But overall business at the Civic Center Coliseum is a far cry from what it was in the late 1970's and the early 1980's when musical concerts featuring internationally known performers were held there. As of now, not a single concert is scheduled for this winter or next spring.
"This is the leanest fall in years for concerts," said Ron Ewing, the executive director of Ogden Entertainment, a Stamford-based company that manages the Civic Center for the Connecticut Development Authority. "There aren't a lot of groups out there that fill halls any more."
Mr. Ewing and his marketing director, Lynn Carlotto, have come up with a plan that at least fills the Civic Center ice rink, which is usually being used by the Hartford Whalers at this time of the year.
On Saturday and Sunday of Thanksgiving weekend, they opened the rink to the public for ice skating without admission charge. Around 2,500 people turned out.
"It gives us a chance to give something back to the city of Hartford and the surrounding communities," Mr. Ewing said. "And it helps bring people downtown."
The rink was opened to the public again on Friday and yesterday "Tentatively, we plan to do it again in January," Mr. Ewing said.
That is, of course, unless the Hartford Whalers are playing hockey again.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Westchester;
Relocation of Ciba Takes Big Step Forward

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD 

 BODY:
THE relocation of the Ciba-Geigy Corporation to the Tarrytown Corporate Park has moved a significant step forward with the Town of Greenburgh's completion of the park's rezoning. The move would keep the company, which is the American subsidiary of the big Swiss chemical enterprise, in Greenburgh.
Acting at what could be considered warp speed by usual county standards, the town and its planning and zoning boards last month capped a five-month review process by granting a myriad of exemptions and variances from property setback rules and other requirements. 
 The attention and speed given the matter is an indication of how significantly the town views Ciba's continued presence in Greenburgh. Now on its own 60-acre corporate campus near Ardsley, the company considered sites in Connecticut and Putnam County before deciding on the Tarrytown park.
"There was absolutely no controversy about any of the changes at the park," said Supervisor Paul J. Feiner of Greenburgh. "The whole town worked incredibly hard to make this happen because everyone realizes that Ciba is worth keeping. If we didn't show good faith, the company would have gone elsewhere."
The rezoning includes a reconfiguration of the property, adding parking spaces and letting Ciba build a 160,000-square-foot laboratory. "The addition of a new building required a new site plan," said Stephen Lopez, the Town Planning Commissioner.
The town also adopted a new zoning law for the parking lots, where the lines are drawn to accommodate smaller compact cars. "A lot of municipalities already have this," Mr. Lopez said. While it didn't create any additional spaces, he said, "it allows for more green space and will be useful to us in our future planning." An empty parcel was rezoned to provide 200 additional parking spaces for a total of 3,500.
In September, Ciba signed a letter of intent to move to the Tarrytown park after receiving $13.25 million in economic incentives, including tax abatements and lower-cost electricity from the New York State Power Authority.
With the boards' actions, the way is now cleared for Ciba to begin moving its operations and 1,000 employees. The move will take place in stages, said Eric Jackson, the company's spokesman, beginning "in the middle of next year."
The Tarrytown Corporate Park, on Route 119 near Tarrytown, is a four-building park with 1.9 million square feet. "Ciba will be occupying approximately 450,000 square feet," said Jon L. Halpern, chief executive of Halpern Enterprises, which owns the park and has its offices there.
Ciba will lease the building known as 520 White Plains Road in its entirety for its United States corporate headquarters, and plans to buy a second building, 540 White Plains Road, for its additives division. Both buildings, which were vacated by I.B.M. late last year, will be gutted and renovated for Ciba's needs.
The impetus behind Ciba's desire to relocate at this time, Mr. Jackson said, is its need for a modern laboratory building for its additives division. "Our labs in Ardsley were built 30 years ago and designed very generally," he said. "This gives us an opportunity to specialize the space and install more sophisticated equipment."
THE office building at 540 White Plains Road will be linked to the laboratory by a walkway. "The division's offices are now located in Hawthorne, seven and a half miles from the lab," Mr. Jackson said. "This will be the first time in the organization's history that the division's offices and lab will be in the same location. It should be a huge boon for us."
The laboratory will serve as the focal point of Ciba's portion of the park, said John P. Gering, a partner with HLW, an architectural firm in Manhattan that is designing it and the office-building renovations.
"The lab is being designed to tie into the other buildings, but not to look like them." Mr. Gering said. "It will be a four-story structure, but with 16-foot ceilings, it will actually be five to six stories in height. We took extra care to break up the exterior so it didn't look massive. The facade will be pre-cast concrete that's meant to emulate stone, and there'll be a lot of windows."
Construction of the laboratory will begin next year and take two years to complete, Mr. Jackson said. In the meantime, the company will use its lab in Ardsley.
Ciba has already signed a lease for 520 White Plains Road, but the purchase of 540 White Plains Road is still being negotiated, Mr. Halpern said. "With this deal," he said "the park is now 97 percent leased."
As a result of the firming of Ciba's plans, Mr. Halpern said several companies had approached him about constructing an office building on a 16-acre vacant parcel at the center of the park. "Several companies have confidentially gotten in touch with me about building there," he said. "They're looking for space in the 100,000- to 300,000-square-foot range."
As part of the complicated relocation deal with Ciba, Mr. Halpern has agreed to buy the company's Ardsley campus, which has 550,000 square feet of office, warehouse and laboratory space. He is asking the town to designate the property an enterprise development zone, which would allow a mix of uses. "It's now zoned for its own use," Mr. Halpern said "I don't want to be stuck with one permitted use if the market changes."
He already has an agreement from ShopRite to open a supermarket there, he said. "The rest of it might remain a biomedical campus," he added. "I've heard from several firms who are interested in the labs and facilities already there."
HE had originally envisioned a total redevelopment of the site. That was "basically because I didn't have any experience in the biomedical area," he said. "But it seems there's interest, and good-quality lab space is at a premium."
The town has already balked at two of Mr. Halpern's suggestions for the property, including a warehouse retailer and a 10-screen movie theater.
"We don't want to overdevelop that area," Supervisor Feiner said. "It's one of the last big parcels available in the county. We've stated emphatically that we don't want a warehouse and a movie theater would create too much traffic. This is a great opportunity for the town to keep an open space and use it for something we can be proud of. But I expect that the rezoning of the Ardsley site will be a lot tougher fight than we had at Tarrytown."

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
Bonds for the Strong of Stomach

BYLINE: By Richard W. Stevenson 

 BODY:
IT is hardly for widows and orphans. But some traders think that the former Soviet Union's $26 billion worth of commercial bank debt, which is trading on secondary markets for around 32 cents on the dollar, could prove a good bet for those investors with the stomach to hold it for the long term.
The loans, one of several classes of Russian debt that are traded in Europe and the United States, have been a volatile investment for several years, and the coming months could bring more of the same. 
 But if Russia, which has taken responsibility for the Soviet Union's debts, can finalize an agreement with its 600 commercial bank lenders to stretch out repayment, traders said the value of the debt, which is mainly bought and sold by sophisticated institutional investors, could surge.
The value of the bank debt has swung in the last 12 months from a high of around 50 cents on the dollar down to half that, and then back up above 40 cents in early October. That was just before the Russian government announced an outline agreement with the bank consortium, led by Deutsche Bank, for a rescheduling package that included a $500 million interest payment by Russia for past due interest to be made by the end of this year.
But when the ruble crashed in October and the Russian government's economic policy threatened to run off course, the price of the debt began sinking again, a process that was accelerated when President Boris N. Yeltsin named Oleg Davydov as his new chief debt negotiator .
In his previous job as trade minister, Mr. Davydov horrified the debt holders by suggesting earlier this year that Russia should seek to have some or all of its loans forgiven. Such a position is at odds with Moscow's long-held policy that as a superpower nation it will honor all its financial commitments.
The rescheduling negotiations have more or less stalled since then. Mr. Davydov has backtracked on his idea of cancelling some of the debts, but in the markets the damage was already done. The bank loans sank to around 28 cents on the dollar last month before rebounding slightly.
The price of the dollar-denominated loans went to 33 cents on the dollar last week, driven by reports that Deutsche Bank would resume negotiations with a Russian delegation this month.
The price then dropped to around 32, but traders said it had remained firm at those levels on reports that there has been buying from Russia. Traders interpreted the Russian buying to mean that Government insiders think that finalization of the deal is within reach and are taking positions in the expectation that the price will rise.
"At these levels we have tended to find that there are some players who will step in and buy as a long-term play," said Bob McCarthy, the head of Eastern Europe trading at Morgan Grenfell in London. "They feel that eventually there will be a deal."
Few investors are taking anything for granted. The $500 million interest payment agreed to in October now is unlikely to be made by the end of the year. Mr. Davydov, although apparently eager to ease the fears of the world's bankers, has not yet revealed much about his negotiating position or how it might differ from that of his predecessor, Alexander Shokhin, who resigned.
Most bankers expect Mr. Davydov to seek to have repayment stretched out further beyond the 15 years agreed to in October, a strategy that his deputy, Sergei Storchak, confirmed in an interview with Reuters earlier this month.
"The longer we can reschedule it for, the more we consider we have done for our taxpayers," Mr. Storchak said. "Our main tasks this year and next year are to calm down creditors and to service debts so they are not too much of a burden on the budget."
Traders said, however, that they expect Mr. Davydov to move relatively quickly to complete the bank agreement.
"I believe the Russians recognize that they need to get this behind them because they are starving for capital," said Nicholas Jordan, a trader at Chemical Bank in London. "They recognize that there's a limit to how much capital will come into their country until they get some of the foreign debt problems out of the way. I think it will be sooner rather than later, but there are still some substantial issues to be dealt with."
Alexander Kirzhnev, senior vice president at the New Alliance Group, an investment firm in Stamford, Conn., that was founded by a group including former Soviet bankers, said there could be more volatility ahead, especially if the $500 million back interest payment is not made soon. But he said there was little doubt that a deal could move forward quickly.
"I personally feel it's a good bargain at these levels," Mr. Kirzhnev said. "There is a willingness on both sides to do a deal, and it would pave the way for Russia to enter the world bond markets."
But given that every month brings an unexpected and usually unpleasant development in Russia's transformation, it remains unclear whether there are enough bulls on Russian debt to drive the price up.
"At 31, it's clearly undervalued in the long term," said Igor Sitnin, a trader at Bank of America in London. "The problem is that, when you have to report your results every quarter or month, can you really afford to take the two-year view?"

LENGTH: 1431 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary: December 4-9

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
No, Orange County Is Not Exactly an Island
So, is the nation weeping for Orange County, or for itself? Or put it this way: if you don't live there, or somehow invest in the county, do you care that it just declared bankruptcy and defaulted on a bond issue after its treasurer, now departed, lost $1.5 billion betting at the derivatives track? Well, yes, you do -- to a certain extent. For one thing, even if there's no logical impact on financial markets, investors thought there was -- and those jitters became real losses. But there's concrete damage on one front: the $1 trillion municipal bond market had a safe, squeaky-clean image, but that's gotten quite a blow. So even if your county stayed clear of derivatives, it might now find it costlier to borrow -- and that cost may somehow get passed right along to you. The moral: treasurers, being human, may sometimes try to get something for nothing. 

All That and Bentsen, Too
Bill Clinton is heading into the Age of Gingrich with an even cleaner slate than he expected. Not only did he lose the House and Senate, but now he'll have to do without one of his team's true grown-ups: Lloyd Bentsen. Last week Mr. Bentsen resigned as Treasury Secretary, saying he'd planned all along to leave when his Senate term would have ended -- and managing to step deftly out of the way of the Republican stampede. Replacing him will be Robert Rubin, who has headed the National Economic Council. Like Mr. Bentsen, Mr. Rubin will be tough on cutting the deficit -- which might be a problem if, as '96 nears, Mr. Clinton is inclined to share the spoils of a mighty economy.
 
Poverty? It's a State Problem
It's a Republican mantra: Shrink Big Government. And a key element, it now appears, is to abolish numerous programs aimed at the poor and ship the money to the states, few questions asked. In other words, the New Deal has had its day; let's try something else. Now the New Deal clearly needs a hell of a tune-up -- Washington is littered with welfare-reform recipes -- but the latest idea goes far beyond even "the Contract." For one thing, the money could shrink by 20 percent as it made this historic shift. But the broader impact could well be that the programs would no longer be "entitlements" -- when the money runs out, that's it.
 
Mr. Pataki's Latest Math
Bet you thought politicians, after that blowout, had stopped raising money for a while. Wrong. Last week, after taking in $14.5 million to get elected, George Pataki raised more than $1 million at a little get-together at the Sheraton -- for his transition and inauguration. Al D'Amato was there ("at this point in time a cheerleader," he insisted; the ship "has one quarterback"), and so were a fair number of Democrats, their professed distaste for the Governor-to-be having miraculously evaporated. The campaign pledges were intact; but what was Mr. Pataki's formula for reconciling a $4 billion deficit with a promised $1 billion tax cut? Simple. Just "cut $5 billion out of the budget."
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Again, Global Thinking
Morgan Stanley is a powerhouse in American investment banking, just as S.G. Warburg is in Britain. But that, apparently, was not enough: Investment bankers are thinking big, thinking global. So last week Morgan said it might buy Warburg, creating a powerhouse that would be right up there with Goldman, Sachs among the world's leading advisers for mergers and acquisitions -- and could challenge Merrill Lynch in underwriting. Warburg, in spite of its fast growth in the 80's, has never been able to get a very big foot in the door in America, which after all is where a lot of the money is.
 
'Dallas,' With a Spot of Tea
It's that age-old American dream (right up there with winning the lottery) -- striking oil right in your back yard. This time, though, it's a rather exceptional, and very British, back yard: Queen Elizabeth has just given permission to a Canadian-run company called Canuk Exploration to drill near Windsor Castle to see if oil lurks there. So is this just another disillusioning sign that the royal family is, alas, all too human -- first marital spats, then fuzzy fantasies of oil riches? No, studies show that the castle is likely to sit on a huge oil pool -- perhaps worth $1.5 billion. And no, any proceeds would go to the Treasury, not to the family. The royal family will have to subsist on tabloid headlines.
 
Move Aside, Wheelbarrows
In the annals of hyperinflation, the most vivid image has long been of Germans in the 20's with wheelbarrows full of cash that would buy, perhaps, a loaf of bread. Clearly, in the new world order, it's time for a new symbol -- and a good one may just have turned up. Last week Ukraine's central bank released a new 500,000-karbovanets banknote. Smaller bills have been left nearly worthless by inflation -- when this currency was introduced three years ago, the exchange rate was 200 to the dollar, but that's soared to more than 100,000, making those new bills worth about $4. So what's the fate of the 35 tons of old, worthless bills? They're being recycled into toilet paper.
 
COMPANIES
 
A Big Slip of Fidelity's Pencil
There are ordinary mutual funds -- and then there's Fidelity Magellan, which for years had such dazzling returns that it became the nation's largest fund. So it came as an especially nasty jolt to the fund universe last week when Fidelity, after promising a $4.32-a-share payment, said: Sorry, slip of the pencil; make that, uh, zero. And how did it manage to make this $2.4 billion error? Fidelity wasn't talking. But suddenly all eyes were on the once-invincible fund -- and it could be plainly seen that it was not doing well: no capital gains, for the first time since 1988. For investors, a lower tax bill will hardly soothe the pain.
 
Boardwalk? Try Baltic This Year
Discussing Wall Street pay is always a bit like playing Monopoly -- the funny money just comes and goes, not a drop of blood spilled. How can mere mortals, with real-world paychecks, ever comprehend "bonuses" -- once meaning a few twenties in an envelope -- that would buy a mansion or two? Well, the mansions may be fixer-uppers this year. With profits expected to plunge 80 percent from a record '93, salaries -- and bonuses -- will shrink, possibly by 40 percent. So will this set off a frenzy of job-hopping? That's less likely. Many past bonuses have been partly stock -- sometimes forfeited if the employee jumps ship.
 
Trendy Gets More Costly
Ford wants to cash in some chips. Auto sales remain hot, with light trucks the hottest. Last week, the industry reported November sales up 5.4 percent, with all three Detroit auto makers setting records for pickups, mini-vans and sport utility vehicles. And Ford's Explorer, of course, is the sales leader in that last pack. So it seemed only natural when, later in the week, Ford raised the base price steeply on the '95 Explorer -- to $20,870, up $2,740, or 15 percent. Ford is stepping up production of the Explorer, apparently convinced that buyers won't defect at the higher price.
 
Ranger Shortage, Year 2
Children, of course, usually leave adults in the pinstriped dust when it comes to independent thinking. But when the herd instinct is unleashed, watch out! If a toy's hot, kids have to have it -- NOW! -- and woe be to the parent who fails to provide. Which brings us (this year) to . . . Mighty Morphin Power Rangers. First, some facts: 11 new factories are churning them out; shipments are running 10 times last year's levels; Rangers' share of the "action figure" market has soared from 4 percent to 40; the year's sales are nearing $1 billion. But guess what: there are still shortages -- leading, in fact, to a black market that can inflate a $13 Ranger to $50. Whew! Maybe, instead, a nice book under the tree . . . ?
 
Oh, That Silly Computer . . .
Two years ago, news broke that a Long Island car dealer had swindled General Motors out of hundreds of millions of dollars by borrowing on nonexistent vans -- but it was a mystery how he managed such a huge scam. Well, it was easy, he said last week, testifying in a separate bribery trial. People rely on computers, but they are also quick to suspect the machines of messing up, and the dealer, John McNamara, simply capitalized on such skepticism. When G.M. officials questioned the vehicle serial numbers he'd invented, he said, they readily offered to simply override the computer. That, said Mr. McNamara -- no doubt grinning wide -- would do just fine.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
In Britain, a Stiff-Upper-Lip Market

BYLINE: By Richard W. Stevenson 

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
IT was a most unsettling week for investors in Britain.
Prime Minister John Major suffered a humiliating defeat in Parliament on a proposed tax increase, leaving him politically wounded, casting doubt on his Conservative Government's ability to serve out its five-year term and forcing a hasty revamping of his budget for next year. 
 Then the Bank of England pushed its benchmark base interest rate up a half point, to 6.25 percent, a move that had been widely expected, but not so soon.
For all the upheaval, the markets -- particularly the bond market -- responded surprisingly calmly. The bond market, in fact, took heart that despite the Government's weakening grip on power, it did not waver from its policy of fighting inflation and striving to bring down the budget deficit.
Helped by the interest rate increases, prices of government bonds, or gilts, firmed. Moreover, an important benchmark of investor sentiment -- the spread between yields on British and German government bonds -- showed growing confidence in Britain's economic management.
Because Germany's Bundesbank is considered the premier inflation fighter, German bonds tend to carry lower interest rates than their counterparts from other nations. But this week the spread between German and British government bonds narrowed from 150 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to around 130.
On Friday, bond prices surged, pushing the yield on the benchmark 15-year gilt down to 8.42 percent from 8.49 percent.
"One of the surprising things is how well gilts have held up in a rough week of economic news," said David Miles, an economist at Merrill Lynch in London.
Some analysts are bullish on gilts, especially if the shift by investors from stocks into bonds that appears to have taken hold in the United States transfers in earnest to Britain and the rest of Europe.
But Mr. Miles said the market's upbeat reaction may not be a good long-term indicator. He said the market may not fully appreciate the extent of political instability likely to afflict Britain in the next year.
The markets would be particularly concerned about Mr. Major's Conservative Government being replaced by the Labor Party. Labor has traditionally put concern with full employment ahead of fighting inflation on its list of economic priorities, although under its new leader, Tony Blair, it has sought to assure the markets of its willingness to retain a tight monetary policy.
"Our view is that as people perceive more clearly that the Government is effectively a minority government and is going to have difficulty passing any contentious legislation, there will be built into the market a larger political risk premium," Mr. Miles said. "We had been expecting gilts to outperform other markets, but we've now changed our view."
The outlook is already murky for British stocks. Many companies are posting strong results and the economic recovery remains steady. Corporate executives have been heartened by the British Government's determined effort to bring down the budget deficit and stamp out inflation, creating the kind of stable business environment they have long clamored for.
Eddie George, the Governor of the Bank of England, said last week that interest rates should "reach a plateau fairly soon," a remark that analysts took to mean another rate increase early next year, followed by monetary stability.
"This reiterates the point that the earlier- than-expected increases in base rates are all about preventing the need for later dramatic rises as the authorities struggle to keep growth and inflation under control," said a report by Natwest Markets in London. "While we should not see the superficially beneficial effects of the boom, neither will we see the usual dramatic bust."
But far more than the domestic situation, investors have been taking their cues from markets in the United States. With Wall Street unsettled by the bankruptcy of Orange County, Calif., share prices here dipped sharply on Friday after having ridden out the political uncertainty at home with barely a blip earlier in the week.
The Financial Times Stock Exchange index of 100 leading shares fell 36.5 points on Friday to close at 2977.3. The index peaked in February at 3520.3, just before the Federal Reserve began raising interest rates in the United States, sending financial markets tumbling worldwide.
"The U.K. is but a small cog in the global markets, and the key behind the weakness we have seen is in the U.S.," said Robert Buckland, an equity strategist at Natwest Markets. "We can sail through the problems with the U.K. budget, but the Orange County budget has more effect on us."
The London equity market has traditionally rallied in December and January, but analysts said hopes of Christmas cheer this year are dim, especially if investors continue to pour into bonds, as they have shown signs of doing.

HEADLINE: Profile;
He's Back! The Amazing Human Selling Machine!

BYLINE: By PATRICK McGEEHAN; Patrick McGeehan is a freelance business writer in Hoboken, N.J.

 BODY:
STROLL through the housewares department at Bloomingdale's this holiday season and you'll find all the top brands: Kitchenaid, Cuisinart, Popeil.
Popeil? As in Pocket Fisherman? 
 The one and only. Ron Popeil, the glib gadgeteer who mastered the art of direct selling on late-night TV in the 1970's, is back in the big leagues of telemarketing. Now 59, he is again slicing and dicing and filling the airwaves with his spiels for plastic gizmos. But he's also seeking retail redemption.
The founder of Ronco Inc. has slapped his surname, long synonymous with overhyped schlock, on an electric pasta maker that sells for as much as $170 at Bloomingdale's and Macy's. And now that he has prevailed in a patent-infringement suit involving the pasta machine, he's planning to introduce more high-end items that can be sold in department stores.
"I've got enough new product for the future to last another five years," says Mr. Popeil (pronounced poh-PEEL), whose smooth baritone, cool blue eyes and wide, magnetic mouth should be familiar to most people who owned a television set in the 1970's. "I can't wait to bring out my next product. Will it be accepted by the American public? Is it going to be bigger than the pasta machine or the food dehydrator."
Or the Veg-O-Matic. Or the Rhinestone and Studsetter. Or Mr. Microphone. Or GLH, his spray to cover bald spots. Or any of dozens of innovations that Mr. Popeil sold using a simple formula: buy lots of TV time and demonstrate the product until people are convinced they need it.
"I ask myself, What can I give people that they don't already have?" said Mr. Popeil, who insists that he has moved more than $1 billion worth of merchandise in his lifetime. "Who wants to make a toaster? Not me."
Steve Wynn, chairman of Mirage Resorts, which owns the Mirage and Golden Nugget casinos in Las Vegas who added Mr. Popeil to his company's board in its early days, said: "Ron's great at what he does because he believes. He has the ability to make people want things they didn't know they wanted."
Need proof that Mr. Popeil, who owns luxurious homes in Las Vegas and Beverly Hills and places his net worth in the "double-digit millions," has his finger on the purchasing pulse of Middle America? Look no further than the Ronco 5-Tray Food Dehydrator.
This simple, brown contraption has served as Mr. Popeil's ticket back. He has sold more than 1.3 million, through 30-minute infomercials and appearances on QVC Network, the home-shopping channel.
What is it good for? Mr. Popeil has thought of hundreds of uses: Think of the money you'll save by making your own banana chips, soup mix and potpourri. Stop impulsively overpaying for beef jerky and make your own. Or, if you don't eat beef, how about fish jerky or even turkey jerky?
And that's not all. Order now and he'll throw in a Food Glamorizer -- a handy little tool that carves baskets out of gourds -- absolutely free. As Mr. Popeil has exclaimed in ads and infomercials for decades, "Isn't that amazing?"
There's nothing new about the food-drying machine. It was sold more than a decade ago by Ronco Teleproducts Inc., which Mr. Popeil founded and took public in 1969 and is now on its second life. He pocketed more than $5 million in the offering -- enough, he says, "to take care of my family and my family's family for the rest of our lives."
Family, though, is not one of Mr. Popeil's favorite subjects. What he will say sounds bleak. Born in the Bronx, he remembers as a child "baking a potato on a curb because I was hungry." His parents divorced when he was young, and he lived with his paternal grandparents in Chicago, and he felt he missed having a true childhood. "I never had a birthday party," he says.
In his teens, out on his own, he went to work selling his father's inventions in a Walgreen's store in downtown Chicago. His father, Samuel Popeil, was the true innovator in the family. He devised several labor-saving kitchen devices, including the Chop-O-Matic and the Veg-O-Matic, as well as the Pocket Fisherman, a full rod and reel that fold into a small carrying case.
Ron Popeil got his start as a television pitchman hawking his father's products, but the relationship was all business. He doesn't discuss the strangest chapter in the family's history: In 1974, Sam Popeil's second wife, Eloise, was convicted of seeking to have him killed. After she served her sentence, the couple remarried.
FOR a while, father and son ran separate public companies that sold similar merchandise. Ron Popeil's Illinois-based Ronco prospered for over a decade. Traded on the American Stock Exchange, its stock peaked at more than $23 in 1970, making Mr. Popeil worth almost $13 million on paper. But after the recession of 1982-83, sales never really recovered. Cash became tight, and in 1984 the company's creditors, led by the makers of the dehydrator, forced a liquidation of Ronco.
Who would want to buy the detritus of an enterprise built around the telemarketing talents of one man? Why, Mr. Popeil, of course. When Ronco's trademarks and inventory were auctioned off a few years later, he bought them back for about $2 million.
After a hiatus of more than three years, Mr. Popeil decided to make his mark in the burgeoning infomercial business. He had sold millions of dollars' worth of products through 60-second commercials. Imagine what he could do in a half-hour demonstration. He said he spent $33,000 to make the first infomercial for the dehydrator and nearly $60 million over the years to broadcast it on local stations and cable channels across the country -- an investment that resulted in more than $90 million in sales.
He may have come late to the infomercial party, but that hasn't stopped him from laying down rules. "There's only two times in an infomercial when you ask for money," he says. The first comes at the halfway point, after viewers have seen the product in action; the second comes about five minutes later, after a testimonial or two.
Infomercials, hatched in the mid-80's after the Federal Communications Commission relaxed limits on the length of ads, are now studded with celebrities like Cher selling everything from hair colorings to psychic premonitions. But Mr. Popeil allows himself to be upstaged only by his products. "None of the people in my infomercials are given a piece of the action," he said.
He does seed audiences with proud owners from whom he can solicit unscripted testimonials. Like many infomercial producers, he hires people to fill seats at tapings, paying the going rate of $35 plus lunch. As an added bonus, this time around there's another sales medium that seems tailor-made for Ron Popeil: home-shopping channels. He has an exclusive arrangement with QVC, which buys his products in bulk, then puts him on the air to sell them.
If he weren't so good at it, the folks at QVC probably wouldn't put up with him. Backstage in QVC's suburban Philadelphia studio on a late-November morning, Mr. Popeil showed how difficult a self-proclaimed perfectionist can be. After about 10 minutes live in front of the cameras with his dehydrators and his Food Glamorizer, he blamed the producer for cutting him short and not taking the all-important calls from satisfied customers. He had spent three hours the previous night slicing and dicing meat, fruit and vegetables, and he demanded a chance at a payoff.
Before going on again, Mr. Popeil worked over the QVC host, Steve Bryant, pressing for more time to "go to the phones." Lucky for him, Mr. Bryant is a big fan.
"Ron literally invented the business of direct-response TV sales," says Mr. Bryant, who recalls being persuaded to buy a Veg-O-Matic as a young man. "Ron paints in very definable brushstrokes, and every doubt in the customer's mind is wiped away."
Mr. Popeil is in the record books at QVC for selling $1.25 million worth of pasta machines in 12 minutes, Mr. Bryant says -- which works out to about 10 a second. That's why he was disappointed about selling fewer than 23,000 dehydrators ($29.86, plus $6.22 for shipping and handling) before 9 A.M.
THE pasta maker represents a breakthrough for Mr. Popeil. It is the first of his products to be sold in stores that takes a sizable bite of a shopper's paycheck. Most marketers would be pleased to get the broad distribution the Popeil Pasta Maker enjoys. Not Ron Popeil. He describes dealing with retailers as more trouble than it's worth.
Barbara Alonge, a vice president of Macy's in New York, had to persuade Mr. Popeil to supply his product to Macy's, and he agreed to do so only through a middleman, the small-appliance distributor Salton/Maxim Housewares.
"I personally hadn't heard of Ron Popeil," says Leon Dreimann, the Australian-born chief executive of Salton/Maxim, whose first exposure to Mr. Popeil was through an infomercial. "When I saw him making chocolate pasta on TV, that was it. My mouth started watering. I wanted that machine there and then."
On the other hand, when Richard Helfman, president of Creative Technologies in Brooklyn, saw the Popeil machine, he wanted to sue then and there. He soon did, asserting that Mr. Popeil was infringing his company's patents. Unlike some electric pasta makers recently rushed onto the market, Mr. Helfman says, his machines and Mr. Popeil's mix dough and shape it into pasta in the same compartment, allowing users to monitor and change the texture of the noodles while they're making them.
In September, a California judge ruled in Mr. Popeil's favor. Mr. Helfman promises to appeal but doesn't sound too unhappy about Mr. Popeil's televised invasion of what had been a small market. Two years ago, Creative Technologies' pasta-machine sales amounted to less than $7 million; in 1994, he said, they should reach $30 million.
"What Popeil did was really create some consumer awareness so that the category really grew," Mr. Helfman says. "He also hurt the category. He created what I call a herd mentality where lots of manufacturers said, Hey, the pasta machine is hot, and soon we had a dozen-plus brands."
Although Mr. Popeil is not complaining about having one of the hottest kitchen products in department stores this year, the patent episode reinforced his preference for his favorite method of selling: direct to the customer over the small screen.
When QVC put him back on the air at 11 that November morning, Mr. Bryant let him go to the phones. A woman named Pat called in from Lawton, Okla., to profess her love for her Ronco Food Dehydrator.
"Is there one thing you really like to do with it?" Mr. Popeil inquired.
The caller shot back: "Deer jerky."
Ron Popeil grinned like a man who has found his calling.
 
Ronald M. Popeil
 
 Born: May 3, 1935; the Bronx.
 
 Education: Attended University of Illinois for a year.
 
 Family: Divorced; three daughters, age 12, 33 and 36.
 
 Drives: 1992 Lexus 400. He considered a newer model, but it "looks so much the same."
 
 Hobby: Collecting olive oil, "hundreds and hundreds of bottles of it."
 
 Recent reading: The chapter about himself in "Monster Trucks and Hair-in-a-Can" by Bill Geist.
