HEADLINE: The View From Far-Left Field

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"A Fond Farewell to Big Government" (At Work, Nov. 13) is as disturbing as it is intriguing. Barbara Presley Noble argues that the many beneficiaries of the welfare state have finally turned their back on it, potentially denying similar benefits to the needy and disenfranchised today. I do not see any statistical underpinning for this thesis but encourage her to share any such data with her readers.
Some other reminders: 
 * The Great Depression was itself a direct result of government action -- the Smoot Hawley Tariff -- compounded by an inept response by the Federal Reserve.
* The great redistribution of wealth since the Depression wouldn't have been possible without the steady growth of the United States economy during the last 55 years. If the wealth creators hadn't stayed active, there would have been nothing to redistribute.
* The majority of Americans who stayed away from the polls on Nov. 8 have been drugged into apathy and indifference by a system that sees them as dependents and victims who are unable to improve their own lot.
* Those who don't feel that way turned out in force, tired of the inefficiency and arrogance of that same system, and voted to overhaul it.
This is not necessarily a hardening of the heart but a recognition that any system that denies choice and resists accountability will eventually deliver inferior results.
Ms. Presley's last line is borrowed from Churchill, who said "democracy is the worst system there is -- except for all the others." Well, democracy has spoken; we all had best be sure we understand the message.
 
JOHN W. WARD
Mamaroneck, N.Y., Nov. 13
 
The writer is chairman of Transitional International, a management consultancy based in Tarrytown, N.Y.

HEADLINE: THE NEEDIEST CASES;
Charitable Giving Lags In Chill Mood of the 90's

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
Even after he was evicted from his Upper West Side apartment, Glenn A. refused to believe he was a few steps from homelessness. He had lost his job in January, but he could not bring himself to apply for public assistance. The shame, he said, immobilized him.
Later, as he slept in church shelters and asked for food on the street, he met with constant suspicion and contempt. "If you're homeless, the assumption is that you're a drug abuser, an alcoholic, someone who's not motivated to work," said Mr. A., 55. "You get a lot of hostility and not much trust." 
 Mr. A. hopes he will not be homeless for long -- early next year he should start receiving pension payments, and he will be able to live with dignity. But for many other New Yorkers who suddenly find themselves destitute, the humiliation goes on for years. As poverty in this city becomes more painfully visible, charity officials say, public sympathy is turning into resentment.
Organizations supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund say that an era of government budget-tightening and economic insecurity is fostering an "us versus them" mentality that furthers social divisions. They point to the Republican Congressional leaders' "Contract With America," which calls for sweeping welfare cuts.In New York City, they say, crackdowns on subway panhandlers and plans to slash spending for social service agencies send an alarming message: the poor are not to be pitied.
"The current administration has not expressed any interest in doing anything for poor people," said Megan E. McLaughlin, executive director of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, one of the charities supported by Neediest Cases. "It's inconceivable that these people who claim to be so cost-conscious are so unconscious."
The budget cuts and proposals to cut social services come at a time when charitable giving is down. A recent study suggested that the decline, though a national trend, is most pronounced in the Northeast. The study, conducted by Independent Sector, a Washington-based coalition of charities, foundations and corporations, found that people in Northeastern states gave only 1.5 percent of their annual income to charities in 1993. That compares with 2.4 percent in the West and 2.3 percent in the South.
The study found that the drop was primarily due to the recession. Seventy-three percent of those surveyed said they worried about having enough money. In 1992, 67 percent expressed that concern.
"My parents always gave a few hundred dollars to charity at Christmastime," said Kathy Maloney, 46, who works for a Manhattan advertising agency. "I would do the same if I could afford it, but this year I don't think it's going to happen."
Some New Yorkers admit their reluctance to give also has to do with mistrust. Peter Duncan, a 23-year-old film maker, said he was tired of watching beggars count out their change for bottles of liquor.
"I really think most of the people you're seeing on the streets have problems with drugs and alcohol," Mr. Duncan said. "They've made a choice, and I don't need to support their habit, either through taxes or giving them money on the subway."
David R. Jones, president of the Community Service Society of New York, said the category of "undeserving poor" was expanding in many New Yorkers' eyes. In recent years, he said, the category has come to include people on welfare and the children of drug addicts.
"If people can distance themselves even from children, if we believe that there is no common humanity, then we will have all sorts of awful effects," Mr. Jones said.
Mr. Jones also said that government cuts to social service agencies encourage the perception that poor people take advantage of the system. But according to the Community Service Society's 1993 poverty study, only 54.5 percent of New Yorkers who qualify for public assistance actually receive it, down from 61.7 percent in 1992.
Terry J. Rosenberg, who conducted the study, attributes the drop to tightened regulations on government aid and a growing reluctance to ask for help.
"They make it so bad that even if you need to ask for help, you'd rather die," Ms. McLaughlin said. "We generate that shame and we feed on that shame, even when these people desperately need help."
Mr. A. finally overcame his shame at a soup kitchen run by the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services. The organization is supported by UJA-Federation of New York, one of the charities supported by Neediest Cases, which is conducting its 83d appeal. Someone there introduced him to a social worker, Karen Norden, who helped him find temporary housing and apply for public assistance. If Mr. A. had asked for help before he was evicted, Ms. Norden said, he probably would not have become homeless.
"The people who have worked all their lives and aren't used to being poor are very ashamed," Ms. Norden said. "They blame themselves, and they don't want anyone to know."
Ms. McLaughlin said she thought the perceived hostility toward the poor was mostly political spin and did not necessarily represent the public mood. "I am not ready to believe the American people are heartless," she said. "Poor people aren't the only ones who need services. It could be any of us, God forbid."
If New Yorkers are resentful about anything, Ms. McLaughlin said, it is that various programs to help the poor have not made homelessness and hunger disappear.
"I think people are frustrated because these problems seem intractable," she said. "In a sense we're embarrassed about it, because we've made some good-faith efforts to do something about it. Why are we still plagued by these troubles?"

HEADLINE: On Preservation: Another View

 BODY:
Your Nov. 27 article was right on the mark except for Jack Shannahan's usual modesty over his role in preserving Milford's original high school.
I have been involved in its preservation efforts for many years and can firmly state that Jack's efforts saved the building within days of its demolition. 
 Preserving Connecticut's past is not a romantic notion of keeping alive the past, but it is a way of economically using buildings that are irreplaceable either because of their construction or their distinctive architecture. The "square glass boxes" of today cannot compare with the style and practicality of older buildings with solid walls, sturdy construction and air flow systems that allow you to open a window for fresh air and not wait for a computer sensor to monitor air quality.
The renovation work by our nonprofit corporation at River Park Apartments was completed in March 1993 and we have always been fully occupied. Our waiting list is longer than we can accommodate and the building, located downtown along the river, is convenient for local services and it has been restored to its former dignity as a local landmark.
This would not have happened without Jack Shannahan. After reading the article, we should all walk through our cities and towns and ask ourselves how we want to leave them for our children and grandchildren.
ARTHUR W. STOWE
The writer is president of River
Park Apartments in Milford.

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Hardy Perenials In U.S. Farm Policy

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
POLICY buffs who enjoyed this year's impassioned debate over health care will love the battles next year over farm policy. Congress has to agree by next fall on how to replace the expiring 1990 farm rules. For the new Republican majority, it will be a stark test of how deeply it really believes that the Federal Government does more harm than good by interfering with market forces.
 In the end, the battle is bound to illustrate just how tough it will be for Republicans to deliver on their promise to trim the role of Government in the average citizen's life.

 
 
Bewildering Barriers
 Current farm policy looks at first glance to be an easy target for radical reformers. No one is denying it is made up of a hodgepodge of sometimes conflicting programs, many of them dating from the Great Depression of the 1930's, when both farming and rural life in general were vastly different. Most of the billions of dollars spent these days on subsidies goes to big corporations or farmers who are wealthier than the average taxpayer.
 Farm programs are intended to boost incomes for producers of dairy products and crops through a bewildering array of barriers to the free flow of goods and prices. There are import quotas protecting the dairy industry and crops like sugar and peanuts. The Agriculture Department sets price floors for the dairy industry by region. And it enforces marketing programs, developed by the growers themselves, of more than 40 different fruits and crops.
 The Government also provides bargain loans and subsidized insurance. And, in a program subject to unpredictable multi-billion dollar swings in cost to taxpayers, Washington makes direct payments to corn, wheat, rice and cotton growers when market prices for those crops fall below Federally designated targets.
 Critics say those policies contribute to ills ranging from the loss of Indonesian rain forests to the decline of the small American family farm. Farmers for their part have deep misgivings about whether the benefits they get are worth all the restrictions they must also accept on how they farm. A recent survey by the University of Illinois and Purdue University of 10,000 farmers found that 37 percent wanted the entire system scrapped, almost as many as the 41 percent who supported it.
 For all its faults, though, American farm policy has a long track record of winning bipartisan support, and some who have followed it over the years wonder why there is so much griping. Americans spend about 12 percent of their disposable income on food, among the lowest percentage in the world.
 The nation's farmers set new production records this year in corn, soybeans, cotton and rice and, with cooperative weather, clearly have the tools to break those records for these and other crops in years to come. Farm goods make up one of the brightest spots in the trade picture -- American farmers are the world's most productive -- and with exports invariably top imports by a wide margin.
 Moreover, farm incomes have been rising in recent years and farm debt has fallen. To be sure, small farms continue to disappear by the thousands, but the rate is down sharply from 30 years ago. Soil is being more carefully preserved. And the newer pesticides are more benign environmentally and used more carefully.
 "I think the programs are working reasonably well," said Dan Glickman, a Kansas Democrat who lost his seat last month and now is said to be the leading candidate to replace Mike Espy as Agriculture Secretary in January.
 The trend in recent times has been to renew the concept of Federal income support for farmers every fifth year, but each time at a lower level and with new environmental, production and accounting strings attached. Payments have already fallen to less than half the record $25.8 billion in direct assistance farmers received in 1986 as the result of reforms in farm legislation passed in 1985 and 1990.
 This year's bumper crops drove prices down to levels that are expected to send the payments soaring by several billion dollars next year, creating new fodder for critics who see the programs as budget dynamite. But Republicans who will lead the debate for their party are already warning off those inclined to push for sweeping reform. "There's something to be said for stability," said Pat Roberts, the Kansas Republican who will head the House Agriculture Committee. Mr. Roberts' constituents include wheat farmers who have been among the biggest beneficiaries of subsidies.
 The problem for those who would settle for tinkering with the existing structure to save money -- say, by decreasing the percentage of land on which a farmer can get support payments or lowering the price targets at which the subsidies kick in -- is that many farmers may simply drop out. That would make a shambles of related "voluntary" programs like those requiring farmers to accept soil conservation rules in order to remain eligible for subsidies.

 
 
'Close to the Bottom'
 "We are pretty close to the bottom of the barrel on what you can cut and still get voluntary compliance in other areas," said Abner Womack, an agricultural economist at the University of Missouri who has studied various possible packages of farm policy for the Food and Agricultural Policy Institute, a research organization sponsored by six universities.
 With the trend toward a slimmed-down Agriculture Department already under way, most notably in plans announced last week to shut down hundreds of field offices, the department looks more dependent than ever on farmers' willingness to observe both the letter and spirit of regulations.
 Congress may get a shock when it adds up the cost of replacing the most popular pieces of the current policies. If the Government does not subsidize exports, American farmers will be playing on an uneven field in world markets and lose market share to subsidized foreign producers.
 If it does not pay to protect rural environments -- through incentives to farmers or bigger budgets for enforcers -- environmental problems will mount. And if Congress does not want to risk much more volatility in food prices, the Government will have to play a role in supply management.
 Indeed, when it comes to getting the Government out of agriculture, it looks like you cannot get there from here.

HEADLINE: U.S. and 33 Hemisphere Nations Agree to Create Free-Trade Zone

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Dec. 10

 BODY:
Determined to sweep aside trade barriers from Alaska to Argentina, President Clinton and 33 other leaders of Western Hemisphere countries agreed today to create a free-trade zone in the Americas. Talks are to start next month, and the leaders agreed to have a treaty in place and start carrying it out by 2005.
"There will be real progress by the end of the century," vowed Mr. Clinton, the host for the first regional summit meeting in 27 years. 
 "When our work is done, the free trade area of the Americas will stretch from Alaska to Argentina" he said. "In less than a decade, if current trends continue, this hemisphere will be the world's largest market."
Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, said "there was absolutely no dissent" from Latin and Caribbean leaders on creating the free-trade zone. The question mark is the United States.
Mark B. Rosenberg, a Latin America specialist at Florida International University, said: "The real pitfalls are the U.S. Congress and the U.S. public. They are not ready to accept open markets in the hemisphere. This was a carrot to the Latins."
Signaling qualified support for free trade, five Republican Congressmen, led by Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the next Speaker of the House, wrote a letter to Mr. Clinton offering their support for "fast track" negotiating authority on a trade treaty in exchange for withdrawal of environmental and labor conditions from trade bills. Such authority enables the Administration to submit a treaty to Congress for a yes-or-no vote without changes.
Some Latin American leaders have criticized the 2005 date, saying it will allow free trade talks to drag on for a decade. In contrast, the Pacific Basin countries set a date -- 2020 -- for abolishing all regional trade barriers.
The Bolivian President, Gonzalo Sanchez de Lozada, urged the group today to hold summit meetings every two years to follow through on the goals set here.
"It would be a tragic mistake to engage in a prolonged process where struggling nations with fragile democracies must wait 10, 15, maybe 20 years in an economic purgatory," he said. "The cost could be nothing less than the democratic foundations of our countries."
But others note that the plan that is being approved here this weekend sets a concrete timetable for ministerial meetings to negotiate specific moves toward a free-trade hemisphere.
"It's not a matter of waiting," said Ron Brown, the United States Secretary of Commerce. He said the Admnistration had scheduled over the next six months regional meetings of trade ministers, transport ministers and telecommunications ministers.
This follow-up process differentiates the Americas summit from the Pacific summit, said Ambler H. Moss Jr., director of the North-South Center at the University of Miami.
"The Miami process is more credible," he said. "The Pacific meeting set the date without the process. This summit sets the process without the date."
While the gathering here is billed as a trade summit, the leaders are approving measures for cooperation in other areas: reducing corruption, confiscating drug trafficking fortunes, freeing foreign investment and improving education.
To reduce corruption, the leaders are to agree to adopt conflict-of-interest standards for government workers and to adopt "stiff penalties" for illicit enrichment. In a region where a common response to a corruption charge is to flee the country, the regional leaders are to develop an agreement to allow extradition and prosecution of people charged with corruption.
"The corruption and democracy talk is a little patronizing," complained a diplomat from Brazil, which in the last two years has purged its Congress and toppled a President because of corruption charges. "The Americans don't bring up corruption with the Europeans because it might embarrass the Italians and the French. Democracy is a taboo with the Pacific Basin, because it might offend Deng Xiaoping."
On drug trafficking, the leaders agreed to push for legislation to freeze and confiscate the proceeds of money laundering. To follow up on this weekend's promises, a regional meeting of justice ministers on the issue is scheduled for next year.
With each Latin leader eagerly competing for foreign investment, a vote was also expected on forming a hemispheric group that would draw up guidelines to liberalize and integrate capital markets.
"After trade, liberalization of capital markets could be the most important part of the summit," Mr. Moss said. "With business input, the countries are going to prepare an inventory of investment obstacles. The next step would be a hemispheric investment code."
Some financial analysts say they believe that after Latin America's current privatization and stock market booms run their course, the region will have to take new steps to maintain a high level of new foreign investment.
"There are still significant amounts of flight capital outside of Latin America," William R. Rhodes, the vice chairman of Citibank, said in an interview Friday. "To attract that back, plus new foreign investment, there is no doubt that they have to continue to open up their financial markets."
In line with the new free-market language spoken by Latin leaders today, the 28-page "Action Plan" also encourages governments to harness private investment to build highways, electricity and telecommunications projects.
According to the World Bank, Latin America has the world's most uneven distribution of wealth. The richest 20 percent of Brazilians earn 26 times what the poorest 20 percent make. In the United States, the ratio is 9 to 1; in India, 5 to 1.
Recognizing that markets are slow in solving urgent social problems, the plan says "nearly one half of the hemisphere's population still lives in poverty," and it sets ambitious goals for education and health.
Calling for universal access to education, the document sets the year 2010 as the target for all the hemisphere's children to be completing primary school, and for 75 percent to be completing high school.
"If this goal is achieved, it will help eradicate child labor and give children a greater hope of acquiring the skills and knowledge needed in a modern global economy," Hillary Rodham Clinton said here today at a symposium on children.
Turning to health, the heads of government set the year 2000 as the goal for cutting child mortality rates by one third from 1990 levels and maternal mortality by one half from 1990 levels. The leaders also agreed to phase out leaded gasoline from the hemisphere by the end of this decade.
"Here in the United States, for example, we are not doing enough to insure that women receive adequate pre- and post-natal health care, particularly poor women and teen-agers," Mrs. Clinton said. "In 1992, 22 percent of pregnant women in this country received no pre-natal care."

HEADLINE: DEMOCRATS READY TO BATTLE G.O.P. OVER NEW BUDGET

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10

 BODY:
Democrats, both in the White House and on Capitol Hill, are keenly aware that the first great defining battle of the 1996 election cycle may center on the Federal budget, and they are struggling to find a way to turn it to their advantage.
The stakes are apparent to every Democrat, particularly the Congressional leaders who met with White House officials this week in a room at a Capitol they no longer control, near a portrait of the late Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. that struck some as a particularly poignant backdrop. 
 The plea from many Democrats, there and in other somber meetings in recent days, has been simple enough: The party must reclaim the allegiance of the middle class if it has any hope of reversing the Republican electoral victories of last month. The President's budget may be dead on arrival in a Republican-controlled Congress, as many predict, but it will be an important political statement in what one Democratic pollster, Geoffrey Garin, called the start of "a two-year war for the political mainstream."
The White House has been bombarded with advice in recent weeks, much of it contradictory. It has been urged to be bold, with big new cuts in Federal programs, and it has been urged to simply lie back and let the Republicans do the hard work of finding the money to pay for their promises. (Some Democrats describe this as the "give them enough rope and they'll hang themselves" strategy.) It has been urged to stay the course of the 1993 budget agreement and push for even more deficit reduction, and it has been admonished to concentrate on tax relief for middle-income families.
President Clinton will begin to make some choices at a series of meetings in the coming week, but one broad thematic direction is already increasingly clear: Despite its cost, some form of middle-class tax cut is widely expected to be a part of the Administration's budget proposal.
The House Republicans included a $500-a-child tax credit in the "Contract With America," their blueprint for the midterm election. For his part, Mr. Clinton promised a tax cut for the middle class during the 1992 Presidential campaign, and the idea has strong support among Democrats in the House.
"We need to make a clear statement to those workers who have been the most hard-pressed and have fallen the furthest behind in the past 15 years," Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the new House minority leader, said in an interview on Friday.
"People earning between $15,000 and $30,000 split their vote in '94," Mr. Gephardt added. "We got 58 percent of those people in '92. If we had gotten 58 percent of them in '94, we'd have held the House."
Similarly the White House is trying to respond to another message from last month's elections by moving toward deep cuts at an array of Federal agencies. The President's advisers contend that all these moves are simply Clinton being Clinton, not an attempt to "me too" the Republicans.
"What the Republicans succeeded in doing was stealing huge chunks of the Clinton agenda, which is reform," said Paul Begala, a longtime political adviser to the President. "Congressional reform, budget reform, line item veto, welfare reform and a middle-income tax cut. The difference is, Clinton is serious about it, while the Republicans are just posturing."
But Bill McInturff, a prominent Republican pollster and strategist, asserted, "My guess is what the President is doing is readily transparent to the American people."
"When Democrats say, 'Maybe we should cut this Cabinet agency or that one,' " he added, "we should just say over and over again: 'Hey, he had two years to do this. He's just trying to get re-elected.' "
Indeed, many Democrats fear that no matter how artful their positioning, the Republicans will have not only their first legislative control over taxing and spending in 40 years but political control of the coming battle as well.
The Democrats worry that getting into a fiscally dangerous tax-cut bidding war with Republicans, like the one that occurred in 1981, would erode last year's hard-won progress on the budget deficit.
"We could accept everything the Republicans suggested and everything the Democrats suggested, and the only people who lose are the future generations," said Representative Benjamin L. Cardin of Maryland, a Democrat on the House Ways and Means Committee.
Democrats also worry about the possibility of deep cuts in social spending programs, or being blamed for cuts in popular programs while the Republicans get credit for the tax breaks. They are also uncertain about the course of the budget process under the new Republican majority; some are already saying the Republicans will lean more toward accounting gimmicks than genuine spending cuts to make their promises add up.
"Part of our budget strategy will be making sure they make those hard choices, because historically they have not," said Representative Steny H. Hoyer, Democrat of Maryland.
The Democrats are still seething at having received so little credit for what they saw as hard choices on taxes and spending cuts in the 1993 budget agreement. Representative Louise M. Slaughter, a Democratic member of the House Budget Committee from Rochester, N.Y., said, "We did a wonderful job on that budget, and nobody knew."
These anxieties are roiling Democratic lawmakers, who are still, by and large, in a state of shock and grief over the elections and still wary of putting too much of their political fate in the hands of Mr. Clinton. One prominent Democrat, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said, "I think there's a feeling in the caucus that one of the reasons they're in the minority now is because they followed his lead."
There is, in fact, some talk that House Democrats will push forward with a budget of their own. "We're going to do what we see as the right thing for our voters and our constituents," said Mr. Gephardt. "We'd hope that would coincide with what the President is doing. But if it doesn't, we'll do what we need to do."
Still, there is a recognition that like it or not, "whatever the President does will be perceived as the budget of the Democratic Party," as one House Democratic strategist put it.
While much of the planning between Congress and the White House has just begun, some themes are emerging. Congressional Democrats hope to present their party's middle-class tax cut as one that is fairly and truly aimed at benefiting middle-income Americans. Mr. Gephardt and others suggest tying it to income -- rather than to the number of a family's children as in the "Contract With America" -- and imposing a cutoff at around $75,000. (The proposal in the Republicans' "contract" would benefit people with annual incomes of up to $200,000.)
The Administration is also trying to present itself as the guardian of fiscal responsibility, unwilling to give ground on the deficit, a stance that poses the knotty problem of finding a credible way to pay for a tax cut.
Administration officials are well aware of uncertainty in the weeks ahead. "What this really is, is the first move in a chess game," one of them said. "And sometimes after three moves, you can see the whole rest of the game, and sometimes you can't."
Some analysts suggest that no matter how strategic the White House tries to be, the underlying dynamics of this process are simply out of its control. Others say the President cannot afford to cede this ground -- the very economic issues that drove his campaign for the White House -- to the Republicans.
Mr. McInturff, the Republican pollster, outlined one very chilling set of options for Mr. Clinton: "We should try to make sure the President has two choices. One, he could govern from a center-right coalition, and face Jesse Jackson as a potential third-party candidate or virulent primaries. And two, he can veto what we do and lose in '96 because he's been pushed out of the center and to the left."

HEADLINE: China's Hidden Army of Workers Strives to Adapt

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MIANYANG, China

 BODY:
Fearing nuclear attack from either the United States or the Soviet Union, China in the mid-1960's undertook what was perhaps the largest industrial relocation in history to protect its strategic factories.
Now, more than 20 years after World War III failed to occur as Mao Zedong had predicted, some of the country's top scientists and engineers are still trickling down from production lines in remote mountains and caves to gleaming cities like this one in south-central China. 
 They are designing television sets, fax machines, satellite receivers and, perhaps, the battery system for the next electric car. Here, they are setting up new factories and sending delegations to New York seeking investment capital for high-technology ventures, They hope to find a market for the talent and the skills they mortgaged for so long to Mao's apocalyptic vision under a policy that relocated hundreds of important industries in the 1960's and 1970's to remote canyons and caves in northwestern and southwestern China.
"You know, there are many things in common with the manufacture of bombs and in the manufacture of automobiles," said Zhu Senyuan, 48, a computer automation specialist at a military institute now helping 600 factories across China convert armaments lines to commercial production.
But many of the strategic factories are old or redundant and, despite their relocation to cities on the plains, they are far from potential markets at a time when China is trying to reform its economy.
The cost of the top-secret program was staggering. Barry Naughton, an economist at the University of California at San Diego, has estimated that during the peak years China was spending 40 to 50 percent of its national investment resources under the so-called Third Line policy, and that it had sent hundreds of thousands of workers to the mountains where they functioned as "human wave" construction brigades to chisel caverns, tunnel for railroads, transport machinery and build assembly lines in remote and forbidding landscapes.
"It very substantially slowed down China's economic growth and on some levels contributed to the collapse of central planning," said Mr. Naughton, a specialist on China's economy who has conducted one of the few studies on the Third Line and its impact.
Beijing's central planners "got so tangled up in directing resources to these remote sites that they never could complete these projects or make them economically viable," he said during a recent visit to China.
By the time the Third Line was completed, Mao had died and it stood as another monument to his willpower over the Chinese.
"The decision by Mao to build the Third Line was a big mistake," said Hua Di, a rocket scientist who spent months living in Third Line bases testing China's first strategic nuclear missiles and who now lives in California. "We have wasted a lot of money by building this Third Line," which, he added, gave China little additional security.
"If you have a rocket program and a bomb or missile falls on just one of the many component factories, then you have no program," Mr. Hua said. "But the leaders were ignorant of this aspect of modern technology."
In its heyday, planners of the Third Line ordered steel mills, nuclear weapons plants and huge truck assembly lines, first built in coastal provinces or near borders with the Soviet Union, disassembled and transported over treacherous mountain roads or paths to what Mao thought would be an impregnable "rear base," or "third line of defense" to sustain a Chinese war effort. The "first" line was China's coastal defenses and the "second" line was a fall-back position on the central China plain.
To build the Third Line, railways were ripped up in some populous provinces to build new links through unpopulated hinterlands.
The consequences of the program are still radiating into the present because the construction was so large in scale and took so long, 15 years in some cases, leaving China with an uneconomical and inefficient industrial architecture. Today, the plants are still being dismantled, abandoned or turned to other uses.
"There is a major investment in this region," said Chen Zhixiang, deputy director of the Mianyang economic and planning commission, "but the problem is that the investment is spread out through canyons some distance from the city. Our production and research bases are located in the mountains and accessible only over very difficult roads."
Even Mianyang is difficult to reach. It can take four hours to travel the 60 miles of winding two-lane road from Chengdu, the provincial capital.
Somewhere amid the peaks and crags that are visible from these clean streets is China's largest wind tunnel. It is too big to relocate, so aerodynamic engineers from all over the country must come here with their aircraft or rocket models to carry out large-scale tests.
One canyon holds a nuclear reactor for making plutonium for nuclear weapons, another an electron accelerator for high-energy physics experiments and yet another a large radar works. To the east is a rocket body factory and the entire spectrum of electronics industries, many of which have transferred part of their production here.
Today, much of the burden of finding employment for the Third Line work force has fallen on the governments of inland provinces, whose economies are not as strong as those in China's coastal belt. There have been some successes, especially in the electronics industry, but these may not be assured over the long term if China lowers its trade barriers as a member of the World Trade Organization.
"They have moved hundreds of factories down to the nearest cities such as Chongqing and Chengdu," Mr. Naughton said, "and they also gave to these factories the privilege to move into new and lucrative product areas."
But as China's market has developed, Mr. Naughton said, most of these privileged military enterprises are facing competition that in the long run threatens to undermine them.
One example is the Long Rainbow radar factory, which first leaped into the television business two decades ago. Its parent factory is still in the mountains, making aviation radars for the Chinese Air Force.
"It can be said that the radar factory is also engaged in civilian production," said Li Yalian, whose title is chief of propaganda, "because they are making the remote controls for the television sets."
Long Rainbow's 60 to 70 percent market share for domestic television sales has begun to slip as Chinese consumers show a preference for foreign brands. Wang Junmai, the assistant general manager of the Mianyang plant, said top managers had been scouring Tokyo, New York and Los Angeles for investors willing to finance a broader range of products with an updated production line to keep the giant enterprise and its 6,000 employees viable. But so far foreign investors have been reluctant to put their money into a military enterprise.
"We want to expand into cellular phones, audiovisual and telecommunications," Mr. Wang said, imploring a visitor to "please tell the world about our potential and our advantages."
Governor Xiao Yang of Sichuan Province said that while the prospects for the best of the Third Line factories were good, nothing seemed certain about the bulk of the rest.
"The state of the Third Line industries is that one-third of them are doing very well," he said in an interview, "but another third are just breaking even and the last third are in very bad shape."
With two-thirds of these industries at break-even levels or worse, their future very much depends on sustained high growth in China's economy.
Local governments throughout inland China will be saddled with Third Line problems for many years to come, Mr. Xiao said. For the workers, it means adapting without a system that provided job security and social programs regardless of productivity.
"It's really hard," he said. "The workers have been living out of the so-called iron rice bowl for so long."

HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook;
An Epidemic Averted: Foot-in-Mouth Disease

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Dec. 10

 BODY:
After the narrow victory in Congress on the North American Free Trade Agreement last year, the Clinton Administration's trade strategy was clear: drop the "N" in NAFTA and create an American free-trade zone that stretches from the cold tundra of northern Canada to the frigid southern tip of Tierra del Fuego.
Every draft agreement faxed around the hemisphere until a few days ago referred almost absent-mindedly to AFTA. Until the Brazilians spoke up. AFTA might roll off the tongue, they pointed out, but in Portuguese it means an open sore in the mouth, a less-than-auspicious acronym for what could become the world's largest free trade zone. 
 "It is caused by foot-and-mouth disease, I think," said Paulo Tarso Flecha de Lima, the Brazilian Ambassador to the United States. "It would be a shame to make people think of a disease that is nearly eradicated every time they heard about free trade."
In Washington, the negotiators at the United States trade representative's office scrambled. And in the communique to be issued on Sunday, the newest pact to link the hemisphere will be known, less felicitously, as the Free Trade Area of the Americas.
Mickey Kantor, the chief American negotiator, politely stepped around the issue today. The new F.T.A.A. "may not be as clever, but it is quite appropriate," he said.
Such nomenclature is a big deal in foreign policy these days. One can almost see the confusion on the faces of diplomats trying to clear their minds of the buzzwords of the cold war -- MIRVed missiles dismantled by START agreements -- so that they can get accustomed to the new and somewhat less weighty lingo of commercial accords, a subject that used to be relegated to the musty corners of the State Department's economic section.
No more. The White House, fresh from the APEC conference (Asian Pacific Economic Cooperation, but there is fierce disagreement over whether the last word should be "area," "zone" or "caucus"), even published a guide to the subregional trade agreements of Latin America: Mercosur, the Group of Three, Caricom, the Andean Pact, the Central American Common Market and Aladi.
"We're hoping a few will merge," one of Mr. Kantor's aides said the other day.
But just as past Administrations tried to manage the cold war by playing Soviet bloc nations against each other, this one is hoping for a battle among acronomic trade groups.
The idea is to create what Fred Bergsten, a Washington economist with close ties to the White House, calls "a competitive liberalization process." In other words, as Latin Americans lower barriers, the Asians will feel the pressure not to be left behind, and the Europeans will jump in as well. In short, the essence of modern American foreign policy is to create leapfrogging trade pacts.
 
One More Snub for Castro
 If Fidel Castro was miffed to be the only leader in the Western Hemisphere not invited to the Summit of the Americas, the insult was compounded on Friday as the 34-nation meeting opened. One of the few Cubans who did show up, Carlos Santana Ojeda, the anchor of an economics program on a Government-run station, announced that he was taking advantage of the moment to defect.
He told reporters in Florida that he was tired of trying to find ways to portray Cuba's crippling economic problems in a positive light, as his bosses at the station required. Escaping during the summit meeting, he said, was a "once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to get out."
The defection was a welcome distraction for the White House, which was trying to play down the sharp differences in Cuba policy among the nations attending the meeting. Virtually all of the South American countries represented here have trade links with the Castro Government and argue that the United States should end its trade embargo against Cuba.
Canada's Prime Minister, Jean Chretien, described America's snub to Mr. Castro as a missed opportunity. "We believe the more you do trade and business with a country like that, democracy will come faster," Mr. Chretien told reporters.
Mr. Chretien sounded much like Commerce Secretary Ron Brown defending the Administration's policy of "commercial engagement," which keeps questions of human rights out of decisions about trade links. But the Administration saw no contradiction in its policy.
"It would have been thoroughly inconsistent with the idea of the summit to have the one non-democracy in the hemisphere present," said Sandy Berger, the deputy national security adviser.
 
The Old Hand in the Wings
 The last time most Americans heard of Roger C. Altman he was resigning as Deputy Treasury Secretary and seemed headed back to Wall Street, where he was an accomplished investment banker. Mr. Altman, a rising star in the Administration, was forced out after some in Congress accused him of misleading them over the nature of contacts between the Treasury and the White House about Madison Guaranty Savings and Loan, which is at the center of the Whitewater affair.
But Mr. Altman, who if history had swept in a different direction last summer might now be the Treasury Secretary-designate succeeding Lloyd Bentsen, moved only two blocks down Pennsylvania Avenue, to the Old Executive Office Building. From there, very quietly, he has been in charge of the White House effort to organize this vast gathering. It was Mr. Altman who spent last week briefing the President. It is Mr. Altman who can be found just out of camera view at each major announcement, standing on the sidelines, a big loose-leaf binder of trade notes, stamped "Secret," tucked under one arm.
Mr. Altman says that he decided to stay in Washington through the end of the school year to create less disruption for his family. "I'm done," he said the other day, "unless there is another special project."
 
 
Learning the Value of Trade
 There is only so much trade that anyone can stomach in a weekend, so the hosts of the meeting made sure there were distractions.
The biggest party off all, the "Concert of the Americas" was staged tonight by the Kennedy Center. The United States contribution to the music included performances by Liza Minelli, Patti LaBelle and Paul Anka.
Then President Clinton took the leaders to Fishers Island for dinner at a 200-acre estate built by a family that really understood the value of trade -- the Vanderbilts.

HEADLINE: Miami's Cuban-Americans Rally for Solidarity Against Castro

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Dec. 10

 BODY:
Thousands of Cuban-Americans marched through the streets of Little Havana to the Orange Bowl today for a rally against Fidel Castro. But while President Clinton and 33 Latin American leaders were here for a regional summit meeting, Mr. Castro wasn't -- he wasn't invited.
The demonstration, one of the largest staged by Miami's Cubans, was intended to draw the attention of leaders who are sympathetic to Mr. Castro and who favor lifting the United States' economic embargo of Cuba. Organizers said it was the first time that they could address the hemisphere's leaders directly to ask for support. 
 "Cuba should be free and it should be free soon," said Representative Lincoln Diaz-Balart, a Republican from Miami. "What's lacking is solidarity in the hemisphere. There should be a total blockade like there was of Haiti."
Although Cuba was not on the meeting's agenda, President Carlos Saul Menem of Argentina said he would bring it up as the leaders met today. President Clinton sent a letter on Friday to Unidad Cubana, the coalition of groups behind today's protest, to reiterate his desire to see "peaceful, democratic change in Cuba," a White House official said.
Cuban-American groups that take a milder stance toward Cuba also tried to reach the leaders this week, staging a demonstration Thursday in Miami to protest Cuba's exclusion from the meeting and to chant their opposition to the embargo.
Today, eight travel agencies licensed to provide charter flights between the United States and Cuba took out a full-page ad in El Nuevo Herald to criticize the Administration's decision a few months ago to further restrict travel to the island.
"We feel that no government should deny the right for people to visit their families," they said. And referring to the sometimes violent acrimony that exists between the different sides of the Cuba issue, the agency owners wrote, "Unfortunately we cannot march through the streets in Miami, since wanting a peaceful transition in Cuba has earned us the title of Communist sympathizers and we would have to fear for our lives."
But the march today was by far the largest public expression from the Cuban-American community, although it fell short of the more than 100,000 people the organizers said they expected. The emergency operations center in Dade County estimated the crowd at 60,000; the manager of the Orange Bowl, Max Cruz, put the number at 90,000 by the end of the event. Larger demonstrations were held in 1989 and 1991 in support of the embargo.
Despite some angry signs about the continued detention of more than 20,000 Cuban refugees at the Guantanamo Bay Naval Station and in Panama, the mood was festive and the event peaceful.
The march began at noon, led by a group of students who carried a burning torch and Cuban flags. By early afternoon the 80,000-seat stadium was half full with thousands outside waiting to get in.
Rafael Dausa, spokesman for the Cuban Interest Section in Washington, said the numbers "neither intimidate nor worry us because in our country we have 11 million people supporting the revolution." He said most countries at the summit meeting voted in the United Nations to condemn the American embargo last October, and the rest abstained.
"That vote showed that there is total disagreement between Latin American and Caribbean countries and the United States over Cuban policy," he said.

HEADLINE: Acknowledging Mistakes, Con Ed Takes Steps to Mend Its Ways

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

 BODY:
Nine Consolidated Edison workers stood a bit awkwardly around a dented 55-gallon drum with a gash on its side that had spilled a puddle of what looked a lot like maple syrup.
In fact, it was maple syrup, but today it represented PCB's. The barrel had supposedly fallen from a truck in Queens, and the drill was to train the workers in how to handle the environmental challenge, the kind of test that the utility has faced often in the last few years, and which, according to Federal prosecutors and state environmental officials, it has often failed. 
 Con Ed -- New York State's biggest and strongest utility -- is seeking to clean up its image, and more importantly, its record. "Each and every person in our company has got to get religion as concerns the environment," the chairman, Eugene R. McGrath, said in a recent speech to employees. It is a goal that could play a powerful role in its survival.
It would not quite be a jailhouse conversion, but it would be close. The company is scheduled to be sentenced next month after pleading guilty to a felony for the way it handled asbestos in the 1989 steam explosion in Gramercy Park. It also recently settled 319 state environmental charges for actions over several years by agreeing to pay $14 million. Further, the state's Commissioner of Environmental Conservation says the company's pattern of violations is evidence of serious problems from top to bottom.
What lies ahead for the company is more scrutiny and, quite probably, more public criticism of the corporate culture that produced its recent problems, and perhaps the discovery of a few more skeletons. Under its $14 million settlement with the state, Con Edison has agreed to bring in outside auditors to thoroughly investigate its practices and its property, including contaminated sites that state regulators say they did not know existed until Con Ed voluntered the information. The company also has large volumes of hazardous materials at various sites in the city, which it must dispose of.
Con Edison has chosen to try to mend its ways at a moment of great upheaval in the utility industry, when new Federal rules that are meant to encourage competition are threatening nearly every electric utility's monopoly status. The company may be especially vulnerable to competition from lower-cost producers because its electricity prices are among the highest in the country. To continue to prosper, it needs the good will of regulators and elected officials, experts say.
"It doesn't look good to have a pattern of environmental problems occur," said Barry M. Abramson, a utility analyst at Prudential Securities. He said such problems can sway elected officials, who often have wide powers over regulated utilities.
Many of the company's 17,000 employees will undergo drills, like the one with the maple syrup, to familiarize themselves with the rules governing environmental contamination. Employees who are more likely to face accidents will get more extensive training.
The new training guidelines stress that protecting people is of utmost importance, followed by the environment and company equipment. Previously, the environment ranked third behind the equipment.
But the company still has a long way to go in improving its handling of emergencies, according to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration and others.
A study of 24 other major electric utilities earlier this year by the Council on Economic Priorities found that from 1987 to 1992, Con Ed's OSHA record was the worst of the group. That record has made some skeptical of the utility's current safety efforts, and they see the company's problems as more deeply rooted.
"You can write all the policies you want on asbestos and PCB's, but if you don't enforce it with middle management, you might as well not even write it," said Michael D. Ivancich, the safety director of Local 1-2 of the Utility Workers of America, which represents about 12,000 Con Ed employees. For instance, he said the company has adopted a system of paying middle managers bonuses for getting jobs done with fewer resources, and that has encouraged them to cut corners.
Mr. Ivancich is not alone in his suspicions. Richard Brodsky, the chairman of the New York State Assembly's Environment Committee, says he will hold hearings on whether management bonuses went to individuals who supervised operations with environmental violations.
Mr. McGrath, the company's chairman, said that the problems like oil leaking from its pipelines or contaminants being dumped into the sewer system were not a product of the utility's corporate culture, but rather are predictable legacies of operating an old system in a densely populated urban environment.
"We've made some mistakes here," Mr. McGrath acknowledged. Environmental problems will continue, he said, although there are some steps the company can take to reduce the frequency and severity of illegal releases to the environment.
Should the company have taken those steps sooner?
"It's easier when you look back and say, 'You should have known,' " he said. "But it's a reasonable question."
A day later, Mr. McGrath called back to stress that the company is embarrassed by its record.
"It's not the kind of company we want to be, or our public wants us to be," he said. And he said there was, in fact, a problem with the corporate culture, at least at the time that the events in question occurred, ending in 1991; he had taken the question to be about the corporate attitude and practice today, he said.
And more violations are likely to turn up as part of Con Ed's settlement with the Environmental Conservation Department. In addition to agreeing to pay a state penalty of $9 million, and another $5 million into an environmental fund, Con Ed has agreed to a remedial program that is the most extensive his department has ever won, said Langdon Marsh, the commissioner of environmental conservation.
After the company pleaded guilty on Oct. 31 to failing to disclose that a steam pipe explosion in Gramercy Park in 1989 had spread asbestos -- more than 200 pounds, as it later turned out -- it promised to bring in an outside firm to perform an "environmental audit," a process in which teams of experts spend months interviewing employees, examining procedures, and sometimes even sampling the dirt and water.
To assure that the audit is done correctly, Con Edison hired two prominent environmental lawyers, both of whom have successfully sued the company in the past: Ross Sandler, a former transportation commissioner in New York City, and Angus Macbeth, a former environmental prosecutor in the Justice Department. Both were formerly at the Natural Resources Defense Council, where they represented fishermen against the utility.
Those commitments could eventually produce a bigger bill than the $14 million the company agreed to pay to settle the environmental charges.
"Depending on what your findings are, it could run into multimillions," said Jerrold D. Atlas, president of Corporation for Land Environmental Audits and Remediation, an auditing firm in Hastings-on-Hudson. Audits that find superfund sites can cost companies hundreds of millions of dollars, he said.
And the costs go beyond the out-of-pocket cash, which thus far is not a major concern, at least in the financial sense.
"We don't think the incremental cost is going to be important to them, because they're such a large company," said Mr. Abramson of Prudential Securities. The $14 million that Con Ed agreed to pay is two-tenths of one percent of its revenues.
"Where we would worry, from an investor's point of view, is how is this going to affect the attitude of the regulators who are going to be deciding on the company's rate cases?" Mr. Abramson said. "Sometimes these intangibles can affect the way a particular commissioner or two might vote, particularly if that commissioner has a strong interest in environmental matters."
Con Ed's recent problems come after a long period in which it had a blissfully low profile. The utility was the frequent target of derision after the blackouts of 1965 and 1977, and politicians could win elections by running against the company.
Now, the company's customers hardly ever face voltage cuts or blackouts. And while utility stocks are down, Con Ed is well regarded among major utilities. The company's conservation program, "Enlightened Energy," won the applause of environmentalists and the financial community, because the Public Service Commission promised Con Ed a higher rate of return if it could invest enough money to help its customers use less power.
But the recent court battles have left the company on a short leash. The settlement with the state, which runs to hundreds of pages, goes into excruciating detail. For example, the company will pay the costs of up to four environmental monitors from the Department of Environmental Protection. There are numerous deadlines, with daily fines for missing them ranging from $250 to $10,000.
Company executives say they believe they have already changed attitudes and practices, a contention partly endorsed by the Department of Environmental Conservation, where people involved in negotiating the consent decree said that after some initial shock when it received the charges in 1992, Con Edison resolved to do better.
Mr. Marsh, speaking of Con Ed like a longstanding enemy he had recently agreed to make peace with, said: "These are serious violations, but they didn't destroy the environment of New York City. There are things that have to be done right, should be done right, weren't being done right."
The company has proven that it can do many things right. On Oct. 26, its Indian Point 2 reactor in Buchanan, N.Y., broke the world record for longest continuous operation of a light-water reactor, the kind used in the United States and most of the rest of the world. The absence of unplanned shutdowns is an indication of safe performance, according to Federal regulators. The plant, which started its current run on May 10, 1993, is scheduled to run until Feb. 4, 1995.
Perhaps harder than running a nuclear plant well, Con Ed now wants to make itself loved. That is especially difficult in a densely populated service territory, which Mr. McGrath called "a fishbowl."
Perhaps thinking of the Con Ed employee in the drills who plays the role of pushy pedestrian, the chairman said that the utility would have to do its job well because "we do our work right here in full view."

GRAPHIC: Chronology: "CHRONOLOGY: Troubles at Con Edison"
 
Gramercy Park Explosion
On Aug. 19, 1989, A steam pipe exploded on East 20th Street, near Gramercy Park, killing three people and injuring 20. Con Edison reported four days later that the accident spread asbestos, and then evacuated the site and equipped its workers with anti-contamination clothing.
In December, 1993, a Federal grand jury indicted the company and one of its executives for conspiracy for failing to promptly report the asbestos. The company maintained its innocence until Oct. 31, when, with the trial under way, it pleads guilty. It has already paid $90 million to settle civil lawsuits.
Current status: a probation officer is preparing a report; sentencing is scheduled for next month.
 
Environmental Violations
On June 9, 1992, the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation charged the company with 319 violations, dating from 1984 to 1991, and sought $20 million in penalties. On Nov. 15, 1994, in the largest settlement ever with the state agency, the company agreed to pay $9 million in penalties, and spend another $5 million on environmental restoration and education. Also, the company agreed to an outside audit and said it would hire two prominent environmental attorneys, both of whom have successfully sued Con Ed in the past, to oversee the work.
Current status: Auditor has not yet been hired.
 
East Side Steam Pipe Blast
On Nov. 10, 1992, a 40-year-old steam pipe at the Waterside generating station, at 1st Avenue and 40th Street, ruptured, killing a echanic who was scalded to death. Five firefighters were injured, one critically. In May, 1993, the Occupational Safety and Health administration concluded that one cause was failure to drain the pipes, the same reason for the Gramercy Park explosion, and proposed to fine Con Ed $247,000. Con Ed contested the fine.
Current status: The case is before an administrative law judge. If Con Ed loses, the United States Attorney could decide to investigate whether any of the violations were wilful, which would make them criminal. (pg. 62)

HEADLINE: Human Rights Organization Urges Stronger Action by the U.N.

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

 BODY:
A leading human rights organization is calling on the United Nations to reconsider its policy of neutrality and to act more forcefully against those who carry out atrocities in the new rash of small conflicts around the world.
"Faced with genocide and mass slaughter, neutrality should not be the ultimate value," the group, Human Rights Watch, said in a report published on Friday. It calls the United Nations "unique in its capacity to legitimize force in the most extreme circumstance to uphold human rights." 
 The international survey, "Human Rights Watch World Report 1995," also accuses major industrial nations of following policies that subjugate, and sometimes obliterate, human rights concerns in the name of trade. It takes issue with the argument that economic growth leads to improvements in civil and human rights and the spread of democracy.
"Indeed, even if economic development could be correlated in the long term with improved respect for human rights -- an unproved proposition -- that would offer little solace to those who are imprisoned or tortured today," the report said.
Human Rights Watch, which this year expanded its organization to new bases in Europe and Central Asia, and also opened an office to scrutinize the United Nations, is sharp in its criticism of the Clinton Administration, specifically Commerce Secretary Ron Brown.
Under Mr. Brown, the report said, American delegations have been "hawking trade and investment deals while relegating human rights to the ineffectual realm of private diplomacy."
"The Administration's position on India exemplified the shift," Human Rights Watch said. "Its refreshing but short-lived public criticism of Indian abuses in Kashmir was replaced by the eager promotion of an 'emerging market' where public discussion of human rights was taboo."
In Indonesia last month to attend a summit meeting of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, Mr. Brown played down questions of Indonesian human rights abuses and what American labor leaders have called unfair practices in the workplace.
The Clinton Administration has also backed away from early promises to be tough on China, at one point publicly undercutting its Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights during talks about renewing a favored trade status for Beijing.
Human Rights Watch said in its report that Washington is not alone in adopting "commercial diplomacy" as a policy.
"Germany, France, Canada and Australia all vied for Chinese commercial contracts, with waning interest in Chinese repression," the report says. "France, driven by geopolitical designs and commercial motives, led the charge to embrace Iraq's genocidal regime. The European Union, having concluded a cooperation agreement with India in 1993 conditioned on respect for human rights, lapsed into silence on the atrocities in Kashmir in 1994."
In addition to focusing on international trends that it believes to be of concern at a time when many countries are poised between uncertain democracy and ethnic conflict or renewed totalitarianism, the report surveys the situations in individual countries, grouped regionally. It also looks at special projects ranging from arms control or prison conditions to women's rights and children's rights.
"Human Rights Watch World Report 1995" is available from the publication department of Human Rights Watch, 485 Fifth Avenue, New York, N.Y., 10017. The price is $25, which includes postage.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Ranchers Balk at U.S. Plans To Return Wolf to the West

SERIES: Who Owns the West? -- Third article of a periodic series.

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK, Wyo.

 BODY:
After more than a century of policy flip-flops that saw the gray wolf go from the most loathsome animal in America to the celebrated subject of perhaps the most extensive environmental impact statement ever done, the mythic predator is a single court hearing away from a formal return to the West.
That it has taken two decades, 120 public hearings, directives from six Presidents, dozens of Congressional committees and $12 million worth of studies to get to a point where wolves could soon run through Yellowstone National Park tells much about the heavy load of significance that has been saddled on the wolf. 
 What Federal biologists hope to do in early January is to return a predator with a lust for fresh meat back to a part of the country that is overrun with moose, elk and deer -- staples of a wolf's diet.
But even as Yellowstone park rangers put the final touches on one-acre pens to be used to acclimate the wolves to the park's Lamar Valley, cattle and sheep ranchers are balking at the turnabout in attitudes and policy. The ranchers, the biggest beneficiaries of the campaign 70 years ago to eliminate the wolves from the West, have filed a lawsuit that threatens to hold up the project. On Dec. 21, a Federal judge in Wyoming will decide whether to issue a preliminary injunction.
For those most passionate about bringing the wolf back, the project is viewed as a grand restorative deed, balancing a zealous act of one era with a corrective act of another. It is absurd, they argue, that wolves still roam free not far from the urban masses of Rome, but are not yet allowed inside North America's largest temperate zone ecosystem, the greater Yellowstone area.
Without wolves, the world's first national park "is a heart without a heartbeat," in the words of Renee Askins, founder of the Wolf Fund, a Wyoming group devoted to returning the animal to this area.
Under the plan, 30 wolves in Canada, tagged with radio collars so biologists can track them, are to be released into Yellowstone and into the wilderness of central Idaho, 15 to each area. Eventually, over five years, the plan is to establish a population of about 150 wolves in each area.
But one person's call of the wild is a rancher's nuisance with a 1,500-pound-per-square-inch bite. The ranchers see an America where less than 2 percent of the population works the land and where beef prices continue to fall with declining demand.
"When wolves were a fact of the area, most people made their livelihood from the land," said Bill Wheeler, a third-generation rancher in western Montana. "Now, only 1 1/2 percent of the population is involved in agriculture, and the other 98-plus percent have been indoctrinated by a Disney mentality about the wolf."
Studies in Minnesota, where nearly 1,700 wolves live among dairy farms, and in northwest Montana, where a few wolves have trickled down from Canada, show that very few domestic animals are killed by wolves. The rate in Minnesota is less than one loss per 10,000 cows. And in Montana, dogs kill far more sheep than does any wild predator.
Federal biologists say fewer than 20 cattle and 110 sheep a year would be lost to wolves near Yellowstone.
But if livestock loss is not the real issue, what exactly has made wolf restoration such a complicated, divisive and expensive effort?
Ranchers say keeping the wolf out of the West is a symbolic stand for control. Wolves, like bison, were eliminated from the West to make way for cows and sheep. Some farmers think they are being pushed aside now to allow a bit of the wild back into the equation. With restoration, they fear, will come a host of regulations.
"Until very recently, the score stood at cows, 99,200,000; wolves, 0," Rick Bass wrote in his book, "The Ninemile Wolves" (Clark City Press, 1992).
Now, even in their own communities, ranchers seem to be losing the spin battle. Once viewed overwhelmingly as the embodiment of lechery and predation, the wolf has become such a cuddly favorite that agriculture groups have tried to force school boards in the West to present them in a less sympathetic light.
A few years ago schoolchildren in Bighorn, Wyo., a tiny ranching town on the front range of the Rocky Mountains, were asked to conduct a mock civic debate on the wolf. To the surprise of their parents, none of the middle-school children wanted to take the side against wolves, teachers said.
A 1991 poll by the fish and game department in Wyoming, perhaps the most conservative state in the West, found that a majority of those surveyed favored a return of the wolf. And surveys in Yellowstone Park have shown that visitors favor a return of the wolf by 6 to 1.
This change is all the more remarkable considering what the Federal Government did over a 50-year period to demonize and eliminate the wolf. From the 1870's to the mid-1920's, up to $1 million a year was paid in bounties for dead wolves. The animals were tortured, burned and poisoned by the thousands, all the while portrayed as child-eating sneaks. By the 1930's, nary a single wolf could be found in all the West.
Now, most Federal biologists say eliminating the wolf was a grievous error, upsetting the balance of nature in one of the few places in America that was balanced. Without the wolf, Yellowstone, with nearly 60,000 elk and 4,000 bison crowding its boundaries, finds itself in desperate need of predators, park biologists say. Wolves would thin the ranks of these animals, which are now near their all-time high for this century, by 5 percent to 20 percent over time, they estimate.
What is more, bringing wolves back to Yellowstone would generate an additional $19 million a year in new tourism dollars, according to a Federal study.
For all the animal kingdom what-ifs and economic numbers, wolf restoration remains an issue that always veers into values and culture. Returning the wolf to the West "is a symbolic act, just as exterminating wolves from the West was a symbolic act," said Ms. Askins of the Wolf Fund.
She laments that the wolf issue has become so wrapped up in the West's political fights over land use. Both sides see it as a place to draw the line.
"Wolves aren't going to cause the decline of Western civilization any more than they are going to restore blissful symmetry to the cosmos," she said. "They will cause some fascinating changes, and once in a while they may cause some trouble."
Ms. Askins, a Yale-educated biologist who lives in Moose, Wyo., inside Grand Teton National Park, has devoted the last 13 years of her life to wolf reintroduction. "I started out with the idea that facts could change minds, and I ended up with the idea that this is a fundamentally emotional issue," she said.
By the first of next year, she expects to do something rare in the age of big-budget environmental lobbying: close the doors of her organization and declare victory, her mission accomplished. "I can't wait to be out of a job," she said.
If Judge William Downes of Federal District Court in Wyoming does not grant the preliminary injunction sought by ranchers, the program to bring back the wolves would go ahead as approved by Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt in May.
But if it is temporarily halted in court, the program could miss its window of opportunity in winter, considered the best time to bring a predator into Yellowstone. After that, critics in Congress could further cripple the program by denying funds to the reintroduction team, as was done in earlier years of political skirmishing.
Many ranchers are not convinced by a provision of the restoration plan that would allow them to kill wolves if they catch them chewing up a farm animal. Nor are they swayed by a $100,000 fund set up by environmentalists to pay ranchers for any loss of livestock. Since 1987, when a few wolves started to wander into northwest Montana, Defenders of Wildlife, an environmental group, has paid $17,000 in compensation to 20 ranchers.
"They're not obligated to pay us," said Jim Magagna, who runs 5,000 head of sheep in Wyoming. "Once the wolves are in there, they could run out of money. Then what?"
In trying to block the wolf's return, various interest groups in the West say they are waging a long-term fight.
The real issue is land use, said Steve Lechner, a lawyer with the Mountain States Legal Foundation of Denver, which filed the suit against the wolf plan.
"Once you get wolves in there and let them run loose, pretty soon the whole Rocky Mountain area will be locked up," he said. Because the wolf is listed as endangered in the West, it has protection under the most powerful environmental law on the books -- the Endangered Species Act.
But under an amendment to the law passed in President Ronald Reagan's first term in 1982, ranchers will be able to kill or harass the wolves if they threaten livestock.
Supporters of bringing the wolf back had hoped to showcase the animal's return around the holidays as a telegenic example of how the Endangered Species Act can work. Now, they are worried about another long legal fight that most Americans would find arcane.
If the wolf is doing well in Minnesota -- the only state in the lower 48 where it is not listed as endangered -- then there is no reason to expend Federal help to bring it back in the West, critics argue. But the act itself, facing what is likely to be a tough fight for renewal next year in Congress, requires the Government to preserve and restore any species threatened with extinction in "all or a significant portion of its range."
Wolves used to live almost everywhere in North America. Bringing wolves back to Manhattan is unlikely (outside of Hollywood's effort this year, in which Jack Nicholson played an editor who takes on wolf-like sensibilities after he is bitten by one).
There is no better place for a fast-moving, meat-eating predator with a keen sense of family values and superb hunting skills than in Yellowstone National Park, the wolf's friends say. "The wolves that are dropped in there are going to think they died and went to heaven," said Hank Fischer, the Montana representative of Defenders of Wildlife.
With the wolf in place, Yellowstone would be the only area in the contiguous United States inhabited by every mammal it had at the time whites first came to the continent -- "a pretty remarkable superlative," said Wayne Brewster, a park biologist on the Federal wolf-recovery team.
Sensing the inevitable, some ranchers have started to adjust their views. They still think bringing wolves back is a wrong-headed idea. But in the West, as elsewhere, money wins a lot of arguments. While cows become less valuable in a era of cheap beef, wolves howling in a forest grove at night might just raise property values, some ranchers say.
"The history of the wolf has not been good," said Mr. Wheeler, the lifelong Montana rancher. "But I can now see one possible advantage to all this -- a parade of land buyers who would get their kicks out of watching wolves."

HEADLINE: The Keys Fight to Put New Life in Florida Bay

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ISLAMORADA, Fla.

 BODY:
He has no fancy scientific titles, but Jimmy Lozar has been fishing off the Florida Keys for years and says he knows dead water when he sees it.
"If I come up on a flat and I see sharks and rays and bait fish hopping up, you know it's alive," said Mr. Lozar, a guide to the shallow fishing waters known as the flats. "When you see nothing, you know something drastic has happened." 
 What has been choking off life in the waters south of the Everglades is algae. The pea-green algae sometimes cover as much as 40 percent of Florida Bay, or 400 square miles. The algae mean that there is little food or shelter left for fish.
The problem, conservationists say, is a system of canals built by the Army Corps of Engineers on the mainland after World War II. The canals channeled fresh water, which normally flowed through the Everglades and into Florida Bay, out into the Atlantic Ocean.
While the canals helped turn swampland into valuable farmland, Government scientists and conservationists say, they also set off a chain reaction that started with the bay becoming briny and ended with the algae incursion. In the process, the changes killed vast patches of sea grass and sponges that serve as breeding grounds for fish, shrimp and spiny lobster.
The algae problem worsened two years ago when a drought increased the salt content of the bay and further threw off it biological balance. Alarmed by what they saw, guides, commercial fishermen, scuba divers, hotel owners and business and government officials in the Keys started fighting to save Florida Bay and the tourism that is the backbone of the economy of the Keys.
Today, the top political issue on the island chain is the fight to bring more fresh water to the bay -- in the way it flowed before World War II. Restoring the natural flow would mean flooding thousands of acres of farmland that are kept dry by the canals, said Paul Dye, director of marine conservation for the Key West office of the Nature Conservancy, a private environmental group. "About 15,000 acres of land on the eastern edge of the Everglades has to be bought to fix the problem," he said.
In November, business officials and fishermen from the Keys and conservationists scored a victory when Florida officials cleared the way for the state's water managers to condemn and buy 1,800 acres of tomato fields to allow fresh water to trickle overland from Lake Okeechobee through the Everglades to the Bay.
State officials expect to pay an average of $2,600 an acre for the land, or about $4.6 million for the 1,800 acres. They will use money set aside for just that purpose.
Farmers and their supporters protested the move, warning that the loss of farmland would mean the loss of jobs as well as tomatoes. Conservationists and fishermen, citing the possible loss of jobs linked to the fishing industry and to water-related tourism, countered that the state and Federal Governments should buy even more land.
