HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Players Present Plan To the Team Owners

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: RYE BROOK, N.Y., Dec. 10

 BODY:
In an effort to begin the end of their four-month-old strike, major league baseball players presented a new proposal to the owners today, calling for a tax of about 5 percent on club payrolls, a contribution of at least $30 million of their money to an industry growth fund and input in crucial matters like television and expansion.
The owners did not reject the proposal immediately, but they left little doubt that they would reject it. 
 Whereas the salary cap and tax plans the owners have on the table are heavy on payroll punishment to drive down salaries, the players' proposal emphasizes partnership to eliminate labor confrontations and create a cooperative relationship and new revenues.
The owners' ideas would have a more immediate effect in achieving their goal -- lower salaries. The players' three-part plan would have a long-range effect by finding ways to generate greater revenues to help pay for player salaries and increase the clubs' profits.
"It is not hyperbole to call the plan revolutionary," said Lauren Rich, a union lawyer and one of the architects of the proposal. "For the first time, players are prepared to put their money where their mouth is."
The players, Rich said, went through "a lot of soul searching" in approving the proposal at their meeting in Atlanta earlier this week.
"There are aspects of this that can be negotiated," she added, "but the central core of the proposal represents the players' unwavering commitment not to give up what other generations of players have achieved for them. They will not give up their basic principles, like free agency and a free market, that other generations made sacrifices to get."
But the players, Cecil Fielder said, also want to "end all this negativity" and "not be in a situation where we scar the game so badly that we would all be in trouble."
After the owners' negotiating committee received the proposal at the Arrowwood resort and conference center in this Westchester County town, it asked union officials to agree to a joint embargo on the release of the proposal's details until noon today.
The members of the clubs' committee, one person who was in the room said, thought that disclosure of the details would prompt owners who weren't present to call committee members and ask questions about the proposal, and they didn't want that happening.
Bill Usery Jr., the mediator, said he, too, had preferred that the union not make the proposal public, but Donald Fehr, the union leader, said his membership had been clamoring to see it.
John Harrington of the Boston Red Sox, the owners' chief labor spokesman, said management was encouraged by the players' concerns "about our mutual self-interest in growing the game," but he said the clubs would evaluate the proposal on three criteria:
"Does the plan address cost certainty? Does it result in the reduction of player costs from 58 percent to 50 percent of revenue? Does it deal with payroll disparity and encourage competitive balance?"
The owners are expected to answer at least the first two questions, and possibly all three, negatively and reject the proposal. They will most likely view the 5 percent tax rate as relatively puny compared with the limitless rate called for in the proposal the owners made Nov. 17. The players proposed a 1.5 percent tax in September.
If the owners' tax had been in effect this year and the season had been played in its entirety, the Detroit Tigers would have paid nearly $44 million in taxes. At the players' rate, the Tigers' tax would been less than $3 million.
The players' proposal, however, would create the same $58 million the owners want to generate for low-revenue clubs under the revenue-sharing plan they adopted last January. But the owners would phase in their plan, reaching 100 percent in the fourth year, while the players would have the full amount in effect immediately but would end the sharing after three years.
The players would generate $35 million with the payroll tax (which they said could cost the players a total of $100 million over all) and the remainder with a gate-sharing plan (25 percent for the visiting team, 75 percent for the home team) and the existing pay cable pool the clubs share.
Using the clubs' 1994 economic projections, the San Diego Padres would have received the most money under the players' proposal, $10,213,000, and the Toronto Blue Jays would have contributed the most, $8,563,000.
The industry growth fund calls for each side to contribute half of a fund of at least $60 million. The players would take $30 million from their licensing program or other union sources; the money would not come from players' salaries. The clubs' share would come from fees they would get from expansion, which, the players proposed, would occur by 1998 with the addition of at least two teams.
The two sides would jointly pursue the creation of new revenue by promotional and community service activities; licensing, advertising and marketing projects; international development, including player tours, licensing, media relations and support for international baseball federations; improvement and replacement of stadiums with particular attention to guidelines for cities and communities for retention of major league teams, and development of new and emerging media technology.
A committee made up of four players, four owners and staff members from both sides would administer the fund.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Players Weren't the Only Ones Holding Paper Bags

BYLINE: By GEORGE VECSEY 

 BODY:
BACK when there used to be baseball -- before greed shut it down -- most teams stayed at the Hyatt on 42d Street. Actually, the hotel is called the Grand Hyatt -- Grand as in grandiosity, as befitting its remodeler, an 80's kind of guy named Trump.
Back when there used to be baseball, a certain type of entrepreneur used to congregate outside the Grand Hyatt, carrying a briefcase or a cigar box or an album with vinyl pockets. 
 I remember one day leaving the Grand Hyatt with a friend of mine who is a star pitcher. We were on our way to Little Italy for some pasta and escarole. A man was standing on the sidewalk, holding a stack of baseball cards.
"Would you sign these, please, sir?" the man asked, with Dickensian servility.
My friend signed one while he walked down the sidewalk. I happened to glance at the man's stash. Another unsigned card of my friend was now on top.
"Didn't I see you here last night?" my friend asked. I know him well enough to recognize his ripe sarcastic tone.
"Yes, sir," Uriah Heep replied. He couldn't afford to be offended. My friend was coming back after lunch. He might sign another card.

 Some ballplayers don't sign at all on the street. I can't say I blame them. Most ballplayers have no qualms about signing at autograph shows where they are being paid. It's a business deal, usually a cash business.
A Federal grand jury indicted Darryl Strawberry and his agent Thursday on charges of not paying taxes on over $500,000 from baseball card shows. I have no evidence Darryl did what they say, but I would guess Darryl's an easy target. He's so noticeable -- he's no hero to establishment America -- and, by his own testimony, he was out of control on drugs and alcohol while playing for the New York Mets, that most 80's kind of team.
Is that the ultimate legacy of the Mets? They won exactly one pennant and one World Series and now that the 80's are long gone, their names surface in cash-only rumors. I'm waiting to see if the Feds are as eager to go after some major icons as they are in going after Darryl.
Sports collectibles are big business. I'm not sure why. I'd love to be able to afford a work by William Dole or Richard Diebenkorn or Joseph Cornell -- to gaze at, every day. But a Mickey Mantle rookie card in a safety deposit box? What's the point? Then again, just the mention of Rotisserie leagues induces a huge aching void deep in my soul. When did money and sports become fused?
We used to ask for autographs at the old Garden and Ebbets Field when I was a kid. It meant we could stand next to Frank McGuire or Jackie Robinson for a few seconds. We'd bring home the autographs and put them in a raggedy album and when we grew up, our mothers would throw them out. It was a rite of passage. Now 11-year-old weasels hoard Doc Gooden rookie cards. And grown men with stubble on their chins, their bellies hanging out of their T-shirts, stand around outside hotels.
"Paper bags full of money," said another friend of mine, who had insight into the collectibles business back in the Gordon Gekko 80's. "Somebody rents a hall to run a card show, probably pays by check. The dealers pay cash to put up a table at the card show. They probably pay cash. The public pays cash to enter. The public pays cash for autographs from stars. And the players take their money in cash."
My friend told about a former player who took his paper sack of money to a mall and tried to get the twenties converted into hundreds. The store manager called security, and it got pretty sticky until somebody recognized the player as a Hall of Famer.
"Another famous player wouldn't take cash," my friend added. "But he would double-bill his plane tickets -- his endorsement and the card-show proprietor. One guy was different. Stan Musial had a reputation for always wanting a check. Stan the Man. He wanted everything done right."

 The market was hot in the 80's. Milken and Boesky were selling whatever they sold. Pete Rose was blustering in from Japan with an attache case full of American dollars and expecting to swagger past customs.
"It just exploded," my collectibles maven told me. "Serious money was being made. It was like buying land in Southern California. With the rare exception, you'd never see officials coming to card shows to make sure about receipts and taxes. Baseball card shows sounded cute, like a flea market. Meanwhile, the prices were going out of sight.
"I'd say, 'Hey, we're only as strong as the economy,' " my friend added. "You used to have just the Topps series. Then you had Fleer and Donruss. You could handle three sets. Then there were 40 sets, still most of them baseball. Companies were putting out cards for players in AA ball, hoping the players would make the majors and their cards would rise in value. Everybody got greedy."
The stock market crashed in 1987. Pete Rose went to prison. Now the Feds are scanning old weekly newspapers and penny-savers and hobby periodicals. The ballplayers' names and faces are very big in the advertisements. I just hope the Feds find it in their hearts to question the Hall of Famers. And the dealers. And the guys standing outside the hotels and the ball parks, with stacks of cards in their hands. It all goes around.

LENGTH: 1355 words

HEADLINE: BASEBALL NOTEBOOK;
Next: Action by Roman Numerals

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Short of an unexpected reversal in their thinking and strategic planning, and the players' new proposal notwithstanding, the owners will meet Thursday in Chicago and invoke Impasse/Implementation I. And the reason this week's action will require a Roman numeral is because it will trigger Impasse/Implementation II.
The sequence will be as follows: Once the owners declare an impasse and implement their Nov. 17 salary cap proposal, negotiation will turn to litigation, the players will continue their strike and the owners will intensify their plans to open spring camps and play the season with replacement players. 
 But the replacement players themselves will have to be a subject for negotiation with the union, and the only way for them to be eligible to play in the major leagues, other than agreement with the union, will be for the clubs to declare an impasse in those negotiations and implement a new type of major league roster by expanding the existing roster or creating a new one. That's II.
Actually, there is another way. The clubs could open spots on their existing 40-man major league rosters by releasing players in wholesale numbers, but somehow it doesn't seem very likely that the Chicago White Sox would release Frank Thomas or the Seattle Mariners Ken Griffey Jr. or the San Francisco Giants Barry Bonds.
"Roster size is subject to collective bargaining," Chuck O'Connor, management's chief labor lawyer, acknowledged. "We'd have to bargain to impasse with the union on it. You can't act unilaterally to bring temps in."
Roster size is covered in Article XV of the collective bargaining agreement and in Major League Rule 2. The clubs can't change the size in their initial implementation because they haven't included it in any of their proposals and they haven't negotiated it to this point.
But the clubs, if they want to use replacement players, would have to do something about the roster because players in the major leagues have to be on major league rosters.
"I don't think you'd see wholesale stripping of regulars," O'Connor said. "I suspect they'd have to expand the rosters. It's not unusual when you have temporary replacement workers that you have interim rules, including wage scales and seniority rules, because they are temps."
Gene Orza, the union's associate general counsel, said the union would bargain with the clubs about rosters. "Expansion of rosters is something we feel strongly about," he said. "We will have significant contributions to make to that discussion."
Bill Murray, the executive director of baseball operations in the commissioner's office, said no decision has been made on rosters. He said the clubs would most likely create a temporary roster or expand the existing roster to a number around 60.
Just where the replacements would come from is the key question, but an agent said he has heard the clubs plan to use players from the Class A and AA levels of the minor leagues and college seniors who have exhausted their college eligibility as well as striking players who are willing to become strikebreakers.
"Far be it from me to suggest to the clubs what they should or shouldn't do with replacement players," Orza said. "I'm just telling them whatever replaces major league baseball players on strike won't be major league baseball."
Those terms -- major league baseball and major league players -- are not meaningless terms. Under a different section of the expired labor contract, they raise an intriguing question.
Article II deals with recognition of the union as the "sole and exclusive collective bargaining agent for all Major League Players, and individuals who may become Major League Players" during the term of the agreement. The agreement has expired, but are the owners prepared to withdraw recognition from the Players Association so that the union cannot represent the replacement players who become major league players?
Impasse/Implementation III?
 
No Hint of Latin Defections
 The way word has spread in recent weeks that many Latin players can be expected to report to training camps next spring, it was beginning to look as though scouts and other club officials had embarked on a campaign to create that impression, hoping that other players would think of going to camp themselves.
But Ralph Avila, a Los Angeles Dodgers vice president who operates the team's baseball complex in the Dominican Republic, said he had no indication that Latin major leaguers would act differently from any other group of players.
"All made statements to the news media here they want to play but they have to support the strike because they want to keep the union," Avila said. "They don't want to strike; they want to play. But they have to support the union."
Avila said his conversations with players have been limited this winter. "We talk off the record a little bit but not too much," he said. "In the past they used to come here every day in the off season to work out, but in the strike situation, they're not allowed to come here. I see them at the stadium, in restaurants. We talk about things off the record. We got instructions not to interfere with anything."
As for the notion that Latins don't have a strong allegiance to the union, Avila said: "I think Latin players are in the same position as American players. They are very disciplined players. We understand they belong to the union and they have to support the union. We think different, but I understand the situation with the players. They have to keep the discipline."
 
Some Kind of Committee
 The partnership portion of the new proposal the players presented to the owners yesterday prompted a look at yet another article of the expired agreement. This one, Article XXV, was designed in the 1990 negotiations and calls for the creation of a labor-management committee.
"The purpose of this Committee," the article says, "is to discuss, explore and study problems referred to it by the parties to this Agreement and to promote the economic development of Baseball." Furthermore, the committee was to meet three times a year.
According to one lawyer involved in labor matters, the committee met in the first couple of years of the agreement, "but I don't remember any over the last two years." That lawyer and another recalled what appears to have been the sole function the committee created -- a charity golf tournament in the first year of the agreement.
The players intend for their proposed partnership venture to be taken slightly more seriously.
 
The Post-Canseco Strategy
 Kevin Kennedy was a sucker for Jose Canseco's cajoling style two seasons ago in Texas, but the new Red Sox manager will not let his newest player compete with Roger Clemens for the No. 1 pitching role in Boston.
The Texas Rangers, on the other hand, believe they will miss Canseco's bat less than they will benefit from Otis Nixon's glove and the arm of the free-agent pitcher they plan to sign with some of the $5.1 million they don't have to give Canseco next season.
The Rangers, it should be remembered, got 31 home runs and 90 runs batted in from Canseco last season and still finished with a won-lost record 10 games under .500, albeit a first-place record 10 games under .500. Their defense was the worst in the American League, committing 106 errors, nearly twice as many as Baltimore's league-low 57, and their pitching staff had a 5.45 earned run average, second worst in the league, and gave up the most home runs, 157.
General Manager Doug Melvin expects Nixon to make a significant difference roaming center field.
"There were more triples hit in this park than any in the league," Melvin said. "I'm a believer in having a quality center fielder. In Baltimore, we had Brady Anderson, Mike Devereaux and Steve Finley. That outfield helped a mediocre pitching staff. Jeff Ballard had an 18-8 record one year. When you have an infield with limited range, they need three ground balls to get through to score a run. A ball that's not caught and gets through in the outfield can do a lot of damage."
So can Canseco -- with his bat, not his arm.

LENGTH: 305 words

HEADLINE: Letters

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your article perpetuates a dangerous equation of psychosis with schizophrenia, reflecting assumptions that contribute to erroneous diagnoses of schizophrenia in manic-depressive cases. 
 Psychosis is a state of brain dysfunction with increased dopamine brain activity that can occur both in schizophrenia and in a significant minority of manic-depressive individuals. Thus the impaired ability to think rationally, distorted perceptions and impaired ability to interpret sensations or the intent of others can strike both manic-depressive and schizophrenic patients.
The assumption that manic-depressive illness typically strikes later in life is not correct; many individuals experience the onset as adolescents, with its main symptom dysphoria rather than mania or depression -- the person is irritable and difficult.
In addition, creativity occurs only when the manic-depressive person goes into remission or stabilizes at a mild low-grade manic level. This reflects a dopamine level that is too low to trigger psychosis. The schizophrenic person has a bizarre semblance of creativity when there is a psychotic loosening of associative thinking. Once the schizophrenic recovers from the psychosis, there is lack of original thinking as well as paucity of all thinking.
Manic depressive episodes follow psychosocial stresses (like a spouse's pregnancy) or physiological stresses (such as smoking marijuana, which lowers serotonin and triggers increased dopamine activity in the brain). All these factors are precipitants rather than causes of manic-depressive illness, which are genetic. The genetic causes consist of contributing to irregular synthesis of proteins like dopamine as well as receptor molecules.
 
LEO I. JACOBS
Lake Barrington, Ill., Nov. 14
 
The writer is a psychiatrist.

HEADLINE: In Praise of the Counterculture

 BODY:
Generational bonding experiences have always been important in American life. Civil War veterans kept meeting until time scythed down the last of them. The Depression shaped the economic dreams, and fears, of millions of young couples and their children. People who fought in World War II have moved through history with a fortifying set of common memories. So have the children born to them during and shortly after that war.
 This last group profoundly altered the way Americans think about their inner lives, their fellow citizens, the earth upon which we live and the process by which older citizens in Washington decide when and where young Americans die in combat. 
 Now, in an excess of Republican triumphalism, the party's new leaders have decided to make "counterculture" into a pejorative. What flapdoodle. Only a few periods in American history have seen such a rich fulfillment of the informing ideals of personal freedom and creativity that lie at the heart of the American intellectual tradition. Like many of his elders, Representative Newt Gingrich may prefer a stricter regimen of social conformity and religious observance.
 But the millions of Americans who incorporated the cultural ideals of the Sixties and the decade's healthy spirit of political activism are foolish to abandon the high ground because of his post-election slanging. Certainly the excesses of the decade are easy to parody, and its summery, hedonistic ethos then and now reduced modern puritans to fits of twisting discomfort. America is still close enough to the frontier experience of relentless work and danger to view any kind of fun with suspicion.
 No true historian, however, can believe that it is possible to repudiate so large a cultural event in a nation's history, or to dismiss its seminal political events as a "McGovern-nik" aberration.
 The 60's spawned a new morality-based politics that emphasized the individual's responsibility to speak out against injustice and corruption. It was this renewed sense of responsibility that led enough people to raise their voices to end America's most disastrous foreign military adventure, the Vietnam War. On this level, the Sixties saw an exercise in mass sanity in which a nation's previously voiceless citizens -- its young -- overturned a war policy that was, in fact, deranged.
 The spirit of the age, like the tactics of the antiwar movement, was shaped by the civil rights movement. Its lessons of citizen empowerment, to use the 90's term, led to the progress of the environmental, women's and gay rights movements. The counterculture, in sum, produced a renewal of the Thoreauvian ideal of the clear, defiant voice of the dissenting citizen.
 There was another empowering aspect of the counterculture's confrontation with the Washington monolith. Those days produced the sad wisdom, now indispensable in American politics, that the Government will lie to protect its interests and that constant vigilance is necessary to keep it honest.
 The influence of 60's individualism was not limited to politics. It fostered a psychological movement that, while it burdened our shelves with tomes of psychobabble, also enabled people in emotional torment to ask for help without being stigmatized. It gave people in dead or abusive relationships permission to break out.
 Would many Americans truly like to imagine a society returned to the dictatorship of the majority culture? Would they like to go back to the days of blatant, sanctioned discrimination against African-Americans and women, to a world deprived of all the 60's ingredients that still simmer in the cultural stew, including an American music that has become a global language?
 We think not. For one thing, there are too many Republicans who are also Grateful Dead fans or, for that matter, divorced, ex-potheads and opponents of state-regulated prayer and abortion.
 At its essence, the counterculture was about one of conservatives' favorite words: values. It was a repudiation of the blind obedience and reflexive cynicism of politics as usual. It was about exposing hypocrisy, whether personal or political, and standing up to irrational authority. As in any large movement, it accommodated its share of charlatans and sociopaths. But it is part of us, a legacy around which Americans can now unite, rather than allow themselves to be divided.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Do We Feed Defense Instead of the Poor?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 I sit on the board of directors of Part of the Solution, a Bronx soup kitchen and shelter. On Nov. 30 we voted, with intense anguish but out of fiscal necessity, to close the shelter component of POTS. That means 12 more people will be out on the streets and the 500 on our waiting list have seen their hopes of shelter dwindle even further. 
 Two days later you reported that President Clinton, apparently seeking to appease Republicans in Congress, is seeking a $25 billion increase over the next six years in military spending.
 The rationale for that increase is that the military must be ready to defend America's "national interests." That ubiquitous phrase, invoked to justify spending more than $1 trillion on the military during the last decade, has a hollow ring.
 What is the national interest? Surely, if the phrase has any meaning, quality education for our children, food for the hungry, homes for the homeless, jobs for the unemployed and affordable medical care for the sick must be critical constituents of our national interest and collective security.
 St. Augustine, in "City of God," criticizes Babylon and, by implication, the militaristic empires of his day: the name for Babylon, he said, was "Confusion." Need more be said about our Federal budget priorities?
 
ANNA J. BROWN
Bronx, Dec. 4, 1994

HEADLINE: Habitats/272 Alexander Avenue;
Bronx Homesteading: It's Grueling, but Rewarding

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
FRED NEHRING first visited New York City in the 70's as a sailor in uniform, and he remembers how well the city treated him: free tickets to Yankee Stadium, free tickets to the U.S.O. dances and a bunk at the Soldiers, Sailors and Airmen's Club on Lexington Avenue for $3 a night.
When he moved to the city, he liked to take the subway to places "outside the beaten tourist track," scouting for places he'd like to live. He said he began to seek out neighborhoods full of abandoned properties. 
 To Mr. Nehring, the deteriorating buildings were "a terrific waste."
"These were beautiful buildings; not like some cruddy, ugly buildings that had been abandoned," he said. "I felt the thing to do was to get into fixing them up."
He found an agency that administers homesteading projects where mostly city-owned abandoned buildings are purchased by individuals or groups willing to put "sweat equity" into fixing up the property. The homesteaders usually receive a combination of grants and loans from local, state and Federal agencies -- and in return, the agencies restrict the amount of profit homesteaders can make if they sell their renovated property. There are also income guidelines for the individual homesteaders.
There were no properties available when Mr. Nehring asked. Nevertheless, he volunteered some time and helped a group called Self Help Works form a credit union. At the time, he says, he was "largely unemployed," although he picked up some small home contracting jobs, mainly painting and plastering.
As he continued to work with the credit union -- it eventually hired him and he now runs it -- he heard about a homesteader group being formed on Alexander Avenue in the South Bronx, about a block from the police station that played a starring role in the 1981 movie "Fort Apache, the Bronx."
There, in an abandoned tenement at 272 Alexander Avenue, he met Juan Carlos Taiano, Mr. Taiano's son, Marcello, and the rest of the homesteaders. When he joined the group, it was in flux, he said.
"The founding members had been starry-eyed artists and idealists," Mr. Nehring said, "and many of those had left. This calls for a commitment to the long haul; we still have one opening."
The chronology of a homesteading project is grueling, not for the faint of heart. The initial offering plan was published in 1986. This particular group's proposal was formally completed in early 1987. In January 1988, Mr. Nehring became a member. On June 23, 1993, the homesteaders bought the building from the city for $1,750.
The group's first task was to clear out the derelict building. The first infusion of money came from the Housing Trust Fund, a state program run by the nonprofit Urban Homesteading Assistance Board, which gave $30,000 in seed money. Most of that went to pay the architect for his drawings and applications, "but we managed to pay for eight or nine Dumpsters," Mr. Nehring said.
"We found rats and a family of puppies," he said. "The roof was filled with refrigerators, which we gleefully threw off onto the backyard; after we cleared out the building, we sealed the windows with plywood."
Their brick tenement had been cruelly treated over the years, and its interior needed to be stabilized. There were three or four fires "before we had site control," he continued. "The last fire was especially brutal; the fire company had to cut through the roof to hose down the building; there were a lot of beams actually burnt through."
TO correct structural weakness, the homesteaders built a four-story interior framework of 2- by 4's to support the rear wall. "At least we stopped the building from falling down," Mr. Nehring said.
But now money was a pressing issue. There had been no budget for the lumber for the restructuring. The group sold the bathtubs and iron pipes to continue.
Each member of the group was paying -- and continues to pay -- $50 a month toward insurance. "We never had any more money to pay for Dumpsters," Mr. Nehring said. "Nevertheless, we managed to get the tubsout, and over this period, a really great thing happened: These strangers who were sort of thrown in your path . . . ." He paused. "You get really close to them."
Mr. Nehring began listing his fellow homesteaders.
"One, Carlos, is married. He was an architect in Argentina but his credentials aren't recognized here, so he's stuck with painting and construction jobs. His wife is Elva. His son, Marcello, or Mark, has a separate apartment. Then there's Gilberto, he's married to Elizabeth. They have a son and a daughter. He works at Roosevelt Hospital, as a surgery admissions clerk.
"Then there's Milton. His wife's name is Mrs. Zorn. He has a grown son and daughter but I think the daughter's going to move in. He's a butler-handyman for very wealthy people. His wife's a housekeeper; they work as a team. Then there's Gloria Garcia, she's single but we gave her a two-bedroom apartment because she wants to have foster kids. Marcello and Gloria are teachers at separate schools."
Eventually, the group received $431,000 from the New York State Housing Trust Fund, $105,000 from the city's urban homesteading program and both a $65,000 loan at 3 percent and a $36,000 grant from the New York Landmarks Conservancy -- the grant to replace the missing metal cornice. The Landmarks Conservancy estimates that the homesteaders have contributed $65,000 of their own money and "sweat equity" to the renovation, which totaled $730,000.
The project also received financial aid from three other groups: an $11,000 loan from the Parodneck Foundation for Self-Help Housing and Community Development; an $8,700 grant from Con Edison's Renaissance Program and a $9,000 loan from the Self-Help Works Federal Credit Union, which Mr. Nehring heads.
The building was established as a self-managed co-op with seven apartments, with the five one-bedroom shareholders paying $420 a month maintenance and the holders of the two-bedroom duplexes paying $540 a month.
ALTHOUGH that may seem cheap, Mr. Nehring points out that the group members did much of the work to fix up the building. And, unlike shareholders in a nonrestricted co-op, the homesteaders cannot make any profit if they decide to sell their units. The program is also income-limited; a single person, for example, cannot earn over $26,700 a year to participate. The group cannot spend any of the building's substantial reserve fund without permission of the urban homesteading board. In addition, the group must pay for an audit each year and $500 for an annual inspection by the board.
"It's a good deal for the homesteaders if they live here a long time, because they pay less per month than the average owner," said Karen Ansis of the Landmarks Conservancy. "But if for some reason they have to move out in the first few years, then they don't do as well."
"Beggars can't be choosers," Mr. Nehring said, "and we're begging."
But the homesteading group is undaunted by restrictions or delays. Last week, the members still had not moved into their spotless units, which they show off proudly: shining floors, superb white tile bathrooms and small but serviceable kitchens with almond formica cabinets.
There is a snag in obtaining the building's certificate of occupancy because of the lack of an interior basement stairway. The group's architect is trying to work it out. Mr. Nehring is optimistic he will be able to finally move in within a month.
Despite his 40-minute commute to work on the No.6 subway from 138th Street and Alexander Avenue -- and despite entreaties from his woman friend to come live with her in Mamaroneck -- Mr. Nehring isn't about to back out now.
"This is my baby -- a person's place defines their identity and this defines my identity," Mr. Nehring said. "I'm a homesteader."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Fred Nehring (above) at 272 Alexander Avenue; participating in homesteading are, from left, Juan Carlos Taiano, Mr. Nehring, Marcello Taiano and Gloria Garcia. (Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times)

And Bear in Mind
(Editor's Choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
THE COLLECTED STORIES OF LOUIS AUCHINCLOSS. (Houghton Mifflin, $24.95.) Nineteen stories, the oldest from the 1940's, by a writer unfashionably and passionately concerned with the beliefs and behavior of the WASP civilization that until very recently produced America's ruling class.
 
D.H. LAWRENCE: The Story of a Marriage, by Brenda Maddox. (Simon & Schuster, $30.) Lawrence's violent life with the formidable Frieda Weekley, who bedded him 20 minutes after she met him, makes for absorbing if unappetizing reading.
 
THE DIVINE CHILD: A Novel of Prenatal Rebellion, by Pascal Bruckner. (Little, Brown, $21.95.) A wonderfully appalling story by a French novelist about a monster in utero.
 
IN PHARAOH'S ARMY: Memories of the Lost War, by Tobias Wolff. (Knopf, $23.) The follow-up volume to Mr. Wolff's memoir "This Boy's Life" is a series of small, elegant, personal sketches of his year in Vietnam.
 
THE LAST SHOT: City Streets, Basketball Dreams, by Darcy Frey. (Richard Todd/Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) Mr. Frey examines the myth of deliverance through basketball on the courts of Coney Island, where black youths compete to be exploited by coaches, colleges and, in the rarest cases, by professional sports.
 
LOST PURITAN: A Life of Robert Lowell, by Paul Mariani. (Norton, $27.50.) This approach to the "real" character of a protean confessional poet uses letters and diaries to reveal a writer whose fascination with preachers, statesmen and generals hints at restlessness with his own art.
 
MAKING MALCOLM: The Myth and Meaning of Malcolm X, by Michael Eric Dyson. (Oxford University, $19.95.) Malcolm X is the thread that stitches together these eloquent, freewheeling essays on hip-hop culture, black films and the tragic lives of poor black men.
 
THE MASTER OF PETERSBURG, by J.M. Coetzee. (Viking, $21.95.) The hero of Mr. Coetzee's grimmest novel yet is Dostoyevsky himself, trapped in generational and political clashes, trying to scrape meaning from the death of a son.
 
THE PRIVATE LIFE OF CHAIRMAN MAO: The Memoirs of Mao's Personal Physician, by Li Zhisui. (Random House, $30.) A detailed recounting of Mao Zedong's prodigious hankerings for fatty pork, young women and sleeping pills.
 
SEARCHING FOR MERCY STREET: My Journey Back to My Mother, Anne Sexton, by Linda Gray Sexton. (Little, Brown, $22.95.) An intimate account of growing up the daughter of a mad, child-abusing, suicidal, brilliant poet, and of resolving such an upbringing from the inside out.
 
TOULOUSE-LAUTREC: A Life, by Julia Frey. (Viking, $34.95.) A valuable life of the only great painter of France's golden age who was an aristocrat, incorporating much family correspondence recently made available.

HEADLINE: WORD & IMAGE;
Jumpers vs. Reefers

BYLINE: By MAX FRANKEL

 BODY:
Sometimes, as a former editor, I read the front pages of The Times -- or The Washington Post or The Los Angeles Times -- the way editors have designed them to be read. Quite an exercise.
I begin at the top right corner, the now-conventional (though hardly logical) place where the editors of large-size papers display their choice of the most important article of the day, called the "lead" but spelled "lede." After reading the page 1 portion of the lede, I move to the left-most column to read the page 1 portion of the off-lede, or second most important article, and then similarly work my way through the opening paragraphs of the other articles at the top of the page, those "at the fold" and finally those at the bottom. 
 En route, I may be interrupted or distracted by assorted pictures, word boxes and charts. But assuming that I reach the bar code at the bottom by the intended route, I would then, as on a recent Thursday with The New York Times, have to plunge inside the paper with the following half-thoughts like these somehow embedded in my mind:
 In the past the CLinton Administration had declined to put strong pressure on the Bosnian Government, citing the suffering of Muslim civilians at the hands of the

 	 	 		--------------------	 	Continued on Page A10, Column 1
The visit be Mr. Dole, a republican from Kansas, comes against a background of growing disarray in NATO, confusing shifts in American policy and a resounding sense of crisis brough by the Serbian

 	 	 		--------------------	 	Continued on Page A10, Column 2
 "I think its a landmark paper,"

 	 	 		--------------------	 	Continued on Page B15, Column 1
 The degree to which American youths encounter peril at the hands of other American youths in reflected in 1992 Justice Department statistics: 55 percent of all

 	 	 		--------------------	 	Continued on Page B14, column 1
 The problem in District 17, which runs from Crown Heights to Flatbush, have been so severe that both school officials and districe administrators have begged Mr. Cortines to help. Nearly half the 28

 	 	 		--------------------	 	Continued on Page B12, Column 4
 "It's the Achilles' hell in the American success story," said Richard B. Freeman, a labor economist at Harvard University and editor of a book of articles, "Work-

 	 	 		--------------------	 	Continued on Page D15, Column 1
 "They order them to the floor, Tupac resisted, he shot numerous times, at least twice in the

 	 	 		--------------------	 	Continued on Page B3, Column 1
 The Republican Council members who sided with their Demo-

 	 	 		--------------------	 	Continued on Page B12, Column 5
Newspaper layout requires that I carry this baggage of six, seven or eight articles interrupted in midsentence or midword until, here and there, I encounter the continuation of each one. I will not, of course, encounter them in the order in which I left them; they were arrayed on page 1 in their presumed order of importance, but their continuations are neatly arrayed inside with articles on related subjects -- starting with international news, then national, metropolitan and so on.
Because The Times is by no means unique in its devotion to this bizarre design, a nasty choice daily awaits tens of millions of readers. They can:
A) Read the front-page articles only to the point of interruption and just forget about the rest;
B) Select one, perhaps two, front-page articles whose continuations they will immediately seek out, as directed, skipping the other front-page news and leaping over a good deal of the news inside;
C) Not read the front page at once in its entirety but rather pursue the continuation of each article as directed, repeatedly returning to page 1 to pick up the next;
D) Take in page 1 and renew acquaintance with the topless bottom of each article wherever they find it, vaguely recalling where they left off or occasionally peeking back at page 1 to pick up the thread. Or simply abandon the interrupted passage and press shakily forward.
Small wonder, given the perversity of this routine, that there is no good English word to describe the process of continuations and, as far as I can determine, no good history of how it came to be. In the jargon of journalism, the interrupted articles are said, accurately enough, to "jump" to an inside page and the second portion of the article is widely called "the jump."
Jumping seems to have started modestly, without hurdles, in the age of movable type and one-sheet papers, when front-page narratives simply continued on the backside. The break came to be called a "turn" or "turning" and many newspapers carried on with this turning from front page to back page when they expanded to four and eight pages. To this day, some large newspapers place the continuations of front-page articles on the back of the same section, even if that requires upsetting the classification of news packages by subject matter.
Until the early 1930's, The Times ended lede stories on page 1 or "turned" them mostly to page 2 or the back page. The routine jumping of other articles to inside pages began about 1907 and accelerated during World War I. By 1933, most front-page stories jumped every which way, burdening the reader but perhaps pleasing the advertisers who wanted more traffic for the pages bearing their messages.
They should be pleased no longer. Experience, anecdote and surveys persuaded me some time ago that readers are annoyed by the jumping and that perhaps half never bother to follow the front-page articles inside; they'd rather quit than leap. But my impatience was not shared by other editors, or the publisher, and the restraint of tradition overcame my resolve. Too bad, because there exists a device that would perfectly preserve the traditional appearance of any paper's front page while eliminating the barbaric ripping in two of every day's most important reports.
The device at hand is a summary and signpost of a longer article, which we call a "reefer" but spell "refer" since it is a sentence, caption or short article "referring" the reader to some kind of elaboration elsewhere in the paper.
As soon as tomorrow morning, with hardly a change in their appearances, The Timeses of New York or Los Angeles or The Washington Post or The Philadelphia Inquirer could produce front pages of "refers" -- meaning concise and well-written summaries that resemble, and occupy the same space as, the tops of the now interrupted articles. But instead of screeching to an awkward halt in midsentence, the refers would end coherently and then advise the reader to seek a "Detailed Account on Page 13."
USA Today often uses this device and has even overcome the refer resistance of reporters, who are reluctant to see their names disappear from page 1 dispatches. Its remedy is to have the same reporter write and sign both the page 1 summary and the detailed account inside.
The editors would still rank the news of the day in descending order by the way they arrange the refer summaries on page 1 and they would still classify the news by subject inside. The reader who is content with a summary of any matter would obtain a coherent one; the reader who wants a fuller account would be directed inside, as always. The reader stumbling upon a dispatch inside would no longer find it topless. And newspapers would run a better race against more fluid media if, replacing jumpers with refers, they finally call off the annoying morning calisthenics.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 75; Column 2; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 3863 words

HEADLINE: Hook, Line and Sunk

BYLINE: By Timothy Egan; Timothy Egan is the Seattle bureau chief of The New York Times.

 BODY:
CLENCHING A KNIFE IN HIS TEETH, FINGERS BLOODIED from a long night wrestling squid and a new net that cuts to the bone, Tony Demelo finishes up his chores in the port where Herman Melville learned how to swear. The morning light has chased away the prostitutes and drug dealers who roam the cobbled streets of New Bedford's waterfront district, bartering in Portuguese. Nearby, commuter traffic carries workers with soft hands and clean clothes to office towers in Providence and Boston.
For more than a week Demelo has bounced atop the Atlantic at its most convulsive, sleeping on a bunk in a cabin smaller than a prison cell. His 55-foot boat reeks of blood, fish slime and rust -- a hybrid scent that has enveloped this harbor since it was a British colony. 
 "Out there, we watch the Red Sox, the Bruins, we got a VCR and I cook too," he says. "Chicken, lobster. I made pork chops the other night. Out there, nobody tells you what to do because everybody knows what they got to do. You can scream at the top of your lungs if you want."
Out there, of course, is the open water. Fishermen have given the world a handful of aphorisms, but one you seldom hear them say anymore is this: It's a big ocean out there.
Instead, the seas became crowded with floating technology units -- million-dollar vessels chasing fish with the aid of Loran navigational systems, sonar and Comsat satellite images. Weekend captains in shiny shoes could punch in a few computer entries and find out precisely where they were on the water and get a look at what was schooling 50 fathoms below.
Man versus fish used to be a fair matchup. But the ancient chase turned into a rout; in many quarters, it's all but over and -- surprise -- mankind has won. To the victors go the empty seas. Now, the only question is what to do with the last of the nation's hunter-gatherers, fishermen without fish.
Demelo says he was drawn to the water, down from the hills above Buzzards Bay, almost by instinct. He may be only 20, but he cannot imagine a life tethered to the land. "You kidding me?" he says. "Why would I ever want to do anything but fish?"
The idea of New Bedford or Gloucester, Mass., or Astoria, Ore., no longer sending people out to sea may also seem unimaginable.
From the mouth of the Columbia River on the Pacific shore, where Lewis and Clark spent a winter subsisting on salmon, to the fog-haunted ports of New England, docks no longer flow with fish blood and fresh cash. Virtually every major American commercial fishing region outside of Alaska is in severe trouble; nearly 80 percent of the nation's known commercial species are now overfished or harvested to the limit of what can be sustained, according to the National Marine Fisheries Service.
Landings of cod, haddock and flounder, the principal ground fish that have long supported the New England fleet, are near their lowest recorded levels. Most of Georges Bank, a centuries-old mother lode, has been closed to commercial fishing; biologists say it is all but played out. Coastal communities in the Northeast and the Pacific Northwest have been declared Federal disaster areas.
Boats weighed down with overdue bank notes stand idle. Taverns fill at midmorning. And with too many vessels and not enough fish, the Federal Government has been asked to buy out all the deeply indebted fishermen that it helped bring into the industry in the first place. The Canadian Government, after the collapse of its Atlantic cod fishery, has done just that, spending more than $1 billion on 30,000 welfare fishermen.
"I hate to think of paying people not to fish in this country, but we already pay farmers not to farm, loggers not to log and dairymen not to milk," says Howard Nickerson, president of the Offshore Mariners Association, which represents boat owners in New Bedford. He is 81, an "old Yankee," he says, in a port dominated by Portuguese-Americans. "A guy who goes fishing thinks he's in control of his own destiny. That's simply not true anymore."
Blame the weather, technology, pollution, environmentalists, bureaucrats. All played a role. But when it comes right down to it, the honest fishermen say that they killed their own future.
THE NATION'S COMMERCIAL FISHING industry was born in the waters of New England, which produced a bounty of cod that allowed the Massachusetts Bay Colony to carry on a prosperous trade with Europe in the 1630's. And the Atlantic shore is where the industry now looks as if it has come to die. In New Bedford and Gloucester, communities that have always matched their civic pulse to the rhythm of the sea, it is not an easy fade.
Ghosts are everywhere in New Bedford, home of the world's largest whaling fleet in the 1850's and the nation's most valuable fishing port for 8 of the last 10 years.
At the town's main wharf, the old brick auction house where millions of fresh fish were sold from boat to buyer has just been sanitized. Commemorative signs are springing up, new floors have been laid and a few tourists with video cameras are sniffing around, one step ahead of the cultural anthropologists. A dead forest of smokestacks surrounds New Bedford, planted in hollowed-out textile mills that had boomed as whaling peaked before the Civil War. Most of them have been closed for more than half a century. They were never given a proper burial.
Just across the Acushnet River from the port is a row of modest mansions, each house straight-lined and strong-shouldered. The neighborhood rose just before the Revolutionary War, inhabited by a lot of people whose names were preceded by Captain, names now engraved on the fronts of the houses. The cemetery, also, is full of captains. For all of the contemporary pallor of New Bedford, this captains' row is a puffed-up chest to the wind. They were mariners then, back when the name meant something more than a baseball team with lousy relief pitchers.
"Nowhere in all America will you find more patricianlike houses; parks and gardens more opulent, than in New Bedford," Melville wrote in "Moby-Dick," published in 1851. At the time, New Bedford was the home port for more than half the American whaling fleet. The sailors went to sea for up to three years and returned with barrels of sperm whale oil to fuel the Industrial Revolution, baleen for corset stays and cash that found its way into the mansions above the bay.
Melville wrote about the Seamen's Bethel -- opened in 1832 and dedicated "to the moral improvement of seamen" -- but he seemed more taken by the bearded, beery conspirators who avoided moral improvement.
Next door to the bethel is the Mariners' Home, a three-story haunt where a transient sailor, down on his luck and stuck in port, can spend the night for $10. It was built in 1787. The latitude and longitude is etched on the wall outside. Inside, an aging "watchman," as Janis Liepa is known, sips from a large bowl of bean soup and chomps on a slab of meat. "Geraldo" blares from a corner television. There is not a sailor in sight.
"We get three or four guys a week that wander in," says Liepa, a native of Latvia who fished for 35 years. "I don't know what we're going to do when the fishermen stop coming in."
They have already started to disappear. For most of this year, New Bedford has ranked as one of the most job-hungry cities in America, with an unemployment rate as high as 15 percent among its 100,000 people. Mandatory restrictions on fishing -- emergency measures designed to save what fish are left -- could cost an additional 8,000 jobs, city officials estimate. Conservation measures adopted this year require most New England fishermen to reduce their workdays by 50 percent over the next five to seven years. By the end of that time, Federal officials say, half the fishermen may be gone for good.
One of those fishermen, John Pereira, captain of the Lucky Venture, strolls the New Bedford wharf, commiserating with other landbound captains. "I'm going crazy right now because I can't fish," he says.
Up the coast in Gloucester, decay is less evident, but the early stages of maritime gentrification have set in -- a sure sign that fishing is on the way out. Gloucester calls itself the oldest fishing port in America. Samuel Champlain came ashore in 1606 to caulk his boat, and the port has been active ever since. "Captains Courageous," the movie tale of two fishing boats on a race home, was set there. Now, a host of captains advertise whale sightseeing trips and below-retail lobster. Weekenders fill the bed-and-breakfasts. In one section of town, there is an earnest-looking art colony, filled with bright-painted clapboards and cozy restaurants.
Though just 30 miles from Boston, Gloucester looks to the Atlantic for self-worth. There is a sense of ageless routine, like a rural village in Europe. It seems musclebound, everything bolted to bedrock, holding on against the winds that whip Cape Ann. The editorial page of The Gloucester Daily Times carries George Will, but above the Washington pundit one typical day is a column about storms, this one titled, "Northeaster Is the King."
The business news centers not on the stock market, nor the rebuilding Massachusetts economy. Its focus is how many fish are brought into port every day, and the price paid for them. Of late, the news has been all bad. Fishermen seem to spend more time nursing hangovers in St. Peter's Club, named for the patron saint of fishing, than they do at sea.
In the Cafe Sicilia, a block or so from the waterfront and nestled between Sal's Hair Styling and Valentino's Sicilian Cooking, a cluster of men sip coffee and argue in Italian about soccer games. An older man enters, and is asked about the fishing.
He shrugs and frowns. "No pesce."
John Sanfilippo is so knotted up with anger he can barely speak. Over breakfast, in a modified accent, he says: "I don't want to sell my boat. I just want to fish. How come I can't just fish?" He wipes his face and, for an instant, seems to cry. "I just want to fish."
Sanfilippo is 49 and wears a baseball hat that says Gloucester Fisherman.
"I went to see the priest," he says. "Told him I didn't know what to do. Things are bad. The priest said, 'What about retraining?' I said: 'Retraining? I don't know nothing else. The only other thing I'd like to do is be a priest.' But I'm too old for that."
He went out this morning in the Giovanna, his 47-foot trawler, which costs about $50,000 a year to maintain. He came back with less than $200 worth of fish, he says. In the glory days, just a few years ago, the catch would have been 5 to 10 times that amount. Dragging a trawl net, he fishes for flounder, cod, haddock -- the most endangered of New England stocks. Last year's haddock catch of 880 metric tons was the lowest ever recorded. Thirty years ago, the fleet used to take up to 50,000 metric tons.
In Gloucester's fishing community, the women do most of the politics, the men work the boats. Angela Sanfilippo, John's wife, has of late taken phone calls at home from people like Senator Edward Kennedy and lawyers from leading environmental groups. Everybody wants to help, she says.
"But only God can bring the fish back," she says. "The Sicilian tradition is, we rely a lot on faith."
She has a gravity-defying stack of dark hair and deep black eyes, and speaks volumes with her hands. In the last decade, she helped to organize fishermen against Government plans to lease rights to drill for oil and gas off Georges Bank. Now she is the local leader of the effort to save their livelihood.
"You used to go to a wedding or somebody's house for dinner and all you would talk about is fishing," says Angela. "Now, everybody says: 'Don't bring up the subject of fish. You'll start an argument.' "
But without fishing, she says, there is little else to hold everyone together. "It's in our blood. My husband, he has six brothers, all fishermen. We once took a vacation to Bermuda, and my husband got up at 2 in the morning to fish. Some vacation, huh? My son, Dominic, he graduated from Gloucester High School, then he went to college for a little while. One day he came home and said: 'Mama, I don't want that anymore. I want to go fishing.' I cried my heart out."
At the telling of the story, she starts to cry as well. She senses there is no future in fishing; after more than 350 years, this is the end of the line.
MORE THAN ANYTHING, WHAT killed the whaling industry was the discovery of oil at Titusville, Pa., in 1859. Of course, whales were disappearing after years of heavy harvesting. But when it became easier to get the basic lubricants for the Industrial Revolution out of the ground, rather than the high seas, whaling went into decline, eventually becoming obsolete.
What has nearly killed fishing in some coastal regions of America, according to many experts, is a Federal law that fishermen lobbied heavily for -- the Magnuson Act of 1976. Until that time, fishing was a relatively small-scale affair. Boats were made of wood. Families passed on tips and nets to other family members. And the fishing fleet, for the most part, did not roam far from the American shore.
But elsewhere, fishing was going through its own industrial revolution. By the 1960's, enormous boats, many from the Soviet Union, were scouring the ocean far from their home ports. When these factory trawlers -- capable of processing fish on board, and therefore staying at sea for months at a time -- began to appear off the shores of America, alarm cries went up. Congress, in passing the Magnuson Act, created a 200-mile "exclusive economic zone" around the United States coastline, reserving that area for American fishermen. The old zone was three miles offshore.
The Government would try to build up a home-grown fleet to replace the foreign fishermen they were chasing away. The Americans, it was thought, would practice enlightened self-interest. Surely, they would never vacuum their own backyard bare.
The act also set up eight regional councils to manage each of the nation's major fishing regions. Their job was to assure that American waters were not overfished, but it was also to set the catch limit at a maximum sustainable yield -- a balancing act that was doomed from the start.
A major reason it failed, many believe, is a section of the law that exempted the fishing industry from conflict-of-interest laws. The idea was to keep regulation out of the hands of Washington bureaucrats and put the fisheries in the hands of those who knew it best.
Though fish are considered a public resource -- like national forests, elk on the open range or offshore oil -- the size of the catch was set by some of the very people who had the biggest economic stake in the matter. It is as if Weyerhaeuser, the nation's largest private logging company, were able to dictate how many trees could be cut in the national forests, and then took the timber without paying a dime for it.
Inevitably, these regional councils set harvest levels that could not be sustained. The result: overfishing by foreign fleets was replaced by American overfishing.
After passage of the act, anyone who wanted to become a commercial fisherman could, with the help of a loan guaranteed by the Government, buy a $250,000 boat and start bringing in the bounty. It was free, after all; the law specifically prevented the Government from charging any kind of royalty or fee for taking fish.
In short order, big steel boats replaced the old oak clunkers. Investors looking for tax shelters found a floating one, thanks to generous depreciation allowances in the Federal tax code. In the first three years following passage, the number of fishing vessels in New England grew by almost 50 percent, to 1,300 boats. New Bedford became the nation's most valuable fishing port. In Alaska, a $2 billion annual fishery for pollock, which is used to make fake crab meat, developed over 10 years, attracting corporate giants like Tyson Foods, the Arkansas poultry king.
The old nose-to-the-wind school of navigation was replaced by digital panels in the wheelhouse. But these boats had to support loan payments, home mortgages, payrolls. Fish prices remained the same, or dropped, demanding an ever-bigger catch just to stay even. By the end of the 1980's, there were more than twice as many boats as needed to catch the available fish. And the fish totals were going down fast; cod, flounder and haddock landings in 1989 were one-fourth of what they had been in the 1960's. Representative Gerry Studds of Massachusetts warned of "biological bankruptcy" for Georges Bank.
"We developed a free-for-all attitude," says Rod Fujita, a marine ecologist with the Environmental Defense Fund. "Fishermen were given an incentive to catch every fish they could because ifthey didn't do it, somebody else would."
As long ago as 1639, laws were passed to assure that the waters of New England would never be fished out. But in the last 15 years, as the numbers were crashing, the fish council in charge of New England could not bring itself to set strict limits. Conservation came, belatedly, only after an order from a Federal judge.
The Magnuson Act is up for reauthorization in Congress. The National Marine Fisheries Service considers it "an embarrassment," as Brian Gorman, a spokesman, says. But efforts to overhaul the law will be fiercely fought by some elements of the fishing industry, who say the act needs only minor tinkering.
"I like to think we learned our lesson," says Dick Schaefer, conservation director of the Fisheries Service. "We should have restricted technology. And we should have limited the number of people who could fish."
By contrast, he and others point to lobster fishing in Maine. Every crustacean on the Atlantic floor could be scooped up in a season if there were no restrictions. But lobstermen are strictly regulated -- mainly by state rules that apply to waters up to three miles offshore -- and the fishery has remained relatively healthy.
"We share an equal part of the blame -- the industry and the Government -- for what happened," says Nickerson, the boat owners' president. He sat in his waterfront office in New Bedford, under a faded picture of a young John F. Kennedy. "We don't want handouts, but a lot of these guys are going to need a buyout or they are going to lose their homes."
Three years ago, when Studds floated the idea of the Government buying out fishermen, there was a storm of opposition. Now, the industry has rallied around the idea as their last, best hope. Take the cash and try something else, they say. The alternative is to dry-dock in a museum.
NEW BEDFORD'S CIVIC LEADERS, DESPERATE for a boost, have proposed turning their waterfront district into a national park, a lure for tourists seeking a bit of old-salt authenticity before moving on to the comforts of Cape Cod. It is the national cycle, churning history into package-tour-cum-cappuccino-stop at an ever-faster rate.
Americans love bloodless villages that recall some bit of their past. Fisherman's Wharf in San Francisco is the largest visitor attraction in California, after Disneyland. Despite its name, there are almost no real fishermen. And thousands flock daily to Williamsburg, Va., the colonial hamlet with authentically dressed daytime residents eagerly showing off the skills of 18th-century Virginians.
But it may be impossible to freeze-frame men who net bottom-dwellers in 20-foot seas, or to import tough guys who know how to mend a net despite a hangover.
John Bullard, the former Mayor, says New Bedford would not need to do much to become a money-making curiosity. The heart of the old town remains largely as Melville described it. But the historical district does have a logistical problem: it is cut off from the port by the expressway. And there is the question of what to do with the real live sailors, prostitutes and assorted old mariners who now inhabit the place. Are they going to pose for tourist cameras, spit on command?
Earlier this year, in an effort at triage for a threatened way of life, Congress appropriated $30 million in relief to New England fishing communities and $15 million to the Pacific Northwest, where salmon runs have been decimated. The fishermen look at the relief money as a way to get rid of them, quietly. Nobody within smelling distance of salt water thinks it will save the industry.
"They want to make this into a tourist town, and fishermen don't fit," says Angela Sanfilippo. "The feeling is, get out of the way." She came to Gloucester after fishing collapsed near her hometown, Porticello, Sicily. Now she sees a similar pattern taking hold in New England.
"The pleasure boats came into Porticello and the fishermen all were forced to leave," she says. "We had a fleet with no fishermen."
More than ever, fish are raised in pens on a fast-growth diet, chickens of the sea. No special skills are needed to round them up. Last year, more salmon came from fish farms than were caught by all the gill-netters of the Pacific Northwest. But if consumers rarely complain, what is the real loss? Norwegian seafood on a menu in Kansas City tastes no different than the same fillet smothered in Yankee charm on Cape Cod. So why should we bother with how it got there?
Over the last seven years, more than 17,000 I.B.M. workers in the Hudson River Valley have lost their jobs, devastating communities like Poughkeepsie and Kingston. Before that, the steel industry all but disappeared in Pittsburgh, taking with it nearly a third of the population. If every fisherman who stands to lose a job in New England or the Pacific Northwest were crowded together -- a total of about 12,000 people -- they might fit into one tall skyscraper. Why, then, should they merit taxpayer bailouts and sympathy?
Perhaps, as some have argued, because most self-respecting fishermen wouldn't be caught dead anywhere near an office building. Fishermen, like cowboys, represent an unshakable part of the American tradition. They are thought to be free, answering only to the elements, slit-eyed at dawn.
"They are tough, resourceful, self-respecting and also (some say) hidebound and cranky, too independent to organize for their own survival," Peter Matthiessen wrote in "Men's Lives," his tribute to Long Island's vanishing striped-bass fishermen. "Yet even their critics must acknowledge a gritty spirit that was once more highly valued in this country than it is today."
Of course, the freedom, the link to a way of life that goes back to the apostles of Christ and then some, does not make fishermen any more deserving of Federal help than the person in the starched white shirt helping to make the office payroll computer more efficient. The ability to mend a net is no more inherently noble than the ability to fix a copying machine.
But the traits, quirks, skills and language that evolved over eons in fishing communities may soon disappear in this country. In five years, we may hardly notice. There won't be fewer fish sticks, or even a dip in the national economy; just another nudge toward homogenization of the national character.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FIFTH AVENUE;
Fifth Ave. Regains Luster, and Even the Ginza Blinks

BYLINE: By Bruce Lambert 

 BODY:
For decades, Fifth Avenue from 49th to 57th Streets ranked as the premiere shopping venue in the world -- until the last five years, when recession pushed it into a slump. As Fifth languished, its rental prices were surpassed by those in Tokyo's Ginza, Hong Kong's Nathan Road and even an intersecting neighbor, East 57th Street.
But now Fifth is back on top again, says the Hirschfeld Group, a Manhattan-based national consulting firm specializing in retail space. Its annual survey shows that the avenue is commanding an average of $375 a square foot in annual rent in 1994, edging the Ginza and 57th Street. Just last year, Fifth Avenue lagged $95 behind the Ginza. 
 Behind the numbers of Fifth's resurgence lies a certain irony, that the avenue has won its new exclusivity as its commercial landscape -- from the Warner Brothers store to Banana Republic -- has gained a new mass appeal. But it is also a story of self-improvement efforts and shifting economic fortunes.
"The crowds have come back, and business is terrific," said Tom Cusick, president of the Fifth Avenue Association, a business group. Faith Hope Consolo, a managing director of the retail brokers Garrick Aug, said: "Fifth is a world-class address. It's making both a comeback and a transformation, still with luxury stores but bringing in theme stores and entertainment retailing."
Property owners formed a business improvement district last year to clean up litter and graffiti and post security guards to chase away sidewalk peddlers, three-card-monte con artists and pickpockets. Under a city program, most airline offices and banks that lined Fifth have relocated to make way for more retail. A concerted effort evicted many disreputable electronics shops and rug merchants who exploited the avenue's cachet with phony going-out-of-business sales and other gimmicks.
In filling the vacancies, Fifth Avenue has changed its personality. Along with elegant stores like Tiffany's, Bergdorf Goodman, Cartier and Saks, it is expanding with stores catering to a wider audience. (Some traditionalists, of course, would say that Fifth, along with 57th Street, has come to resemble something of a theme park.)
Warner Brothers, which opened last year on the corner of 57th Street, filling a long-vacant spot, draws thousands of customers daily and averages a sale every six seconds, said Michael Hirschfeld, whose firm conducts the rent survey. Other new stores include Coca-Cola's gift shop, the Nine West shoe store and the Museum Company and Tower Records at Trump Tower. Disney is on the way to 55th Street, Nike is taking the old Bonwit Teller space at Trump Tower. Near 52d Street, Liz Claiborne is filling a vacancy, and Banana Republic is taking the former Japan Airlines spot.
"Fifth has certainly gone through major turnover, a changing of the guard," Mr. Hirschfeld said. "If I were going to predict the future, I would say it will be more of the Disneys."
Also boosting Fifth Avenue is the recovery in the city's economy and tourism. Fifth Avenue stores are a destination for many visitors and draw others who come for the area's attractions.
"The foot traffic is phenomenal," Mr. Cusick said. Business from Fifth's flourishing scene is spilling over to some side streets, especially restaurants.
Fifth Avenue's restored worldwide ranking also reflects the declining fortunes of competing strips overseas. The Ginza's tumble after five years in first place comes at a time of Japan's economic troubles and big currency swings.
Fifth Avenue offers not only a prime site for selling but also a prestigious promotional location -- "a symbolic billboard," Mr. Hirschfeld says. After years of vacancies, Mr. Cusick said the opposite problem was emerging. "If you want flagship property on Fifth," he said, "hurry up, because we're running out of space." BRUCE LAMBERT

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: SOUTHEASTERN QUEENS;
Panel's Proposals to Divide A District Divide a District

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

 BODY:
With 32,000 students in Woodhaven, Richmond Hill, Ozone Park, South Ozone Park, Howard Beach and the Rockaways, School District 27 is one of the city's most crowded. Because demographic projections predict continued growth in southeast Queens, a Board of Education advisory panel has recommended splitting the district in two.
But the proposal has divided the local school board and pitted neighborhoods against one another in a debate over its geographic, economic and racial implications. 
 Under the two variations of the proposal, a new District 27B would consist of the Rockaways, Broad Channel and perhaps three schools in Howard Beach. District 27A would comprise the northern part of the current district.
However, opponents of any split, most of them residents of the western Rockaways, with a predominantly white and affluent population, say a new District 27B would be too small, too isolated by the peninsula's peculiar geography and choked by the poverty of Far Rockaway. They say it would foster racial segregation and decrease property values.
James B. Egan, the school board president, questioned the viability of a District 27B, which would have fewer than 12,000 students. "If you look to some of the other districts," he said, "being small doesn't seem to have helped them."
But some Rockaways residents, particularly those in Far Rockaway, which is mostly black and mostly poor, believe that creating a District 27B would create a positive focus on the problems in their schools, which have the lowest reading scores in the district. James Sanders Jr., a member of School Board 27, who lives in Arverne, said: "We need to bring services to where the people are. It will increase parent involvement, because it will be our district instead of the district."
Splitting the district would in some ways make an unofficial arrangement official: a satellite district office was set up in Intermediate School 53 in Far Rockaway after parents there complained of not being able to make the trip the district office, which is in Ozone Park.
In a report last month, the advisory panel offered two alternatives for creating District 27B. One plan would include just the Rockaways and Broad Channel. The second plan would add three Howard Beach elementary schools.
Many residents of Howard Beach, which is predominantly white and working class, support the first idea. Mr. Egan, the school board's president, said: "There is a group on the mainland that would like to cut Rockaway out of their lives. They want to get rid of the Rockaway schools, which are some of the lesser performing and more impoverished schools in the district."
Margaret Cummings, a secretary and mother of three who lives in Howard Beach, said she supported the split -- as long as her community was not affected. "We don't want our children going over a bridge to a junior high school in Rockaway," she said.
By law, the advisory panel was required to consider the district's size, educational needs and compliance with the Federal Voting Rights Act, as well as the area's geography.
Across the city, redistricting has raised complex and sensitive issues of race and class as the panel has considered the representation of minorities on local school boards, and which schools, because of their poverty levels, would qualify for special Federal financing.
The Board of Education has until February to make a decision on redistricting. Meanwhile, debate and discussion on the issue are continuing at public hearings.
"It has created a lot of ill will among the different areas," said Steve Greenberg, a member of School Board 27, who lives in Breezy Point, on the west end of the Rockaways. "People are saying, 'You don't want to be with us,' and, 'We don't want to be with you.' Personally, I would prefer to leave things as they are." DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
