HEADLINE: COPING;
Nurse Radio: Out of the Medical Wilderness

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE 

 BODY:
WHILE pushing a needle into me recently, Renee Trambert ordered me to listen to her radio program. I was in no position to argue. She told me that it was on WBAI-FM (99.5) every Friday at 1 P.M. for an hour, and that it reflected the sensibility of the nursing community -- precise and honest, yet compassionate. And so I became a fan of "Healthstyles," even if it meant missing a lunch rich in fats and empty calories.
It's the least I can do. These are embattled times for nurses. While female healers are no longer burned at the stake, they are subjected to the modern equivalent, being dismissed and replaced with billing clerks. In the city alone, the State Health Department predicts, more than 3,000 hospital-based registered nurses are expected to lose their jobs in the next three years. I imagine that one of them may very well be the person who doesn't respond when I press my call button in the middle of a hospital night. 
 "Healthstyles," an informative mix of interviews, readings and call-ins, was founded in 1979 as a monthly show called "everywomanspace" by two nurses, Diane Mancino and Paula Tedesco. The current producers and moderators are all nurses at major medical centers. Their show is the rarest of voices in the current health care debate -- an outreach to the medical consumer, open to feelings, long on sharing information and refreshingly free of surgeons who sound like fighter pilots.
"Whoa, no doc-bashing please," said Barbara Glickstein, slightly red-eyed from editing a show on organ transplants. "We are not whiny nurses; this is not a negative show. We promote the positive. You know about the Child Life program at Bellevue? A national model. I grew up on the Lower East Side and went to Bellevue and got better pediatric care than a lot of rich kids who went to private physicians. Child Life has Bank Street developmental workers, nurses, docs, dealing with the whole child."
"Doctors and nurses collaborate, but their roles are different," said Diana J. Mason, a director of education and research with a Ph.D. "Doctors treat the disease. We treat you, get you out of bed, teach you the breathing exercises, involve your family. We talk to you about preventing the disease or minimizing its effects, and we're listening to you and looking for clues about what else might be going on."
"It's a cliche, I know, I know," said Ms. Trambert, waving a hand without a needle, "but we use the word empowerment a lot. We want people to be able to help themselves, find the support groups, the alternative options. Nursing is about dealing with the real things, the constipation after surgery, sex, urinating, eating, the quality of life after the crisis."
We were sitting around a table talking about nurse radio and the delicate balances of a highly trained profession -- predominantly female in a male-dominated subculture -- struggling to shed old images of witch or handmaiden while holding onto old images of intuitive caregiver, toucher, comforter. Along with Gwen Alford and Belinda Wheeler, the three nurses have produced shows ahead of the wave on assisted suicide and suicide prevention; the politics of pain, and violence as a public health issue. On any given Friday, you might learn about the overlap between nurse practitioners and primary-care physicians; how to talk sex to your kids, and what to ask first when you're picking a hospital (what's the nurse-patient ratio?). The tone tends to be firm, calm, upbeat and very direct.
"New York City is behind the times in many ways," said Dr. Mason. "While it's the mecca for research and high-tech medicine, it's not progressive in certain aspects of patient care where nurses are involved. In smaller communities, nurses and doctors often run in the same social circles, which is not true here. So class as well as gender issues play out bigger."
Ms. Glickstein, who has master's degrees in public health and urban planning, thinks that most doctors enter medical school filled with altruism, but that their "inner light" is often destroyed by residency.
"The big thing now is 'patient satisfaction.' Docs are told to be more humanistic for economic reasons. I don't care how they come around as long as they do. They need to be more like nurses."
AIDS, the nurses agreed, has had an enormous impact on attitudes. As young health workers see other young people die, they must confront not only their own mortality but their inability to triumph over disease.
"This is why so many nurses volunteer for AIDS or hospice duty," said Dr. Mason. "It's back to basic nursing, about symptom management and caring, not curing."
"Something we want to do in the program," said Ms. Glickstein, "is help people recognize that an illness is not self-defining. It doesn't become who you are. And that you can be challenged by change."
"We'd like everyone to recognize that nurses are very cost-effective," said Dr. Mason. "When a nurse makes sure that a mother knows how to hydrate her newborn properly, she won't be back in a few days with a dehydrated baby. And another thing: I don't order a lot of tests."

HEADLINE: THE NIGHT;
Splendor in the Glass, 3 Kings, Many Menorahs

BYLINE: By BOB MORRIS 

 BODY:
DOWNTOWN -- En Garde Arts, the site-specific theater company, had a site-specific benefit on Dec. 5. It was held on the vast, unfinished 51st floor of one of those Wall Street financial towers with offices so high up that they seem almost above the law as well as the city.
 "Great performance in a great setting," Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan borough president, said from a lectern in front of floor-to-ceiling windows that were looking out at a glittering panorama of the metropolis. "That's what En Garde Arts is all about, and I submit to you that that's what New York is all about, too." 
 The guests, including Wendy Wasserstein, Madeline Kahn and Brendan Gill, who were sitting at tables under exposed insulation and strings of light bulbs, seemed to agree with that. They also applauded Ms. Messinger's stalwart promise that much of the Manhattan waterfront below would be converted to parkland for public use over the next decade.
 But if New York is all about great performances in great settings, it's also a playground where everybody who wants be included in the game learns to get along. Donald J. Trump, whose plans to develop part of the Upper West Side waterfront have been one of the major controversies of Ms. Messinger's tenure, didn't make any speeches. But he was there, waiting to see Marla Maples Trump preside as the Queen of New York in a special performance of a play by Ms. Wasserstein. It took a poke at him even before his wife had a chance to deliver her lines.
 "I love this parade," Sarah Jessica Parker said to Michael J. Fox in a scene in which they watched the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade. "It reminds me of New York before there were Benetton shops and a Trump Organization."
 UPTOWN -- "Nobody asked me to play one of the Three Kings," Charles Kuralt was saying backstage at Avery Fisher Hall on Dec. 5 before a performance of "Bending Towards the Light," a jazz version of the Nativity, "but I was sort of hoping they would."
 Mr. Kuralt, the former CBS News correspondent, would have to content himself with introducing the 10-year-old nontraditional tradition (which was performed last year at a synagogue).
 The Three Kings were being played by the jazzmen Tito Puente, Jon Faddis and Jimmy Slyde.
 "I love this event," said the jolly Mr. Kuralt, who would have looked terrific in a Santa suit. "When you first hear that they're going to swing 'Silent Night,' you worry, but it has a very reverent feeling. Jazz is just the thing to get you into a spiritual mood."
 A little later, when "The First Noel" was wafting out of a shepherd's saxophone and drifting up toward the concert hall's heavenly heights, the Three Kings (who don't appear until the end of the Nativity, as anybody familiar with the story knows) had just finished being dressed.
 "This king's for hire," said Mr. Slyde, 67, who has danced with Honi Coles and Gregory Hines. With tap shoes in hand to avoid making a racket, he joined his fellow Kings on their pilgrimage: they went up in an elevator, then down some stairs into the backstage darkness, where no light from the east or anyhere else was there to guide them.
 "Watch your train," Mr. Faddis, the trumpet player and music director of the Carnegie Hall Jazz Band, told Mr. Puente, the Latin percussionist.
 They emerged into the brightly lighted terrazzo desert of the lobby (they'd be making their entrance from the back of the hall) and were held there by a kindly stage manager, while Gail Wynters as the Virgin Mary finished singing a jazz lullaby inside.
 Finally, the doors were opened, and to the raucous swells of a big-band version of "We Three Kings," they stepped inside and down the aisles to present the gift of their talents.
 DOWNTOWN -- "It feels so weird to have my menorah in my backpack," Jon Nalley was saying on Dec. 1 at the Brecht Forum educational center on West 27th Street, where he placed his menorah next to some others on a table for a ceremonial group lighting.
 Mr. Nalley, an openly gay member of Community School Board 2, was at a combination Hanukkah Festival and Commemoration of World AIDS Day, organized by a group called Jews for Racial and Economic Justice. "During the Berkeley sit-ins of 1964, the students lit menorahs, too," he said.
 A little later, with matches at the ready, Mr. Nalley joined a circle of about 100 people who expressed as much faith in the power of political action as they did in prayer, and who were also feeling somewhat dimmed by November's election results.
 "It's a very dark time in this city of ours," said Rabbi Ellen Levine, who works for a Jewish hunger relief organization called Mazon. "In very dark times, we want to try to light up the night. And when we light these menorahs, we have to think about how we ourselves are going to become the candles."
 The program that followed included dreidel-playing, post-modern dancing, singing and some political speechifying that emphasized the Hanukkah story as one of refusal and insurrection. As is the age-old tradition with political meetings, talent shows and school assemblies, the evening went on for a long, long time. So long that by the time the last comforting latke had been eaten and the last song sung, the candles of the menorahs had gone out.
 But even then, it seemed that nobody wanted to go home.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 14, 1994, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
A report in the Night column in the Styles pages on Sunday about a Hanukkah festival and commemoration of World AIDS Day organized by Jews for Racial and Economic Justice and held at the Brecht Forum on Dec. 1 misidentified one participant. She was Rabbi Ellen Lippmann, the director of the New York regional office of Mazon, a Jewish hunger-relief organization, not Rabbi Ellen Levine.

HEADLINE: Coming In From the Cold: A Fur Lovers' Backlash

BYLINE: By JULIA SZABO 

 BODY:
FOUR years ago, a New York record company executive who lives with two cats adopted from the North Shore Animal League bought herself a full-length female ranch mink coat. Shortly after that, she witnessed an antifur protest in front of Fred the Furrier, a Fifth Avenue shop that has since gone out of business, and she began to feel less and less comfortable about wearing her coat on the street.
 Eventually, fearing verbal assaults, paint splattering, egg hurling or some other form of antifur harassment, she put her fur into storage, where it remained until last December, when she began wearing it again. And two weeks ago, she ordered it out of storage again in preparation for winter. 
 With determination and misgivings, weighing a desire to stay warm and look good against fear of social pressure, many women are planning to wear fur again. This trend is not a reversal of the one against wearing fur; rather, it's a backlash by fur wearers who have felt intimidated in the last few years. Some are taking furs out of prolonged storage, and some are buying new or used furs. Others are buying parkas, sweaters and anoraks with fur trim. Most have struggled with the specter of threats and intimidation -- real or exaggerated -- but have decided that wearing fur is a matter of choice rather than a moral issue.
 The record company executive said she overcame her fear of public ridicule after doing volunteer work with terminally ill babies, which made her feel there were far worse things in the world than wearing fur. "I'm very much a staunch supporter of the First Amendment," she said. "They have a right to their opinion and to protest, and I have a right to my opinion and to wear fur."
 Despite her anger at the antifur movement, she is still cautious. Like many women who have decided to wear fur, she spoke on condition that she not be identified, concerned that her employers would think less of her for wearing fur. She will wear her fur to work, she said, but will take it off and fold it inside out before taking the elevator to her company's offices. "That way, I don't offend them, they don't offend me, and I can enjoy my fur and stay warm," she said.
 Some statistics seem to support the anecdotal accounts of women planning to wear fur again. "Every year there's a carry-over of coats that are brought in for storage that the women do not take out and wear," said Bob Selden of Goldin Feldman, a Manhattan furrier that offers storage services. "I'd say this year the percentage is significantly lower than in previous years, which means that more women are taking their coats out for whatever reason -- I assume to be worn."
 Fur retrieval is also up at Madame Paulette, a dry cleaner on the Upper East Side that offers fur storage. George Melidosian, who handles the furs, said that 280 pieces were retrieved in the last few weeks alone, compared with 200 in all of last year.
 Nonetheless, for every woman who's planning to wear fur again, there are plenty of women who are deciding this is the year not to wear fur, in deference to the wishes of friends, employers and children.
 Dan Mathews, a chief strategist for People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, an antifur group, asserts that fewer people are wearing furs and that those who do in New York are generally foreigners. But the fur industry, which has faced problems quite apart from the antifur movement, including a prolonged recession and several warm winters before last year's deep freeze, says sales are up.
 KAREN HANDEL, a spokeswoman for the Fur Information Council of America, says fur sales have risen 20 percent in the last two years, from $1 billion in 1991 to $1.2 billion in 1993. But at the same time, many designers have abandoned fur, including Calvin Klein, Donna Karan, Giorgio Armani, Bill Blass, Ralph Lauren, Isaac Mizrahi and Todd Oldham.
 One reason people may be feeling more at ease wearing fur is that it is becoming harder for fur lovers and haters alike to tell the difference between real and fake furs, so advanced is the technology employed by makers of synthetic pelts. Some designers even combine real and fake pelts in the same coat. Karl Lagerfeld, for one, in his last collection for Fendi, mixed the real and the fake the way his muse, Coco Chanel, once mixed real jewels with paste.
 On lower Broadway, the Canal Jean Company offers a selection of vintage furs priced from $5 to $70, with a few pieces marked as high as $100. Out front, fake furs are jumbled up with their real cousins in bins that invite vigorous investigation. Smaller fur pieces, anything with fur trim and fake fur coats are selling especially well, said the store's merchandise manager, Sandra Cullen.
 Nonetheless, the high profile of the antifur movement has placed many people in the position of having to justify and rationalize their decisions to wear fur. Many fur wearers insist they are humane, animal-loving Americans who are simply exercising their right to freedom of expression.
 "My parents came from China, so it's really hard for me to understand people in this country telling you what you can and cannot wear," said Helen Lee Schifter, a fashion editor at Mademoiselle who owns one fur and two coats with fur trim.
 Shannon McLean, owner of the Cose Belle boutique on East 69th Street, is a vegetarian but owns a fur coat. "I don't go to restaurants and tell people: 'How can you eat meat? Don't you know what it's doing to your system?' " she said.
 For some, buying used furs has helped relieve them of the dual stigma of ostentation and cruelty; their justification for wearing secondhand furs is that it's a form of recycling, the animals in question having died long before animal rights was recognized as an issue.
 "I bought a sable shawl last summer at a thrift shop in Southampton," said Anne Moore, a hat designer. "It's the best thing in the world, and I don't feel guilty because it was killed years ago and it cost only $35."
 Lauren Ezersky, a contributor to Paper magazine, who described herself as "very antifur," said of fur-wearing: "I think that it's kind of passe and a sign of vanity. However, I do have an ermine handbag from the 20's. I bought it at a flea market and I paid almost nothing for it. That animal's been dead for so many years. Why should he go to waste? He was beautiful, and now I'm wearing him."
 Of course, such arguments do not sit well with antifur advocates.
"I think those are the most callous fur wearers of all," Mr. Matthews of People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals said of people who consider themselves animal lovers and wear fur.
 Some complain that fur wearers are unfairly singled out, in a way that meat eaters and leather wearers are not, because fur is primarily women's apparel. "It is an exquisitely, emphatically female piece of iconography," said Marcia Pally, the president of Feminists for Free Expression, an advocacy group, and the author of "Sex and Sensibility: Reflections on Forbidden Mirrors and the Will to Censor" (Ecco Press, 1994). "I remain concerned and troubled by what I think is veiled misogyny in the antifur movement. I notice that people do not go after leather, which is iconographically more male than female, and I think one question that needs to be asked is, Why the tremendous rage against women who wear fur?"
 "It's not a women's issue," said Ingrid Newkirk, the founder of People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals. "Whoever is wearing fur hears from people who are appalled by the pain and suffering and death, and women should not be considered so frail that we have to be insulated from criticism. If we are doing something that's appalling, it doesn't matter what gender, what race, what age, what anything we are -- cruelty is cruelty."

HEADLINE: Connecticut Q&A: George F. Cloutier;
Pines, Pure Water and Lots of Wildlife

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
THIS is the time of year when everyone is fixated on trees, particularly the Christmas products of Connecticut's tree farms. And among tree farmers, George F. Cloutier of Ballamahack Road in Windham, the state's Tree Farmer of the Year, is considered one of the best.
Mr. Cloutier, 72 years old, is a 1949 graduate of the forestry program at the University of Connecticut. A forest fire spotter in Idaho, he later joined the International Paper Company in Maine and New Hampshire before returning to Connecticut to take various forestry jobs and retiring in 1978 as acting state forester. 
 During a recent stroll on the fire roads that crisscross his 110-acre property, Mr. Cloutier discussed the Christmas tree business and the role it plays in forest management. Following are excerpts from the conversation.
Q. How much land do you need for a Christmas tree farm?
A. I've got about an acre and a half. That gives me crop of a couple of hundred trees a year in a 10-year rotation. I used to have about 15 acres but the gypsy moths came in and wiped them right out.
Q. What do people want?
A. They want spruce, and they want fir. Spruce is an easy one, it's very compact, but it doesn't hold its needles as well. Fir is the premium one. I've got Fraser fir from the southern Appalachians, a wonderful tree, and Douglas fir from out West. Balsam fir is all right if you grow it up north -- I've got 10,000 down here that aren't worth the powder to blow them up.
Q. What are the main advantages of Christmas trees for a farmer?
A. They make money. That's why I'm back in the Christmas tree business. And they're a fast crop. But it's also a heck of a lot of hard work.
Q. What's the work?
A. Trimming, clearing around them, and keeping them healthy. Everybody wants a prime, beautiful, unmarked Christmas tree, but they're hard to come by. A certain percentage of your Christmas trees will be perfect without you doing anything to them. But the greatest percentage of them, you have to work like a dog on.
And then there are the different tastes -- some like them open grown, others like them so dense you can hardly put anything on them.
Q. From a grower's perspective, what's the perfect tree?
A. Well, the average house ceiling is about seven feet tall, so let's say a six-and-a-half footer. It's medium density to maybe full density. And it should be a conical shape opening to a 30 to 60 degree slope from top to bottom, and it should be four inches in diameter at the base, so you can put it in a stand. But some people are very choosy, and some people are not. Trees that I wouldn't touch, someone will come in and fall in love.
Q. What percentage of trees meet those criteria?
A. That depends. If you control the brush the first seven or eight years, 60 or 70 percent of them might be. But if they're not growing in good, open sunlight, it might be 30 percent.
Q. Is there any use for trees that don't meet the grade for Christmas?
A. Just let them grow. Christmas trees evolved from timber plantations. They would plant the trees close together to get good form and high branches, then every 10 years they'd go in and clear some out, and the thinnings would become Christmas trees. When they got too big, the thinnings were used for something else, pulpwood or boughs or whatever. Eventually what was left was used for timber.
Q. How long has tree farming been around?
A. The tree farm program was started right after World War II, but there have been tree farmers around since the 1890's. Most farmers didn't care very much for the woodland, but some did and took very good care of it. Certain species, clearcutting is the only way to grow them. But you should cut in patches, never destroy a large enough area that you lose the feel of the forest. And that kind of management can be beneficial. Wildlife, particularly birds, are creatures of the edge, so they're going to have more area to live.
Q. Does tree farming ever really pay the rent?
A. Only on rare occasions. You have to have a lot of agricultural land close to a large population for Christmas trees. But the competition is getting very stiff -- everyone wants to get in on it. A crop of timber, on the other hand, takes 60 to 80 years to grow. Any one landowner today probably has it for 20 or 25 years, so all you do is build up the equity in it. You'd need a minimum of 2,000 or 3,000 acres for a working tree farm, and there's no such a property left today in Connecticut.
Q. Is tree farming less bothersome to neighbors than other forms of agriculture?
A. Yes and no. It certainly doesn't have the odors, or the continual noise. But some neighbors are pretty darned fussy about what you're doing. They don't even want you cutting down a tree. Do you know there are towns that are outlawing tree cutting in certain places because people are afraid it's going to destroy the view? This is private, tax-paying property, and you're not allowed to cut the trees because it destroys someone's esthetics. We've got to shut those people off.
Q. Besides the Christmas trees, do you plant the others, or tend what's there naturally?
A. There's some planting. I collect red oak seed, which is about our superior hardwood right now, and every time I take a walk I spread them out, Johnny Appleseed style. But sometimes it doesn't pay to plant. Out there I planted 1,000 or 2,000 hemlock trees every year for 40 years, and almost all are gone because of the deer population explosion. Usually you don't plant trees unless you're in an open field and all the old fields have grown into hardwood forests. You might introduce species to help wildlife, such as a crab apple or elderberry, or plant something that you don't have, but you're always bucking Mother Nature when you do that.
Q. Do foresters ever make the wrong decision about what to plant?
A. Well, when I was on the state Agricultural Stabilization and Conservation committee we heard about this wonderful shrub in Pennsylvania, multiflora rose. And another, autumn olive. So we brought them in and planted them, and they turned out to be great for wildlife, but they also turned out to be noxious weeds. We can't control their spread.
Q. So we don't have as much control as we'd like to think?
A. Mother Nature does a lot to govern any management that you try to do. She changes it at her will. She's got wind storms and heavy snows and ice storms. Anyone who thinks they're smart enough to control an entire ecosystem is a nut.
Q. What benefits do we derive from the forest other than wood?
A. You're producing drinking water, primarily. You're protecting the watershed. You're preventing pollution. The forests filter the water going into the ground, and going into the streams and rivers. Every time we put in a highway or a house lot, we put in drainage ditches and culverts to direct rain water down to the nearest stream, instead of putting it off onto the land like it used to be. You know any trout streams left in Connecticut? Darned few. Because so many of the forests are gone.
Over there I've got a stand of maple, and I get maple syrup out of it. I've got walnut trees, and blueberry and raspberry. There's lot of wild turkey in here, beaver and otters, mink and weasel, all the waterbirds you can think of, hawks and owls. This used to be farmland too poor to support people, but now it's supporting forest crops and wildlife.
Q. Do people understand the need for forest management?
A. People don't understand. When they start teaching in the schools that you don't cut trees, something's wrong. Where are you going to get paper for writing or books, or pencils? We need wood for furniture and houses. The problem is the lawyers who are making policies where it should be left up to the natural resource managers. We've got 3 million acres of land in Connecticut, more or less. And 1 million of it is already developed, or maybe a little more. There's about 1.5 million acres left of forest land. We need a million acres at least to protect our watershed. Long Island Sound is dying because of what we're doing in the forests. We've got to zone it to protect it. But they bring in lawyers to make decisions in natural resource management, and you're going to get the wrong decisions.
Q. Is Christmas tree farming important to forest preservation, or is it too tightly managed?
A. Even land in Christmas trees is a good forest. It filters the water supply, and it provides habitat for wildlife. Lots of trees are never going to make it as Christmas trees; they're going to stay in the ground. And as soon as you cut a section, you're going to get another crop in. It will always be covered with trees. You can't do any economic forestry on 5 or 10 acres -- you've got to have large tracts of land. And if you want to collect and filter water, and have all the amenities that go with forest land, you can't afford to continue to chew up the forests. All our land is going into development, and some day it's going to catch up to us.

GRAPHIC: Photo: George F. Cloutier, forester, on his Windham acreage. (Janet Durrans for The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: December 11, 1994

SECTION: Section 3; Page 11; Column 3; Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1848 words

HEADLINE: Viewpoints;
U.S. Decline? Not in Golf Balls, Mister!

BYLINE: By BILL GEIST; Bill Geist is a correspondent for CBS News and a former "About New York" columnist for The New York Times. This article is adapted from his most recent book, "Monster Trucks and Hair-in-a-Can: Who Says America Doesn't Make Anything Anymore" (G. P. Putnam's Sons).

 BODY:
I KNOW, I know: America doesn't make baseballs any more, no VCR's or fax machines; steelworkers and farmers are endangered species; the balance of trade has completely lost its equilibrium, and our top companies have lost a third of their jobs to places like Mexico at 10 cents on the dollar.
But to those who lament the post-industrial economy's going to hell in a handbasket, let me say a few inspiring words. Monster trucks, aerosol hair, fingernail technology, Elvis impersonators and, yes, used golf balls. 
 It's a high, arching drive off the eighth tee at Grand Cypress, a beautiful drive, sailing through blue skies this spring morn in Orlando, Fla.
And yet . . . the drive is beginning its initial descent a bit . . . early . . . it seems, its path carrying it well short of the green, toward splashdown in this altogether charming (to the landscape architect) little -- kerplop! -- lake.
"Attaboy! One more time!" whoops Jim Reid, sitting idly by in a golf cart by the water hazard. He would. He is the Used Golf Ball King of Florida. And therefore the World!
Where others see grief and frustration, he sees opportunity. "Basically, I profit from the mistakes of others," Jim says.
Next comes a ball struck rather poorly, flying low as if to evade radar detection and skipping once! . . . twice! . . . three times! on the waters, before sinking to Davy Jones's pro shop below.
"It's a sweet sound, isn't it?" Jim asks, leaning back comfortably, one foot on the dash of the golf cart, listening to the sound of palm fronds in the breeze punctuated by the bloop! plop! kerplunk! of golf balls upon the waters.
Anyone can play golf; fortunately for Jim Reid, not very well. (In my own case, if I want to play 18 holes, I have to do it on the longest day of the year.) And golf is growing fast -- more and more people every day are not playing the game very well. Florida alone has more than 1,000 courses.
And even as the level of play is going down, golf-course design is becoming more spectacular, with larger and more abundant water hazards, many of a size that, were they in Arizona, developers would be putting up 1,200 condominium units around them and calling them "Pollo del Mar." This is all to the good, the way Jim sees it.
JIM moved to Florida from Oklahoma a few years ago, to leave the rat race for paradise.
But things turned out a little differently from planned. Jim took a job as a surveyor with Walt Disney World, pulling down about $250 a week. His wife, Beverly, took a job with the phone company. They bought a little house. Not all that different from Oklahoma when you got right down to it. They sat in traffic with the air conditioner on instead of the heater. And they worried about hurricanes instead of tornadoes.
But Jim did get to go scuba diving once in a while. And one day, he put on his gear and hopped into a water hazard on the Rolling Hills golf course in Longwood to see what he could see.
"I dove down to the bottom," he recalls, leaning back in his golf cart, "and what I saw was amazing. The entire bottom was solid white. Golf balls. Thousands of golf balls. White gold!"
He scooped up a bunch and examined them in the daylight. "Most of them looked just like new," he said. He showed them to the course manager, who offered Jim 10 cents a ball.
Jim dove back in. He came up with more than 2,000 balls that day, making almost as much in a few hours as Disney World paid him for a week.
After talking it over with Beverly, he took the plunge and quit his job at Disney World.
"It was kind of embarrassing" at first, he says. "When people ask what you do for a living and you say you work at Disney World in Orlando, they say, 'Well, this guy's a solid citizen.' But you say your profession is diving in mud holes for golf balls, and they kind of back off, you know?"
But dive he did, and the harvest was plentiful. He brought home carloads of balls and put them in the washing machine. Beverly had supported him in his decision to try this cockamamie scheme but drew the line at destroying her washing machine. She told him to buy his own: a 20-year-old Maytag. A capital investment.
The neighbors didn't much care for the idea either, listening to 500 golf balls go round and round in the washing machine until all hours of the night (you'll recall the racket of just one tennis shoe in a dryer). So Jim did what he had to do. He hired the neighbors.
And he experimented with the technology. "You don't just open up the Yellow Pages and look for used golf-ball processing equipment," he notes, correctly. For a while he cleaned the balls in a cement mixer. But that scoured the dimples completely off the balls, making them behave peculiarly coming off the tee. A golf pro complained about this, but called back to say maybe it wasn't such a bad thing after all -- everybody was signing up for lessons.
Jim and his staff of neighbors washed the balls, then perched them on nails and spray-painted them for that "Like New" look. They boxed them up by brand and by condition for resale, often at half the price of new balls.
Word spread, and other divers became interested in this promising Golf Ball Recycling Industry. Jim began buying balls from other divers. Soon, 18-wheelers were backing up to his garage, bringing old muddy balls and taking them away Like New. He finally had to move his business, called Second Chance, to an industrial area.
"When I quit my job," he said, "I figured I'd have to find 2,500 golf balls a week to break even" -- to get back the $250 a week he made at Disney.
Fortunately for Jim, last year he found 10 million golf balls.
I mean, like, so what if America's not making steel anymore! One single citizen with entrepreneurial spirit is retrieving more golf balls than the rest of the world combined!
"HOW'S the fishing today?" yells Jim, greeting one of his divers, who is backing up to the loading dock with bags of balls in his pickup truck. Remember the sponge divers of Tarpon Springs? No? Well, these are the Used Golf Ball Divers of Orlando, the epicenter of the golf boom, where Used Golf Ball Diving is becoming a full-time, full-fledged occupation. Soon the Teamsters will be trying to take it over. Students will be able to major in Used Golf Ball Diving at Florida State.
But environmentalists needn't worry. America's oyster and clam beds may be dying from over-fishing and water pollution, but not Florida's golf-ball beds.
"Some of them completely replenish themselves in a couple of weeks," Jim says, amazed. But then, some 200 million new golf balls are manufactured every year. And where do they all go? Gone to hazards every one. When will they ever learn? "Never, I hope," Jim replies.
All manner of species thrive in these waters: the Spalding, Max-Fli, Top-Flite, personalized balls (Jim Harrison, Jim Reid has found your golf ball), balls imprinted with the Lord's Prayer.
The beds yield other treasures, too: bicycles, X-rated videos, murder weapons -- occasionally even the murderees themselves! The divers find lots of golf clubs, hurled into the water by temperamental golfers. One diver has 200 clubs at home.
"Pretty good day," says Tony Chastain, a meat-cutter turned diver. "About 2,500 balls."
"Get 'em over at Grand Cypress?" Jim asks.
"Yeah. Right off the tee there on the ninth," Tony replies, graciously divulging a hot spot to the other divers.
Al appreciates it. He's a little disappointed with his catch: 1,383. "One day I netted 4,500 over at Pelican Bay. Now that was a day."
Jim Reid pays the divers 8 cents a ball. Waders -- who retrieve them with their toes from the shallows -- get 10 cents. It's a skill thing.
One diver, Dan Beecher, retrieved 600,000 balls one year. He makes about $50,000 a year, and drives an El Camino with a car phone.
But Tony says it's no picnic out there. "It takes a different breed of person to be down there hour after hour in the dark with snakes and eels and your imagination." Others talk of stepping on broken glass and jagged pieces of metal. Several divers have been struck by golf balls, one lost a finger to a snapping turtle and Jim Reid himself was hit by lightning while under water.
And golf-ball diving is a craft. Bob Cooke has retrieved more than three million balls, and he is a pro in every sense of the word. "I don't wear gloves," he says. "You've got to feel the balls. Gloves'll cut down your take 30 to 40 percent." Analysis is part of the game, too. "Most golfers are right-handed," he says, "and most slice the ball, so you work the hazards on the right side of the fairway."
About 50,000 golf balls a day(!) arrive at Second Chance from courses as far away as Hawaii. They are counted, rinsed and then marinated in a vat of Jim's secret sauce, a whitener. And he does mean secret. His workers sign a five-page pledge not to divulge its contents. The business has become lucrative and competitive.
The business has become structured, too, even to the point where Jim pays golf courses up to $2,000 a month to mine their water hazards. "Once I pick the balls up, I own them," he explains. "Legally, they're abandoned property."
After the balls are soaked in his secret whitening sauce, they're sprayed with a clear acrylic formula that is, likewise, top secret. The balls are then sorted by condition and brand name by three people who drop them into a Rube Goldberg contraption with PVC pipe going every which way. Jim didn't order that monstrosity out of the Yellow Pages either. He built it.
Some of the balls in poor condition are sold to cruise ships, on which passengers practice their drives into the ultimate water hazard. Other bad balls -- get this! -- are used in counter-poaching. If Jim finds extensive poaching on courses where he has the rights, he'll dump them into the water to make the poachers work for hours picking up worthless balls. Yes, he carries it that far.
THAT'S how Jim Reid became the Used Golf Ball King of Florida. In 1993, his company had gross revenues of about $1 million. His factory had gone to two shifts, and he was buying and selling on the world market. About one-third of the sales went to Europe; one-third to pro shops in this country; and one-third to chain stores. One big customer: Wal-Mart. And he started to prefer the term "reconditioned" to "used" for his product, if you don't mind.
"The only thing that could hurt me," he said, with no trace of a smile, "is if one of the major companies comes up with a floating golf ball. That won't happen. It would hurt them worse. The way it is now, everybody makes money but the guy who hits the ball."
But what did happen is that Jim sold out. He recently got $5.1 million for Second Chance from Sport Supply Group, a Dallas company traded on the New York Stock Exchange.
So. Jim Reid found paradise, just as he'd planned when he moved from Oklahoma. At 50, he is retired, spending much of his time on his 53-foot boat, cruising from Fort Pierce down to the Bahamas and over to the Keys. But he doesn't play golf. Not really fond of the game.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: December 12, 1994

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 2; National Desk 

LENGTH: 3105 words

HEADLINE: One Family's Cursed Heirloom: Homicide

SERIES: When Trouble Starts Young -- A periodic report.

BYLINE: By DON TERRY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MILWAUKEE, Dec. 11

 BODY:
When other children were hearing fairy tales, Garland Hampton heard bedtime stories about the day Uncle Robert killed two Milwaukee police officers, or the time Grandma, with both barrels, blew away the father of two of her children back in '62. By the time he was 9, he had seen his mother kill her boyfriend.
Now, at 15, locked up in the County Jail and awaiting trial on murder charges, Garland is still enough of a child that he is afraid he might cry when darkness falls. 
 But he is old enough to have had a nasty past of his own, too: at 10, there was trouble about stolen bicycles; at 12, he was picked up for shooting and wounding a gang rival; at 14, for carrying a .357 Magnum and a bag of cocaine, and now, for gunning down a fellow gang member. Prosecutors say he is an adolescent menace to society, who must pay for his sins like a man.
Garland just says he is scared.
"I guess I been scared all my life," said Garland, a stocky boy with a hint of a 70's-style Afro, who cried as he talked about his life. "For me, living has been the same as running through hell with a gasoline suit on. I don't want people feeling sorry for me, but I really ain't had nothing good happen to me. The ax fell heavy on my head."
The trajectory of Garland's life so far was not inevitable: indeed, many children whose family lives are enmeshed in violence and neglect never get into trouble with the law themselves.
"Not all kids from violent families will be violent themselves," said Patrick H. Tolan, an associate professor of psychiatry and psychology at the University of Illinois in Chicago. "But the more violence that kids are exposed to, the greater the likelihood that they will become violent. If you're going to bet on somebody, he's got the history."
In Garland's family history, violence was like a cursed heirloom, passed from generation to generation. As a little boy, Garland wanted no part of that legacy. He used to stay up late, on a kind of guard duty, afraid that the grown-ups drinking and screaming in the next room would kill each other.
When he was 9, they did. His mother spent 14 months in prison on manslaughter charges for killing her boyfriend as he slapped her around the kitchen and slammed her into a radiator during an argument over money. She was pregnant with the man's baby, their third child, her fifth. Garland saw the shooting while hiding behind the washing machine a few feet away and smelled the gun's smoke as it curled upward like a lost spirit.
"I seen him die on the floor," Garland said. "I always called him Daddy. He was one of the only people who was nice to me. He used to talk to me about being a man."
Garland is not yet a man, but the family legacy of fighting, and killing, has already passed to him. In June, Garland had his own argument over money with Donell T. Storks, another 15-year-old in his gang. In a few minutes, Donell was dead, two bullet holes in his head, and Garland was headed for jail and judgment.
 
The Studies
A Volatile Mix: Neglect and Abuse
 Garland could hardly have been groomed for a life of crime and punishment any better if his family had followed a set of instructions.
Experts in criminal justice, psychology, and child development all cite precisely the experiences of his upbringing as the major factors that lead children to become violent: neglect, abuse, inconsistent parents, a violent neighborhood and family members who engage in violence themselves.
"The family is the most powerful predictor for a child becoming violent," said Byron Egeland, professor of child development at the University of Minnesota. "Clearly the family is crucial in understanding the violence we're seeing in the streets. The streets may have something to do with it, but it's what the kid brings to the street that I think is the most important."
While it is impossible to predict how an infant will be affected by a childhood of violence, fear or neglect -- and indeed, many children are remarkably resilient -- there is no doubt that children learn their most important behavioral lessons, healthful or unhealthful, from their families.
"The family is the strongest socializing influence for a young child," said Kathleen Kostelny, a senior research associate at the Erikson Institute for Advanced Study in Child Development in Chicago. "Kids who experience violence in their community and violence in their home are at a greatly increased risk for a whole host of bad developmental outcomes."
Children who come from families in which a close relative has been incarcerated have an especially high likelihood of getting into trouble with the law themselves. Justice Department studies based on data from the late 1980's show that more than half the juvenile delinquents imprisoned in high-security reformatories had close relatives who had also been incarcerated.
Children who have suffered neglect or abuse, too, are more likely than others to turn to crime. In a 1992 study, The Cycle of Violence, for the National Institute of Justice, an office of the Justice Department, Cathy Spatz Widom, a criminology professor at the State University of New York at Albany, reported that "being abused or neglected as a child increased the likelihood of arrest as a juvenile by 53 percent, as an adult by 38 percent, and for a violent crime by 38 percent." One estimate put the number of child abuse and neglect cases last year at 1.9 million.
Professor Widom says, however, that while violent, abusive homes increase the odds that children will end up in jail, "it's by no means inevitable." Most of these children never have run-ins with the law, she said. Many other factors, including neighborhood, school, peers, access to firearms -- and luck -- play a role in who pulls a trigger and who doesn't, who goes to prison and who goes to college.
Not many children have witnessed as much bloodshed as Garland or come from a family so quick to pull a gun or a knife to settle disputes. Not many know, as Garland did, that they can get a pistol any time from beneath their grandmother's mattress.
But America is full of children who have seen so many fathers beating up mothers, so many playground gang fights and so many years of bloodletting on the big and small screen, that they could easily think that violence is as natural as eating or sleeping, that everybody does it.
This can be especially true in the neighborhoods like Garland's on Milwaukee's North Side, where resources are few, frustrations high and most of the youth programs and decent jobs long gone.
"The extra-home social supports have deteriorated to almost nothing," said Dr. Bruce Perry, chief of psychiatry at the Texas Children's Hospital in Houston. "These kids are really left adrift. The truth is we made these kids. Our culture is reaping what it sowed."
The harvest is as bitter as it is plentiful. Almost everyone in these places knows someone who died a violent, early death. But the deadly mix of children and violence is not confined to the inner city. The offspring of abuse and neglect can be found almost anywhere in the nation: in Appalachian hollows and in comfortable suburbs.
And they can be found in white, working-class neighborhoods like the South Side of Milwaukee, where 16-year-old David Newbury and another native son, Mark Rea, sexually assaulted and then clubbed to death a 15-year-old classmate, Charlene Dvorak, near Pulaski Park in 1993.
David's court records and other documents reveal a childhood of domestic violence, alcoholic parents, beatings with belts and fists, cruel words and indifference. His parents did not attend his murder trial. Before he was sentenced last year to life in prison, David told a probation agent, "I lived like I was treated."
 
The Family
'Shotgun Mamma' Filled in as Mother
 "Garland had a lot of potential," Janet Mayfield, one of Garland's seventh grade teachers, said in an interview. "He still does. He's caring and smart. This didn't have to happen. All he ever needed was some love and a chance to get out of his environment."
Those charged with protecting the city's children were well aware of that environment. Case workers and probation and police officers had been keeping track of Garland and his family since he was 2 years old.
In 1988, he and his six younger siblings were removed from the custody of their mother, Willie Jean Hampton, because of her drug use and allegations that the children were being abused and neglected.
But they weren't sent far. They were placed with their grandmother, Fay Lee McCoy, nicknamed Shotgun Mama or Grandma Gauge since as she puts it, "people in the neighborhood know I've killed before."
Mrs. McCoy did not hide her history. She bragged like a soldier home from the front, telling everyone -- family, neighbors and even case workers -- that in her 67 years she had killed several people. Only one killing could be confirmed: the slaying of her boyfriend in Arkansas in 1962.
"I don't believe she killed all them people she said she did," said Marie Grant, a friend of Mrs. McCoy for almost 30 years. "She gave the kids those impressions so the kids would be afraid of her. It worked. They thought violence was a way of life."
One case worker wrote in Garland's file that although Mrs. McCoy did "not reflect the image of a perfect substitute parent," the children preferred her to their mother and accepted Mrs. McCoy as "the most stable and secure alternative to their turbulent past life style."
Over the years, the children went back and forth between the two women. When they lived with their grandmother, the household often included their mother, her half-sister Melinda Collins and Ms. Collins's son. Always, they lived in neighborhoods where gang members owned the hallways, selling drugs and women's bodies and firing their guns in the middle of the afternoon.
Garland has never met his father, who walked out while Garland was being born. His whereabouts are unknown.
What finally took Garland away from his family was his 1991 arrest for shooting into a group of gang rivals and wounding one of them. The Juvenile Court sent him to a detention center, and later a group home.
In 1992, case workers placed six of Ms. Hampton's seven children in foster homes. But Garland, who at 13 had just been released from the group home, was allowed to stay with his grandmother. His mother was still living there.
"Why did they place him back in that house?" Mrs. Grant asked. "They knew the circumstances. I guess the system don't give a damn."
Garland was sent back to the group home in November 1993 for possession of cocaine and a gun. He ran away in March, returning yet again to his grandmother's apartment, and three months later, got into the fight that led to the death of Donell Storks.
 
The Guns
At the Age of 11 A Gift of a Pistol
 When Garland was 10 his grandmother, Mrs. McCoy, pulled him downstairs to the basement and taught him how to handle a pistol. She thought she was doing the right thing. She had grown up poor and hard in the 1930's and 40's in the rural South. Having a shotgun hanging over the bed was as common as wearing hand-me-down shoes.
Mrs. McCoy had to drop out of school in the third grade and go to work picking cotton and figured that Garland had a better life than hers. She just wanted him to know how to protect it on the streets.
A psychologist wrote in the custody case that Mrs. McCoy's instincts were protective but that she had been simply overwhelmed by her family's life and luck. Violence has haunted her family for at least three generations, from Warren, Ark., to Milwaukee, where the family settled in the late 1960's hoping for a better life.
In 1962, during a fight, Mrs. McCoy shot and killed Robert Lee Collins, the father of two of her 17 children. She pleaded guilty to manslaughter and spent a short time in jail.
Her son with Mr. Collins is Garland's Uncle Robert, who is serving two life sentences for murdering two Milwaukee police officers during a robbery and chase in 1981. He was 19 when he was sent away.
Garland started carrying a gun, a pistol his grandmother gave him, at 11. "Everybody I knew was strapped," street slang for armed, he said. "If you weren't strapped, you was risking your life."
And around the time he should have been blowing out the candles for his 12th birthday, Garland shot into a knot of street gang rivals with a .22-caliber rifle, wounding one of them in the chest.
 
The Streets
A War Zone For Life's Lessons
 In Garland's America, there is little time for childhood. "I feel like I been grown my whole life," he said.
Long before he was charged with a murder of his own, Garland had seen neighbors and strangers stabbed, hit with shovels, kicked, beaten, pistol-whipped, threatened, robbed, riddled with bullets, arrested, overdosed, passed out drunk, strangled and zipped into body bags.
One of Garland's elementary school teachers, Lonnie Anderson, a soft-spoken African-American who became Garland's mentor, used to drop him off at home after field trips.
"Our relationship was like father and son," Mr. Anderson said. "I don't think his family even knew his dreams. He wanted to go to college, to play football. You knew you had a person who wanted better in life. I wonder if his family knew what they were doing to him."
Mr. Anderson could see what the streets were doing to him. He would watch Garland get out of his car and with each step down his block, be transformed from a seventh grader still excited by a school outing into a tough guy trying to survive in a tough place. The little boy's face became hard, his gait a swagger, his smile a memory.
"If I had to wear the same pair of pants and walk 10 miles to work every day," Mr. Anderson said, "I wouldn't raise my son in Garland's neighborhood. I don't know what I would have become if I had gone through what that boy has."
Donald Krueger, the former principal at the Bell Middle School, which Garland attended for a couple of years, said Garland had been a "quality kid" despite his troubles.
"There were two Garlands," Mr. Krueger said. "You could see this war going on inside him all the time."
Signs of his internal war appear on his seventh grade report card, where his home economics teacher wrote, "Cooperative and courteous, is a pleasure to have in class." But his science teacher said, "This is a minus grade, lacks respect for authority."
By the end of eighth grade, Garland stopped going to school. The street had called him.
On the street, Garland is known as Boo, a name his family gave him because when he was small he enjoyed jumping out of closets to scare people.
At 15, Garland became a father himself. His 9-month old son, Garland, or Lil Boo, lives with his 15-year-old mother and her grandmother on Chicago's West Side.
"I'm going to be there for Lil Boo," the baby's young mother said. "Garland's mother wasn't there for him. Nobody was."
The baby's grandmother smiled as he tried to stand. "He's a sweet baby," she said. "I hope he stays that way. I'm going to do my best to make sure he does."
 
The Legacy
A Broken Promise Of a Better Life
 Garland's mother, Willie Jean Hampton, was 16 when Garland was born. Now at 32, her soul and spirit are weary from living a life that sounds a lot like her son's.
She said she was abused by her aunt when she and her brother and sister lived with her mother's sister in Kansas City, Kan. "She treated her dogs better than us," she said earlier this fall. "A person who treats kids like that don't need to live."
Now in jail awaiting trial on armed robbery charges, she used to tell Garland about the whippings and the hungry nights that she and her sister and brother had suffered through, and she promised her first born that his life would be better.
"It ain't worked out that way," Garland said. "We were raised just the same as she was." He took a bite of a Kit Kat bar, his favorite candy, and offered a piece to his lawyer, Robin Shellow.
Garland says he wants his son to grow up different than he did. "I want him to grow up with love. I want him to know he has a daddy. Even if I can't be there with him. I'll always love him."
He said he had found more love on the street than at home. His arms are scarred with gang tattoos from around the time he joined the Vice Lords street gang at 11 or 12. One, a champagne glass, is a tribute to ghosts, he said, "to celebrate all the brothers who ain't here no more."
Now Garland is charged with killing one of those brothers himself. Last June 10, shortly before midnight, he and Donell Storks had an argument in an overgrown yard behind an abandoned house.
The two had known each other since age 8 or 9. As members of the Vice Lords, they had run the streets, gambled and bragged about girls together.
Police reports, prosecutors and Garland say that the day before Donell was killed, Garland was given $100 by his grandmother but that he had lost the money and blamed Donell. Garland recruited 18-year-old Kenyetta Helm, another Vice Lord, to help him get the money back, and the three teen-agers stepped into the darkened backyard.
Moments later, Donell was dead, shot twice in the head from a few feet away. Either shot, the coroner reported, was enough to kill the boy.
Garland signed a confession, saying he was sorry for shooting Donell, that he was sorry for everything. Mr. Helm also had his gun out that night. He did not fire it but was convicted of murder and sentenced to life in prison.
Garland says now that he did not tell the police the whole story, about how scared he was that night, how he wet his pants, how he shot Donell in self-defense after Donell pulled his gun, like a wild West gunfighter.
The police say no gun was ever found on Donell. Garland said Mr. Helm had taken it and hidden it, an assertion Mr. Helm denies.
"We were all strapped that night," Garland says. "I wanted to run but I thought Donell would shoot me. I felt like I was going to die. I felt like the world was going to come to an end. I was scared."

HEADLINE: Trade Pact Casts Shadow for Garment Workers

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PEN ARGYL, Pa., Dec. 8

 BODY:
They are scared, angry and frustrated, but mostly scared. Many have worked in the garment mills of Lehigh Valley for 30 years and more. The whine of sewing machines and dust of fabric have become as familiar as early snows and now the threat of unemployment.
While the removal of worldwide trade barriers and the lowering of tariffs under the North American Free Trade Agreement and GATT are expected to help American high-tech and service industries, they mean fear among the nation's garment workers. 
 These are men and women of modest means from modest towns, like this one in the rolling hills above the Allentown-Easton corridor of eastern Pennsylvania, who cut large swaths of cloth and sew together the various elements that become a piece of clothing. They already work for relatively low pay, about $15,000 a year, but they face strong competition from places like Bangladesh, Taiwan, Singapore, where wages are far lower, working conditions bad and benefits virtually nonexistent.
But the rush toward a free trade world, which began during the Reagan and Bush years, is threatening the little security American garment workers still have. Their industry has been in turmoil for more than 30 years, as many of the mills in the North fled to the South and then overseas. In its peak year of 1973, the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union had more than 1.2 million members around the country, mostly women; by June of this year, membership had dropped below 800,000.
In the Lehigh Valley, the decline has been even worse. A study released last month by Thomas Hyclak, a professor of economics at Lehigh University, found that the region lost almost 54 percent of apparel workers from 1972 through 1990. While other types of manufacturing jobs also fled the region in that time, the decline in apparel was one of the steepest.
The area has managed to attract new jobs in insurance, health care and other service industries, but many apparel workers, trained for nothing else, say they have no idea what they could do if their factories closed down. They feel that trade pacts like GATT, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, will jeopardize their well-being.
"It seems like a dying industry," said Tammy Impechiate, a 37-year-old mother of three who works as a seamstress at Fashions by Danielle here, even though her husband, Joseph, is a part owner. "Used to be, there was a blouse mill on every corner. Now, there's only a handful left. Even when I started out of high school 19 years ago, mills were everywhere. Now, it's scary. You don't know if your company is going to close down or if you can get another job. I've got children who want to go to college. I don't know if I can afford to send them."
Mrs. Impechiate is typical of apparel workers in the region. Many finished high school, married young, moved into small houses on an acre or two of land, found a job in the mills and never did anything else. Never had to. For the most part, they led quiet, stable lives.
But through the 1980's, and more so now with the conclusion of the international trade agreements, the feeling of insecurity pervades every garment factory.
Some, like Maryann Corcione, who sews blouses for Scotty's Fashions in Little Gap, Pa., already work a second job to make ends meet. For 12 hours every two weeks she cleans a bank. Her husband, James, is a maintenance worker at a K-Mart.
Mrs. Corcione and others in the plant have already seen life without Scotty's, a family-owned business with five plants in the region. The company shut down for six months two years ago and then called back just over half the 2,100 employees. She was one of the lucky ones.
"I worked at the bank a little more and kept hoping I'd get my job back," she said. "I called every day, asking what was going on."
And if the plant closed again? "I don't know what I'd do," she said. I was a meat-packer once. Maybe I could go back to that field if something happened. Without experience at anything else, forget it."
Many workers say they know of GATT but understand little of the economic theory that says it will make the country richer over all. They believe it is only the latest nail in the garment industry coffin.
But Nancy Shoemaker, a 54-year-old sewer at Anna Sportswear in Pen Argyl, says she understands all right. She follows all the political developments that affect the industry, and GATT makes her boil.
"What's a little person going to say?" she said. "What good does it do to scream our heads off? We're helpless." A single mother with three grown children, she has worked almost 25 of her 59 years in the mills and watched many of her friends lose their jobs.
"The industry I work in is not going to be here in a short while," she said. "Textiles are gone. We ought to have a Boston Tea Party for textiles, bomb the ships as they bring in the goods. Am I afraid? Of course, I'm afraid. Wouldn't you be scared?"
She mustered up a laugh. "I'm going to be on welfare, if the Republicans don't do away with it."
Others see no humor at all. Ronnie Smith, 52, who works in the cutting room at Anna Sportswear, said his view is that free trade does nothing but put people out of jobs.
"I blame Clinton," he said, alluding to the Administration's promises to create jobs. "He lied like hell at the beginning, then as soon as he got a good offer, there it is. Everybody here's losing their job."
Mr. Smith has worked for 30 years as a part-time electrician and for 21 years in the mills, which is steadier work, he said. If he loses his job, he said, he will go to school to learn something else.
Age is a factor that weighs heavily on many of the workers. Mrs. Impechiate said she was worried about her 55-year-old mother who lives alone and works at another mill.
"She's afraid," Mrs. Impechiate said. "She's worked there since she was 16. She has no other skill. What would she do? Me and my sister, we would have to take care of her." She acknowledged how lucky she was to have married the boss. "But if the business goes, we're both out of a job, and my mother couldn't help us."
A mother of five from Bangor, Pa., Mary Shiner, 54, and the only wage earner in her family, said she always loved working in the mill because she had time to get her children off to school before beginning work at 8 A.M. and she got off early enough, 3 P.M., to greet them when they returned.
But over the 11 years she has sewn garments, she has watched factories close and friends lose their jobs and now worries constantly that her plant might shut down.
"I love my work," she said. "It's been good to me and it's been a good job for the kids. But I told all my children to try to stay out of the factories. It's not going to be there through their lifetimes."

 BODY:

The Economy
 
The upcoming Republican Congress is likely to make it more difficult for the S.E.C. to expand regulatory activities. Several legislators, aides, executives and regulators agreed that commission's programs to hire more examiners and to provide more consumer education would clash with Republican concerns that the agency is already too intrusive. [Page A1.] 

The flow of foreign oil into the United States could be disrupted late this month because of a new Federal law that requires tankers to have 10 times the accident liability insurance they previously carried. [A1.]
While the Federal Reserve is determined to raise short-term interest rates, comments by its top two officials suggest that it may not act at the next meeting of its senior officials on Dec. 20, preferring to wait until January or early February. [D1.]
California officials moved on two fronts to assess the damage caused by Orange County's declaration of bankruptcy last week, and a county supervisor said the investment loss might have reached $2 billion, a third greater than previously indicated. [D1.]
Though a new U.S. forest management proposal would produce an estimated 1.5 billion board feet of lumber, industry spokesmen criticized the plan for not going far enough. [A1.]
 
Companies
 
While most of Wall Street reeled, Merrill Lynch, on track to log its second most profitable year ever, had become a darling of securities industry analysts. Then came Orange County. [D1.]
Apple Computer has filed suit against a small software developer in a case that may reignite a legal quarrel between Apple and Microsoft, its principal rival for operating software. [D1.]
 
International
 
The United States, Canada and Mexico agreed to admit Chile to the North American Free Trade Agreement. The announcement came at the end of a meeting at which President Clinton and 33 other Western Hemisphere leaders agreed to create a free-trade zone for the Americas within a decade. [A8.]
Many of the Latin American leaders who attended the Miami meeting speak more than English. They speak the economic language of the United States. [A8.]
 
The Media Business
 
After two years of preparation, a torrent of publicity and a delay of more than six months, Time Warner will hook up the first of about 4,000 homes to the most ambitious experiment yet in interactive television. [D1.]
The Utne Reader, considered the Reader's Digest of the alternative press, is rethinking and redesigning itself to include excerpts from the mainstream press as well. [D7.]
A press critic suggests journalists need to rethink their avowed claims of objectivity. William Glaberson: Press [D7.]
The objective of ad campaigns for Lands' End is to build a relationship with customers that leaves them happy to receive its catalogues. Advertising. [D8.]
Federal officials said a mail bomb that killed Thomas J. Mosser, the newly named general manager of Young & Rubicam, was sent by the same man who has struck targets across the corporate and academic landscape since 1978. [A1.]
 
Today's Columns
 
A new microwave technology may help to deliver clear images of body organs. Teresa Riordan: Patents. [D2.]
Exide, a maker of batteries, is looking to Europe for another spurt in growth, and investors are responding. Market Place. [D6.]

HEADLINE: Highflying Merrill Hits a Snag

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
In a year when most of its Wall Street rivals have been reeling from tumbling earnings, Merrill Lynch & Company is on track to log its second most profitable year ever.
Having escaped the large trading losses suffered by rivals like Salomon Inc., Goldman, Sachs & Company and the Morgan Stanley Group when interest rates began rising in February, Merrill, the country's largest brokerage and investment firm, continued to rack up profits and became the darling of stock analysts who follow the securities industry. 
 Then came Orange County.
Since news of Merrill's heavy involvement underwriting and bankrolling a large part of the highly leveraged portfolio that forced the California county into bankruptcy last week, the company's stock has plunged. Lawsuits are piling up, and Merrill is under investigation by Federal and state regulators.
Though it remains to be seen what the company's liability will be, at the least Merrill faces years of litigation that could end up costing it millions of dollars.
"Most of these cases get settled whether there is merit to them or not," said a lawyer at a rival securities company who insisted on anonymity.
Even so, with what is known so far, few securities analysts and industry executives believe that the potential payouts threaten the future of Merrill, which had $16.5 billion in revenues last year.
In an interview on Friday, Merrill's top managers said that the company acted properly in all its dealings with Orange County, and they expressed confidence that this would become clear once all the facts are in.
"People can write what they want and they can also file lawsuits," said Daniel P. Tully, Merrill's chairman and chief executive. "That doesn't mean that everything that someone writes is accurate, or that all lawsuits are meritorious."
On Friday, the Securities and Exchange Commission subpoenaed Merrill about its relationship with Orange County.
Separately, the S.E.C. is already investigating accusations of fraud relating to Merrill activities in both Massachusetts and New Jersey.
Mr. Tully said there was nothing wrong with Merrill's municipal finance department, which leads Wall Street in underwriting. If anything, he said, "we are extremely proud of our municipal finance business from the point of view of our origination and underwriting efforts."
As Orange County's troubles have unfolded, Merrill has been accused of a variety of misdeeds, including irresponsibly selling highly risky derivative investments to the county's treasurer, Robert L. Citron, who controlled a portfolio representing the assets of 187 county agencies, school districts and cities.
Derivatives are securities whose performance is based on the performance of simpler, underlying securities. About five years ago, Merrill pioneered the sale of derivatives -- they are sold mostly to corporations -- to municipalities. Merrill will not say how much it earned from its sales to Orange County.
Mr. Tully and his team said Merrill acted as a salesman to Orange County, not as its financial adviser, and therefore bears no responsibility for the way an experienced investor like Mr. Citron, who resigned last week, invested the fund's money.
What went wrong, they said, had more to do with Mr. Citron's decision to borrow heavily than the derivatives that Merrill sold to him.
Still, future litigation may hinge on whether Merrill had a responsibility to stop selling securities to such a heavily leveraged fund.
"I think a brokerage has a duty not to permit a customer to invest in an inappropriate fashion, especially when taxpayers' money is at stake," said Melvyn I. Weiss, a partner at the law firm of Milberg Weiss Bershad Hynes & Lerach in New York.
Mr. Weiss represented the City of San Jose, Calif., when it sued 13 brokerage firms, including Merrill, after losing $60 million in the early 1980's.
Those controversial investments were similar to the ones made by Orange County. Indeed, Michael Stamenson, the Merrill salesman who serviced San Jose, also sold billions of dollars worth of securities to Mr. Citron, reaping tens of millions of dollars in revenue for Merrill Lynch.
Merrill executives call the San Jose case different because there were questions about whether the city's financial officer had made illegal investments.
The company litigated the case for six years before settling for $750,000 in 1990 without admitting any wrongdoing. The executives said they settled to avoid a costly new round of litigation after a new judge was assigned to the case.
Two other companies involved in the case, E. F. Hutton and Paine Webber, continued the legal fight. After a six-month trial that ended in June 1990, the two firms were found liable for violating Federal securities laws and were ordered to pay the city $13 million.
Mr. Weiss said he felt that the situations in San Jose and Orange County "are virtually identical."
Mr. Stamenson has also aroused controversy because he and two other Merrill employees each contributed $1,000 to Mr. Citron's re-election campaign.
On Friday, the National Association of Securities Dealers, which along with the S.E.C. regulates brokers, said it was investigating whether Merrill violated the "pay to play" rules that prevent securities firms from making political contributions in order to win underwriting business from municipalities.
Mr. Tully and his team said Merrill had not violated the rule because it was applicable only to municipal finance professionals. Mr. Stamenson is an institutional salesman separate from Merrill's underwriting business, they said.
Asked if Mr. Stamenson was the kind of employee the company wanted on its payroll, Mr. Tully answered: "Hell, yes. We're totally supportive of him."
David H. Komansky, Merrill's executive vice president in charge of the debt and equity markets group, went further. "I would say that Stamenson is exceptional as far as understanding the investment philosophies and goals of the clients he works with," he said.
Merrill also faces a lawsuit from a group of investors who say that they were not told the true nature of Orange County's troubles when they bought some of the $600 million in notes issued by Merrill on behalf of the county last summer.
Merrill executives said the offering statement circulated at the time made clear that the proceeds were to be placed into the county's investment fund, that the fund was highly leveraged, that it was interest-rate sensitive and that it invested in derivatives.
For Mr. Tully, Orange County is a black mark in what by most accounts has been a stellar performance as chief executive. Five years ago, Merrill was known as a bloated giant that spent lavishly and was unable to wring profit from the huge revenue brought in by its more than 40,000 employees.
At the end of 1989, the company took a $470 million charge against earnings as part of a huge reorganization that many skeptics predicted would bear little fruit.
But under Mr. Tully, the company managed to rein in its costs. It also exploited its huge retail broker network to become the industry's leading issuer of new stocks and bonds.
From 1990 through 1993, Merrill earned $3.1 billion, more than it had earned during its previous 18 years as a public company.
Still, those were fat years for every firm on Wall Street. The true test of Merrill's strength came this year, when it continued to reap profits while the rest of the industry stumbled as interest rates began to climb.
In the first nine months of this year, Merrill earned $855 million, putting it on course to surpass 1992, Merrill's second-best year with earnings of $893 million.
Merrill has an asset management business that earns it regular management fees -- no matter how the markets perform. The company directly manages $167 billion in customer assets and holds an additional $381 billion in custody, a franchise that no other firm challenges.
"These are very steady businesses," said James Hanbury, a securities analyst at Wertheim Schroder & Company. "When the rest of Wall Street goes down, they don't. They go up."
Last month, Moody's Investors Services said it was considering raising the rating on Merrill's $15 billion of long-term debt above A1, making it the highest-rated independent securities firm. That would have decreased the cost of Merrill's borrowings.
But as a result of Orange County, Moody's said on Friday that it was no longer considering the move because the company's liability was unclear. Still, it gave Merrill a small vote of confidence by reaffirming the company's existing A1 rating for long-term debt, which among securities firms is shared only by Goldman, Sachs and Morgan Stanley.
After dropping more than $4 a share since Orange County's problems were publicized, Merrill stock closed at $33.625 a share on Friday, up 12.5 cents.
So far Mr. Tully has earned praise concerning his handling of the crisis. Last week, when several other firms sold off a total of $11.5 billion of securities held as collateral for loans to Orange County, Merrill did not call in its $2 billion loan.
"I think it was a statesman-like act," Arthur Levitt Jr., chairman of the S.E.C., said. Merrill's decision also spared it from being named in a lawsuit by Orange County against the other securities firms.
Orange County officials declined to comment on their relationship with Merrill Lynch. And Mr. Tully declined to discuss what talks, if any, went on between Merrill and Orange County officials before the bankruptcy filing.
