HEADLINE: The Hemisphere Summit Talks: Strictly Business

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Dec. 11

 BODY:
Although Latin American leaders have often been seen as distant neighbors in the past, most of those who came here this weekend knew Miami better than the American President.
With their countries building on this intimacy, economic integration seems bound to accelerate in the Americas through the end of the decade. 
 For the summit meeting, statisticians froze a frame in the blur of United States exports and investments speeding south. In the last decade, they said, United States exports to Latin America have doubled and direct United States investment has quadrupled.
Increasingly, Latin leaders speak more than American English. They speak the economic language of the United States.
"The United States needs 450 million guys down there with credit cards," President Gonzalo Sanchez Lozada of Bolivia said in an interview, referring to the economic aspirations of Latin Americans.
With all of the countries of the hemisphere but Cuba finally governed by democratically elected leaders, traditional themes like human rights and democratic rule are taking a back seat to business.
"The business of the summit is business," the Council on Hemispheric Affairs, a left-leaning research group based in Washington, said at the meeting by way of complaint.
On maps, Miami is closer to 16 Latin American and Caribbean capitals than it is to Washington. Noting that trade with Latin America through Miami increased from $2.4 billion in 1971 to $40 billion last year, officials here said they feared that a new, protectionist Congress would not share Miami's euphoria over a free-trade zone for the Americas.
"Our fear is that Congress will only approve fast track for Chile," said Charles Dusseau, Florida's Secretary of Commerce, referring to a tool that simplifies the process for trade treaties by allowing the executive branch to negotiate them.
But Clinton Administration officials predict that Latin America's shining trade and investment opportunities will penetrate any protectionist fog that collects over the nation's capital. Bolstered by the recent bipartisan victory for the global trade agreement, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the Administration's free traders found their voice in Miami.
"Most everybody accepts that the global economy is here -- if you build a fence you miss markets," Thomas F. McLarty 3d, the President's senior counselor, said of prospects of building bipartisan support for a hemispheric free-trade zone. "We are going to have to work very earnestly to find the right balance and to move ahead with the free-trade agreements."
Although the United States has the hemisphere's third-largest Latin American population, after Brazil and Mexico, it has been painfully slow to look south. The last inter-American summit was held in Uruguay in 1967.
At that time, recalled Ambler H. Moss, who took part in the Uruguay meeting, the Latin Americans "were all expanding state enterprises, raising barriers against imports, nationalizing American companies and blocking American investment." As director of the North-South Center at the University of Miami, Mr. Moss has watched Latin America's free-market policy revolution of the last decade.
"Today, the typical Latin American head of state is a salesman," he said. "They are all here hustling business for their countries."
Buoyed by the amiable mood here, participants proposed holding inter-American summit meetings regularly, either every two years or every four years.
"The atmosphere was splendid," Jose Angel Gurria, Mexico's Secretary of Foreign Affairs, said as the summit meeting closed today. "We now have a flight plan that will keep us busy for years to come."
With an economy five times as large as Latin America's, Uncle Sam has traditionally felt an avuncular urge to give economic lectures to his Latin nieces and nephews. But on the subject of free trade and integration the pupils seem to be racing ahead of their teacher. Only 10 years ago, Mexico refused to join GATT for fear that it would harm its protected industries. After joining the North American Free Trade Agreement this year, Mexico is joining a free-trade group with Colombia and Venezuela on Jan. 1.
By the end of this decade, a series of regional free-trade blocs are to be merged, allowing goods and services to circulate largely duty free throughout Latin America.
Regular regional summit meetings are quickly wiping away the pomp and tension that traditionally characterized meetings of Latin American heads of state.
"When I was Foreign Minister in 1985, there were countries that had never been visited by presidents of their neighboring countries," said Enrique Iglesias of Uruguay, president of the Inter-American Development Bank. "Now they use the familiar 'tu' with each other," he said, referring to the intimate form of address. "Their wives know each other."

HEADLINE: Time Warner's 'Time Machine' for Future Video

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

 BODY:
This is a test. This is only a test. It is not -- repeat, not -- the interactive television and home-shopping system that will be in your home by Christmas. Or next Christmas. Or maybe ever.
That, roughly, is the cautionary message from executives at Time Warner Inc. as they prepare to plug in their long-awaited "full service network" in Orlando, Fla., on Wednesday. 
 After two years of preparation, a torrent of publicity and a delay of more than six months, Time Warner will hook up the first of about 4,000 homes to the most ambitious experiment yet in interactive television. By some time next year, the company hopes, nearly the entire group of homes will be wired.
But for all the sizzle -- and there will be plenty of it -- the watchword is still caution, not just at Time Warner but at most other telephone and cable television companies that are conducting similar tryouts. No company has yet committed itself to offering exotic new services on a broad basis.
Time Warner executives refuse to say how much they are spending on the Orlando project, though in terms of the company's revenue it is surely a drop in the bucket. And they refuse to predict when they might reach a verdict on a wider expansion.
"The task here in Orlando was basically to build a time machine," said James Chiddix, senior vice president for engineering and technology at Time Warner Cable and a principal architect of the Orlando network. "This platform represents where technology can be a couple of years hence, and we are now in a unique position to discover how real people are going to spend real money to buy services."
Over the last year, the cost and difficulty of building interactive video systems has become more apparent. One trial after another has been delayed by technical problems. Within the cable television and telephone industries, there is great uncertainty about which services will be popular and whether they can be offered profitably, particularly exotic services, like interactive video shopping and grippingly realistic on-line video games.
Even in what is widely expected to be a popular service, like video on demand -- allowing customers to order movies whenever they want from an on-screen menu -- many experts say the economics are dubious. In an extensive test of movies on demand completed last year by U S West and Tele-Communications Inc. in Denver, customers bought fewer than three movies a month on average. In surveys, moreover, viewers have proved unwilling to pay much more for a movie than the $3 or $4 charged by video stores.
That leads to basic cost problems for a telephone or cable service, said Robert Alexander, head of Alexander & Associates, a New York consultant. "A movie can tie up your line for two hours," he said. "if you can only charge about $4, and Hollywood is going to take about half of that, it means you're getting about 1.6 cents a minute for the line." That is less than what telephone companies often charge for ordinary phone calls.
The point of the Orlando experiment, Time Warner executives say, is to find out what people will want when the equipment that is now so expensive becomes affordable several years down the road.
The Orlando system is undoubtedly the most futuristic network introduced so far. Beyond using the latest switching and computer technology, Time Warner and marketing collaborators like Spiegel Inc. have done more than any other group to blend Hollywood magic with Madison Avenue marketing in developing new video services.
Viewers will turn on their television sets to see a rotating carousel on the screen that will allow them to select and watch specific movies at any time of day, shop in an "electronic mall" and play what promise to be grippingly realistic video games.
Entering the mall, viewers will pass by graphical representations of storefronts and they will be able to view video displays of products from Spiegel, Eddie Bauer, Crate and Barrel and other merchants. A printer next to each television will be able to deliver tickets, discount coupons and printed information.
Time Warner has plenty of competition. Nationwide, cable or telephone companies have started or are planning more than 30 significant trials of new video services, according to Alexander & Associates, which has monitored the experiments. Most of these will let viewers call up movies from a library -- a service known as video on demand -- and many will offer a selection of two-way information services as well.
But nobody is sure how much interactivity the ordinary viewer will want. "The vast majority of consumers are very interested in better entertainment and information options, but what 'better' means varies among different segments of population," said Nicholas Donatello, president of Odyssey Inc., a market research company in San Francisco that surveys customer attitudes toward new media technologies.
Many companies are being conservative even as they try out new services. In West Hartford, Conn., for example, Southern New England Telephone has started a trial in 400 homes that allows customers to get ordinary cable television service and to choose from a library of 1,650 movies and shorter programs. But the company is wary about plunging into more unusual services, and chiefly views the video on demand as an added option with which to win over cable subscribers.
"There is a real danger that you can overload customers with a bunch of services that are too complicated and not easy to use," said Ron Serrano, a senior vice president at Southern New England Telephone.
In Castro Valley, Calif., Viacom Inc. has been preparing to test an elaborate system that includes video on demand, interactive games, information services and shopping. But that project has been repeatedly delayed as executives rethink elements of the plan, and the company now says only that it hopes to test its newest services some time in 1995.
Two other prominent trials, one by Bell Atlantic in Alexandria, Va., and the other by U S West in Omaha, have been delayed by technical and regulatory problems.
But the biggest uncertainties are over where the real opportunities lie. Proponents of video on demand note that video-rental stores already represent a $15 billion industry; they maintain that the new technology would save customers the trouble of leaving home and worrying about late fees. Most systems, including Time Warner's Orlando project, would allow viewers to pause or rewind the programs, as if they were using a videocassette recorder.
The demand for video shopping and on-line computer games is even more difficult to predict. Catalogue sales represent a $54.7 billion business, and many consumers may indeed appreciate the ability to view video images. Spiegel, for example, will let customers view moving video images of curtains, as they are hanging in a window, in each of the colors they have available.
Davia Kimmey, corporate vice president of advertising at Spiegel, speculated that it would also be possible for customers to get experts on video to offer advice about particular products or problems. But the costs of producing interactive advertising are high, and customers will still have to wait for any product that must be shipped by regular mail.
Time Warner executives readily acknowledge the uncertainties, but add that the only way to learn is to develop a system that offers people as much as possible. To that end, they have used all the tricks of a movie and television studio to make services entertaining and easy to use. They have also used numerous focus groups to refine the look and feel of each application.
Early on, for example, the company created a vivid three-dimensional graphic presentation of a city. Viewers fly through the city, with its tall buildings and signs, and stop at their particular destination. But early focus groups of viewers found the demonstration confusing, and the company shifted to the much simpler image of a cylindrical carousel that offered different choices -- movies on demand, video games and shopping.
The technology is advanced and, at least for the moment, costly. Silicon Graphics built the computers, known as servers, that act like jukeboxes to store video programs in electronic form. With Scientific Atlanta, it built set-top boxes that have many times the processing power of current personal computers.
The devices cost several thousand dollars each -- nobody will say precisely how much -- but the theory is that those costs will plummet as chip technology advances and production in volume allows for economies.
Even more exotic services and features are in the works. Time Warner is already preparing a system that will allow viewers to call up different programs or services by giving spoken commands.
Still, they emphasize that they are not assuming the success of interactive services. The company is already investing heavily in fiber optics, which will allow it to increase capacity, improve quality and expand into the local telephone business. These modernized networks will allow room for expanded pay-per-view services and other alternatives to full video on demand.
"We are not simply spending money to enhance our systems in the hope that interactivity will some day pay off," Mike Luftman, a spokesman for Time Warner, said. "The fiber upgrades will accomplish a number of things before interactive services come along. This is a very careful, prudent, phased introduction."

HEADLINE: Chile Is Admitted as North American Free Trade Partner

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Dec. 11

 BODY:
President Clinton and the leaders of Canada and Mexico said today that they had agreed to admit Chile to the North American Free Trade Agreement, a move that clearly puts pressure on the other nations of South and Central America to speed the opening of their markets if they want expanded trade with the United States.
The announcement came at the conclusion of a surprisingly harmonious three-day summit meeting. Mr. Clinton and 33 other leaders from the Western Hemisphere -- only Cuba was excluded -- agreed to conclude a treaty within a decade to create a free-trade zone for the Americas. 
 But Mr. Clinton's aides made clear today that they hoped the process would actually be much speedier as countries of South and Central America race to reform their economies and to meet a still loosely defined set of requirements to join the year-old pact that is commonly known as Nafta.
"This should be evidence that we intend to accelerate the process" of eliminating a wide variety of trade barriers that still slow commerce across the two continents, Mr. Clinton said today.
A broader goal is also at work: the Administration makes no secret of its efforts to use the prospect of trade liberalization in Latin America to put pressure on the European Union and Asian countries -- where the United States will have a trade deficit of nearly $100 billion this year -- to open their own markets.
"The Europeans will be encouraged, to use a delicate word, to be more open in a number of areas we have been concerned about," said Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, in an interview today. "And the Asians will also be encouraged to go in this direction, or they too will be left behind."
The Administration saw reason for celebration today over the speed at which the Latin American countries have become converts to free trade after decades of competing for American foreign aid and of playing the United States and the former Soviet Union against each other for influence in the region. But the celebration did not drown out some signs of discord.
Some human rights and labor groups criticized the Administration for placing business first, contending that the communique approved today made only vague acknowledgments of the need to protect worker rights and the environment, and said nothing about broader human rights issues.
Caribbean countries complained that their tiny economies could be greatly damaged by rapid market liberalizations. The Prime Minister of Barbados, Owen Arthur, warned that "a rising tide can also overturn small boats" and used the occasion to lecture a surprised-looking Mr. Clinton about American policy on trade in bananas.
The President acknowledged at the news conference today that the continuing American embargo against Cuba had been criticized by many Latin American leaders during private meetings. Several told him that the effort to speed the collapse of Fidel Castro's regime in Cuba and to replace it with a democratically elected Government would be aided by opening commerce.
That is exactly America's argument in favor of expanding trade with China, but Cuba has been the exception to the Clinton Administration's policy of "commercial engagement" as a means of aiding democracy movements.
"Most of these countries don't agree with the United States policy," Mr. Clinton said, though he showed no inclination to change the American position. But he said that there "was a great deal of feeling that it is urgent to restore democracy to Cuba."
Chile's accession to the North American Free Trade Agreement has been expected for some time. The country has been widely regarded as the free-market gem of Latin America after privatizing all but 50 of its 500 state-owned enterprises, slashing tariffs, greatly liberalizing its markets, and welcoming foreign investment. The result has been a decade of uninterrupted growth and a steady rise in wages.
For Mr. Clinton, Chile also represents a relatively controversy-free way of setting the precedent of expanding Nafta. The Administration expects little real opposition to Chile's inclusion, partly because of the country's small size. It has a population of only 13 million people, and a gross domestic product of $43.7 billion, significantly smaller than the annual sales of the I.B.M. Corporation. But its admission will pave the way for far larger economic powers, including Brazil and Argentina.
"I think Nafta will be neat, clear and straightforward," Eduardo Aninat, Finance Minister of Chile, said in an interview today, predicting bipartisan support in the United States Congress.
"The free-trade pact will provoke more foreign investment in Chile by reducing risk for the countries, and by establishing international investment rules," he said. "This puts Chile high on the map."
Canada's Prime Minister, Jean Chretien, said he welcomed Chile's inclusion, which will not be final until a series of negotiations take place next year over the exact conditions of entering into the agreement. "We have been the Three Amigos," Mr. Chretien said, appearing with President Clinton and Ernesto Zedillo, the newly elected President of Mexico. "Now we will be the Four Amigos."
The summit was another element in what the Administration has been portraying as a string of successes in foreign economic policy. Mr. Clinton has depicted these steps as a strategy to create hundreds of thousands of new jobs in the United States by expanding the market for American exports.
The first step was the passage last year of Nafta. That was followed by Congressional approval 10 days ago of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which set a minimum standard of tariff reduction and protection of intellectual property rights with more than 120 countries around the globe.
The next step will be to attempt to go far beyond the trade liberalization requirements of the GATT, not with more global talk but rather with regional trade accords, and to get the three major regions of the world to agree to even larger trade liberalization.
For Mr. Clinton, that means taking a significant political risk. He must convince American workers that they will gain more jobs from new export markets than they will lose as the United States opens itself to more cheap imports. Today, for example, the President contended that NAFTA has brought a net increase of 100,000 jobs.
The biggest element of the Administration's strategy is its effort to get Asian countries to agree to free regional trade. Mr. Clinton reached a vague but promising agreement with Asian leaders in Indonesia last month to accomplish that goal by the year 2020. But in Asia, it is the United States pressing for freer trade; here in Miami it was the Latin American countries urging Washington to move faster.

HEADLINE: Is Western Civilization Worth $20 Million?;
The Gift Is Huge and Welcome, but Its Restriction to Western Studies Fuels a Debate

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN, Dec. 11

 BODY:
Yale University called a news conference on April 17, 1991, to announce an extraordinary gift: Lee M. Bass, the youngest of four billionaire brothers from Fort Worth, had pledged $20 million to his alma mater to further its study of Western civilization.
The centerpiece of the Bass program was to be a rigorous, yearlong undergraduate course that would analyze virtual every major development in Western history, from ancient Mesopotamia to Nazi Germany. Conceived by Mr. Bass, Benno C. Schmidt Jr., then Yale's president, and Donald Kagan, the dean of Yale College, the double-credit course was to begin in the fall of 1993 and was intended to make a powerful statement -- that multiculturalism might be laying siege to the study of the West on other campuses, but not at Yale. 
 Nearly four years after that grand announcement, however, the course has yet to be designed, let alone offered to students. And half the Bass gift -- the $10 million that was to be spent on the new course and its teachers -- sits untouched in a college account, while fierce disagreement continues over how it should be spent.
The dispute says much about the perils of trying to expand a Western history curriculum in an era when debates about multiculturalism divide campuses. It also illustrates the risk of accepting a major donation with strings attached at a time of immense budgetary constraints.
The matter has become a cause celebre among conservatives at Yale, who feel the delay in using the money has been engineered by liberals on campus intent on undermining the teaching of a traditional curriculum. In an effort to diffuse emotions, Yale's current president, Richard C. Levin, is to fly to Texas on Tuesday to meet with Mr. Bass.
Yale is hardly the only institution to stir criticism by accepting a gift from a donor for a pet project. Earlier this fall, for example, Ahmet Ertegun, the founder of Atlantic Records and son of a Turkish diplomat, gave $3.5 million to Princeton University to start a Turkish studies program, prompting an editorial in The Daily Princetonian that questioned whether there was "demonstrated student interest" in the subject.
Citing other gifts to Princeton -- including a half-million dollars from the Ruling Prince of Lichtenstein for research on self-determination -- the student editors wrote that "the specificity of these recent donations creates the impression that wealthy benefactors can purchase a professorship to help further their agenda."
Kevin Whitelaw, a senior who is the editorial chairman of The Daily Princetonian, added: "I'm not trying to say that you can buy a program at Princeton, but I must admit that the way this has happened, you could almost make that conclusion."
Such tensions between donors wishing to dictate how their money will be spent and school officials trying to retain maximum control of that spending arise all the time at universities, said Peter Buchanan, the president and chief executive of the Council for the Advancement and Support of Education, a nonprofit advocacy group.
"If you're on the university side," said Mr. Buchanan, a former development officer at Columbia University, "it seems to me that you try to make sure you don't make commitments or tie people's hands in ways that are going to turn out to be a real problem."
At Yale, the delay in carrying out Mr. Bass's wishes can be partly attributed to the loss of the program's two champions, Dean Kagan and Mr. Schmidt, within 14 months of accepting the gift. Dean Kagan, a vociferous conservative, had repeatedly clashed with most of the faculty, which he accused of engaging in "mutual massage" with a generally liberal student body. He resigned the deanship in April 1992 to return to teaching history and classics at Yale.
A month later, during a virtual faculty revolt over steep budget cuts that he had supported, Mr. Schmidt followed suit. Mr. Schmidt, who left to become president and chief executive of the Edison Project, did not return phone messages left with his assistant. Professor Kagan declined to be interviewed.
Leaders of some conservative national and campus groups contend that the same "liberal" faculty members who had pressed for the resignations of Dean Kagan and Mr. Schmidt are leaning on Mr. Schmidt's successor, Mr. Levin, to quietly modify the Bass course.
But many of the Yale faculty members said the problem was not one of ideology, but was a question of need: there are, they said, already more than 100 undergraduate courses at Yale that deal with broad periods of Western history or thought, from Religious Studies 277A (History of Christianity in the Ancient World: Jesus to Augustine) to Humanities 221A (Medieval Europe: From 1000 to 1492).
It is now up to Mr. Levin, an economics professor who became Yale's 22d president in July 1993, to figure out what to do with the grant. Presented last fall with an outline of the Bass course by a faculty committee appointed by Mr. Schmidt, Mr. Levin rejected it, saying the course would have tied up too many of Yale's best faculty members in an effort that would benefit a limited number of students.
While professing his support for the course content -- "What could possibly be wrong with a course that studies Plato and Aristotle and Aquinas and Machiavelli and Dante and Shakespeare?" he said -- the president is in an unmistakable bind.
With a $12 million deficit in Yale's $1 billion operating budget and a freeze on new teaching positions, Dr. Levin has no shortage of uses for $20 million. But the agreement negotiated by Mr. Bass and Mr. Schmidt is fairly explicit, calling for the appointment of seven full professors in various Western subjects and four assistant professors, as well as the implementation of the course. So far, $10 million has been used to endow the chairs of five full professors -- Mr. Kagan was appointed by Mr. Schmidt to one of them -- while the remaining $10 million remains idle as Dr. Levin mulls its fate.
"Would it be necessary to have such a course?" Mr. Levin said, repeating a reporter's question during an interview at his office here. "No."
"Was it a gift intended to serve Yale in a useful and important way?" he continued. "Absolutely."
Mr. Levin has appointed a new committee to design an alternative Bass curriculum -- rooted, he assures, in Western history -- but its proposals have not yet been made public. He denies that any faculty members have lobbied him to kill the program.
What remains unknown is how Mr. Bass, a 1979 Yale graduate whose family is among the most generous benefactors in the school's history, feels about all this. Notoriously publicity shy, the Texas-based investor did not even attend the news conference announcing his gift. In denying an interview request this week, one of Mr. Bass's assistants, Viki Slate, cited his family's policy of "not commenting on personal affairs or business."
Word of the delay broke last month in Light and Truth, a conservative campus journal financed by the Intercollegiate Studies Institute, which is based in Bryn Mawr, Pa., and was founded by William F. Buckley Jr., a Yale graduate himself. Institute members have singled out six campuses, including Yale, for being dominated by what they call a "radical" liberal faculty. Two newspapers that often present a conservative point of view on their editorial pages quickly picked up on the story late last month: The Washington Times, with a front-page news article and The Wall Street Journal, with an editorial.
"Whatever new courses emerge at Yale University -- under the watchful eye of faculty ideologues," The Wall Street Journal's editorial said, "they will clearly bear no resemblance to the kind the remarkable Bass grant was supposed to pay for."
Mr. Levin says that at his Tuesday meeting in Texas he intends to present Mr. Bass with alternatives to the original course outline.
"We have every intention of introducing a program that satisfies the intention of Mr. Lee Bass," said Mr. Levin, who predicted that the revised course would be approved by the faculty and in place by next fall. "I want everyone inside the Yale community and outside to be assured that we are not going to subvert the intention of the donor."
Pat Collins, the president of the Yale Conservative Forum, said he would consider any detour from the original course -- which would have employed the 11 faculty members toexamine the art, religion, philosophy, literature and politics of the West -- to be a betrayal.
"The money was given for that purpose," said Mr. Collins, who wrote the Light and Truth article describing the dispute. "If President Levin doesn't want to do it, then give the money back."
But Serena Parker, a philosophy major from Manhattan, disagrees, saying that the money could be better spent on other subjects. Ms. Parker said she had taken plenty of Western-oriented courses on thinkers like Plato, Kant and Rousseau but could not name a single non-Western course in her department.
"I'd like to write my senior thesis on African philosophy," said Ms. Parker, a 21-year-old senior. "But there isn't anyone in the department who knows about it."
 
COURSES
Western Civilization At Yale
 
In 1991, Benno C. Schmidt, then president of Yale University, accepted $20 million from Lee M. Bass, a Texas investor, to start a course on the history, literature and art of western civilization. But Mr. Schmidt's successor, Richard C. Levin, contends that more than 100 courses at Yale cover the same territory. What follows are descriptions of 15 of those classes.
 
English 125: Major English Poets. (Chaucer, Spenser and Milton, among others)
 
 English 265A: The Victorian Novel. (Includes Dickens, Eliot and Hardy)
 
 French 330A: The Englightenment Novel (Includes Montesquieu's Lettres Persanes and Laclos's Les Liaisons Dangereuses)
 
 German Studies 150A: Introduction to German Culture and Thought.
 
 History 201A: The History of European Civilization from the Fall of Rome to 1648.
 
 History 202B: The History of European Civilization Since 1648.
 
 History 253B: Stuart England 1603-1700.
 
 History 271A: European Thought and Culture, Rousseau to Nietzsche.
 
 History of Art 115B: History of Western Art from the Renaissance to the Present.
 
 History of Science 421A: From Galileo to Newton.
 
 Humanities 141A: The Age of Augustus: An introduction to Rome and its empire.
 
 Music 350B: History of Western Music: Middle Ages and Renaissance
 
 Philosophy 116A: Introduction to Ancient Philosophy (Plato and Aristotle)
 
 Philosophy 170B: 19th Century Philosophy (Hegel, Marx and Kierkegaard, among others)
 
 Religious Studies 285A: History of Christian Thought: Modern Western Europe, 1648-1789

HEADLINE: Delay Seen In Fed's Rate Move

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11

 BODY:
While the Federal Reserve is clearly determined to raise short-term interest rates further, comments by the central bank's top two officials suggest that it may not act at the next meeting of its policy-making committee on Dec. 20, preferring to wait until January or early February.
The delay seems likely because top Fed officials made clear last week that they wanted to weigh information on the economy's health that would not be available until January. Fed officials also expressed little concern that any tax cuts would widen the budget deficit and feed inflation next year. 
 "The truth is that we have to be into January, beyond the end of the quarter, before we have a substantial majority of the data," said Alan S. Blinder, the Fed's vice chairman, at a news conference on Friday organized by the Chicago Board of Trade.
The Fed, which has already raised short-term interest rates six times this year, believes it must brake the economy's growth to head off inflationary shortages of goods and skilled labor.
Several sets of Government statistics to be made public in the next several days may still persuade Fed officials to act before January. The Labor Department is scheduled to issue November figures for producer price inflation on Tuesday, and for consumer price inflation on Wednesday. Also on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve plans to issue its estimates of how close American heavy industry was to operating at full capacity during November.
An unexpectedly large inflation gain -- or signs that American factories are straining to produce enough goods -- could so alarm the bond market that the Fed might be compelled to raise rates to reassure investors that it remains intent on fighting inflation.
As Administration officials have been wont to do, Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen today declined to predict what the Fed would do. But in an interview on "This Week With David Brinkley" on ABC, he said the Fed faced a difficult decision.
"I believe the next call for them will be the toughest one yet," he said, because the central bankers will not be able to precisely judge the braking effects of previous rate increases.
Several comments last week by Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, and Mr. Blinder indicate that the central bank is reluctant to play the role that Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, Democrat of Maryland, described last week: the grinch who stole Christmas.
Rather than raise rates immediately, the senior officials could decide on Dec. 20 to give Mr. Greenspan the explicit discretion to raise interest rates in January if Government statistics then show a risk of inflation.
If Mr. Greenspan does not use this authority, then Fed officials would probably raise interest rates sharply when the policy-making panel, the Federal Open Market Committee, meets next, on Jan. 31 and Feb. 1.
"They have seen nothing so far that dissuades them from their concern that higher inflation is around the corner," said Michael J. Boskin, the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers during the Bush Administration.
Some of the strongest evidence for thinking that the Fed will delay action came last Wednesday. Mr. Greenspan told members of a Congressional panel that overall consumer, business and Government spending was critical to the level of economic growth now, and indirectly important to the level of inflation. "The degree of strength in final sales will be central to the support of future gains in output," he said.
But reliable Government statistics on spending in the fourth quarter will not be available by Dec. 20. Mr. Blinder said on Friday at the news conference that "on the spending side, we have as yet relatively little information on the fourth quarter and we are as yet guessing."
The Commerce Department is scheduled to issue its estimate of November retail sales on Tuesday. But this statistic will reflect only the beginning of the crucial Christmas spending surge.
"Next Tuesday's retail sales is another straw on the camel's back, but we need a lot more straws before we can put together a picture," Mr. Blinder said.
Fed officials often rely on anecdotal information, like the quantity and price of steel in purchasing orders by the auto makers, to gauge the strength of the economy when accurate statistics are not yet available. But they have long considered such information to be particularly unreliable around Christmas, when retail sales are an especially important part of the economy.
Retail sales, unlike sales of industrial products like steel, tend to vary considerably from city to city and from region to region because shoppers, unlike car makers, cannot scour the country for the best deals. So anecdotes from one city tend to be a poor indicator of overall sales.
Alice M. Rivlin, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, speculated last month that the Fed might raise interest rates anyway if Republicans pass tax cuts without spending cuts. With the economy already operating at close to full capacity, such a tax cut could stimulate further growth and feed inflation, she reasoned.
But Mr. Blinder played down this concern. "I'm only modestly worried about that," he said. "Both the Administration and the leadership of the Republican Party have said that any tax cut will have to be paid for" with matching spending cuts.
Ms. Rivlin warned of a replay of 1981, when Congress passed tax cuts proposed by President Reagan but not spending cuts. But Mr. Blinder said that he thought that sequence of events to be much less likely now because Congressional procedures have been changed to require that spending cuts be offset by tax cuts to prevent the Federal budget deficit from widening.
Mr. Blinder's willingness to play down the risk of widening budget deficits is particularly significant because he is one of the few Democratic appointees to the Fed. His Republican colleagues have been even more inclined to give the benefit of the doubt to Republican plans in Congress.
In June, Mr. Greenspan, first appointed by President Ronald Reagan, endorsed the Republican idea that the deficit would not widen if Congress cut the tax on profits from the appreciation in value of stocks, bonds and other investments. Reducing that capital gains tax, he told the House Budget Committee, would stimulate so much investment and so improve the workings of the economy that other tax revenues would rise and there would be no overall widening of the budget deficit.

HEADLINE: Consumers' Optimism Up

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The University of Michigan's preliminary consumer sentiment index for December rose to 97.7 from 91.6 in November, people with access to the report said last week.
The University of Michigan index is based on 100, set in 1966. An increase in the monthly reading reflects consumers becoming more optimistic about the economy. Since 1966, the record high for the sentiment index is 101, set in March 1984. The record low is 51.7, set in April 1980. 
 The jump in the index suggests that "the Christmas selling season is going to be very strong," said Brian Wesbury, chief economist for Griffin, Kubik, Stephens & Thompson, a Chicago securities firm. "Consumers are in a positive mode. Retailers are going to be very happy."
The university also said its preliminary December index of perceptions of current economic conditions rose to 106.7 from 102.1 in November.
The preliminary December index of expectations, a component of the Government's index of leading economic indicators, also rose, to 92, from 84.8 in November.
The university delays public release of the information for one month.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Clubs Say Offer Is New, But Players Say It Isn't

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: RYE BROOK, N.Y., Dec. 11

 BODY:
Baseball's major league club owners, on the last day of the fourth month of the players' strike, handed the players a new tax proposal tonight that they championed for its "substantial movement." But Donald Fehr, the union leader, said the proposal appeared to have "virtually all of the elements" of the salary cap the clubs really want.
Another union official, who insisted on anonymity, called the plan brilliant but said, "It's designed to deceive people." Management people appeared to be disturbed by the union's characterizations. 
 While the players' negotiators were waiting for the proposal, Gene Orza, the union's associate general counsel, disclosed that the Labor Department certified the strike last Thursday, meaning the Immigration and Naturalization Service will not grant visas to foreign players who could replace the striking major leaguers.
Orza said the certification applies to "job opportunities as a professional baseball player for major league clubs." Because the Labor Department specified professional players, Orza said the certification "arguably encompasses guys in the minor leagues."
More immediate, though, is the owners' new proposal, presented as a counterproposal to one the union made on Saturday. That calls for a 5.02 percent tax on club payrolls and a $30 million contribution from each side to create an industry growth fund.
The clubs gave the union 24 hours to respond, saying they needed to know by Monday evening because they have a calendar to consider, beginning with a meeting scheduled for Thursday at which the owners are expected to vote to declare an impasse in negotiations and impose their salary cap.
The cap proposal remained on the table as an alternative to the new tax plan, which borrows from the union's latest proposal. It includes the industry growth fund and a payroll tax that begins at a 4.64 percent rate.
"We look favorably upon many of the noneconomic or secondary issues they have proposed," John Harrington of the Boston Red Sox, the clubs' chief labor spokesman, said. "We indicated we could work together to grow the game here and abroad. For our new economic proposal, we adapted the framework of their proposal to address some of our concerns, namely cost control and competitive balance."
He said that the owners' plan represented "substantial movement."
While the taxes appear similar, their results would work differently, and the owners' plan would have a secondary tax that would affect teams with payrolls over a designated threshold.
Union officials said the implications of the plan could not be discerned immediately. "I'm not even sure I know enough to ask questions," one union person said.
Members of the two sides held late-night technical sessions to go over elements and implications of the plan. But based on what they received in a session earlier in the evening, union people said the system would reward clubs with high revenues but low payrolls.
A basic difference in the union and management plans is the use of the $35 million that would be generated by the payroll taxes.
The union would use it as the bulk of the $58 million that would be distributed to the low-revenue clubs under the owners' revenue-sharing plan.
The clubs would maintain the elements of the revenue-sharing plan they adopted last January, moving $58 million to the low-revenue clubs in the way they originally designed. They then would take the $35 million raised by the payroll tax and use $10 million of it each year for their share of the growth fund and distribute the remaining $25 million to clubs based on the ratio between their revenues and their payrolls.
Clubs like the Mets and the Colorado Rockies would benefit the most because this year they had high revenues and low payrolls. Under the players' plan, the Mets and the Rockies would pay money into the revenue-sharing pool, but under the owners' proposal, those teams would get money back from the tax pool. The clubs thus would be encouraged to make as much money as they want; just don't spend it on salaries.
Because the high-revenue clubs generally are the ones that more likely would have the highest payrolls, the reward of tax-pool money would be an incentive to keep their payrolls down.
Clubs also would be induced to keep payrolls down by the second part of the owners' tax. The more a club goes beyond the threshold, the higher the tax rate would be.
With clubs looking to avoid taxes and gaining paybacks from the tax pool, the union believes the system would have similar effects to a salary cap. The overall aim of the system would be to get total major league payrolls down to 50 percent of total revenue, the same portion of revenue offered in the salary cap proposal.
"It seems to me the distance is still reasonably wide," Fehr said. "I can't say until we understand it. That won't be until sometime tomorrow."
If the two sides do not reach an agreement and the clubs try to use replacement players, they could try to use two different groups of foreign players as replacement workers: those who have played minor league baseball for major league organizations, and players who play baseball in their countries, from the Dominican Republic to Australia, but have not played professionally in the United States.
Orza, the union's associate general counsel, said the union has asked the immigration service to watch specifically for players that may be taken by major league clubs after they have been recruited by minor league clubs. Under the player development contract, major league clubs control players in organized baseball's minor leagues.
On the other hand, Orza said, the union doesn't want to block legitimate minor leaguers from playing minor league baseball.
"If they want to establish a procedure to stay in the minor leagues, fine," Orza said. "We don't want to prevent anyone from playing minor league baseball. But we don't want anyone to circumvent the procedure and play major league baseball."

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
Breaking the Mideast Cycle of Kill and Be Killed

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT 

 BODY:

BEYOND THE PROMISED LAND
Jews and Arabs on the Hard Road to a New Israel
By Glenn Frankel
416 pages. Simon & Schuster. $24. 
 By the main title of his book, "Beyond the Promised Land," Glenn Frankel means that in the last seven years, Israel has undergone a deep change, from "a small, collectivist, mobilized garrison state under siege to a more open, pluralistic, bourgeois and democratic society." In other words, Israel has been forced by events to go beyond "the old Zionist state" perceived as a utopian ideal to "a new post-Zionist Israel" that is part of the real world.
To emphasize the import of this change, Mr. Frankel, a reporter for The Washington Post who has spent many years in Israel, sets his book apart from what he calls some of the best books on Israel published in recent years: "In the Land of Israel," by Amos Oz; "The Siege," by Conor Cruise O'Brien; "Arab and Jew," by David K. Shipler, and "From Beirut to Jerusalem," by Thomas L. Friedman.
These books, he says, "tend to reinforce the fatalistic image of a promised land locked into an unbreakable cycle of violence and retribution, of kill and be killed." His book, by contrast, holds that the fateful cycle is being broken.
This break is a result, he argues, of several other momentous changes: the rise of new political forces in Israel; the fall of the Soviet Union and the arrival of nearly half a million Jewish immigrants; the death of socialism and the birth of a market economy; the defeat of Iraq in the Persian Gulf war and the ascendancy of the United States, and perhaps most significant, alterations in the Arab world, beginning with the Palestinian uprising known as intifada, which literally means "shaking off" in Arabic.
This eruption Mr. Frankel considers to have been a spontaneous boiling over of rage at Israeli oppression on the West Bank and in Gaza. Yet paradoxically, he says, the intifada empowered the Palestinians to set forth on the path that eventually led to the handshake on the White House lawn in September 1993 between Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel and the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, Yasir Arafat. As one Palestinian leader told the author: "We'd been fighting these people for decades and yet we didn't know them. We thought we could learn. The intifada made it possible by creating a sense of power inside us, a sense of equality with them. It wasn't master and slave anymore. We could talk."
To illustrate his thesis, Mr. Frankel examines these various changes by focusing on some of the people and places he has come to know in Israel over more than two decades. For instance, his close-ups of Israeli soldiers and Palestinian community leaders powerfully dramatize the impossible dilemmas forced on both sides by the intifada rioting and its brutal repression.
His portraits of disillusioned kibbutzniks and striving businessmen give the reader a sense of how the economy changed as the old dream of a vast cooperative farmland was gradually abandoned. Most fascinating of all is Mr. Frankel's penetrating account of how and why Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and his Likud Party blundered in its dealings with the Bush Administration and thus gave way to Yitzhak Rabin's Labor Party administration, which was slightly more amenable to peace negotiations. Intelligent too is his interpretation of the complex roles played by the conservative religious parties throughout the turmoil.
True enough, Mr. Frankel's narrative doesn't exactly lift the reader off the page. He neglects to convey the sense of the physical setting of Israel that, say, Amos Elon does in "Jerusalem" or Saul Bellow does in "To Jerusalem and Back." His portraits of the principals are more functional than sparkling. You slog through his text picking up facts as if they were stones for a new Jerusalem.
Moreover, the author offers little in the way of historical framework, nothing about the history of the land before the arrival of Zionist settlers. The advantage of this is a sharp focus on the present. The disadvantage is a lack of deep perspective.
Still, the history that Mr. Frankel relates is coherent and dramatic. Particularly provocative is his point that by the time the Israelis and the P.L.O. reached their agreement, American Jews had lost touch with what was going on. Whether or not this is fair, you reach the end of Mr. Frankel's narrative as if emerging from a dark tunnel into a landscape that has been radically transformed. As he presents Israeli attitudes, possession of the territories doesn't seem so essential anymore, if only because Iraq's attack with Scud missiles during the gulf war demonstrated the irrelevance of territory as a buffer zone.
For an epigraph to his final chapter, Mr. Frankel has found a particularly fitting passage from Dostoyevsky's novel "The Gambler": "Sometimes the wildest notion, the most apparently impossible idea, takes such a firm hold of the mind that at length it is taken for something realizable. . . . More than that: if the idea coincides with a strong and passionate desire, it may sometimes be accepted as something predestined, inevitable, foreordained, something that cannot but exist or happen."
Whether or not peace eventually comes to the Middle East and Mr. Frankel's vision of a land beyond the promised land is fulfilled, his book shows why ineluctably the parties had to take the gamble that peace could happen.

HEADLINE: In Miami, Freer Trade

 BODY:
The United States, Canada and 32 Latin American countries declared yesterday in Miami that they would create a free-trade area by 2006 -- in effect, a larger version of Nafta. That represents a political victory for President Clinton and an economic victory for people throughout the hemisphere. By one estimate, free trade could raise income in Latin America by $500 per person -- a huge boost in countries racked by poverty.
The summit meeting's declaration is credible. Compare it to a similar pledge by Asian-Pacific nations meeting last month in Indonesia. There, countries bowing to pressure from the U.S. announced a commitment to free trade but wavered by delaying a start date and taking no immediate steps to achieve their lofty goals. Some signatories backed away within hours of the declaration. Not so in Miami. The Latin American leaders pushed the U.S. to adopt an early target date for free trade. They also agreed to concrete steps to get negotiations under way. 
 The best evidence of their resolve can be found in the record of political and economic changes that have swept over Latin America. In 1967, the last time leaders from the hemisphere met, a third of the countries were run by dictators. In Miami, every official was elected -- though elections in the Dominican Republic were corrupt and problems plague democracy in Peru and Guatemala. In 1967, most of the economies were controlled by government, closed to foreigners and stagnating. Today, governments from Mexico to Argentina are privatizing state-owned enterprises, reducing deficits, controlling inflation and opening borders to imports and investment. The turnabout in policy has turned Latin America into the second-fastest-growing region in the world and the fastest-growing purchaser of U.S. exports.
The summit leaders must now confront two challenges: how to create a free trade pact out of the dozens of trade accords that already bind nations within the hemisphere; and how to create a free trade zone that is open to democracies outside the hemisphere. Open trade within the Americas should not become a no-trade zone for anyone else.
The obvious model is the Nafta accord the U.S. negotiated with Mexico and Canada, and now Chile. Nafta goes further toward free trade than GATT, which 124 nations signed in April and Congress recently approved. Unlike GATT, Nafta will eliminate tariffs and require signatories to enforce laws protecting workers and the environment. If governments in the hemisphere negotiate an accord like Nafta, and then welcome other countries willing to play by the same rules, the Miami summit meeting will prove momentous.

LENGTH: 532 words

HEADLINE: Orphanages Are No Solution

 BODY:
The party that professes to support family values seems excessively eager to yank poor children away from their mothers and dump them in institutions. Republican proposals for welfare reform suggest orphanages as an alternative to supporting young single mothers with children on welfare for years and years. And Newt Gingrich, the next House Speaker, has held up Boys Town, the fabled orphanage in Nebraska, as a model way to care for youngsters who might otherwise be thrown off balconies or dropped in dumpsters.
But before the nation moves very far down the orphanage road, it needs to recognize some uncomfortable facts. Orphanages, if staffed and equipped properly, are very expensive. Moreover, even well-run orphanages are often unsuitable, especially for the very young. The act of institutionalization often harms their social and psychological development. 
 The impulse behind the idealization of orphanages is understandable. All too many children live in dysfunctional homes or with relatives or foster parents who lack the resources and skills to care for them. The adoption process is often slow and cumbersome. So in extreme cases a youngster might well be better off in a small group home run by caring professionals, or even in a larger institution. But all too often the current political discourse veers in the direction of separating children from caring mothers whose only sin is that they are teen-agers, poor and unwed. Orphanages should only be a last resort. The best institution for raising children remains the family.
The move toward orphanages reflects hardening attitudes toward single mothers on welfare. One proposal endorsed by Mr. Gingrich would allow states to deny cash subsidies to single teen-age mothers and use the money instead for group homes for unwed mothers and their children -- or orphanages for their children. While some adolescents can benefit from living in small group homes, the North American Council on Adoptable Children says many infants and young children raised in institutions have a hard time sustaining healthy personal relationships.
As to cost, the Child Welfare League of America estimates that the price of maintaining a child in an orphanage, with support services, is $36,500 a year. By comparison, the average cost for foster care is $4,800 and a child's share of welfare and food stamps is $2,644. While some politicians talk breezily of private charities picking up the tab, those in the business of caring for troubled or abandoned youngsters say private resources are already stretched to the limit. Even the head of Boys Town doubts that it could be widely replicated.
That would leave the burden of supporting orphanages to the states, which have not, historically, done a very good job running or supporting such institutions as prisons, mental hospitals or nursing homes. The states would do better using their money to establish more family preservation programs, provide support services to foster families and increase efforts to recruit foster and adoptive families. Those are more modern, humane and economical solutions for dealing with dependent children than institutions like orphanages.

HEADLINE: Mr. Pataki: Save the Watershed

 BODY:
Despite their differences, there is one huge task that Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and Governor-elect George Pataki must face together: stopping pollution in the 2,000-square-mile watershed northwest of New York City. The watershed supplies eight million city dwellers and one million upstaters -- half the state's population -- with cheap, high-quality drinking water. Failure to protect it will require billions in filtration costs.
That is a financial punch neither official can happily absorb. They have only two years to duck it. Last December, the Federal Environmental Protection Agency told the city to clean up the water supply. If there is no real progress by December 1996 the E.P.A. will order filtration. City Comptroller Alan Hevesi says a filtration plant will cost $4.5 billion, plus annual debt service of $365 million and operating expenses of $145 million. Water and sewer rates could easily double -- a ridiculous price to pay for something New Yorkers now get cheaper than most Americans. 
 The watershed includes 100 sewage treatment plants that discharge wastewater into the streams feeding the reservoirs; most of them need upgrading or replacement. There are 128,000 individual septic tanks. There are thousands of acres of farmland and hundred of miles of roadways that produce runoffs of extraordinary toxicity. The visible product of all this human and animal activity is the algae in the reservoirs; the invisible products are the micro-organisms that water-drinkers would just as soon not think about.
New York City has long had the right to regulate economic development in the watershed. Basically, that means control over sewage, from barnyard manure to the effluents from housing developments. Under the E.P.A.'s hammer, the Dinkins administration developed a $700 million plan to upgrade the watershed sewage treatment plants and septic systems, reduce agricultural pollution, tighten restrictions on land use and acquire some 80,000 acres of buffer zones near the reservoirs and the streams that feed them. With some modifications, Mayor Giuliani has accepted that plan.
But the city cannot act unilaterally. The state's Department of Health must approve regulations governing water pollution; the Department of Environmental Conservation must approve the land purchases. It is crucial that Mr. Pataki appoint people who are sympathetic to downstate concerns.
It is even more important that Mr. Pataki engage himself personally. Whatever the city's statutory powers, watershed protection cannot proceed without the cooperation of local residents. They did not much like it when the city condemned farms and uprooted villages to create the reservoir system over the last 100 years, and they do not much like it now that the city has decided to impose new restrictions on their assumed right to develop their land.
Mr. Pataki, an upstater, has credibility in the region. Though he once sponsored a bill in the State Senate to strip the city of its regulatory powers, he now says he will do whatever it takes to avoid filtration. Gov. Mario Cuomo could speed things along by ordering his health and environmental agencies to approve the city's regulations before he leaves office. But regulations can be defeated by endless litigation; it will still be up to Mr. Pataki to win the active consent of his wary constituents in watershed counties like Delaware, Sullivan and Ulster, places where he is known and liked.
Rebuilding and replacing waste treatment plants and septic tanks and buying up 80,000 acres at negotiated prices constitute a staggering two-year workload. It is fine to tell local residents that a clean watershed with magnificent landscapes and clear trout streams will be more valuable to them in the long run than one-shot development. But they are more likely to cooperate if they can be convinced that the city will treat them fairly, involve them in planning and underwrite most of the costs.
That is where Mayor Giuliani comes in. The Dinkins administration set aside $120 million in its capital budget for municipal waste treatment programs, far short of the $700 million required for complete protection. The Mayor must assure upstaters -- not to mention Washington -- that the rest is on the way.

HEADLINE: A Needed Capital Gain

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In the renewed discussion of a possible cut in the capital gains tax, it is seldom mentioned that for many middle-class Americans the most significant capital gains vulnerability will come when they retire to a smaller dwelling. 
 Presently, a onetime, over-55 exemption of $125,000 is in effect. With previous housing inflation, this is often inadequate to cover the capital gains in many areas of the country. Replacing this with a full capital gains exclusion for a primary dwelling (also one-time, over-55) would place extra capital in the pockets of older Americans and reduce their retirement needs for supplemental services.
 
GILMAN CHESLEY
Santa Cruz, Calif., Dec. 5, 1994

HEADLINE: Republicans May Hold Down The S.E.C. and Investor Suits

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES 

 BODY:
The shift to a Republican-controlled Congress in January is likely to make it more difficult for the Securities and Exchange Commission to expand its regulatory activities and for investors to pursue claims of fraud against the securities industry.
In interviews last week, more than a dozen legislators, staff aides, industry executives and regulators agreed that an expanded S.E.C. budget to provide for more examiners to oversee mutual funds and investment advisers and to upgrade consumer education would collide with Republican concerns that the agency is already too intrusive and creates unnecessary expenses for the industry. 
 "The greatest area of potential difficulty we face in the new Congress is with respect to the budget," Arthur Levitt Jr., the commission's chairman, said in an interview last week. Mr. Levitt would like the agency to be able to keep the fees and fines it generates to cover its own budget rather than turning the bulk of that money over to the Treasury.
But that approach has been rejected by Senator Phil Gramm, the Texas Republican who is in line to lead the Banking Committee's securities subcommittee. Mr. Gramm said self-financing would allow the commission to be too intrusive and free it from legislative oversight.
The new Congress and the regulators may also collide on the issue of when and how investors may sue when they believe they have been defrauded in securities transactions. Because Newt Gingrich, the next House Speaker, has called for broad changes in the litigation process in his "Contract With America," securities litigation will be the top priority of the S.E.C.'s overseers in the House, said Stephen A. Blumenthal, who will serve as the majority counsel to the House subcommittee responsible for the commission's operations.
The S.E.C. and state regulators say that lawsuits filed by investors, called private rights of action, deter fraud and augment the agency's work.
"The prime mission of this agency is protecting the investor's interest, and the private right of action is fundamental to that mission," said Mr. Levitt, who acknowledged "a need for doing something about the costly, time-consuming and inefficient kind of litigation we've experienced."
Advocates for change, led by Mr. Gramm and his key staff adviser, the economist Wayne A. Abernathy, went further, saying the current securities litigation process, in Mr. Gramm's words, "has been distorted by greedy lawyers into a form of piracy."
Representative Jack M. Fields Jr., the Texas Republican who will head the House subcommittee that oversees the S.E.C.'s operations, questioned the merits of "a vast majority of the class action suits that are filed and settled" and would not rule out a system in which the loser in a lawsuit would have to pay all the costs. Mr. Gramm said that while he did not mean to deter small investors from going to court, "quite frankly, if someone is going to impose costs on a company, they should be liable for it."
Democrats have opposed the "loser pays" concept, saying it would discourage small investors from seeking redress.
Those who favor the Republican agenda say it will make American capital markets more competitive and efficient, without weakening investor protections. But many market watchdogs at the Federal and state level say they fear the proposed changes will shake investor confidence in the fairness and honesty of the American markets.
"We support the strongest, most efficient S.E.C. possible," said Philip Feigin, Colorado's securities commissioner and president of the North American Securities Administrators Association, which represents state regulators across the country. Mr. Feigin said he was concerned that the commission would not be able to obtain the level of financing it needed to be effective and was also concerned that the Republicans would try to change litigation rules to prevent small investors from bringing meritorious cases.
"There will never be enough cops on the beat," he said. "Investors have to be able to protect themselves."
Mr. Gramm said his goal would be "to reach that balance where the benefits that regulation yields in terms of an orderly and honest market is equal to the cost that regulation imposes in terms of burdens on the market." Mr. Gramm said he strongly opposed any increase in funds for the commission.
While the investor litigation process is a House priority, the debate could be more protracted in the Senate, where some of the S.E.C.'s future overseers have been less strident. Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the New York Republican who will head the Banking Committee, has pointed out repeatedly that the current judicial system already provides safeguards against frivolous litigation.
Joel Seligman, a securities law specialist and author of a history of the S.E.C., said he was concerned about the impact that budget cuts could have. "At the moment, certain aspects of the market -- such as investment advisers -- appear to be near crisis because of a lack of meaningful oversight or inspection being conducted," Mr. Seligman said. "Unless the S.E.C. receives adequate support for that, you run the risk of a significant number of cases such as those in Orange County."
The messy bankruptcy of that Southern California county last week provided a mesmerizing backdrop for discussions about Congressional priorities for revising securities litigation rules. Some Democrats wondered whether the new leadership would become more cautious about putting limits on such lawsuits in the wake of the unfolding scandal, which has already prompted investors and the county itself to sue several Wall Street firms over $1.5 billion in losses incurred by an aggressively managed county investment fund.
"They say that a conservative is a liberal who has just been mugged," mused Representative Edward J. Markey, the Massachusetts Democrat who will yield his subcommittee gavel to Mr. Fields. "Perhaps a liberal is a conservative who has just been defrauded out of $1.5 billion."
Unlike most agencies of the Federal Government, the commission actually generates money for the Treasury, turning over roughly $2 in fees and fines for every $1 it spends. And in recent years, the S.E.C. and some industries it regulates, notably the mutual fund industry, have argued that the agency should be able to use its own fees to finance its operations.
That option was rejected by at least one powerful Republican. "There will be no self-funding for the S.E.C. on my watch," said Mr. Gramm, whose disputes with the agency have had a personal edge since the late 1980's, when Richard C. Breeden, then the chairman of the commission, tried to take over the duties of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, headed at the time by Wendy Gramm, Senator Gramm's wife.
If self-financing is almost certainly doomed, Mr. Levitt said, he hoped the Republican leadership would at least recognize that the agency's budget needs are "dynamic" and fluctuate with market activity.
Explosive growth in the investment advisory business and in the mutual fund industry in the last decade have substantially outstripped the commission's inspection programs. Despite improvements made by Mr. Levitt and Mr. Breeden, the agency is still able to examine on a regular basis only the largest and most active managers of the public's money.
Smaller fund operations or advisory firms are likely to be inspected only when a scandal has occurred -- and such scandals, including unreported risks in money market mutual funds and fraudulent activities by investment advisers, have occurred frequently enough in the last year to suggest that additional regulatory oversight might be needed.
Without additional resources, Mr. Levitt's supporters say, such inspection could be provided only by reducing resources now devoted to policing the public markets and reviewing the documents supplied to investors by companies trying to raise capital.
In addition to planning a substantial increase in the inspection staff, Mr. Levitt has initiated a small but ambitious program of consumer information, aimed at giving small investors a better understanding of how to protect themselves from market fraud.
Mr. Seligman noted that Republican-dominated Congresses have not produced expansive S.E.C. budgets in the past. Indeed, historians note that the commission was kept on short rations for at least 15 years after World War II, even as the postwar markets grew explosively. The result was a flood of financial scandals that swept through Wall Street by the end of the 1950's.
"That's why it is so important that the S.E.C. be adequately funded," Mr. Seligman said. "It has the potential to nip problems in the bud through inspection and review of filings, rather than solely through enforcement actions after the fact."
The commission's supporters note that Mr. Levitt, who was appointed last year by President Clinton, is perhaps the agency's best protection against draconian budget cuts since he is seen as a practical businessman without imperial ambitions. Even Senator Gramm had kind words: "I have had a very good working relationship with Mr. Levitt. I have had nothing but the best dealings with him."
But the commission will need more than charm to head off the effects of the new leadership's agenda, its supporters said; it will need the vocal support of Wall Street itself.
"The likes of a Merrill Lynch knows that its enemy is not the S.E.C.," said one senior regulator. "Its enemies are the con artists who scare investors out of the market. Wall Street's viability depends on a very strong, pro-active S.E.C."

CORRECTION-DATE: December 19, 1994, Monday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, a front-page article last Monday about ways in which the Republican-controlled Congress might restrain the Securities and Exchange Commission misstated proposals by the S.E.C. for financing its operations out of its own income. The commission has sought to keep only the fees it generates, not both its fees and its fines.

HEADLINE: CD-ROM Review;
CD-ROM's to Get Better and Faster But Even So They May Not Survive

BYLINE: By PETER H. LEWIS 

 BODY:
ALTHOUGH it has been around for more than a decade, CD-ROM technology has only recently become a standard component in new personal computers. And wouldn't you know it, today's technology is already well past its prime just as it is becoming widespread. That does not mean that the CD-ROM is nearing the end of its useful life, but rather that new generations of devices are emerging that will gradually, but inevitably, replace it.
The next generation of CD-ROM players and disks will begin showing up early next year, and some really dazzling advances are just two to three years away, analysts say. 
 The "ROM" part of CD-ROM -- read-only memory -- is ideal for large amounts of information that does not change. But in a rapidly changing world, a medium that cannot change rapidly is an impediment. Affordable CD drives that can be written upon repeatedly, much like a high-capacity diskette drive, will reach market next year, bringing with them great possibilities as backup devices as well as multimedia creation and distribution tools.
New standards are being developed to eliminate the difference between CD-ROM and audio CD formats. The two are largely incompatible today. One can play audio CD's in a CD-ROM drive, but not CD-ROM disks in an audio CD drive. In terms of hardware, an "enhanced CD" standard will simplify manufacturing, which in theory would lead to lower prices. In software, audio, text and video can be tightly integrated, permitting truly interactive music video disks, for example.
Most CD-ROM drives in use today are "double speed" drives, meaning they spin at twice the rate of the first generation, and thus can send data to the computer more quickly, resulting in improved video and sound performance. Triple speed or 3X is a lame-duck technology that soon will be eclipsed by "quad speed" drives.
"By the end of 1995, most computers will ship with quad-speed drives," said Bruce Ryon, an analyst at Dataquest Inc., a market research company in San Jose, Calif. "Most of the manufacturers have stopped making double-speed drives already."
The next jump in storage capacity will allow CD-ROM drives to store 3.3 gigabytes (3.3 GB) of information on a single disk.
The leap in capacity could transform the video and music industries. Even with the best data compression, the current CD-ROM disks can hold only about an hour of video images. A typical feature film thus would require at least two CD-ROM disks. At 3.3 GB, a feature film could be stored on a single "super" CD-ROM disk.
By the time these 3.3-GB disks become widespread, new technologies may have replaced quad-speed drives with something even faster. The combination of higher-speed drives and higher-capacity disks opens the possibility of laser-quality movies on a single disk, which in turn could hasten the demise of VHS video tapes. When the rewriteable 3.3-gigabyte optical disk drives reach the consumer market in 1998 or so, the VCR itself will begin to fade.
Eventually, CD-ROM itself will begin to be displaced, or even replaced, by advances in so-called broadband networks and alternative storage technologies.
There is no technical reason why software, including video and audio, cannot be transmitted over networks, whether the network belongs to the phone company, the cable TV company or the satellite company. The issue is bandwidth, or capacity of the data pipe, and time.
"It can takes hours to download video on a 14.4-kilobit per second telephone line," said Thomas Ryan, manager of media products at Apple Computer Inc., referring to the current personal computer modem standard. "For the near future, until the rest of the information superhighway catches up, we'll have to have some sort of storage capacity."
That storage may or may not be on CD-ROM. "Even in quad-speed drives, a hard disk is 100 times faster than CD-ROM, and RAM is 1,000 times faster," said Mr. Ryon of Dataquest, referring to random-access memory. As a result, CD-ROM software developers are becoming adept at mainlining parts of their programs into the computer's memory.
It is unlikely that we will have three gigabytes of RAM in our personal computers any time soon, but gigabyte-sized hard disks are already common. In the meantime, expect some sort of hybrid system involving the static storage on data on CD-ROM, linked to the immediacy of an on-line service.
