HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Drop In Advance of Inflation Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fell lower yesterday as investors and traders grew concerned that economic reports this week will suggest that interest rates have not risen high enough to keep inflation from accelerating.
Traders also attributed early weakness in the market to selling prompted by President Clinton's comments on Sunday that he might back a middle-class tax cut. The bond market fears a tax cut would undermine prices by stimulating the economy and swelling the budget deficit. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 22/32 , to 957/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 7.92 percent, from 7.86 percent on Friday.
In the municipal market, where there was lingering concern about the bankruptcy filing by Orange County, Calif., yields pretty much tracked the rising rates of the benchmark Government securities.
Municipal bond prices were down an average of a quarter-point to a half-point in trading that reflected a lack of confidence in the market and apprehension of the next move by the Federal Reserve. The average yield to maturity in the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal issues rose to 7.06 percent, from 7.04 percent on Friday.
Some traders expect the Fed to raise short-term interest rates when its policy-making committee meets next Tuesday. They say the market has already priced in an increase of 50 basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent.
But many Fed watchers see only a modest chance of a rate increase before January. That view was strengthened by comments from the Fed's top two officials last week that suggested the Fed would not be prepared to raise rates before January. The Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, and the vice chairman, Alan S. Blinder indicated that they wanted to see economic data that would not be available until January.
The market took a beating in the morning, as buyers held back ahead of today's producer price numbers and tomorrow's consumer price data. Retail sales are also due today. The week includes reports on industrial production and capacity utilization, business inventories, housing starts and the Philadelphia Fed's survey of business activity.
Analysts expect producer prices to show gains of four-tenths of 1 percent for November in both the overall index and the so-called core rate, which excludes volatile food and energy prices.
Economists note that the Producer Price Index has been restrained in the face of this year's higher prices for crude and intermediate goods, and the market will be sensitive to evidence that these are being passed through to the finished-goods level. Analysts expect a seasonal decline in the tobacco component of the index to offset a similar rise in prices for passenger cars.
Traders said that the long end of the market did not fare so well amid talk of middle-class tax cuts, fearing that any spending cuts to pay for them will not be enough, thus leading to a bigger Federal budget deficit and higher interest rates.
Yesterday, the Treasury sold $27.2 billion in new three- and six-month bills at rates that were lower than than those auctioned last week. The average rate for a three-month issue was 5.76 percent, down 7 basis points from the previous auction, while the six-month issue was down 1 basis point, to 6.32 percent.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
National Gypsum Spurns a Bid

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
The National Gypsum Company turned down a takeover offer from a group led by its nonexecutive chairman yesterday, saying the $940 million bid, worth $43.50 a share, was too low.
The response from National Gypsum, the nation's second-largest maker of gypsum-coated wallboard, which is used mainly in houses, came less than a month after C. D. Spangler Jr., the North Carolina investor who is also the company's largest shareholder, made his offer. 
 Delcor Inc., a Spangler family investment company, began buying shares in National Gypsum about a year ago, and now holds a stake of around 19 percent.
The Delcor offer was considered by a four-member special committee of the company's board, along with Smith Barney, National Gypsum's financial adviser.
In a letter delivered to Mr. Spangler, the special committee said it had concluded that "a sale of the company at this time is not in the best interests of all the stockholders of the company, and we cannot recommend that the company pursue or support a transaction with Delcor on the terms contained in the Nov. 15 offer."
Though he holds the title of chairman, Mr. Spangler does not participate in operating decisions at National Gypsum. Mr. Spangler declined to comment on the board's decision.
Based in Charlotte, N.C., National Gypsum trails only the USG Corporation in the manufacture of wallboard. Last year the company posted sales of $511 million.
Analysts had predicted the bid would be rejected, saying the price offered was far too low, even though when National Gypsum emerged from bankruptcy in July 1993 it was valued at $12.50 a share.
"When they were coming out of bankruptcy, most of our clients were still talking about the economy as still in recession," said Barbara Allen, an analyst who follows the housing industry for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "And the industry as a whole did not become profitable until the first quarter of this year."
Ms. Allen said that based on anticipated 1995 earnings, the company is worth around $60 to $65 a share.
Despite steadily rising earnings this year, fears about the impact of rising interest rates on the housing industry had pushed National Gypsum's stock down by nearly 40 percent before Delcor's bid.
In Nasdaq trading yesterday, the stock closed at $39.875 a share, down 87.5 cents. In the last year, the stock has traded as high as $52.75 a share.
Ms. Allen and other analysts said they regarded the offer from Mr. Spangler's group as an opening thrust in what could turn into a bidding war. Indeed, National Gypsum officials said they would consider other offers.
"The board has completed its work as far as that offer is concerned," said Alan V. Cecil, a National Gypsum spokesman. "But the committee certainly views it to be in the obligation of shareholders to consider any legitimate offer."

HEADLINE: States Win in Ruling On Taxation of Interest

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12

 BODY:
In a victory for state treasuries, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that states may tax the interest earned from repurchase agreements involving Federal securities.
States are barred by Federal law from taxing interest income on Federal notes and bonds. But states have contended that the law does not apply to repurchase agreements, a financing arrangement in which the security serves as collateral for a loan, because the income from such an agreement reflects not the interest rate on the underlying security but rather the premium that the borrower has agreed to pay to get the security back. 
 The Court agreed today in an opinion by Justice Clarence Thomas, who said that the income from a repurchase agreement involving a Government security was interest on a loan between private parties, not interest on an "obligation of the United States Government."
Since all states already treat this income as subject to state taxation, the decision essentially reaffirmed the status quo. The Nebraska Supreme Court, however, ruled earlier this year that the state could not tax the income received by shareholders in mutual funds that participate in repurchase agreements involving Federal securities. The Court's decision today overturned that ruling. Six other state high courts have recently ruled that the income could be taxed.
The case was of particular interest to the mutual fund industry. Under earlier court decisions, mutual fund dividends attributable to direct investments in Federal securities cannot be taxed by the states. Mutual funds providing tax-free income have been popular investments, and the industry was concerned that a decision in this case might erode the general principle of tax exemption.
The Court, however, made it clear today that it was not revisiting the general issue but was addressing only the taxability of income from repurchase agreements. The Nebraska investor who brought the case, John Loewenstein, owned shares in two mutual funds, the Trust for Short-Term U.S. Government Securities and the Trust for U.S. Treasury Obligations, that participated in repurchase agreements.
Although repurchase agreements were used in Orange County, Calif., the tax issue before the Court was unrelated to the county's problems. Repurchase agreements, known as repos, were part of the county's highly leveraged investment portfolio and contributed to its fiscal collapse last week.
The decision today was Nebraska v. Loewenstein, No. 93-823.

HEADLINE: No End to Growth;
People Are Spending With Abandon And U.S. Goods Are Selling Overseas

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
The economic recovery, like the Energizer Bunny, just keeps going and going. In spite of tax increases, sharp rises in interest rates this year and widespread skepticism that Washington will be able to put its fiscal house in order, rapid growth continues unabated. Unemployment has dropped to its lowest level in four years.
Indeed, as the Federal Reserve's chairman, Alan Greenspan, told Congress last week, "there is very little evidence throughout this economy of any degree of slowdown." Mr. Greenspan, who only a little more than a year ago was complaining of powerful forces holding back the economy, added that "the 50-mile-an-hour headwinds have disappeared" and that the real worry today is inflation. 
 What is powering this juggernaut? Why were most forecasters, who as recently as this summer were predicting a much leaner expansion and higher unemployment, so far off target? Most important, can the good times last?
Two explanations for the unexpected boom stand out.
For one, many consumers -- who as recently as last year were mostly worried about keeping their jobs -- are spending with abandon. Now, with about three million jobs added to the economy this year, some of the anxiety about employment prospects has eased. And disposable income, after falling for several years running, shows signs of starting to turn up. The result? "Big-ticket buying has blown through every benchmark," said Stephen S. Roach, an economist at Morgan Stanley.
Even more important, America's trading partners are coming out of their own recessions -- and the surprisingly weak dollar has made American goods an irresistible bargain on world markets. "Exports explain the difference between an O.K. recovery and a blockbuster," said Robert Mellman, an economist at Morgan Guaranty Trust.
As recently as this summer, most forecasters were predicting that unemployment would bottom out at 6 percent in the fall and economic growth would slip below 2 percent in the last quarter of 1994. Instead, unemployment is down to 5.6 percent and fourth-quarter growth is now expected to exceed 4 percent.
But can the good times keep rolling on? The forecasters' coin has certainly been debased in the last year. Nonetheless, predictions of a slowdown in 1995 and perhaps even a recession in 1996 should be taken very seriously.
This year's rapid growth proved even more surprising because the same forecasters who expected only modest gains also assumed that interest rates would be one and a half percentage points lower than today's figures. With six rate increases by the Federal Reserve this year, why has the gain in jobs and output picked up rather than slowed?
There are a variety of reasons, from more aggressive lending by banks to the long lags between tighter money and reduced investment. But that in itself is hardly an explanation for how the economy came to be so hot. And here, economists generally agree that the surge in output and employment was largely fueled by strong buying both at home and abroad of America's increasingly competitive goods and services.
Consumers did more than their share, in large part because millions of homeowners fattened their wallets in recent years by refinancing mortgages to cut their monthly payments. Another key factor, said Richard F. Hokenson, an economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, is that exceptionally large numbers of Americans are in their mid-20's, a stage of life in which households are formed at a rapid pace and credit-card bills are run up to the top.
All this helped generate a boom in autos, appliances and consumer electronics that exceeds the typical rebound in sales after a relatively mild recession. More generally, consumer confidence, as measured by the University of Michigan and the Conference Board, a New York business research group, is higher than it has been since the economic downturn that began in 1990.
Consumers have a more optimistic sense of their improving prospects, Mr. Roach of Morgan Stanley suggested, than those gloom and doomers who focus on the stagnation of wages rather than the steady increase in jobs. And they are plainly tired of postponing the pleasures of the good life, like Jeep Grand Cherokees and Apple Macintosh Power Books. "They're just gritting their teeth and going shopping," he said.
The less widely heralded kick to economic growth is exports. Merchandise exports constitute roughly 10 percent of overall output. With merchandise exports now growing at a remarkable 15 percent annual pace, Mr. Mellman of Morgan Guaranty pointed out, the export boom is contributing one and a half percentage points to the overall economic growth rate of about 4 percent.
Some growth for American exports was expected as the big industrial economies climbed out of recession. But the early exit from the downturn and the rapid pace of economic growth in Europe and Canada, averaging more than 3 percent, has far exceeded consensus forecasts.
Growth in global demand for everything from forks to fork lifts does not, however, guarantee that the foreign buyers will buy American. Price matters as well as quality and availability. And in the last year, American exporters have been blessed by a weak dollar that has helped make increasingly productive United States manufacturers even more cost competitive versus their European and Japanese counterparts.
But even though the expansion should continue next year, its best times may be about to end.
While exports should keep rising, it would take exceptional circumstances to match the current pace of export growth. After all, the coincidence of rapid economic advancement abroad and a weakening dollar is not likely to continue. Indeed, the dollar has already started to regain some of its lost ground.
Then, too, with factories approaching capacity and employers scratching harder to find qualified workers, sustaining strong growth without a significant increase in cost-driven inflation should prove difficult to achieve, if not impossible. In fact, most economists believe the economy is now operating so close to capacity that further increases in demand will largely translate into higher prices, rather than higher output.
Most important, the Federal Reserve's swing toward tight money in 1994 is most likely to be felt in 1995. And if rapid growth continues into next year, the Fed would feel even more compelled to respond to accumulating evidence of an economy pushing past its productive limits.
That makes the risk of a crash landing later on even greater. "The lags in monetary policy are so long," said Van Doorn Ooms, an economist with the Committee for Economic Development, "that we almost inevitably overshoot."

Orange County's Bankruptcy
Bankruptcy is unlikely to derail economic growth in Orange County, Calif., even as school districts and county supervisors consider financing problems. The county's economy remains fundamentally healthy, analysts say. [Page A1.]

HEADLINE: Entitlement Bungling

 BODY:
The bipartisan commission on entitlements is heading for failure. It is scheduled to meet tomorrow for the last time to vote on a plan by its chairmen -- Senators Bob Kerrey and John Danforth -- to cut Federal spending by enough to keep the deficit from claiming a larger share of the economy over the next 35 years. That is the right goal. But their proposed solution is misguided, and has no chance of garnering enough votes.
The failure is sobering. Mr. Kerrey is right that entitlements, programs like Social Security and Medicare for which spending is driven by formula rather than annual decisions by Congress, pose a huge budget problem. They, along with interest payments, are expected to account for over 70 percent of Federal spending by the year 2003, leaving crumbs for everything else. Addressed now, the solutions need not be onerous. Left to fester, they could prove horrific. But as Mr. Kerrey observes, Washington displays little stomach for tackling a problem that will not bite soon. 
 The President and the chairmen made a difficult task harder still. The commissioners possess little expertise or strong ties to the White House or Congressional leaders. Politicians on the commission refused to discuss hard choices in public, especially before the elections. They were, quite properly, not allowed by law to formulate policy in private. The chairmen compounded problems by delivering their plan last week -- in effect telling commissioners to vote on politically charged ideas that they do not understand and for which no consensus has been built.
The Kerrey-Danforth plan would control deficits. But it would do so with unnecessarily Draconian cuts in Social Security. Robert Ball, a former commissioner of Social Security, estimates that the plan would reduce benefits of the average wage-earner by over 40 percent; he estimates that it would take only a 15 percent benefit cut to bring Social Security into long-term balance.
The plan also proposes to begin privatizing Social Security -- replacing the Government tax with mandatory contributions by individuals to personal savings accounts. The idea is revolutionary. But it would be prohibitively expensive to set up and serves no important economic purpose. It borders on the bizarre that the chairmen would spring this controversial idea on the commission with virtually no discussion.
Parts of the Kerrey-Danforth plan make good sense. Modestly raising the retirement age for Social Security and limiting the tax deduction for employer-paid health insurance are sound ways to save money (though savings from the tax cap would be better spent to subsidize health coverage of uninsured families than to reduce the deficit). The best outcome of tomorrow's vote would be for the commission to adopt good ideas that the chairmen have identified, even if they do not add up to the full solution Mr. Kerrey desperately sought.
The shutdown of the commission also casts doubt on President Clinton's renewed flirtation with a middle-class tax cut. It would be hugely expensive, since both parties are almost certain to include in the middle class for this purpose nearly every American. The Republicans promise to give families a $500-a-child tax credit, costing about $20 billion a year. Mr. Clinton may start off with half that much. The catch is that under current law, Congress must offset tax cuts with cuts in entitlement spending. So even if Mr. Clinton gets by with half a loaf, he will have raised the crossbar that Mr. Kerrey could not clear by $10 billion a year.
If Democrats and Republicans engage in a tax-cutting frenzy, the outcome will be hypocritical or vicious. It will be hypocritical if the cuts force Congress to make up the loss by hitting Medicare and Social Security, middle-class benefits. It will be vicious if Congress also turns, as it surely must, on welfare, housing subsidies and job training that go primarily to the poor.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
ARBY'S PARENT IS NOT BUYING LONG JOHN SILVER'S

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
Citing higher interest rates, the Triarc Companies, parent of Arby's roast beef restaurant chain, called off a planned purchase of Long John Silver's seafood restaurants. Triarc's plan to buy Long John Silver's, based in Lexington, Ky., for $525 million would have created the sixth-biggest fast-food company in the country. Nelson Peltz, chairman of Triarc, said the proposed merger was grounded because "the higher interest rate environment and difficult capital markets resulted in significantly higher costs and unacceptable terms of financing." Long John Silver's operates 1,456 restaurants. Arby's operates more than 2,700 restaurants worldwide.

HEADLINE: Orange County to Gradually Sell Fund in Effort to Limit Its Losses

BYLINE: By SALLIE HOFMEISTER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SANTA ANA, Calif., Dec. 13

 BODY:
Orange County said today that it would sell all the holdings in its investment fund in an effort to minimize further losses, setting off a scramble among local governments and agencies in the fund to recover as much of their money as possible.
The fund now faces a 27 percent loss, or $2.02 billion, nearly one-third more than estimated two weeks ago, and the loss could grow -- especially if the Federal Reserve decides to raise short-term interest rates in the near future. 
 The fund essentially has lost money because it borrowed heavily and made big bets that interest rates would fall, not rise.
Orange County's announcement closes a chapter in the story of an investment fund whose dramatic losses forced the county to declare bankruptcy last week, the largest county ever to do so.
As financial advisers for the fund began talking to Wall Street firms about selling the holdings, more than 180 of its investors -- including cities, agencies and school districts -- stepped up their battles to get back their money, totaling $7.4 billion. [Page D1.]
The financial team advising the county may ask all investors to share the loss equally. But school districts are already demanding that they get back all their money because they were required by state law to keep their money in the county's fund.
In the meantime, these investors must decide what cuts to make in local programs to cover whatever losses they end up facing. Many have already suspended expansion projects and new hiring. They have also begun to press harder to get those who owe them money to pay their bills.
Payrolls continued to be met today, but some suppliers have asked local agencies with money in the fund to pay on delivery of goods.
Thomas W. Hayes, the former California state treasurer appointed by the county to fix the fund's problems, stressed that the liquidation of its holdings "will not be a fire sale," but "an orderly restructuring to eliminate interest-rate risks and reduce the average maturity of the portfolio." Mr. Hayes said it would take about 90 days to liquidate the fund.
The cash from the sale of the assets, he said, would be invested conservatively and without the large-scale borrowing and risky financial instruments known as derivatives that led to the heavy losses.
After days of closed-door meetings and complex numerical calculations, the new financial team, which includes Mr. Hayes and William Rifkin, a managing director of Salomon Brothers, gave its first status report in public today to the county Board of Supervisors.
The driving force behind the decision to sell the holdings was the threat of rising interest rates compounding the losses. Salomon Brothers, which has as many as 30 people working on the project, estimated that the fund would lose $300 million for each rise of one percentage point in short-term rates. The firm said that Government figures due out this week -- including those on consumer prices, retail sales and factory use -- could help encourage the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates for the seventh time this year.
While the financial advisers said the fund could be partly protected from a rise in rates, selling the assets was still important because the county and its other investors needed cash in the next 90 days.
"A $2 billion loss is extremely serious," said Bruce Bennett, the county's bankruptcy lawyer. "We're getting our arms around what this loss means in terms of belt tightening." Mr. Bennett, of the Los Angeles firm of Stutman, Treister & Glatt, said the first priority was getting the losses in the portfolio under control.
The fund disclosed losses of $1.5 billion a week ago. The county had borrowed nearly $13 billion from Wall Street firms against the $7.4 billion provided by the funds' investors, so that the investment pool totaled more than $20 billion.
Mr. Rifkin said Salomon Brothers had already "approached Wall Street firms" about selling the fund's assets and "has been encouraged by their interest." Among the firms said to be considering such bids were J. P. Morgan & Company. A J. P. Morgan spokesman declined to comment today.
Such a firm would profit by selling the various bonds in the portfolio for more than it paid. Orange County may still be better off selling the bonds all at once because the market would be depressed over time if it sold them slowly. A global firm like Morgan can try to dodge such market risk by seeking far-flung buyers for the various securities.
The most difficult aspect for a brokerage firm or bank in making such a bid would be dealing with Orange County's investments in what are known as structured notes, traders said. In the current market, with its rising short-term interest rates, there are few buyers for such bonds, which are intended to profit from sharp declines in rates.
Therefore, bond dealers are looking to combine those notes along with other kinds of investments that will make up a more appealing package and enable the firm to profit on the sale. The firm that will bid the most will be the one that has the most confidence in its ability to actually sell these notes, traders said.
More than half of the portfolio has already been liquidated. Through what are known as reverse repurchase agreements, about 15 Wall Street brokerage firms lent the county more than $13 billion and took as collateral fixed-income securities that Orange County owned.
The county was forced into bankruptcy a week ago when it defaulted on one of those loans from CS First Boston, which in turn sold its $2.1 billion in collateral. Fourteen other brokerages have since sold most of the rest of the collateral. But Merrill Lynch, which has dealt with Orange County for 20 years, has chosen to keep its $2.5 billion in collateral.
Mr. Rifkin said today that the county had lost $1.3 billion on these sales. The remaining losses that bring the total to $2.02 billion are expected to occur when the portfolio is in fact sold.
Apart from the $12 billion in liquidated collateral and Merrill's $2.5 billion, the fund has about $5.4 billion in assets. Mr. Rifkin said 40 percent of that was in conventional securities like fixed-rate debt, where the market value has declined roughly 4.4 percent. The rest is in derivatives, whose performance is tied to an underlying asset like bonds, where values have fallen 10 percent.
The county's advisers said today that meetings with the fund's top 11 investors -- who contributed 90 percent of the $7.4 billion -- were continuing in an effort to determine their needs for cash.
Fund investors said the advisers had told them that the $230 million in cash now in the fund would be sufficient to meet the most pressing needs of the top investors for the immediate future. Beyond that comment, there were no new answers on how the county would offset the losses and what services might be cut.
Late today, the Federal Bankruptcy Court here approved the fund advisers' request to sell the assets. The approval was considered routine because under a Chapter 9 bankruptcy, which governs municipalities, the court may not interfere with a debtor's revenue or property. The court has limited authority, mostly to approve the plan for coming out of bankruptcy.
And in a related matter, Senator Barbara Boxer, Democrat of California and a member of the Banking Committee, cited the Orange County situation today. She called on the new Republican Congressional leadership to reconsider the Contract with America proposals to be put before the next Congress on retroactively changing the nation's securities-litigation process by raising the legal standard for proving fraud.
"If the contract language is enacted," Senator Boxer argued, "municipal bond investors, private investors and even the Orange County fund itself would find it more difficult to sue successfully. The contract would do great injustice to the investing public."

GRAPHIC: Table: "The Imminent Debt Schedule" lists debt payments owed through January by participants in the Orange County Investment pool, which is being liquidated. Pool investors face losses exceeding $2 billion. It is not yet clear whether all debt payments will be made. The amounts invested in the Orange County pool, where listed, are as of Nov. 30. (Source: Moody's Investors Service; Orange County)

HEADLINE: Modest Cuts At High Cost

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13

 BODY:
The Republicans have their proposal for a middle-class tax cut. Not to be one-upped, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House Democratic leader, offered his plan today. President Clinton will probably put forward his own tax cut for the middle class in a speech on Thursday night.
The proposals have these things in common: They are frightfully expensive in terms of what they would cost the Government in lost revenue. They spread the money so thin that they offer most middle-income families less than what it costs to buy a pizza a week. And most economists, regardless of their politics or ideology, view such tax cuts as a lousy idea. 
 The last is not surprising. Proposals for a middle-class tax cut are not about the economy. They are all about political positioning.
Take Mr. Gephardt's plan, which would reduce the taxes of all households with annual incomes below $75,000. In a speech this morning, he said, "We ought to be focusing help to the hard-pressed, squeezed, middle-income families that are either standing still or have been moving behind for the last 15 years."
In other words, the swing voters who determine election results.
Neither Mr. Gephardt nor his staff would say exactly how much his plan would cost or how large a tax break he was contemplating for each family.
But say he decided to offer each family $300 a year, or about 82 cents a day. In 1991, the last year for which statistics are available, there were 107 million taxpayers with pretax income below $75,000, about 94 percent of all taxpayers. If each one got a tax cut of $300, it would cost the Government $32.1 billion (107 million times $300), which is half again as much as the Government spends each year on Aid to Families With Dependent Children, the main Federal welfare program.
Mr. Gephardt said he would find spending reductions to offset the tax breaks. But as has been the case with Republicans, he declined to be specific.
The plan being pushed by Republicans in the House of Representatives would offer each family with income below $200,000 (99 percent of all taxpayers) and children in the household a $500 tax credit for each child. That means that a family with two children would have its taxes reduced by $1,000. The 64 percent of taxpayers who have no dependent children would get nothing.
Generally, the more income that taxpayers have, the more likely they are to have dependent children. For instance, 55 percent of taxpayers with incomes from $100,000 to $200,000 in 1991 claimed at least one exemption for a dependent. Only 42 percent of the taxpayers with incomes from $30,000 to $35,000 claimed such an exemption.
The Republican staff of the House Budget Committee reported last year that the plan would cost the Treasury about $20 billion a year. Internal Revenue Service figures show that about 40 million taxpayers have children and an income less than $200,000; 40 million taxpayers times $500 comes to exactly $20 billion.
Some families, of course, have more than one child and thus would get a bigger credit. But they are presumably offset by the families whose incomes are so low that they pay less than $500 a year in taxes anyway and thus could not take advantage of the full credit.
Politicians of both parties obviously believe such proposals to be good politics: all voters would like to pay lower taxes. But if opinion polls are to be believed, the public is not particularly concerned about taxes nowadays.
In a Harris poll taken after the elections last month, two-thirds of the respondents believed that the state of the nation was not good. But when asked why they felt that way, only 3 percent said the reason was high taxes.
Robert J. Shapiro, a campaign adviser to Mr. Clinton in 1992 and now director of economic studies for the Progressive Policy Institute, is one of the few economists who advocate small tax reductions for middle-income families, and he does not do so on economic grounds. The institute is the research arm of the Democratic Leadership Council, the organization of moderate and conservative Democrats formed to push the party to the center.
"The argument is a social policy argument, not an economic argument," Mr. Shapiro said. After years in which tax breaks were given to the wealthy (the lower rates of the Reagan years) and the poor (the earned-income tax credit), the middle class should have its due, he maintained.
"People in the political class think $300 or $400 a year isn't meaningful, and if you make $100,000 a year, it isn't," he said. "But if you make $25,000 or $30,000 a year, it can be rent for a month or two."
Economists and tax policy analysts say this is precisely the wrong time for such political positioning.
"We can't afford it," said Robert S. McIntyre. "If they have extra money, why don't they cut the deficit or build a bridge or something?"
Mr. McIntyre is president of Citizens for Tax Justice, a liberal group sponsored mainly by labor unions that does research and lobbying on tax issues.
Norman B. Ture, president of the Institute for Research on the Economics of Taxation, looked at the issue from the other end of the ideological stage and came to a similar conclusion.
"The question," he said, "is what should we do to generate growth and savings and investment and technological innovation, and for those purposes a middle-class tax cut is irrelevant."
What really irritates the economists is that they believe a strong economy, like the one now, should be the setting for strong medicine, not sugar doughnuts. Alternatively, when the economy is sour, steps like deficit reduction can worsen the problem.
"The best time to make strategic moves is when times are good," said Mickey D. Levy, chief financial economist at Nationsbank Capital Markets, an investment banking concern on Wall Street. "What the policy makers ought to be saying is: 'The economy is great. Now's the time to put in place some strategies that are going to help the nation in the long run.' "

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
A Harsh New Arena

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 13

 BODY:
As new products go, the problems with the Intel Corporation's Pentium microprocessor are little more than the kind of bugs that computer-chip designers expect with each new generation of technology.
What's different this time is that the escalating importance of the personal computer in work and life -- and Intel's own efforts to promote the Pentium as a brand name for home and office use -- have thrown the designer's craft into the harsh light of public scrutiny. 
 The bugs can be worked out in future versions of the chip. Intel's high-tech reputation may be harder to repair.
Indeed, in Silicon Valley this week there was widespread condemnation of Intel's continuing refusal to acknowledge what outside experts consider to be the true depth of the problem. And yet the consensus among computer designers outside Intel seemed to be sympathy for their technical colleagues inside the world's largest chip maker.
"Most of these guys think, 'There but for the grace of God go I,' " said Jerome Coonen, an independent computer designer who helped develop the mathematical functions for Apple Computer Inc.'s Macintosh computer. "They think, 'I'm lucky they haven't found those wacky operations under my hood,' " Mr. Coonen added.
Intel's Pentium foul-up can be traced to a tiny human error by an unidentified designer at the company.
The flaw that has mired the Pentium in controversy was created by the simple omission of several lines of data from the software the designers used to create the chip's transistors. That in turn meant that a handful of transistors were missing from the finished chip -- an omission that Intel did not notice in early 1993 when the Pentium was being rushed to market.
As a result a small number of division operations made by the Pentium -- just how small is a matter of hot dispute -- create an error that can affect the accuracy of some calculations.
If this were a matter of concern only to scientists, engineers and professional computer users, then the controversy would generate little interest outside the technical community.
But the fact is, of the estimated three million to four million Pentium-based computers that have been purchased, a full 50 percent have been sold into the expanding home market -- a portion of the computer industry that including all makes and models represents a business whose growth rate is outpacing business computer sales.
The lesson for technologists is clear. Consumer products, once thought to be throwaway products that could be made to lower technical tolerances than scientific and engineering gear, may in fact have even more demanding specifications. Consumers have little patience with the trouble-shooting, "bug fixes" and "software patches" that computer professionals may be willing to take in digital stride.
"It is impossible to be perfect," said Aart J. de Geus, chief executive for Synopsis Inc., a Mountain View, Calif., developer of software tools used by chip designers. "But the economic stakes are so huge."
That became clear on Monday when the International Business Machines Corporation said that it was halting shipments of its Pentium-based personal computers because its researchers had found arithmetic errors far more frequently than the one-in-nine-billion occurrence rate claimed by Intel. Instead of once every 27,000 years of normal computer use, an individual could encounter the flaw as frequently as once every 24 days of typical computer use, I.B.M. said.
I.B.M.'s motives for making the announcement were quickly debated, given that only about 5 percent of the computers I.B.M. sells are Pentium-based machines and that I.B.M. intends eventually to promote its own Power PC chip as a Pentium rival. But computer scientists say there is mounting evidence that Intel is understating the likelihood that the division errors will occur.
"I.B.M. has done exactly the right thing; customers have to be aware of the magnitude of the problem," said Vaughan Pratt, a Stanford computer scientist who has conducted his own independent analysis of the frequency of errors in the Pentium chip and found it to be significantly higher than what Intel has reported. His findings are more in line with I.B.M.'s -- and disclose even more errors in some cases.
Mr. Pratt said he was planning to meet with Intel officials to discuss his conclusions this week.
Yet some other scientists said that it was difficult to predict average error rates, as researchers at both Intel and I.B.M. had attempted to do.
Cleve Moler, president and chief technical officer of Mathworks, a software company in Natick, Mass., compared the likelihood of finding a division error with the Pentium to driving on the Massachusetts Turnpike and encountering one of five potholes deep enough to damage a car's suspension.
"If you're in California, you don't care," he said. "But if you drive on the Turnpike frequently, you had better think about whether to drive in the fast lane or not."
Several software companies, including Mr. Moler's, have already used computer networks to distribute free software fixes that work around the chip error by doing division in software rather than hardware. But these can make the mathematical calculations done on standard programs like computer spreadsheets and computer-aided design applications where precision is necessary hundreds of times slower.
Meanwhile, Intel, which continues to stand by its 1-in-9-billion assessment, has said it is working with software companies to provide a solution that will slow down the Pentium by only 5 percent. Intel officials said they would release that software sometime before the end of the month.
Some computer industry analysts worried this week that the bruising battle between I.B.M. and Intel would end up hurting all computer makers as consumers lose confidence in technology entirely.
This seems highly unlikely. Computing has become a way of life for America and the consequences of the Pentium bug are likely to be suffered foremost by Intel.

HEADLINE: County's Schools Say Get in Line, Behind Them

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ANAHEIM, Calif., Dec. 13

 BODY:
Local school districts were shouldering their way to the front today in the race to claim shares of the billions of dollars left in Orange County's depleted investment fund.
The scramble, which began after the county said it would sell off the remaining holdings in the fund, will pit the needs of schoolchildren against those of police officers, city bureaucrats and the providers of all services that make a county work. The fund's value is already estimated to have dropped by more than $2 billion, and forced the county to file for bankruptcy last week. It remained unclear how the proceeds of the sale would be divided among the many municipalities, government agencies and even individuals who have invested in the fund. 
 Orange County school districts, by law, have invested about $1 billion in the county's $7.4 billion investment pool and could face losses of around 27 percent, the size of the overall loss in the fund. But as they figure out how to answer to more than 400,000 young constituents waiting for their books and crayons and hot lunches, school officias are saying they should be protected.
"It's going to be the position of our clients that we should be paid 100 cents on the dollar out of that fund before the county of Orange gets any money," said Richard A. Marshack, a lawyer who represents three school districts that collectively have $138 million in operating funds in the county fund.
"If there is anything left over, then the county would be entitled to it, but I doubt there will be anything left over," Mr. Marshack said.
Even before today, the financial crisis had already begun to bite at schools throughout the county. At Patrick Henry Elementary School here, the principal, Patrick Hart, was told on Monday that he could not have the nine new buses and the extra portable classrooms he had been counting on for an increasing student population.
As small, noisy children carrying large briefcases poured out across the lawn to their waiting parents, Mr. Hart described his economies -- no new hiring, no extra programs, no special supplies -- and recited the new mantra of the county's schools: "Basically, it's one day at a time."
Because the schools were required by law to use the county treasury as their bank, they now argue that they are blameless and should not lose a penny because the county mismanaged its investments.
In the uncertainty that has gripped the county for the last week, most nonessential municipal spending has been frozen. Major projects have been put on hold, from the construction of toll roads, jails and stadiums to an expansion of a police communications system.
"It's certainly no picnic around here," Mel Lopez, the superintendent of the Anaheim school district, said. "We have put a freeze on everything that is not involved with what we call health and safety."
That means no out-of-town teachers conferences, he explained, no faculty seminars, no hiring to fill vacancies, no replacement of textbooks, no nonessential use of the print shop and minimal substitution for support staff like gardeners and custodians, except for bus drivers.
Peter A. Hartman, superintendent of the Saddleback Unified School District, based in the wealthy city of Mission Viejo, warned that without new funds many districts might not be able to operate past February.
"I assume public safety will have the first claim on the funds," he said. "Then I hope it will be the schools. But there are a whole lot of other people out there, big players, with billions of dollars in this. The public schools have about $1 billion, but that's $1 billion that we need, not $1 billion that we don't need. There are no cutbacks available. The only thing we can do is shut down."
In such cases, the state would have the constitutional obligation to keep the schools functioning by providing at least the minimum in operating funds.
Half of the funds for the county'sschools come from property taxes, a quarter from state aid and the rest from a mix of Federal, state and local revenues as well as the state lottery. All the funds have been deposited in the state's treasury and apportioned to the schools based on their daily attendance, local tax base and special needs.
A first order of business, officials said, was to insure that new revenues coming in are separated from the county's investment pool.
In a letter to the county, the state's acting school superintendent, William D. Dawson, demanded that as a condition for continued state financing, a special new account be opened for all new school funds.
"When we write the check, they need to assure that this goes to the schools," said Patrick Kegan, assistant superintendent for the state department of education.
Mr. Marshack, the lawyer, said that bankruptcy suits could continue for years and that some form of interim agreement would be needed to insure that school financing could continue.
Monday was the annual deadline for the property taxes that provide the bulk of school financing. A lawyer for some school districts, speaking on condition of anonymity, said, "The fear is that county employees are sitting in a room opening envelopes and depositing checks and that the county is simply commingling the money and using it to pay county expenses."
The next major payroll for the county's teachers is Jan. 3, and Laura Mathiowetz, a third-grade teacher at Patrick Henry, said: "We are just waiting, like everybody else. I'd be lying if I said I'm not concerned."
On Monday, she said, as she has every year, she dutifully made out her tax check to "Robert L. 'Bob' Citron," the former county treasurer whose risky investments have put her paychecks at risk.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The dire financial problems of Orange County, Calif., are having an impact on pupils at the Patrick Henry Elementary School in Anaheim, where spending is being cut back even as the student population grows. (Jan Sonnenmair for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Carl Marzani, 82, 'Loyalty' Case Defendant, Dies

 BODY:
Carl Marzani, a former employee of the Office of Strategic Services and the State Department imprisoned after being convicted of hiding his Communist Party affiliation from Government loyalty examiners, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 82.
The cause was heart failure, said his son Anthony. 
 Mr. Marzani worked for the O.S.S. and the State Department during World War II. He was convicted in Federal District Court in Washington in 1947. In instructing the jury, Judge Richmond B. Keech said: "This court is not concerned with Communist vices. The issue is whether the defendant knowingly, willfully and feloniously made false statements to Government loyalty examiners."
Mr. Marzani was charged with lying about his Communist Party membership to keep his State Department job. The Government also contended that he had been a Communist organizer in New York.
During the trial, he denied that he had ever been a Communist Party member. Afterward, he called the trial "a travesty."
The case went to the Supreme Court twice. The court's deliberations ended both times, in 1948 and 1949, in tie votes by the Justices, with one abstaining. That left the conviction standing, and Mr. Marzani spent more than two years in prison.
On Monday, Anthony Marzani said his father had resigned from the Communist Party in 1941, after having been a member for two years.
Over the years, Carl Marzani was an economics instructor, film director and book-club co-owner. His writings include three volumes of memoirs in print from Topical Books in Manhattan. Two more volumes are to come out.
Born in Italy, Mr. Marzani graduated from high school in Scranton, Pa., and studied at Williams College and Oxford University.
His 1937 marriage to Edith Eisner ended in divorce.
In addition to his son Anthony, of Manhattan, he is survived by his second wife, Charlotte Pomerantz, whom he married in 1966; another son, Daniel, of Manhattan; two daughters, Judith Cutler and Gabrielle Marzani, both of Manhattan; a sister, Marcella Cullington of Perry, Ga., and two grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Georgia Unit Discloses Loss

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Dec. 13

 BODY:
The Municipal Electric Authority of Georgia said today that it had unrealized losses of about $49 million as a result of derivatives in the authority's $928 million investment portfolio.
The authority, set up by the State of Georgia, supplies wholesale electric power to 48 communities. The authority said that, unlike Orange County, Calif., it had not leveraged its portfolio through borrowings. 
 "We do not need to sell these securities to meet our cash needs, so we do not anticipate that we will ever realize actual losses," said Ron Vasquez, vice president of financial services for the authority.
In its financial statements for the period ended Sept. 30, the authority reported a $40.3 million charge as a result of rising interest rates, which decreased the value of some of the authority's securities. Mr. Vasquez said that by Nov. 30, the authority had lost about $9 million more from the portfolio as a result of the continued upward drift of interest rates.
The charges are booked against accumulated net revenues, which came to $300.2 million after the September charge, Mr. Vasquez said.
Mr. Vasquez noted that the authority had many long-term investments for money needed 20 to 30 years from now to decommission nuclear power plants. "On some of our investments, we have no cash flow requirement until the year 2015 or 2026," he said.

HEADLINE: Simpson Lawyers Ask to Forgo DNA Hearing

BYLINE: By DAVID MARGOLICK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 13

 BODY:
Lawyers for O. J. Simpson today asked Judge Lance A. Ito to cancel a hearing on the admissibility of DNA evidence and consolidate it instead into Mr. Simpson's trial. But it was unclear whether the prosecution would agree to the defense motion, which could allow testimony to begin shortly after New Year's Day.
In their 13-page motion, defense lawyers offered several reasons the two proceedings should be joined: that combining them would help assure Mr. Simpson's constitutionally guaranteed right to a speedy trial, that many of the same issues regarding DNA's reliability will be addressed at the trial anyway, and that expediting things would protect the jury from further waves of adverse publicity. 
 Mr. Simpson's lawyers also said canceling the hearing would give some relief to the people of Los Angeles, who as of Nov. 1 had spent $1.24 million on the Simpson case.
"This course of action is plainly in the interests of judicial economy and of the California taxpayers who have been patiently footing a multimillion-dollar bill for the prosecution of this case," the motion stated.
There was no immediate response from Marcia Clark, the chief prosecutor in the case, who could oppose the defense request. But experts said there was little reason for her to go along and predicted that a separate session on the admissibility of DNA evidence, known as a Kelly-Frye hearing, would probably still have to be held outside the jury's presence before the trial, though that hearing might not be as long as previously expected.
Peter Arenella, a professor at the law school of the University of California, Los Angeles, said delaying arguments about the reliability of DNA evidence until the trial would keep the prosecution from making its best case in opening statements, where neither side can refer to evidence that could later be ruled inadmissible. Moreover, testimony that is so highly technical and tedious -- "about as exciting as listening to paint dry," said Stan Goldman, a professor at Loyola University Law School in Los Angeles -- could break the flow of the prosecution's case.
Mr. Arenella said: "I see no reason why the prosecution should go along with this, because it would be a disaster. I expect this trial will not start January 4th."
But he said the Kelly-Frye hearing may go more quickly than anticipated because of what apparently prompted the defense proposal in the first place: Mr. Simpson's dwindling reservoir of patience, money and, as the families of the two victims blanket the airwaves with increasingly accusatory language, public support. Mr. Simpson is accused of killing his former wife, Nicole Brown Simpson, and her friend Ronald L. Goldman last June 12.
Though jurors are supposedly steering clear of all publicity in the case, the public relations setbacks being suffered by the defense could affect them. Should the protracted DNA debate take place during the trial, the jury would probably be sequestered. Should it go on beforehand, jurors would be forced to spend as many as eight more weeks ducking publicity about the case.
"They like this jury," Loyola's Mr. Goldman said of the defense team. "They believe that if they have to wait until the Ides of March before this jury actually hears testimony, they are going to lose some of these jurors." He also noted that holding the Kelly-Frye hearing during the trial would spare the defense from having to telegraph its strategy on DNA evidence.
In their motion, defense lawyers said their proposed calendar held risks for Mr. Simpson -- specifically, that the jury could get to hear damaging evidence that Judge Ito could subsequently rule inadmissible. They said Mr. Simpson had been apprised of those risks but had gone along with the motion and pledged not to raise the issues on appeal.
But Mr. Arenella, echoing widespread feelings that Judge Ito is almost certain to admit the DNA tests into evidence, said that the risk to Mr. Simpson was minuscule.
One way or another, DNA evidence promises to play a crucial role in the Simpson trial, whenever it finally gets under way. With no murder weapon and, apparently, no eyewitness testimony, the most persuasive evidence in the case may be blood samples taken from the crime scene, Mr. Simpson's Ford Bronco and his home in west Los Angeles.
Even if Judge Ito allows the DNA test results into evidence, defense lawyers are certain to mount a double-barreled challenge to them. Experts will surely criticize the manner in which the blood samples were collected and preserved, as well as the weight that should be given to any of the results.

HEADLINE: Gephardt Calls for Tax Cut For Incomes Below $75,000

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13

 BODY:
The next Democratic leader of the House promised today to propose a tax cut for anyone earning less than $75,000 a year when Congress convenes next month, a proposal that would instantly set his party apart not only from the ruling House Republicans, but also from its own White House.
President Clinton plans to present at least some of his own domestic programs for the next two years, possibly including a tax cut, in a speech scheduled for 9 P.M. on Thursday. Today, in his own speech to a policy group, the new leader of the House Democrats, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, said he did not intend for his announcement to eclipse the President's plans. 
 But he also made it clear that neither he nor his House colleagues were lashed to them, either.
"We'll work as closely as we can with the President and with our colleagues in the Senate," Mr. Gephardt said. "But our agenda will come from America's houses, not from the White House and not from anywhere else."
A spokeswoman for Mr. Gephardt, Laura Nichols, said later that House Democrats had discussed their tax proposal with White House officials, but had yet to hear whether Mr. Clinton, who also favors a cut, would offer an alternative plan. If he does, she said, "We'll talk about it."
In his speech today at the Democratic-leaning Center for National Policy, Mr. Gephardt also said he would seek to force Republicans to offer a detailed plan to balance the Federal budget before any such constitutional amendment was approved and sent to the states for ratification.
He also said that House Democrats would oppose the Republican plan to cut the capital gains tax, and that they would offer a competing plan to reward companies that distributed more profits to their workers, rather than to shareholders.
Those proposals and others amount to a campaign platform for House Democrats, who, Mr. Gephardt said, are already working to regain control of the chamber in the election two years from now.
The thrust of that platform is to direct more Federal money and other Federal benefits to the middle class, and to oppose Republican policies, like the cut in the capital gains tax, as giveaways to the wealthy.
In that vein, Mr. Gephardt bitterly attacked the incoming House Speaker, Newt Gingrich, and his allies, calling them "trickle-down terrorists" and asserting that their legislative program was based on "division, exclusion and fear."
In the next election, he predicted, "they'll lose because their 'Contract on America,' whether you like or hate it, is all slogans and hot buttons without so much as a wink or a nod at real jobs and real opportunities. They'll lose because every time they've taken control of the Congress, they've rolled out their real priorities, more tax breaks for the rich."
And he rejected Republicans' assertions that the last election was an endorsement of their concept of governing. "They think they've won a mandate every time somebody turns right at a stoplight," he said.
As a practical matter, however, the Democratic platform has little more chance of passing the Republican-controlled Congress than did the many proposals Republicans presented in many similar speeches in their four decades as a minority.
Mr. Gephardt wrapped his proposals in a long and sometimes florid speech in which he asserted that Democrats had been tossed out of power not because their ideas were bad, but because they had defaulted on a promise to halt a long slide in the economic fortunes of the average worker.
"We didn't speak to the growing sense of insecurity that is sweeping our factories and stores and even our board rooms: the fear that today's jobs and job growth can't guard us from tomorrow's layoffs and pay cuts," he said. "We did not speak to the growing sense that our children won't have the opportunities that we had, the sense that the American dream, the dream of doing better than your parents, may be slipping beyond their reach."
More than ideology or dislike of Government, he said, voters saw the 1994 election as a referendum on politicians' ability to deliver. On that score, he said, "The Democratic Party, the party that has fought for working people since days of the New Deal, just isn't doing enough for them."
The proposed tax cut is the House Democrats' principal answer to that disaffected middle class, and their first parry to the tax-cutting strategy of the Republicans.
Representative Bill Archer of Texas, who will be the new Republican chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, mocked Mr. Gephardt's effort to keep pace with Republicans. "His statement is exactly five weeks too late," said Mr. Archer, whose committee has jurisdiction over tax policy. "Perhaps if the Democrats' actions had matched their new-found rhetoric, last month's election would have been different."
Mr. Gingrich and other Republicans have proposed their own family-based version of tax relief: an actual cut in tax bills of $500 for every child in every taxpaying family earning less than $200,000 annually. That proposal would omit both the wealthiest taxpayers and the poorest, who do not pay taxes and would not be eligible for the credit.
Ms. Nichols said today that Mr. Gephardt's plan remained in flux. But in essence, it would exempt from taxation a part of the wages of anyone who makes less than $75,000 a year, except low-income wage earners who already receive a break called the Earned Income Tax Credit. Those people could receive either Mr. Gephardt's tax cut or the existing tax credit, but not both.
Mr. Gephardt's office said his proposal would benefit about 69 million taxpayers and would probably cost as much or more than the Republican plan, which is estimated at $20 billion a year. At that rate, Mr. Gephardt's proposal would cut the bill of an average eligible taxpayer by about $290, but how the money would be distributed is not clear.
Republicans have not said how they would pay for their tax cut. Mr. Gephardt would not say how he would pay for his either, but he promised to find some financing device that would not increase the Federal deficit.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the next House Democratic leader, announcing yesterday that he would propose a tax cut for anyone earning less than $75,000 a year. Mr. Gephardt said he did not intend to eclipse a tax-cut plan that President Clinton might announce on Thursday night, but he made it clear that under his leadership, House Democrats would set an agenda apart from the White House. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times--)

HEADLINE: New Old Yankee Stadium?

BYLINE: By MATTHEW PURDY 

 BODY:
A preliminary plan for the renovation of Yankee Stadium calls for construction of an exact replica of the original facade of the stadium as a new outer wall for the ball park, according to Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx Borough President, who was briefed on the plan.
Mr. Ferrer said the new facade would be built 40 feet out from the existing outside wall of the stadium, creating more space for a concession area and additional seating. 
 The plan is being designed by the firm of Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum under contract by the city and the state, which have joined forces to try to keep the Yankees' principal owner, George Steinbrenner, from moving the team out of the city. The Yankee management has said that fans are fearful of coming to the stadium, which is located in the South Bronx.
The preliminary plan also proposes the construction of 90 luxury seating boxes, 12,000 new parking spaces and a picnic area in the left-field bleachers, Mr. Ferrer said. A new parking garage on the Harlem River would be connected to the stadium by a pedestrian overpass.
To make access to the stadium easier, the subway station would be improved, a Metro-North railroad station built on the stadium grounds, and a new exit would be built to allow cars coming off the George Washington Bridge to take the Harlem River Drive to the 145th Street Bridge across the Harlem River.
Outside the stadium, stores, lighting, signs and parks would be upgraded, Mr. Ferrer said. River Avenue in front of the stadium would be widened into a "Walk of Fame" dedicated to Yankee heroes. Also a public high school teaching sports management would be built nearby and a 500-seat amphitheater in Joyce Kilmer Park is also proposed.
Mr. Ferrer praised the plans and said he thought it would be received well by residents of the area.
City officials who reviewed the plans have not publicly commented on them. No money figure was attached to the preliminary plan, Mr. Ferrer said. A final plan is due next year.
Forrest R. Taylor, a spokesman for the Giuliani administration, said the Mayor and Yankee officials had not been briefed on the plan. He said John S. Dyson, the deputy mayor for economic development, was familiar with the plan but had no comment.

HEADLINE: A Private Study Finds Many Children in Shelters Have Signs of Malnutrition

BYLINE: By ESTHER B. FEIN 

 BODY:
Many homeless children tested by health workers in the New York City shelter system suffered from iron deficiency and other symptoms of malnutrition that could severely affect their long-term health, according to a survey by an advocacy group for the homeless.
The yearlong study of 200 children was done by the New York Children's Health Project, which operates four medical vans that travel among some of the city's shelters providing free care. The study was not scientifically designed to project precisely the extent of poor nutrition among the city's nearly 10,000 homeless children. 
 But the doctors who worked on it, and other advocates for the homeless, said the findings were a sign that the health of children in the shelter system, already at risk because of their families' economic and social instability, is further imperiled by a poor diet. They said the problem resulted not only from poverty, but from a shelter system that makes it difficult for mothers to feed their children well.
The study found that 42.5 percent of children between ages 1 and 3 living in the shelter system who were examined suffered from iron deficiency or anemia -- a level twice as high as the national average for children living below the poverty level and six times greater than for those living above it.
Preschool children between 3 and 5 who were examined fared even worse. Their rate of anemia and iron deficiency -- 24.7 percent -- was 2 1/2 times the national average for poor children and 10 times greater than for children in economically stable homes.
The children studied were all those seen by Health Project doctors in their medical vans on one day last year and whose cases were followed.
Nutritional deficiencies have been shown to cause problems not only in children's physical health, but also in their cognitive development.
Iron deficiency is widely considered as one of the best indicators of poor nutrition. The project plans to study nutrition among the city's homeless children more intensely, said Dr. Anne Greene, the project's medical director, but decided to release these preliminary findings now because "they were so disturbing we wanted to draw attention quickly and begin to intervene."
The study also found that nearly 20 percent of the homeless children surveyed were not receiving food stamps, which they are entitled to, and that two-thirds were without benefits due them from the Special Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants and Children, or WIC.
Beyond the statistics, doctors working with the Children's Health Project said that mothers they interviewed were frustrated and demoralized trying to adequately feed their children while in shelters that often have limited cooking equipment, provide little refrigeration, are far from affordable supermarkets and supply pre-packaged meals that are often tasteless and lacking in basic nutritional value.
The mothers also complained that even when they receive the proper food stamps and WIC benefits, the money falls far short of what they need to give their children healthy, filling meals.
"This is consistent with what we see day to day," said Steven Banks, coordinating attorney for the Legal Aid Society's Homeless Family Rights Project. "Federal, state and city policies are creating a lost generation of children indelibly scarred by their experience in the shelter system, literally physically harmed as a result of their shelter experience."
Joan Malin, the Commissioner of the city's Department of Homeless Services, said it was difficult for her to comment on the study before reading it. She said that the city provided extensive nutritional counseling to homeless families, tried to place them in shelters with cooking facilities and worked to assure that they received all the benefits to which they are entitled.
"A portion of the homeless population has complicated problems" that would affect the nutritional health of their children, Ms. Malin said. But, she added, "I don't think by and large that they are different from those of the very poor throughout the city."
Dr. Irwin Redlener, president and co-founder of the Children's Health Fund, which provides private money for the Children's Health Project and other medical initiatives for poor city children, scoffed at Ms. Malin's assertion that the city provided means for homeless families to feed their children nutritionally.
"If that's what she thinks, she needs to visit some shelters," said Dr. Redlener. "There's a lack of reality to her claims."
In response to the project's findings, the Children's Health Fund plans to announce today a new initiative to improve nutrition among homeless children. The new effort, called the Health and Nutrition Action Initiative, will be financed in part by a grant from Share Our Strength, a national hunger-prevention organization.
The new program will include improving nutritional counseling for homeless mothers and increasing nutritional screenings for children.

HEADLINE: Pataki Team Weighs Curb On Welfare

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Dec. 13

 BODY:
Governor-elect George E. Pataki's transition team is reviewing a proposal by a Republican lawmaker that would allow the state to establish sharp new restrictions on welfare benefits to adults deemed able to work.
The plan is intended to circumvent provisions of the State Constitution requiring the state to provide "aid, care and support of the needy." Advocates for the poor have long viewed that clause as a safeguard against the Legislature's slashing of welfare services for the poor.
But under the new proposal, which was developed by the State Senate's Social Services Committee, the Legislature would create a new category of needy people, known as transitionals, who would be eligible for reduced services and cash grants. 
 Though the plan does not clearly define who would fall into that group, it would mainly include able-bodied, childless adults. Other welfare recipients who were deemed unemployable because they were permanently disabled, chronically ill or aged would continue to receive a higher level of state benefits.
The plan is directed at only the state and locally financed program known as Home Relief, which provided $1.2 billion in aid last year, mostly to single or childless adults. State and Federal welfare programs for families and children are not dealt with in the proposal.
Zenia Mucha, a spokeswoman for Mr. Pataki, said: "There are a number of reports being prepared on how to achieve fundamental reform in welfare. We will take a look at all the proposals and their recommendations as soon as we receive them."
Senator Joseph R. Holland, a Spring Valley Republican who is the Social Services Committee chairman and a member of the transition team, said setting restrictions on welfare programs, including time limits, has always been considered vulnerable to court challenges because of the State Constitution's provisions for the needy. His proposal, he said, would allow such restrictions to pass the constitutional test.
"This particular way of defining the needy has never been tried in New York before," he said. "The constitutional mandate to help the needy is not a bad thing, but it's getting out of hand."
In the campaign, Mr. Pataki advocated reducing welfare spending by cutting administrative costs, improving anti-fraud measures and requiring more Home Relief recipients to work for their checks. But he also said he would consider setting time limits on Home Relief grants, a proposal he voted for in the Legislature.
One member of the Pataki transition group reviewing welfare proposals praised the report, saying she thought it established a constitutionally defensible approach for the state to set time limits on welfare. "The Home Relief population is no homogeneous group," said Mary E. Glass, Westchester County's Commissioner of Social Services. "It contains a group of people, probably somewhere between 35 percent to 40 percent, who are employable."
The state's Home Relief population is larger than in any other state, about 390,000 people, three-fourths of whom live in New York City. In 1993, Home Relief cost $1.29 billion, which was split evenly between the county governments that administer the programs and the state.
The idea of restricting Home Relief is sure to encounter strong opposition in the Democratic-controlled Assembly. Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, a Manhattan Democrat, said he had not seen Mr. Holland's report and could not comment on it. But other Assembly members expressed reservations about the idea.
"There may be cost-efficient means of getting more people into work," said Assemblywoman Deborah Glick, a Manhattan Democrat. "That's where we ought to direct our efforts instead of looking at more punitive measures."
Mr. Holland said he planned to introduce legislation early next year to create the two-tiered system for Home Relief. He also plans to introduce bills setting restrictions on cash grants and other services to transitional Home Relief recipients.
Senator Joseph L. Bruno, the incoming Senate majority leader and a supporter of restricting welfare spending, said he had not seen Mr. Holland's report today but he thought changes in the welfare system were "inevitable" next year.
A task force named by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo will release its own proposals for revamping welfare on Wednesday. That study, which will be sent to the Pataki transition team, will call for allowing counties to cut off welfare checks to employable Home Relief recipients who do not find jobs or enter work-training programs within three months.

HEADLINE: Stocks Little Changed as Dow Slips 3.03

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Stocks ended little changed yesterday as gains in bank issues, Walt Disney, and Philip Morris outweighed lower prices for oil, drug and technology issues.
The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 3.03 points, to 3,715.34. But the broader Standard & Poor's 500 index rose 0.68 point, to 450.15, and the Nasdaq composite index added 0.37 point, to 719.49. 
 Advancing stocks outpaced declining issues by almost 6 to 5e on the New York Stock Exchange, where volume climbed yesterday to 307 million from 285.7 million.
Thom Brown, money manager at Rutherford, Brown & Catherwood Inc. in Philadelphia, said, "The bank stocks received a lift after Lehman Brothers raised its investment opinion on Mellon Bank and Keycorp." The stocks were also bolstered by a decline in interest rates as yields on the 30-year Treasury bond fell to a two-month low of 7.85 percent. Higher rates had led to concern that banks' profit margins will shrink.
Among banks posting the largest gains were Bankers Trust New York Corporation, ahead 1 3/4, to 58 7/8; the First Chicago Corporation, up 1 1/8, to 46 3/4; Nationsbank Corporation, up 1 1/8, to 46 1/4; Mellon, ahead 1, to 31 3/4, and First Fidelity Bancorp, up 1 1/8, to 45 5/8. Keycorp rose 1/2, to 24 3/4.
Electric utilities, also sensitive to moves in rates, extended a three-week-long advance. The Duke Power Company climbed 1/2, to 41 3/4; Northern States Power Company rose 7/8, to 46 7/8, and Houston Industries increased 1/4, to 35 1/2.
Since dropping to a six-year low on Nov. 22, the Dow Jones utilities average of 15 stocks has climbed 4.5 percent.
Elsewhere, Philip Morris climbed 1 1/8, to 57 5/8. Analysts said tobacco stocks were unlikely to be hurt any time soon by a Florida judge's decision to grant class-action status to a lawsuit brought by 25 airline attendants. The attendants contend they were harmed by second-hand smoke.
Disney surged 1 1/4, to 43 3/4. The company said sales of "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs" videos topped 20 million copies.
General Electric rose 1/2, to 47 7/8. The company's chief executive, John F. Welch Jr., told analysts at a meeting last night that "it would be better to err toward raising the dividend too much rather than not enough." Sears, Roebuck & Company rose 5/8, to 45 1/8. The Commerce Department said yesterday that retail sales last month increased 1.2 percent amid a surge in purchases of consumer durable goods such as refrigerators.
Rhone-Poulenc Rorer dropped 3 1/4, to 38. A Food and Drug Administration advisory panel rejected Rhone-Poulenc's Taxotere as a treatment for breast cancer and some types of lung cancer.
Automatic Data Processing Inc. surged 2 1/2, to 55 1/4. The data processing company said it expects earnings in the year ending next June 30 to grow more than 15 percent.
