HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Bank's Head Will Retire Early in 1998

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
J. Carter Bacot, the strong-willed chairman of the Bank of New York Company, said yesterday that he would retire in early 1998 and that the bank's board had approved his choice of Thomas A. Renyi to be his successor.
Until now, Mr. Bacot, 62, had not set a retirement date and had divided management responsibilities among a group of executives, none of whom was a clear heir-apparent. In an interview in his ornate office on Wall Street yesterday, Mr. Bacot, who has run the Bank of New York for 12 years, said he had been planning to name a successor for nearly a year. 
 "You've got to let someone else run the show at some point," he said. "I will have been chairman for 15 years."
The Bank of New York, with $50 billion in assets, is the country's 16th-largest banking company.
Mr. Renyi, 48, was named yesterday to the posts of president and chief operating officer of the holding company and its main operating unit, the Bank of New York. He had already been president of the holding company.
The appointment pushes aside Alan R. Griffith, 52, who had been chief operating officer and president of the holding company. Mr. Griffith will now be vice chairman of the company and the bank and will principally look after its rapidly growing credit-card operations.
Mr. Renyi has most recently run the bank's other quickly expanding area: providing computer processing and safekeeping for various securities-related areas. For example, the bank is the leader in holding shares of foreign companies so they can issue American depository receipts that are traded on exchanges in the United States.
Mr. Renyi will keep those duties and also supervise banking with corporations and consumers and the bank's credit policy. Previously, he had been the bank's top officer in charge of preventing bad loans. In 1988, he oversaw the integration of the Irving Trust Company into the Bank of New York.
That merger, one of the few hostile takeovers in the banking industry, established Mr. Bacot's reputation as one of the toughest bankers in the country, willing to offend the gentlemanly sensibility of the profession in the relentless pursuit of efficiency. Mr. Bacot said Mr. Renyi's performance in that merger was one reason he was chosen for the top spot.
"The two banks had very different cultures," Mr. Bacot said. "Tom did a fine job explaining to those people that we wanted to stay the way we did things around here and why we did them that way."
Since then, the bank has grown by employing a strategy based on parsimonious spending and diversified businesses. The bank has extensive branches in the suburbs of New York City, a nationwide mortgage company and a series of lending specialties for various industries, including the media business.
Analysts said Mr. Renyi's appointment was a clear signal that the Bank of New York was no longer pursuing a merger with the Fleet Financial Corporation, a similarly sized banking company based in Providence, R.I. Fleet has been looking for a partner for a so-called merger of equals in which the combined institution could achieve economies of scale and diversification. Such deals are easier to arrange financially than those in which one bank pays a large premium to buy another, but they are much more difficult socially, because the managements of the two partners must cooperate.
Mr. Bacot declined to talk about Fleet in particular. He said that the company would like to diversify outside the New York area but that it would seek to do so by acquiring banks under terms that kept the Bank of New York and its corporate culture under the control of the current holding company.
"Mergers of equals are hard to do," he said.
Mr. Bacot said the bank would continue to seek acquisitions to expand its securities and credit-card businesses and would likely wait to buy banks until the prices for banks fall. "We don't have to merge to grow, so we will be opportunistic," he said.
Mr. Renyi lives in northern New Jersey with his wife and the youngest of his three children. In his spare time, he plays golf and hikes near his house on the coast in Maine. After receiving an M.B.A. from Rutgers University and serving in an Army military intelligence unit, Mr. Renyi joined the Bank of New York in 1971 as a trainee.
Shares of Bank of New York rose 75 cents yesterday, to $28, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Producer Inflation Moderate; Retailers Post Strong Sales

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13

 BODY:
Inflation at the producer level climbed by half a percentage point in November, while retailers posted very strong sales in the month, the Government announced today.
But most of the increase in the Labor Department's Producer Price Index reflected rising energy prices, particularly gasoline prices, which tend to be volatile and do not always signal broader inflation trends. Excluding food and energy, producer prices rose one-tenth of a percent in November. Producer prices are the prices manufacturers and farmers charge for the products they sell to retailers, distributors or other buyers. 
 The slow pickup in prices came even as retail sales increased 1.2 percent from October. The reports indicated that the accelerating inflation that the Federal Reserve has repeatedly forecast in raising short-term interest rates six times this year has yet to appear. The data heartened investors, who appeared to agree with the more optimistic interpretations of today's figures and bid up bond prices. [Page D7.]
The Fed's top interest-rate policy committee is scheduled to meet on Tuesday, after extensive speculation about whether it will raise rates for a seventh time since February.
Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, told a Congressional committee last week that sales of finished products to consumers, businesses and government were an important consideration now as the Fed tries to gauge the economy's health.
But Alan S. Blinder, the vice chairman of the Fed, said at a news conference on Friday that today's retail sales figure would not by itself represent a reliable barometer of the economy, because the figure is subject to revision and because retail sales represent only part of the overall demand in the economy for goods and services.
The producer price figures today held hints of trouble ahead that might concern the Fed. Raw material prices rose a full percentage point in November. Prices for so-called intermediate goods like steel bars and lumber, which are used to make finished products like cars and houses, jumped 1.1 percent, the largest monthly increase since October 1990, when these prices rose 1.4 percent.
Sooner or later, producers will start passing these prices on to retailers, which will eventually pass the increases on to consumers, said Eugene J. Sherman, director of research at M. A. Schapiro & Company, a New York brokerage firm.
 But Jerry Jasinowski, the president of the National Association of Manufacturers, pointed out that with food and energy included, intermediate prices have risen only slightly over the last year while raw material prices have actually fallen by 2.7 percent.
"The increase in producer prices looks worse than it actually is," he said.
The overall Producer Price Index had fallen by half a percentage point in September and again in October, so many economists had expected it to bounce back today.
By contrast, retail sales rose considerably faster than most economists had expected, and many different kinds of retailers posted higher sales. Retail sales were up 8.7 percent from November of last year. The Commerce Department also revised upward its estimate of the gain in retail sales in October, to 1.3 percent from 1.1 percent.
Seasonally adjusted sales of cars, furniture, building materials and other durable goods were especially strong in November, rising 2.3 percent, while sales of nondurable goods like clothing and groceries were much weaker, climbing four-tenths of a percentage point.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Report On Inflation Spurs Bonds

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Treasury bonds surged yesterday as buyers were encouraged by a report on producer prices that showed no evidence of inflation accelerating.
The price of the 30-year bond rose 22/32 , to 9530/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 7.85 percent, from 7.92 percent on Tuesday. The yield is only five basis points more than the yield of 7.80 percent on the five-year note and four basis points more than the yield on the 10-year note. 
 The narrowing difference in yields between some Treasury notes and bonds suggests that "inflation expectations are being lowered," said Tony Crescenzi, a trader at Miller, Tabak, Hirsch & Company.
Prices of municipal bonds rose even as Orange County, Calif., authorized the liquidation of its investment pool. Some $1.2 billion in new issues came to market yesterday. The average yield to maturity in the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal issues fell to 7.01 percent, from 7.06 percent on Monday.
Traders concerned about the selling of Orange County debt were relieved by the announcement that the sale would take place over 90 days, said Ron Jester, a trader at Lehman Brothers.
"Everybody was aware that there was an additional $8 billion," Mr. Jester said. "The only thought was of $8 billion hitting the Street all at once, which would immediately have to be hedged."
Treasury bonds rose after the Government said producer prices rose about as expected in November. The Producer Price Index gained half a percentage point in November. But excluding the volatile categories of food and energy, the index rose just one-tenth of 1 percent. The slow growth in producer prices came even as retail sales showed a stronger-than-expected gain of 1.2 percent for the month.
The reports "are good news for us," Michelle Baires, investment analyst at the Beneficial Life Insurance Company in Salt Lake City, which has $1.2 billion in bonds.
Today, the market turns its attention to the report on consumer prices for November. Economists surveyed expect the Consumer Price Index to rise three-tenths of 1 percent from one-tenth of 1 percent in October.
"The bear market is certainly not over yet," said Mark Sauvigne, a trader at Chemical Securities. "Rates will continue to go higher into next year."
In the corporate bond market, Laidlaw Inc. led three issuers in selling $359 million of corporate and related debt as spreads on some corporate debt widened.
Bonds of finance companies and other short-term corporate securities lost value yesterday as some investors sold them to buy bonds of government-sponsored agencies that offer fatter yields.
Spreads between bonds sold by government-sponsored agencies and comparable Treasury securities have widened by as much as 30 basis points in the last week as investment banks sold agency debt held as collateral for loans made to Orange County.
"It's still a buying opportunity," said Anne Ruff, who manages $2.5 billion for the United Services Life Insurance Company. Ms. Ruff, who was buying agency bonds even before the bankruptcy, said the spread widening gave her even more incentive.
Even so, while agency bonds may have taken their lumps, they may not narrow immediately. "Even though a lot of dealers have already sold collateral, there's more for them to sell," she said. "That will keep agency spreads wide."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Grey Will Take A Big Write-Off

BYLINE: By Anthony Ramirez 

 BODY:
In an unexpected disclosure, Grey Advertising Inc. in New York said yesterday that it would take a large noncash write-off in the fourth quarter, resulting in "a substantial loss" for the full year of $18 million to $20 million.
The write-off will be in the range of $35 million to $40 million, or $27 to $31 a share, the agency company said, almost entirely for good will associated with acquisitions made overseas mostly in the 1980's. 
 Edward H. Meyer, Grey's chairman, president and chief executive, said the charges were related to "our experience in coming out of the advertising recession in Europe and other markets." For instance, Grey's direct marketing operation in France was closed, and several British subsidiaries were integrated into the Grey agency operations there.
On an operating basis, Mr. Meyer said, "Our international operations as a group are strong and are a major contributor to the company's profits."
Grey will raise its annual dividend for the 20th consecutive year, by 25 cents a share, to $3.50, payable on Dec. 29 to shareholders of record on Dec. 22. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, Grey shares closed at $148, down $1.

HEADLINE: How Rent, Not Food, Can Hold a Restaurant's Fate

BYLINE: By BRYAN MILLER 

 BODY:
LA COTE BASQUE, one of New York City's most esteemed and historic restaurants, has lost its lease after 36 years and will be moving in April. As is true of so many restaurants in New York, its dislocation has little to do with food quality, dining trends or management practices. It will have to move, and take on the risk and disruption that entails, because the Walt Disney Company wants to open a gift shop in the space, at 5 East 55th Street, and has offered the landlord substantially more than the $750,000 a year La Cote Basque pays for its 4,500 square feet.
"What can I do?" asked Jean-Jacques Rachou, the chef and owner. Mr. Rachou is being bought out with one year remaining on his 15-year lease. He is now looking at another site in the same neighborhood. Neither Mr. Rachou nor his landlord, the Coca-Cola company, would discuss the terms of the agreement. 
 In New York, where prime restaurant sites command six-figure rents, where many entrepreneurs are now compelled to take on partners with cash to cover expenses and where every square foot must be accounted for on the bottom line, it is clear that real estate plays a big role in determining the city's tastes.
Restaurant industry sources estimate that roughly 50 percent of new ventures in New York City fail within three to five years. Of those, at least 10 percent close primarily because of lease difficulties, real-estate agents and restaurateurs say.
"Rent is one thing you can't really control, and it is such a key element in success," said Fred Sampson, the president of the New York State Restaurant Association. "It is one area where you can be sandbagged before you even get started." After several years of stagnation, restaurant rents have recently started rising.
New York's gastronomic trail is littered with restaurants that have closed in the last year over rent disputes -- among them Chelsea Central, on lower 10th Avenue; Hulot's, on Lexington Avenue; Lora, on West 13th Street; Brazilian Pavilion, on East 53d Street; May We, on Lexington Avenue, and Romeo Salta, on West 56th Street.
Sometimes a landlord refuses to renew a restaurant's lease because it can get more money from another tenant; other times, bad timing contributes to real-estate problems.
In 1986, less than a year before the stock market crash, a luxury restaurant called Mondrian, owned principally by the chef Dennis Foy, signed a $28,000-a-month lease on a space at 7 East 59th Street. The restaurant opened in 1988, after more than $3 million in renovations. "We never made money," recalled Tom Colicchio, the former chef. "We tried to renegotiate the lease, like a lot of restaurants back then, but the landlord had no interest in it." Mondrian closed in 1992.
Many restaurants that assumed high leases in the booming 1980's have renegotiated the rents, as property values and their earnings declined. "Those that could not, just struggled or closed," said M. David Tell, a real-estate lawyer with the Manhattan firm of Wormser, Kiely, Galef & Jacobs.
Still, despite the high rents and volatility in the economy, restaurateurs, real-estate agents and landlords say that entrepreneurs are still drawn by the potential for great success.
"The rents are lower in other cities, like San Francisco, but you don't do the kind of business out there that you can in Manhattan," said Drew Nieporent, who has three restaurants in New York, including TriBeCa Grill, Montrachet and Nobu, and the year-old Postrio in San Francisco.
A large restaurant in midtown Manhattan occupying a 5,000-square-foot space, say on 56th Street between Fifth and Madison avenues, could pay $600,000 or more a year in rent; on Madison Avenue, from the 50's to around 80th Steet, also a prestigious location, the lease could be in the $400,000 range.
Five thousand square feet on Park Avenue South, one of the hottest new restaurant areas, commands rents in the $150,000-to-$200,000 range. On the Upper West Side, prices can go as high as $350,000; prime space in TriBeCa is only slightly less.
Restaurateurs in Chicago have far lower costs to contend with. A 5,000-square-foot restaurant space in one of the most desirable areas, say, off North Michigan Avenue, rents for around $120,000, one-fifth of an equivalent location in Manhattan.
New York's extraordinary rents -- not to mention building costs -- affect the restaurant business in many ways. For one, they influence what types of establishments open. The modest family venture -- the work of a husband and wife who save their money and open their own place by themselves -- is increasingly difficult to realize in a prime Manhattan location, real-estate agents say.
"The days of the mom-and-pop operation are finished," said Michael Whiteman of the Joseph Baum & Michael Whiteman restaurant consulting company. "With minor exceptions, you have to have backers today."
Mr. Whiteman added that the need to find financial backers necessarily affects a restaurant's size, decor and food approach and puts tremendous immediate financial pressures on the owners.
"A restaurant needs instant success," Mr. Whiteman said. "There is such a heavy outlay to get started that there is no time to build up business. The pressure to succeed quickly is immense."
Alan Stillman, who owns four major midtown Manhattan restaurants, agreed. "Ten years ago you would get a location and work it for a number of years," he said, "but now the imperative is for instant success."
Part of the need for outside investors comes from high leases and start-up costs. "Today you see many three-to-five-partner package deals," said Joseph Porcelli of Maloney & Porcelli, a real-estate law firm. "In the 80's there were a lot of investors who went into restaurant investment for the fun of it, but those days are over."
Restaurateurs differ on what they consider to be a reasonable ratio of rent to sales. Mr. Nieporent said that he considered a rent in TriBeCa to be reasonable if it equaled 4 to 5 percent of sales. "That means if I do $1.5 million I can't afford more than about $65,000 rent." Others said 7 to 10 percent of gross was more realistic.
Restaurateurs in New York say that rents are relative; a high rent in a busy part of town may be preferable to a low rent in a quieter spot.
"It remains true that the most important thing is location, location, location," added Jean de Noyer, who has 30 years' experience on the Manhattan restaurant scene and currently owns Le Comptoir, on East 67th Street; La Goulue, on Madison Avenue, as well as the Supper Club, near Times Square. "If you can do the business necessary, then these rents are not a big problem."
After La Goulue lost its old location, on 70th Street off Madison Avenue, in 1992 because the landlord preferred another tenant (Prada, a women's accessories store), Mr. de Noyer moved to Madison Avenue and 65th Street, reopening in late 1993. There, his 2,800 square feet cost $360,000 a year, compared with less than $200,000 in his old 2,000-square-foot space.
Restaurants are frequently urban pioneers, the first new businesses to put down roots in marginal neighborhoods. They may benefit from reasonable leases at the beginning but often find that rents soar when the neighborhood improves.
"Landlords in New York are not looking for a good tenant usually," Mr. Nieporent said. "They are looking for someone who can pay the rent. That's why you have so many lease changes." Earlier this year, Mr. Nieporent concluded negotiations for a space on Hudson Street in TriBeCa.
"It was difficult, and there had been several failed restaurants in the space before, most recently Cafe Americano," he said.
Landlords have mixed feelings about restaurants as tenants. They are desirable because they tend to pay higher rents than retail or other commercial tenants, but they are risky. "Restaurants tend to go out of business more than other places, so they may pay extra for the stability risk," Mr. Porcelli said.
Landlords say it is unfair to paint them as avaricious business people who have no regard for their tenants aside from the monthly rent check.
"There are some landlord villains just as there are some tenant villains," said Jon Chodosh, a real-estate broker who also owns some rental properties in TriBeCa.
"I have been left with a $10,000 water bill by tenants, unpaid rent and other bad debts that I just had to cover," he said. The risk in this tenuous marriage, he contends, is mutual.
Despite the perils, restaurateurs continue to scour New York City for spaces.
"It's very busy out there right now," said Ernest Graziani, a restaurant and lease consultant in Manhattan.
Mr. Porcelli, the real estate lawyer, added, "The restaurant business continues to be an occupation for romantics."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
MORE JOB CUTS ARE POSSIBLE AT BOEING, CHAIRMAN SAYS

BYLINE: Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The chairman of the Boeing Company, Frank A. Shrontz, said yesterday that more production and employment cuts were possible next year, though they would not be close to the huge levels of the last two years. "I am not sure all the decline is behind us," Mr. Shrontz said at a news conference. Boeing, based in Seattle, has laid off about 24,000 people in the last two years and has cut production by about 50 percent, to 18.5 airplanes a month, because of the worldwide airline recession.

HEADLINE: Clinton Tax Plan Said to Include Family Credits and Student Help

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14

 BODY:
The White House is preparing to propose about $50 billion in income tax cuts, probably through a mix of tax credits for families with preschool children and new deductions for college and technical education, Administration aides said today.
The proposal is an effort to reclaim middle-class voters who deserted the Democrats in last month's mid-term elections and to fulfill a promise President Clinton made during the 1992 campaign. 
 Mr. Clinton is expected to sketch the outlines of his tax proposals in a speech to be broadcast nationwide from the White House at 9 P.M. Thursday. The President's speech will be carried live on ABC, NBC, CBS, CNN, PBS and C-Span.
Perhaps $35 billion in cuts over the next five years would come in the form of a $500 per child tax credit for families earning less than $100,000 a year, with another $20 billion in tax deductions for post high school education, officials said.
To pay for the President's proposals, there would have to be compensating savings in a wide range of Government programs and agencies, including the sale to the private sector of some operations of the Department of Energy that produce electric power in western states.
These ideas were among the most popular that emerged after a two-and-a-half hour meeting with the President and his senior economic and political advisers this morning, officials said. But it was unclear tonight whether Mr. Clinton had given final approval, and several officials emphasized that the specifics could yet change.
Even before the White House proposal could be settled, House Democrats unveiled similar ideas on Tuesday. The President now faces the pressure of far more sweeping proposals from Congressional Republicans, including a letter today outlining a 10-point list of recommendations for Mr. Clinton's speech from the next Speaker of the House, Representative Newt Gingrich, and the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole.
Among the suggestions in the letter, which was understood to have been suggested by Mr. Dole: That Mr. Clinton endorse a balanced budget amendment to the Constitution, "recommit" himself to tax relief for working families, trim the bureaucracy and red tape, reform welfare and refuse to support or expand United Nations peacekeeping operations without Congressional agreement.
Mr. Dole and Mr. Gingrich also called on the President to announce that United States forces would assist the evacuation of United Nations peacekeepers from Bosnia only if the European allies first agree to support lifting the arms embargo against the Bosnian Government. The Administration's policy has been to shy away from imposing such a specific demand on the allies.
"The American people have afforded us an historic and once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to dramatically change government for the better," the letter reads. "And the American people aren't the only ones watching -- so is the world, and its young democracies emerging from generations of government oppression."
The White House tonight rejected one Republican proposal: That the Administration impose a moratorium on new regulations for the first 100 days of 1995. Calling the idea a "blunderbuss" in a letter to Mr. Gingrich, the Office of Management and Budget said it could harm food, health and labor standards.
Cooperation will not be easy. The House Republicans' "Contract With America" calls for a child tax credit about three times as costly as the one Mr. Clinton is considering. It would also offer $500 per dependent child, but with no age limit, and it would be extended to families earning up to $200,000. Nearly two-thirds of taxpayers have no dependents and would not benefit from the proposal.
White House officials said the 10- to 15-minute address, which Mr. Clinton wants to use to set a course for the second half of his term, would include many specifics on how the President hoped to help middle-class families. The details of his proposals for shrinking government and cutting spending are more likely to be embodied in his State of the Union and budget messages next month. Aides said tonight he would deliver the Thursday speech from the Oval Office, not his residence, as they had said earlier.
"We have a whole plan, a full circle," one aide said. "You won't see all the circle Thursday night."
One of the questions that remains unclear is precisely how an income tax credit would be structured. For example, officials said the full credit might be available for families with incomes up to $60,000, and phased down in value for families earning up to $100,000.
After promising a tax cut for the middle class in 1992, Mr. Clinton dropped the idea in favor of deeper deficit reduction last year, when Congress did pass an expansion of the Earned Income Tax Credit that amounted to a significant tax break for low-income working families.
Repeatedly, and especially since the Democrats' sweeping losses in the November elections, Mr. Clinton has said he wants to make good on his promise to do something for the middle class. Tax credits for worker education would be especially consistent with Mr. Clinton's longstanding beliefs, and similar ideas have been backed by labor unions and the centrist Democratic Leadership Council whose leaders have recently blamed Mr. Clinton for straying from the group's core beliefs.
The President and his top advisers have repeatedly said whatever tax cuts they proposed would be aimed squarely at working Americans -- which is why the White House has been particularly cool to Republican pressure to cut capital gains taxes.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Personal finance magazines are profiting from concern over financial markets.

BYLINE: By Leonard Sloane 

 BODY:
IT seems most unlikely that 1994 will go down in history as a great year for the financial markets. Stocks, as measured by the Standard & Poor's 500 index, are down close to 3 percent thus far, while the price of the 30-year Treasury bond has dropped so much that its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, is up nearly one-fourth.
Nevertheless, the four leading personal finance magazines -- Money, Kiplinger's Personal Finance magazine, Smart Money and Worth -- all turned in good performances for the year and have realistic expectations for further growth in 1995. Why? 
 "We are running into a monumental wave of acute interest in personal finance," said W. Randall Jones, chief executive of Worth, which is owned by a subsidiary of Fidelity Investments. "In these uncertain times when the economy looks more like an electrocardiogram than the Great Plains of America, people are looking for answers and solutions."
David Carey, publisher of Smart Money, owned by the Hearst Corporation and Dow Jones & Company, offers a similar rationale. "Everyone today is essentially self-employed in that they have to take control of their retirement planning," he said. "If the business books like Business Week, Forbes and Fortune are about the life of business, then the personal finance magazines are about the business of life."
The four magazines reported significant advertising revenue increases for the first 11 months of this year over the corresponding period last year, according to the Publishers Information Bureau. But discounting from the rate card is rampant in the magazine industry, leading to widespread skepticism of the numbers by some media buyers. Still, ad pages can be easily counted, and here, too, there were gains all around.
The largest ad-page percentage increases were racked up by the two new kids on the block, Smart Money, which soared 92 percent, to 828 pages, and Worth, which jumped 21 percent, to 612 pages. Kiplinger's rose 12 percent, to 790 pages, and Money continued in first place with 1,133 pages, although its gain was less than one percentage point.
Worth and Smart Money also posted big circulation gains of approximately 50 percent over the previous year, according to the most recent figures from the Audit Bureau of Circulations for the period ended June 30. Worth posted paid subscription and single-copy volume of 391,000, and Smart Money had sales of just under 500,000 copies. Money and Kiplinger's sold many more copies -- the former about two million and the latter around one million -- but they both reported declines of 7 percent.
Whatever the editorial similarities among the personal finance magazines, each tries to maintain a distinct identity. One may claim that it attracts an audience with a larger household income and so will focus more articles on upper-income readers. Another may claim that its audience has greater educational achievements and therefore is more inclined to read magazine articles.
Perhaps the most extensive separate-identity program in this field is that of Money, which has behind it the resources of Time Inc., itself a unit of Time Warner Inc. In addition to the magazine, Money's other activities include the publication of the Money for Kids annual and two newsletters, the testing of an as-yet-unnamed magazine for young adults and the creation of three indexes: the Small Investor Index, the Consumer Comfort Index and the Cities Index.
"We are moving from a single magazine entity to a broad-based business of personal finance," said Michael Pepe, a group publisher who lists Money among his responsibilities. "It's the creation of what we call Money Inc."
With brokerage firms, banks, insurance companies, mutual funds and other financial services companies moving more and more into each other's turf, the demand for ad space in the personal finance magazines could very well expand next year, regardless of market fluctuations.
"The appetite for personal finance guidance is so great that there is room for magazines that have different tones and different philosophies," said Knight A. Kiplinger, publisher of Kiplinger's. "The first cutbacks will be in the secondary books that don't generate the leads and the sales that the personal finance press does."

HEADLINE: Panel on a U.S. Benefits Overhaul Fails to Agree on Proposals

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14

 BODY:
After 10 months of work, a Federal advisory commission said today that it could not agree on any specific proposals to slow the growth of Social Security, Medicare or other Government benefit programs.
The commission's failure, at its final meeting today, bodes ill for efforts by Congress and President Clinton to deal with the same problems next year. Since Republicans took control of Congress in the November elections, both parties have been proposing tax cuts for the middle class and have vowed not to make any cuts in Social Security benefits. 
 "I feel some disappointment that we were unable to make specific, detailed, item-by-item recommendations," said Senator Bob Kerrey, the Nebraska Democrat who persuaded Mr. Clinton to create the 32-member commission and who then served as its chairman.
And addressing tax reduction, Mr. Kerrey said in an interview tonight, "Tax cuts are inconsistent with the spirit of the commission's work, especially if they make the long-term problem worse."
Buffeted by political crosswinds, the panel, many of whose members serve in Congress, voted 24 to 6 to send a letter to the President saying, "This commission could not reach agreement on the details of a plan to achieve our objective."
The objective, on which commission members generally did agree, was to eliminate disparities between the projected cost of Government benefit programs and the money available to pay for them over the next 35 years.
The panel, the Bipartisan Commission on Entitlement and Tax Reform, said lawmakers and policy analysts should take a much longer view of spending and tax proposals, assessing the likely effects over 30 years, rather than over the five-year period normally used in discussions of the budget.
Mr. Kerrey said the panel had served a useful purpose by measuring the problem and by laying out policy options. "I see it as a success," he said, asserting that Congress now had the information needed to change the laws governing Federal benefit programs.
Several commission said Congress and the President were racing to cut taxes for the middle class without adequately considering long-term effects. Senator John C. Danforth, Republican of Missouri, the vice chairman of the commission, said no one seemed to be concerned about the long-term economic effects of "the tax-cut proposals now cropping up like mushrooms."
Robert Greenstein, a member of the commission who is an expert on antipoverty programs, said he feared that Republicans and Democrats would "get into a tax-cut bidding war that makes our problem much worse than it already is." And another commission member, Representative Alex McMillan, Republican of North Carolina, said politicians were rushing to provide "even more free lunches."
Mr. Kerrey had wanted to increase the age at which people qualify for Social Security and Medicare benefits, reduce benefit payments to affluent people and impose new limits on tax deductions.
Labor unions and spokesmen for the elderly attacked the proposals, saying they would gut the nation's social insurance programs. John C. Rother, chief lobbyist for the American Association of Retired Persons, called Mr. Kerrey's proposals a "slash and burn" approach and said they would reduce the standard of living for millions of workers and retirees.
Another critic was Robert M. Ball, a former Commissioner of Social Security, who expressed relief today at the inconclusive results of the panel's work. "It's a good resolution," he said. "They did no harm."
But Senator Alan K. Simpson, a Wyoming Republican on the commission, said, "Inaction is a willful decision to consign our descendants to misery and bankruptcy." Another commission member, Representative Porter J. Goss, Republican of Florida, said, "Doing nothing is disaster." And Senator Carol Moseley-Braun, Democrat of Illinois, said, "If we do nothing, we'll self-destruct."
Mr. Greenstein said the letter to President Clinton was "a confession of failure." But another commission member, Richard L. Trumka, president of the United Mine Workers of America, denied that there was a crisis in Social Security or other benefit programs; he said the panel, in earlier accepting the assumption of a crisis, had failed to do its job of sorting fact from fiction.
In its report to Mr. Clinton, the commission said the Federal budget deficit was now equal to 2.3 percent of the nation's total economic output. If benefit programs are allowed to grow with no change in current law, it said, the deficit will be 19 percent of economic output in the year 2030.
Members of the commission repeatedly praised Mr. Kerrey as bold and courageous, but they said he had not laid the political groundwork for his recommendations. Indeed, they said, there was little discussion of the details. Representative C. Christopher Cox, Republican of California, said, "We have been unable to debate, consider or amend any of these recommendations." Alluding to the Republican victories on Nov. 8, Mr. Cox said, "Our commission has been overtaken by events."
Senator Harry Reid, Democrat of Nevada, a member of the commission, said that Mr. Kerrey and his staff had not done enough work to estimate the effect of their proposals on the average person receiving Social Security or Medicare benefits. Likewise, when "my staff asked what kind of savings could be expected, in real dollars, over the next 5, 10 and 20 years," he said, "the commission did not have the data."
Other criticism of Mr. Kerrey came from outside the commission.
Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., said Mr. Kerrey had pressed the commission to accept his proposals "without any of the careful deliberation that such consequential decisions" require.
Lawrence T. Smedley, executive director of the National Council of Senior Citizens, said the true problem was not the generosity of Medicare but the rising cost of health care. Nothing proposed by Mr. Kerrey would curb such inflation, he said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Companies
 
General Mills plans to split the company in two, dividing its food and restaurant businesses. Wall Street analysts praised the plan to spin off the restaurant operations to shareholders. [Page D1.]
 
As it completes two hefty purchases, Forstmann Little is now expected to turn to refilling its war chest. Private investors familiar with the company's plans say it will look for roughly $2.5 billion in fresh capital in January. To succeed, its founding partner, Theodore J. Forstmann, must convince Wall Street investors that he can still get the best deals. [D1.]
 
The Transportation Secretary ordered a safety audit of the nation's airlines and a speeding of new rules, which would essentially force commuter airlines to meet the same stringent standards as those for leading carriers. [A1.]
 
A hearing on whether a class-action suit against tobacco companies should be allowed brought out some big legal guns in a New Orleans courtroom. A potential liability of an estimated $100 billion may be at stake for cigarette manufacturers. [D2.]
 
Ameritech will acquire a top security monitoring company. [D2.]
 
National Health Laboratories and Roche Biomedical Laboratories plan a $1.79 billion merger. [D4.]
 
AT&T won a $1.2 billion contract for a 17,000-mile undersea fiber optic cable, linking Britain and Japan. [D4.]
 
"Santa got spammed" -- Internet lingo for bombarded with electronic mail -- as eager programmers apparently misunderstood an offer involving corporate donations to charity. [D4.]
 
Nike Inc. agreed to pay $395 million for Canstar Sports of Canada, a leading manufacturer of ice skates and hockey equipment. [D4.]
 
Philip Morris's chairman will retire on Feb. 1. Geoffrey C. Bible, the chief executive, will replace R. William Murray. [D5.]
GTE said the Army had canceled a contract for hand-held warfare computers valued at $19 million. [D5.]
 
Amtrak plans to cut more than a fifth of its service. [A1.]
 
The Economy
 
Consumer prices rose moderately in November, while industrial output posted robust growth. The data, which showed a strong economy with low inflation, suggested the Federal Reserve was unlikely to raise interest rates next week. [ D1.]
 
Salomon Brothers planned to start selling Orange County debt today as the California county's financial crisis began to stabilize. Salomon will auction $1 billion of bonds bought by the county from several Government-sponsored agencies. [D1.]
 
A plan to require companies to report executives' stock options as an expense was shelved by the Financial Accounting Standards Board after protests by companies and legislators. [D1.]
 
Markets
 
Stocks staged a broad rally, with the S.& P. 500 index rising 4.82 points and the Nasdaq composite index gaining 6.18 points. [D8.]
 
Bond prices edged lower after first rallying on the consumer prices report. Prices of notes and bills surged. [D18.]
 
Lumber prices tumbled ahead of a report on November housing starts. Coffee prices fell sharply for a second day. [D19.]
 
The dollar was held down by the German mark, which continued to gain against the French franc and the Italian lira. [D19.]

HEADLINE: After Year of Despair, Tobacco Farmers Enjoy Prospect of Better Times

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: THOMASVILLE, N.C., Dec. 9

 BODY:
This time last year, tobacco country was awash with doomsayers, and John Collett, a tobacco farmer for three decades, felt little but gloom.
Manufacturers were cutting domestic tobacco leaf purchases in favor of less expensive imports. Lawmakers and health experts were pressing for tough new restrictions on smoking. To finance its health care overhaul, the Clinton Administration was proposing a steep tobacco tax increase that could raise the cost of cigarettes to $4 a pack. 
 "In more than 30 years as a tobacco farmer, I sent two children to college and kept my wife in the clothes she likes," Mr. Collett said as he wandered his 150-acre farm. "But last year and before that it looked bleak for us farmers and I was just glad that I was 62 and not 32 and just starting out."
What a difference a year makes.
To the surprise of just about everyone in the industry, imports of foreign tobacco leaf declined this year while exports of American-blended cigarettes surged, swelling the demand for home-grown tobacco.
The call for a huge tobacco tax increase faded with the death of the Administration's health care plan. Furthermore, last month's elections cheered tobacco interests convinced that the new Republican-controlled Congress will be as hostile to new taxes and restrictions on smoking as the Democratic-controlled Congress was receptive.
The good news for tobacco country is likely to get still better on Thursday when the United States Department of Agriculture is to announce a sharply increased growing quota for tobacco farmers for 1995.
At the start of summer, growers thought the quota, which they accept in exchange for stabilized tobacco prices, would fall as much as 40 percent. Instead, the quota is expected to rise 16 percent to 19 percent, meaning farmers could sell at least 926 million pounds of tobacco in 1995, according to the growers group, the Flue-Cured Tobacco Cooperative and Stabilization Corporation.
A big reason for the increase is that manufacturers have declared that they would nearly double their purchases of top-grade flue-cured tobacco, to 570 million pounds in 1995 from 288 million pounds last year. The rest of the sales will be in burley tobacco.
"It's a surprising turnaround and I'm on cloud nine," said Mr. Collett as he examined his five curing barns packed with the crinkled, dry, golden leaves of tobacco.
That buoyancy is also evident at Tobacco Road, the Philip Morris plant 60 miles south at Concord, in Cabarrus County. There, for an average of $20 an hour, skilled technicians in pressed, tan uniforms work on a highly automated production line that spits out about 85 billion cigarettes a year, or up to 14,000 a minute.
The increases in export demand have meant boom times at the plant, with 40 percent of its output of Marlboros, the No. 1 selling cigarette worldwide, going overseas.
"We could have worked seven days a week and 12 hours a day since Labor Day to meet the demand, and many people did," said Amos L. McClorey, president of Local 229-T of the Bakers, Confectionery and Tobacco Workers International Union, which represents the unionized hourly workers among the plant's 1,800 employees.
"Three years ago we were on three- and four-day work weeks because of slack demand and the anti-smoking zealots poking holes in the industry left and right," he said. "And last year at about this time, management here was telling us to expect the same this year. But it didn't happen and there's been a real upswing now."
Canny politics, incessant marketing and good timing contributed to the upturn for tobacco and tobacco growers. Last year, as cigarette makers increased their use of cheaper imported tobacco, lawmakers from tobacco-growing states pushed through legislation that required manufacturers to have at least 75 percent American tobacco in their cigarettes.
Irate over the requirement, which took effect in January, manufacturers drastically lowered their planned 1994 purchases of newly harvested tobacco or tobacco in growers' inventories, choosing to use up their own extensive inventories instead. But then the demand for cigarettes surged overseas, forcing the manufacturers back into the auction barns this fall, said Tom Slane, an analyst with the Tobacco Merchants Association.
Agriculture Commissioner James Graham of North Carolina, who has seen tobacco's many ups and downs in the last 30 years, said cautiously that the prospects "look good for another year and perhaps even beyond that." For more than three years, he said, growers have been "perched at the edge of a cliff," and the upswing in the demand has let them draw back.
"It's like a reprieve to a dying man," Mr. Graham said.
As for the anti-smoking forces, they concede that the Republican victories in Congress and the cooling of the electorate's ardor for changes in health care make it far less likely that new taxes or new Federal restrictions on smoking will be passed any time soon. But Joe Marx, a spokesman for the Coalition on Smoking or Health, an umbrella lobbying group for anti-smoking and health advocates, said that efforts by state and local government to restrict tobacco had their own momentum.
Despite the conservative tide, he noted, 70 percent of California's voters rejected a proposition that would have weakened local smoking restrictions, while Arizona voters approved a 40 percent state tax increase on cigarettes.
Further, Mr. Marx said, the market forces generally favoring cheaper imported flue-cured tobacco have not disappeared and will continue to haunt domestic growers.
Before the upturn, tobacco growers had seen their sales drop to 798 million pounds last year from about 899 million pounds in 1992. In 1993, for the first time in a decade, the sale of the tobacco crop in North Carolina fell below $1 billion. The state is the nation's largest grower of the flue-cured tobacco, which makes up about 60 percent of most cigarettes made in the United States.
Domestic demand for cigarettes has been shrinking an average of 3 percent a year as the public has grown health conscious, putting dents in the $47 billion-a-year American tobacco industry. Tobacco companies had been able to offset this a bit with an average 2 percent annual growth in the $4.2 billion export market for American-made cigarettes, although that market decreased somewhat in 1993.
But this year tobacco exports came roaring back, encouraged by manufacturers' aggressive marketing of American-blended cigarettes, changing social patterns that made smoking more acceptable for women and the falling of some trade barriers. Projections suggest exports will jump 10 percent this year, to a record 216 billion cigarettes, from 195.5 billion cigarettes in 1993, said Mr. Slane, the tobacco analyst.
That kind of demand is allowing workers in cigarette plants like Concord's to tap into the good life long associated with tobacco growing.
"You see a lot of those around here lately," said Mr. McClorey, the union official, pointing to a Mercedes Benz among the cars leaving the plant during a recent shift change. "And those are hourly workers driving those cars, not executives."
The campus-like Tobacco Road factory, whose 2,100 acres are bathed in the sweet smell of tobacco leaves, sits in the heart of the state's traditional textile region but has become Cabarrus County's largest taxpayer, returning about $2.5 million a year in taxes to the county compared with about $900,000 from the textile plants.
Statewide employment in cigarette manufacturing plants has declined to 17,900 in 1994 from nearly 29,900 in 1965, said Thomas Faison, a senior associate with MDC Inc., an economic development consulting firm in Chapel Hill. But he and other analysts said that the declines reflect increased automation, higher productivity and increased capital investment in manufacturing.
While older plants in Richmond, Durham, N.C., or Louisville, Ky., have experienced layoffs in recent years, the 15-year-old Concord plant has trimmed staff through attrition.
"We haven't felt the decline in domestic demand for cigarettes here," said Terry Rowland, the Cabarrus County tax administrator. "And if there is any obsolescence in the tobacco industry it's not here at this plant."
Back at the Collett farm here in Thomasville, a smile spread over Mr. Collett's weathered face as he contemplated the future, his foot resting on 250 pounds of burlap-bundled tobacco stored in the cool, dry darkness of one of his barns. This tobacco and about 12,000 pounds more hanging in five curing barns were the excess he had grown over his 75,000-pound growing quota this year. The bumper crop was the result of good weather, good soil and superior growing techniques, he said with a wink.
It is not hard to understand why Mr. Collett was smiling: The crop from his relatively small farm should bring in about $140,000, far more than if he were growing peanuts or corn.
"I'll sell this the opening week of leaf season next August," said Mr. Collett, his hand sweeping in an arc to indicate the stored tobacco. "And with the increase in quota, I can still grow a good bit. There was a time in North Carolina when a family of four could live a year off of four acres of tobacco. You need more acres than that nowadays, but you can still make a good living."

HEADLINE: Transit Aides Flouting Rule On Residency

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

 BODY:
For 15 years, the Transit Authority has circumvented or ignored a requirement that its managers live in New York City, and as a result more than half of its senior officials reside outside the city, according to an audit released yesterday.
The study, conducted by the inspector general of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the Transit Authority's parent organization, found that transit officials had "afforded little more than lip service" to the 1978 residency requirement, issuing dozens of waivers almost as a matter of course. 
 In fact, the policy was so widely disregarded that the Transit Authority has paid nearly $100,000 over the last four years to move seven newly hired executives from other parts of the country to suburban towns outside the city, said the inspector general, Henry P. Flinter.
"These waivers were little more than a vehicle for circumventing the residency policy while maintaining an aura of enforcement," Mr. Flinter said in the report. "If the T.A. does not believe in its residency policy and does not intend to enforce it, it should just be honest with the public and say so."
The Transit Authority's president, Alan F. Kiepper, acknowledged that his senior managers had been "less than ardent" in following the rules. He said the authority had been forced in many cases to bend the policy in order to attract highly skilled managers who were unwilling to trade suburban life in other cities for New York's urban environment and expensive private schools. "By having a strict residency policy, you restrict your choices," he said.
When the requirement is waived too often, however, the authority runs the risk that too many of the people making big decisions about the subways and buses do not in fact have to ride them, Mr. Kiepper said.
The residency requirement was established in 1978 at the request of former Mayor Edward I. Koch. Newly hired managers were asked to agree in writing to move to the city within six months of being appointed. No exceptions were allowed.
The idea was to help the city's economy and to insure the managers had first-hand experience with the bus and subway systems.
But the audit found the policy was never enforced. In the 1980's, waivers were granted freely, often for no reason at all, the report said. The audit's survey of managers who live outside the city found that about 60 percent gave no meaningful explanation for their request and 40 percent ignored the rule altogether, never even asking permission to live outside the city.
In 1990, the authority amended the policy, saying that it would allow waivers only when the residency policy created a hardship for an employee's spouse or family. But that decision backfired, the audit said. The guidelines were so vague that they became a vehicle for getting around the requirement while maintaining a veneer of enforcing it, the report said.
The results are clear. Of the 1,308 managers hired since the rule was adopted in 1978, about 512 -- or 39 percent -- still live outside the city. Counting the officials who were hired before 1978, it turns out that 42 percent of the 2,404 managers are not city residents.
Within the Transit Authority's upper echelon, the percentage is even greater: 52 percent of the executives making more than $98,000 a year live in suburbia. The list includes four of Mr. Kiepper's senior vice presidents: Jack Lusk, vice president for customer services, Jerome Forman, vice president for capital programs, Velva Edwards, who resigned yesterday as vice president for buses, and Albert C. Cosenza, the general counsel.
None of the four returned calls yesterday to discuss the policy.
The Giuliani administration, which has fought with the Transit Authority over the size of its bureaucracy and the salaries it pays its top officials, criticized the transit agency's handling of the residency requirement. First Deputy Mayor Peter J. Powers said transit managers should be subject to the same residency requirement that city officials in charge of other services must comply with.
'When you have an agency that pays excessive salaries to its senior managers and doesn't require them to live in the city, there is a concern that there is not a sensitivity to keeping costs down so that we can avoid fare increase," said Mr. Powers, who makes $112,000 a year and lives in the city. "This is essentially a city agency, although independent, and it should have the same rules that apply to it."
Mr. Kiepper, who lives in Manhattan, said yesterday that he personally believes people with responsibility for buses and subways ought to live near them. But he said in many cases the authority has found it difficult to recruit managers if they are forced to desert their large suburban homes for cramped city quarters.
"I frankly think we need to take a tougher line on that," he said. "I am in favor of a more rigid enforcement. I am also in favor of a better policy."
But the improved policy Mr. Kiepper has in mind would in effect render the rule meaningless for most managers. In a letter to the auditors, Mr. Kiepper said the authority had drafted new guidelines that would let most managers live anywhere within the 12 suburban counties in New York State and 2 counties in Connecticut that are served by the M.T.A.
Asked about the proposal, Mr. Kiepper said he still wanted his senior managers and their deputies to live in New York City. "I think a distinction needs to be made between people who really manage the service and who make decisions about the quality and frequency of service as compared to people at lower levels who don't have that much of a direct impact," he said.
Mr. Kiepper also said the authority should be able to make exceptions in order to keep a highly skilled person. "Some judgment has to be used," he said. "Its obvious that from the figures we erred on the side of granting too many waivers and we have to right that equation and be tougher."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Notes And Bills Stage Rally

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended mixed yesterday after a report on consumer prices confirmed many investors' expectations that the Federal Reserve would not raise short-term interest rates this month.
Treasury notes and bills, which are more sensitive to increases by the Fed in overnight bank loan interest rates, rallied yesterday, while the long end of the market declined. 
 The price of the two-year note rose 6/32 , to 9913/32 , for a yield of 7.58 percent, down from 7.68 percent on Tuesday. The price of the 30-year bond fell 1/8, to 9528/32 , for a yield of 7.86 percent, up from 7.85 percent on Tuesday. Yields and prices move in opposite directions.
The mixed results came after the Labor Department reported that consumer prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent in November, but only two-tenths of 1 percent when food and energy prices were excluded.
The increases met the market's expectations, and bonds rallied early in the session on the news.
With the report showing that inflation is running at the same 2.7 percent annual pace as last year, chances that the Fed will raise interest rates at its policy-making meeting on Tuesday "are getting smaller and smaller by the minute," said Terrence Pigott, head trader at Daiwa Securities America.
If the Fed does surprise traders and investors by raising rates for the seventh time since February, "it would be very bullish for the long end of the bond market," said Gerry Guild, head trader at Advest Inc. The Fed has raised the Federal funds rate for overnight loans between banks to 5.5 percent from 3 percent at the beginning of the year.
In the municipal market, yields on many of the $693 million in new issues that came to market attracted investors, traders said.
Many of yesterday's new issues attracted interest from money managers looking to buy bonds in anticipation of a slowdown in issuance next year, traders said.
The average yield to maturity in the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal issues fell to 6.98 percent, from 7.01 percent on Tuesday.
In the corporate market, ERP Operating L.P., an apartment house property manager, sold $100 million of notes, while Clark USA Inc. scrapped plans to raise as much as $250 million by selling junk bonds and stock.
The decision by Clark to shelve its sales may jeopardize its planned purchase of a Texas oil refinery. Clark is an oil-refining unit of the Horsham Corporation of Toronto.
Clark was planning to use the proceeds to finance its $214 million purchase of a Port Arthur, Tex., refinery from the Chevron Corporation., which was expected to be completed tomorrow.
Mortgage-backed securities of the Government National Mortgage Association, or Ginnie Mae, rallied amid expectations that the Clinton Administration would present a plan today to shrink the role of the Federal Housing Administration in insuring mortgages of low-income borrowers.
A diminished F.H.A. role might curb Ginnie Mae mortgage pass-through sales, since 70 percent of the mortgages backing those bonds are guaranteed by the agency, said Lakhbir Hayre, an analyst at Salomon Brothers Inc. The other 30 percent of the loans are guaranteed by the Veterans Administration. A pass-through is a security that passes income from debtors through intermediaries to investors.
Speculation about a decline in issuance of Ginnie Mae bonds prompted some buying.
The benchmark Ginnie Mae 9 percent pass-throughs delivered in January rose 1/4, or $2.50 per $1,000 bond, to 10023/32 , where they yield 8.96 percent. The yield is 114 basis points more than the 10-year Treasury note, down from 119 basis points yesterday. A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent.

HEADLINE: Refilling Forstmann's War Chest

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES 

 BODY:
It will be difficult for Forstmann Little & Company to top 1994.
By Christmas, Forstmann Little, the New York leveraged buyout firm, will spend $2.1 billion to complete the purchase of the Ziff-Davis Publishing Company's stable of computer magazines and the Thompson-Minwax line of paint and wood-care products. Earlier this year, it cashed in on two previous buyouts, generating bundles of profits for the firm's investors. 
 Adding fame to fortune, a founding partner, Theodore J. Forstmann, was recently linked romantically to the Princess of Wales, a rumor that he says is inaccurate and that put his face on the cover of at least one supermarket tabloid.
But after all the gold and glitter of this remarkable year, the 16-year-old buyout firm is now expected to return to an essential, if more prosaic, task: raising money. With his war chest now nearly empty, Mr. Forstmann will try to find roughly $2.5 billion in fresh capital in January, according to private investors familiar with the company's plans. To succeed, he will have to convince Wall Street that he is still hungry enough -- at age 54 and with a fortune estimated between $250 million and $500 million -- to continue fighting for the best deals.
Mr. Forstmann, in a four-hour interview at his Manhattan office, carefully dodged the question of whether and when he would approach investors. But he acknowledged that his firm, with just $300 million left after the $1.4 billion Ziff-Davis transaction closes next Wednesday, would be unable to do any new deals of similar size unless it raised new capital.
"All I can say is that I haven't decided," he said, "but I have a record I'm very proud of."
When the books are closed on the 18 deals in Forstmann Little's current portfolio, limited partners will have gotten back at least $4.9 billion from an investment of $1 billion made between 1980 and 1992. The successes include the Dr Pepper Company, now the Dr Pepper/Seven-Up Companies, and the Topps Company, the bubble gum and trading card maker, both in 1984. The 1990 deal to buy the giant General Instrument Corporation, a maker of cable television equipment, was also lucrative.
Those profits are certain even if all four of Forstmann's uncompleted deals are written off as a total loss, which he said was an extremely unlikely outcome. More realistically, if the firm can eke out at least a modest return on its last troubled investments -- the most promising is the Gulfstream Aerospace Corporation -- investors could recover as much as $6 billion on their $1 billion outlay, according to Wall Street estimates.
Despite this highly profitable track record, many Forstmann watchers wonder whether today's big pension managers, who are coveted and courted by every partnership and hedge fund on the Street, will agree to grant the firm the same fees and profits as its earlier investors.
"I'm not interested in haggling over terms," Mr. Forstmann said, slicing one hand through his silver hair. "I've never changed a comma of these agreements over the years. If some guy wants to change them, his remedy is to invest with somebody else."
Speaking quietly but firmly, he added with a frown: "I know the kind of relationship I wanted to have with my investors, and I have done everything I can to keep my promises to them. If that's not good enough, then fine. I don't need it. But I'll tell you this: If I start out to raise money, I'll finish. I think it would be virtually fraudulent for me to go raise money and not plan to be here for its investment."
That's pure essence of Teddy Forstmann: intense, proud, competitive and, yes, a bit sanctimonious. And "pure Forstmann" is just what will make his new money-raising exercise so fascinating to Wall Street.
It has been nearly a decade since Mr. Forstmann stepped up to the pulpit to deliver his first, fierce sermons to Wall Street in general -- and to his rivals in the leveraged buyout business at Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company in particular. Warning of the evils of using junk bonds, he argued that the only virtuous way to finance buyouts was the way he did them.
His firm often put up as much as two-thirds of the purchase price, with the cash coming from its equity fund, augmented by money borrowed on easy terms from the firm's debt investment fund. The debt fund can afford to be lenient because it also shares in the equity of the newly privatized company.
Sure enough, when the junk bond market faltered in the early 1990's, a host of buyouts arranged by rivals limped into bankruptcy court. By contrast, only one Forstmann deal has seen the inside of Chapter 11. That is the Pullman Company, the only deal that had junk bonds outstanding before the buyout. Pullman filed a prepackaged reorganization plan last month.
"Pullman is a company we shouldn't have bought," Mr. Forstmann readily acknowledged. "We got a good price, but price is about fourth on my list of priorities -- a very distant fourth. It had no significant core business, no dominant market share, no serious growth potential and it was too hooked to the economy."
The failure, Mr. Forstmann reflected with a self-deprecatory smile, was perhaps still useful as a reminder that "there is so much more risk in what I do than I thought there was."
"I really did think you could do things without ever having a problem," he said.
Mr. Forstmann's tone is not all that has changed since the days when he was scolding the Street. The eight-partner firm has undergone a quiet transformation over the last two years. W. Brian Little, the co-founder, has ceded supervision of day-to-day activities to Mr. Forstmann and his brother, Nicholas C. Forstmann, another co-founder. John A. Sprague, one of the early deal-makers, has left to start his own firm. Younger partners -- Steven B. Klinsky, a scout for new deals, and Sandra J. Horbach, whose career began at Morgan Stanley -- are emerging from Mr. Forstmann's considerable shadow. And Daniel F. Akerson, formerly president of the MCI Communications Corporation, has been recruited to add management depth.
Still, no one on Wall Street can imagine the firm without Teddy Forstmann's presence. And one need not follow Buckingham Palace gossip to know that Mr. Forstmann is deeply committed to political and philanthropic concerns that go far beyond Wall Street.
He was a national co-chairman of President George Bush's unsuccessful 1992 re-election campaign. He personally collected and delivered relief supplies to Bosnian refugees -- a commitment that inadvertently helped generate those rumors about the Princess of Wales. He said he talked with her about Bosnia at two circumspect dinner parties, one a large formal gathering in London to promote Gulfstream Aerospace, the other a party at the Georgetown home of Katharine Graham, the chairwoman of the executive committee of the Washington Post Company. (Romance was on neither menu, the lifelong bachelor snapped, closing the subject.)
Despite his outside interests, Mr. Forstmann remains intensely involved in the firm's portfolio, his colleagues say. He is managing the turnaround effort at Gulfstream, and he personally negotiated a key element of the Ziff-Davis deal with the Ziff family.
Ms. Horbach, who joined the firm seven years ago, dismissed fears that Mr. Forstmann would abandon Wall Street for Washington. "He would be very frustrated by all the bureaucracy," she said. "It's true Ted is not motivated by money; he has certainly made more money than I can imagine. But he does love the challenge of each new deal -- finding the deal, winning the deal, and then making the deal work."
For a long time, finding the deal was the hard part. From January 1992 until last month, the company did not complete a single buyout because it was unable to find one that met its criteria. Then, almost back to back, came the opportunities to buy the Thompson-Minwax line from the Eastman Kodak Company, and the Ziff-Davis publishing venture from the Ziff family heirs.
Looking to the future, Mr. Forstmann says the biggest problem may be coping with the consequences of his own success. Many of his investors place self-imposed "asset allocation" limits on the share of their investments devoted to high-risk, high-return ventures like his. "All the equity they still hold in our deals, which is worth many times what it was originally worth, still counts as an allocation to me," he said.
But if he decides to raise fresh capital, there is a simple way around that obstacle, he notes with a shrug. They can just put more of their eggs in Teddy Forstmann's basket.

HEADLINE: Caucasus Rebels Attack, Downing Russian Copter

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Dec. 14

 BODY:
Responding to their leader's appeal to fight the Russians "until they die of fear and horror," separatist fighters in the Chechnya republic today shot down a Russian helicopter 25 miles west of the regional capital and attacked the Russian troops ringing the city.
Film taken after the helicopter was shot down showed Chechen soldiers throwing the co-pilot, who may have been alive, into a ditch by the side of the road. The pilot was killed in the crash. 
 Thursday is the deadline President Boris N. Yeltsin has given for the secessionists to lay down their weapons. In a statement tonight the Russian Government repeated its threat to "use all means necessary to restore order" in Chechnya, an autonomous republic in the Russian Federation.
"We confirm our intention to put an end to the bloodshed in the zone of the Chechen conflict," the statement said. "Those who fail to lay down their arms by Dec. 15 will be responsible for the consequences of their criminal recklessness."
The oil-rich region is important to Russia because oil from Russia's Caspian oil fields passes through pipelines in Chechnya to the Black Sea, where it is pumped aboard tankers for export.
But the chances for peace grew less likely by the hour today after the Chechen delegation abruptly walked out of truce negotiations in Vladikavkaz, North Ossetia, 50 miles from Grozny, the capital of Chechnya.
Pitched battles erupted at several points near Grozny. Russian television tonight showed film of dozens of houses aflame in Pervomaiskaya, 10 miles northwest of Grozny. Russian forces there launched missile attacks, according to reports from the scene.
The overall number of casualties is not clear.
The Russian Deputy Prime Minister, Nikolai Yegorov, told the Interfax news agency that Russian troops would not storm Grozny before Thursday, the deadline. It was the first time a senior Russian official had implied so directly that Russian forces are prepared to do just that.
Grozny seemed to be under siege today, according to reports from the capital. Streets were deserted, many shops were closed and prices were shooting up.
At the other side of the border, edgy Russian officials kept a tight lid on information, banning reporters from visiting military hospitals, interviewing soldiers or entering the military command post in Mozdok, Ingushetia.
And in Moscow tonight, the police began to sweep through train and subway stations and to stop cars to prevent possible terrorist attacks. The police have increased already common searches of anyone they suspect is from Chechyna.
Vice President Al Gore arrived in Moscow today, and while the issue of Chechnya will be addressed in discussions with Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, Washington repeated its general support of Russia in what it views as an internal dispute.
Vladimir F. Shumeiko, the speaker of the upper house, spoke today in favor of the tough line, calling Chechnya a "shelter for criminals from all over the country." Mr. Shumeiko described the breakaway republic this way: "A spreading cancer can only be removed by surgical intervention, however sad that may be."
But others in Moscow, supporters and opponents of Mr. Yeltsin, warned that Russia seemed to be on the verge of a long, hopeless struggle for a region it might never fully control. They expressed concern that any war in Chechnya could quickly spread to nearby regions, none of which are politically stable.
Mr. Yeltsin ordered tanks and troops into Chechnya on Sunday to end what has become a three-year drive for independence.
"You would have to know absolutely nothing about Russian history to behave in the Caucasus like a bull in a china shop," said Vyacheslav N. Shostakovsky, a member of the parliament faction headed by the economic reformer Grigory A. Yavlinsky. "The war Russia fought for decades under the czars never led to victory, even though Russia had an army with the same strength as the one that defeated Napoleon. The war ended only when it was resolved that people in the Caucasus could live as they pleased."
Newspaper editorialists and liberal politicians attacked the President, questioning the timing of the invasion and voicing concern that the political tensions and fears will be used as a pretext to introduce a state of emergency in Moscow and other cities where Chechens live and work.
But in North Ossetia, which Chechnya has not always had friendly relations with, some residents said Russia should storm Grozny without delay.
"They are criminals," said Nina I. Karayeva, 72, a retired teacher in Vladikavkaz. Referring to the Chechen president, Dzhokar Dudayev, she added, "If I had a Kalashnikov, I would shoot him myself."
Mr. Dudayev, a former Soviet Army general, said Russia had increased the likelihood of all-out war. "I call on the population to wage war with Russia until it leaves the territory of Chechnya," he said in a television address, which he delivered in combat fatigues. "We have no other option. The earth should burn under the Russian occupiers."
Russian television reported that this evening, Mr. Dudayev moved from his office on the ninth floor of the presidential palace in Grozny to his basement bunker, where at least eight of the dozens of captured Russian troops are reportedly being held.
Mr. Dudayev warned that if his palace was assaulted, the prisoners would be treated according to "the rules of war." He did not appear to be referring to the Geneva Conventions.
