HEADLINE: Consumer Prices Rise Moderately

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14

 BODY:
Inflation continued at a moderate pace while a rising tide of goods flowed out of the nation's factories and mines in November, according to Government reports made public today. Together, they provided new evidence of the American economy's robust health.
Stocks rose as investors interpreted the economic statistics as a signal that a prosperous economy would reward long-term investments while inflation would not significantly erode the returns. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 30.95 points to close at 3,746.29. [Page D8.] 
 But the bond market, after rallying early, was more circumspect. It dropped slightly as the yield on 30-year Treasury bonds climbed to 7.86 percent from 7.85. [Page D18.]
With only the final month's report to go, it now appears all but certain that 1994 will end as the third year in a row in which consumer prices advanced by less than 3 percent.
The Clinton Administration welcomed today's reports, pointing out that consumer prices are only 2.8 percent higher than a year ago. "We're ending 1994 with the same good-news message about the economy we've had all year -- the economy continues to show strong growth with modest and stable inflation," Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the chairwoman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said this afternoon.
Private economists were also enthusiastic. "This is about as good as it can get -- pretty good production and low inflation," said Sung W. Sohn, a senior vice president and chief economist at the Norwest Corporation, a bank holding company in Minneapolis. "What more can you want?"
Some experts also said that the figures made it less likely that the Federal Reserve would raise short-term interest rates when its top policy-making committee meets on Tuesday.
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, "does not want to be the Grinch that stole Christmas," said Kenneth A. Guenther, a former Fed official who is now the executive vice president of the Independent Bankers Association of America, a Washington-based trade group.
But some monetary-policy economists disagreed, saying that the economy's sheer unrelenting strength may yet cause Fed officials to want to take action next week because of worries that inflationary shortages of scarce materials and skilled workers may develop.
Robert V. DiClemente, a senior economist at Salomon Brothers in New York, said that recent signs of strong car sales and other retail sales, coupled with today's figures, had persuaded him to raise the odds of a rate increase on Dec. 20 to one in two from one in three.
"The odds have been creeping higher," he said, adding that Fed officials may be further influenced by the latest figures on housing starts, which the Commerce Department will issue on Friday.
Led by rising gasoline prices, the Consumer Price Index rose by three-tenths of a percentage point in November, the Labor Department said today. It was the biggest increase since August, after increases of a tenth of a percentage point in October and two-tenths of a percentage point in September, but was still within the expectations of most economic forecasters.
Excluding food and energy prices, which tend to be volatile and do not always signal broader inflation trends, the index rose by only two-tenths of a percentage point.
The output of factories, mines, electric utilities and other industry rose by half a percentage point from October, the Fed announced today. Industry operated at 84.7 percent of full capacity, the highest level since April 1989. That is again approaching the 85 percent level often linked to higher inflation.
Today's generally benign consumer price figures masked two possible hints of trouble ahead. The overall index was held down by a drop in apparel prices as warm weather forced stores to offer discounts on winter clothing, and by a drop in new-car prices because of a seasonal adjustment.
Now that colder weather has hit and with demand for new cars remaining strong, both drops could be reversed soon. "Certainly in apparel and car sales, we will see higher prices in December and January," Mr. Sohn said.
The Producer Price Index, released by the Labor Department on Tuesday, also showed that raw materials prices were rising quickly, as are prices for so-called intermediate goods like steel that are used in making finished products like cars. Mr. Greenspan has warned that these rising prices may eventually be reflected in consumer prices.
Ms. Tyson tried to respond to these worries in her statement today, pointing out that labor costs have barely risen this year. Some other economists say this reflects the rising efficiency of American workers and a willingness on the part of many workers to accept relatively slow increases in wages because of fears of losing their jobs.
"As long as wage pressures remain in check," Ms. Tyson said, "an acceleration of overall inflation is unlikely."
Medical care costs, the subject of considerable political debate this year, rose only three-tenths of a percentage point in November after an increase of six-tenths of a percentage point in October.
By contrast, the Labor Department's index of entertainment costs jumped seven-tenths of a percentage point, led by rising costs for sports equipment and fees for participant sports. The department's food and beverage index rose two-tenths of a percent in November, with a substantial rise in fresh vegetable prices.
The index of gasoline prices rose six-tenths of a percentage point, but remained 14.3 percent below its peak in December 1990. Airline fares dropped 4.2 percent in November, and, adjusted for seasonal variation, were 7.7 percent lower than in August as carriers have competed vigorously for market share by offering many discounts.

HEADLINE: Toronto Journal;
A Land Apart: A Canadian Looks South Sourly

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TORONTO

 BODY:
When American invaders crossed the Niagara frontier during the War of 1812, they came upon the family farm of one of the forebears of the author Robertson Davies and were astonished to find angry youths shooting at them from the farmhouse windows.
"They thought we'd be delighted to lay down the hateful British yoke, but they didn't think they were bringing another kind of yoke with them," said the man some consider to be Canada's greatest living writer. 
 Four of his ancestors fell in that engagement, the Battle of Stoney Creek, and he is proud that it helped to turn the tide against the invaders.
That Canadians are distinct from Americans is a subtheme of his novels, the most famous of which are the Deptford trilogy, "Fifth Business," "The Manticore" and "World of Wonders." In the 11th and latest novel, "The Cunning Man," the aging hero -- not unlike his 81-year-old creator -- rues the withering of Canada's British connection and the growth of the American connection "under the caress of the iron hand and buckskin glove."
Greg Gatenby, the literary scholar who directs the Harborfront International Reading Series in Toronto, said that "in anyone's delineation of the pantheon of Canadian writers, Davies holds a place close to Zeus."
With his magnificent snowy beard, great white mane and protuberant brow, Mr. Davies has a magisterial look as well. As he talked about his views of Canadian nationality on a recent day, wisps of sunlight filtered into his second-floor office above the red-brick quadrangle at Massey College, the University of Toronto's graduate college, where he is the founding master.
Mr. Davies, who was born in Ontario, said the biggest difference between Canada and the United States is in their underlying myths. "The myth of America is a very powerful one and one that we in Canada look toward with envy," he said. "You have your heroes. You have your great men of the past, you have your myth of tradition, of the conquering of the west, and the pioneer life and the gold rush life and all that sort of thing, which is enormously romantic, and nations feed on the romantic tradition."
"We don't go for heroes," he said. "As soon as a man begins to achieve some sort of high stature, we want to cut him down and get rid of him, embarrass him."
He also sees Canada as "very much a northern country -- much more like Scandinavia or Russia than the United States." Moreover, he went on, "Canada is a socialist monarchy. You hate monarchies and socialism -- and we're both."
Mr. Davies is just as eager to see Canada hold together as he is to avoid an American yoke.
"The present hullabaloo about Quebec is precisely that," he said. "It will not die down, but it will not come to anything."
He contends that economic considerations will keep Quebec in the fold. "What happens to the thousands of French Canadian civil servants who are no longer on the public payroll?" he said. "They're suddenly going to be without a job, and certainly the new Quebec wouldn't be able to provide them with comparable income. And what would Quebec do with its share of the national debt? They wouldn't want to shoulder it."
He also expects pressure from the United States. "I don't imagine for one instant that the United States wants a balkanized Canada to the north," he said. The United States says officially that it supports a strong and united Canada.
Quebec separatism is Canada's civil war, Mr. Davies said, but unlike the American Civil War, he predicted, it will not become violent. "Our civil war is a psychological one," he said. "It's a tough kind of war to fight because it's very wearing. There is never any letup. There is never any cease-fire. There is never any stopping to celebrate Christmas."
His comments about French Canadians underscore the observation of Richard C. Davis, professor of Canadian literature at the University of Calgary, that Mr. Davies "comes from a traditional male, English-Canadian base."
The French are "always complaining," Mr. Davies contended. "They have never got over the defeat on the Plains of Abraham," the battle in 1759 that established British rule in Canada.
"They're terribly unrealistic about this sort of thing, but they are also very shrewd and very practical," he said. "They know the dollar better than they know their mothers, and if they think that is threatened by leaving the dominion, they will stay."
Mr. Davies's reflections on politics come from a certain academic distance.
His cozy office is dominated by a large writing desk, bookcases and portraits of Shakespeare, Rabelais, Robert Burton -- whose "Anatomy of Melancholy" provides inspiration for the latest novel -- and John Cowper Powys, the 19th-century novelist whom Mr. Davies called "a great, great, undervalued man."
With the help of a secretary, he handles correspondence in the office and researches current projects. For example, he is now working on an article for the Dictionary of National Biography on a 19th-century English actor, Henry Irving. But his main creative work is done on his 150-acre estate in the hills of Caledon East, about an hour from downtown Toronto, where he lives with his wife, Brenda.
He taught literature at the university for 21 years and still confers with students, including many, he volunteers, who ask whether getting a job on a newspaper would harm their writing style.
A former editor of The Peterborough Examiner, as well as an actor and playwright, he tells them that journalism "teaches you to write more concisely and to get busy and write when you must, instead of just sitting around waiting for the inspiration, which isn't going to come."
And if students are making noise below, he has no qualms about opening his window, looking down sternly, beard flowing, and thundering, "God is watching!"

HEADLINE: Americans Like G.O.P. Agenda But Split on How to Reach Goals

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD 

 BODY:
Americans say they now trust the Republicans in the new Congress more than President Clinton to make good decisions on major social issues. But most remain uninformed about the Republicans' "Contract With America" and they are leery of Newt Gingrich's proposals on orphanages and a Constitutional amendment on school prayer, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.
While there is broad public support for substantial change and, in general, for limiting the welfare system, balancing the Federal budget and allowing organized prayer in schools, that support splinters on the details of how to achieve these goals. 
 For instance, although nearly two-thirds of the respondents favored permitting organized prayer in public schools, about the same number said they would not want to change the Constitution to allow it.
"Those guys 200 years ago knew what they were doing," said Stanley Jaremko, a Republican from Queens who works as a fire marshal. "That's a bad thing to start off doing, because once you change one thing, then maybe you go into another thing and then, before you know it, the whole Constitution's different."
Mr. Gingrich, the next Speaker of the House, and other Republicans have portrayed the mid-term elections as a referendum on their policies and leadership, as they prepare to try to end Washington's domination over social programs by replacing many of them with grants to state governments. Mr. Gingrich has been talking in grand terms about refashioning American civilization and values.
It is not surprising that most people like the basic thrust of the Contract on social issues, even though they may not have heard of the document itself. Mr. Gingrich and his allies molded the contract after extensive Republican polling to test the public's attitudes.
But the new poll suggests that the meaning of the election is far less conclusive than Mr. Gingrich suggests. Many of those polled were still fuzzy on such fundamental matters as Mr. Gingrich's identity.
"Who the hell is that?" asked Don Sherrod, 28, of Florence, Ala., an automobile painter who was one of a number of respondents who agreed to follow-up interviews after taking part in the poll. "Maybe I've seen him on TV, speaking and stuff. But when I come home from work, I'm tired, and I want to sit down in what little time I have and play the guitar a bit."
About the Contract With America, the collection of legislative proposals that Mr. Gingrich plans to bring to a vote in the House in the first 100 days of the new Congress, Mr. Sherrod said, "I'd like to have somebody tell me more about it."
Although Mr. Gingrich has been waving around his copy of the Contract with America, which was printed in TV Guide, 72 percent of those polled said they had not read or heard anything about it. And 65 percent said they still did not know enough about Washington's most celebrated politician to have an opinion of him.
Those familiar with the Georgian have a negative impression of him, by 2 to 1. Only 11 percent held a favorable opinion of him, but those 11 percent are expecting big things.
"I like his fire," said Susan Wuori, 44, a teacher from Guyton, Ga. "He's going to yell and scream and make a difference."
The new poll, conducted Dec. 6 through 9, included telephone interviews with 1,147 adults nationwide and has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 3 percentage points.
Most of those polled had doubts about Mr. Gingrich's proposal that welfare benefits should be denied to young mothers and the money used to promote adoptions or Boys Town-like orphanages for their children. The public instead seemed to side more with President Clinton, who said "Governments don't raise children -- parents do."
Seventy-two percent said the children of young mothers with no income were still better off living with their mothers on welfare than being placed in foster care or a government-run orphanage; only 20 percent said the children would be better off if institutionalized.
"I almost wound up in an orphanage myself as a child when we lost our mother and our father gave us up, and it terrorized me," said Janice Evanson, 48, a computer marketing specialist from Aloha, Ore. "I wouldn't want it to happen to anyone else."
While those polled seemed reluctant to amend the Constitution, a majority said they would welcome the recitation of prayers from many religions in the public schools. Most wanted parents or students to choose the prayers to be said, rather than a school board, principals or teachers.
"I want prayer back in the schools but there are so many different religions now," said Wendy Cardona, 23, the mother of two small boys who works in a factory in Buffalo, putting foam into chair seats and bed packings. "We pray to Jesus. Someone else prays to some other statue. I don't want my son praying to Buddha."
People say they trust Republicans in Congress more than the President to make good decisions on welfare (by 60 to 28 percent); on balancing the budget (60 to 28 percent), and on school prayer (49 to 33 percent).
Mr. Clinton's overall job performance rating has dipped since November's Republican sweep, with only 38 percent expressing approval. In early November, 43 percent approved.
At first, Mr. Clinton's greater attention to foreign policy seemed to pay off with higher approval ratings; in early November, he had a 49 percent approval in foreign policy. But now that rating has slipped to 36 percent.
His rating on handling the economy has ticked up slightly, with 41 percent now expressing approval, compared with the 37 percent offering approval before the election.
But this is a matter that continues to trouble and confuse White House advisers, who do not understand why Mr. Clinton does not get a big boost from the healthier economy: 49 percent of those polled disapprove of Mr. Clinton's handling of the economy.
The public overwhelmingly favors overhauling the welfare system and balancing the budget. But when those polled are asked about specifics, their desires grow murky.
Americans hold overwhelmingly negative views of welfare recipients, for instance, and would like to place limits on how long someone can receive benefits, as the Republicans propose to do. But people also respond very positively to requiring welfare recipients to enroll in Government-sponsored work programs, a proposal of Mr. Clinton.
Seventy-one percent favor allowing welfare recipients in a work program to receive benefits "as long as they are willing to work for them," rather than being cut off after a year or two, as some Republicans propose.
Americans feel so strongly about the work ethic that 59 percent say they are willing to pay more in taxes to provide job training and public service jobs for people on welfare so they can get off welfare.
Despite their instinct for compassion, the public judges those on welfare harshly. More than half say welfare recipients could get along without it if they tried. Another 53 percent said that when people are on welfare, it is because of a lack of effort rather than because of circumstances beyond their control.
"The values and priorities of these families are really out of whack, I think," said Ms. Wuori, the Georgia teacher who says she has worked with underprivileged children for 20 years. "We know that they don't always use their food stamps to buy nutritious food. We know that the kids show up in class wearing $125 sneakers. The Government needs to work it out so that it's not a penalty for those on welfare to work. They need to work and live and start seeing the fruits of their work."
Another contradictory response came on the balanced budget amendment. While 81 percent said they favored an amendment to the Constitution to require a balanced Federal budget by the year 2002, most people were not willing to pay the consequences.
Support for the amendment tumbled to 41 percent if it would require the public to pay more in Federal income taxes. Support for the amendment fell to just 30 percent if it would require cuts in Social Security. Support fell to 27 percent if it would require cuts in Medicare. It fell even further, to just 22 percent, if it would require cuts in spending on education.
Asked what she would give up to balance the budget, a 74-year-old retired shoe factory worker in Lebanon, Pa., who identified herself merely as Mildred, ruminated about saving "oodles of money" by cutting funds for the security of former Presidents and for military bands overseas.
Then she laughed. "There ain't going to be any balanced budget," she predicted. "Not as long as there's a world."
 
How the Poll Was Conducted
 The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Dec. 6 through 9 with 1,147 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of exchanges in the country. The exchanges were chosen to assure that each region of the country was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. Within each household, one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the survey.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to region, race, sex, age, and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
For smaller subgroups the potential sampling error is larger. For example, for blacks it is plus or minus nine percentage points.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll. Variations in question wording or the order of questions, for instance, can lead to somewhat different results.

HEADLINE: Carl Marzani, 82, 'Loyalty' Case Defendant, Dies

 BODY:
Carl Marzani, a former employee of the Office of Strategic Services and the State Department imprisoned after being convicted of hiding his Communist Party affiliation from Government loyalty examiners, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 82.
The cause was heart failure, said his son Anthony. 
 Mr. Marzani worked for the O.S.S. and the State Department during World War II. He was convicted in Federal District Court in Washington in 1947. In instructing the jury, Judge Richmond B. Keech said: "This court is not concerned with Communist vices. The issue is whether the defendant knowingly, willfully and feloniously made false statements to Government loyalty examiners."
Mr. Marzani was charged with lying about his Communist Party membership to keep his State Department job. The Government also contended that he had been a Communist organizer in New York.
During the trial, he denied that he had ever been a Communist Party member. Afterward, he called the trial "a travesty."
The case went to the Supreme Court twice. The court's deliberations ended both times, in 1948 and 1949, in tie votes by the Justices, with one abstaining. That left the conviction standing, and Mr. Marzani spent more than two years in prison.
On Monday, Anthony Marzani said his father had resigned from the Communist Party in 1941, after having been a member for two years.
Over the years, Carl Marzani was an economics instructor, film director and book-club co-owner. His writings include three volumes of memoirs in print from Topical Books in Manhattan. Two more volumes are to come out.
Born in Italy, Mr. Marzani graduated from high school in Scranton, Pa., and studied at Williams College and Oxford University.
His 1937 marriage to Edith Eisner ended in divorce.
In addition to his son Anthony, of Manhattan, he is survived by his second wife, Charlotte Pomerantz, whom he married in 1966; another son, Daniel, of Manhattan; two daughters, Judith Cutler and Gabrielle Marzani, both of Manhattan; a sister, Marcella Cullington of Perry, Ga., and two grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Dow Gains 30.95 on Price and Factory Data

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
In unusually heavy trading, the stock market rallied across the board yesterday, defying many analysts' expectations that stock prices would fall.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 30.95 points, to 3,746.29, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 rose 4.82 points, to 454.97. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 6.18 points, to 725.67. 
 Advancing stocks outnumbered declining stocks by 2 to 1, or 1,565 gainers and 771 losers on the New York Stock Exchange. Still, 133 stocks established new lows and only 16 set new highs.
The stock market generally tracked the bond market yesterday, but kept on rising even when bond prices fell near the end of the day. The yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose to 7.86 percent from 7.85 percent.
The proximate cause of yesterday's rally appeared to be moderate inflation prospects as reflected in the Government's Consumer Price Index for November, which came in around the level of Wall Street expectations. At the same time, industrial output rose by half a percentage point in November, showing a prosperous economy.
If the price index had shown signs of accelerating inflation -- in other words, evidence that the Federal Reserve had miscalculated and had not raised interest rates enough -- the market would have plunged, analysts say. The low numbers ease, at least for now, traders' worries that the Federal Reserve would raise short-term interest rates at its policy-making meeting next Tuesday.
"We've had a run of bad markets lately, so we just needed some sort of spark to set off a rally," said James R. Solloway, director of research at Argus Research. Many analysts had expected the market to fall because they estimated that stocks were overpriced by 10 to 15 percent.
But Mr. Solloway cautioned that the market might be driven by largely technical factors, meaning that traders were buying and selling for the needs of their own portfolios, rather than responding to news events or economic reports.
For example, Mr. Solloway said, traders in recent weeks may have been selling stocks in anticipation of a reduced capital gains tax next year or engaging in "window dressing," selling poor performers and loading up on a few strong performers to improve the appearance of a portfolio.
Whatever the case, the market may have become oversold for the short term, and thus prices for many stocks became too low to ignore, he said.
The Consumer Price Index rose three-tenths of 1 percent, with the so-called core rate, which excluded volatile food and energy costs, rising only two-tenths of 1 percent. If December continues at this moderate pace, annual inflation for this year will come in at under 3 percent.
Many stocks rose. Nextel, after falling for much of the year, jumped 2 3/8, to 15 7/8. Nextel and another operator of networks similar to that of cellular telephones, American Mobile Systems, said they would proceed with their previously announced agreement in which Nextel would own a controlling interest in American Mobile. Agreements with other companies had been delayed earlier in the year.
Novell, a computer software developer, fell 1 3/8, to 15 7/8, after Novell reported fourth-quarter earnings that were below Wall street expectations. Novell was the most actively traded stock at 15.2 million shares in some 5,400 trades. MCI Communications, the next most active stock at 5.7 million shares, involved fewer than 2,000 trades. MCI fell 5/8, to 18 1/2.

HEADLINE: New York Is Just Dandy (if You're From Another Country)

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER 

 BODY:
New York is falling apart? Mean-spirited? Expensive? A terrifying urban jungle?
Nah. Not, at least, if you're from another country. 
 Turns out New York City is a nicer place to visit than many foreign tourists think it's going to be before they arrive.
Such is the finding of a new study of tourism in the metropolitan area released yesterday by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
Certainly any New Yorker who has ever traveled abroad and been asked whether life here really is the way it is portrayed on "Kojak" or "N.Y.P.D. Blue" is aware of the city's image problem.
But Port Authority officials said yesterday that among the most surprising findings of the study, "Destination New York-New Jersey: Tourism and Travel to the Metropolitan Region," was that foreign visitors found the city safer, more welcoming and a better value than they had been led to believe.
More than 1,000 tourists from the Britain, Brazil, Germany, Japan and France were interviewed this fall at Kennedy and Newark airports. More than a third said they had a better time than they expected, and only 6 percent had a worse time.
For some reason, Brazilians like New York better than any other nationality does, the study said; the Japanese and the French like New York the least.
The results announced yesterday represent the concluding half of a $600,000 study, "Tourism and the Arts in the New York-New Jersey Region," that the Port Authority undertook three years ago. The results of part one, "The Arts as an Industry: Their Importance to the New York-New Jersey Metropolitan Region," were released in 1993. The purpose of the project was to quantify the relationship between tourism and the local economy, and to help the city's tourist industry.
These were among the figures:
*The region was visited by 43 million people in 1992, generating $20 billion in economic activity and $1.4 billion in state and local taxes.
*Tourism generated 185,830 jobs in 1992, making it the city's second largest industry employer, after health care.
*Foreign travelers accounted for 15.4 percent of visitors to New York.
The study also took note of the fact that though business forecasters predict a growth in the nation's tourism industry through the end of the century, the increased popularity of pursuits like gambling and outdoor adventure vacations, as well as the construction of convention centers in many other American cities, means that New York's tourist industry is not likely to keep pace.
Indeed, New York is already falling behind. Between 1989 and 1993, overseas visitors to New York City increased at a rate of 1.4 percent a year, yet the overall increase in American travel by overseas visitors was 7.5 percent annually.
As a result, the study concludes, it behooves the tourist industry to promote the image of the region more heavily and to come up with new ways to tie the city's attractions to those of the region as a whole.

HEADLINE: China Delay on Trade Pact

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Dec. 14

 BODY:
China acknowledged today that it no longer expects to join the new World Trade Organization, the successor to GATT, when it opens its doors in January.
In an angry report from Geneva in today's issue of International Business, published by China's Foreign Trade Ministry, the ministry said the outlook for its entry was not optimistic, with the United States and other members of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade making increasing demands on China. Beijing said it was now prepared to postpone discussions of difficult technical issues until the second quarter of 1995, as long as substantive negotiations were completed this year. 
 China wants to be treated as a developing nation, which would give it more time to prepare key economic sectors for liberalized trade.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Advances Made by Mark Put Pressure on the Dollar

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar edged lower against most leading currencies yesterday as the German mark continued to strengthen against European currencies, particularly the French franc and the Italian lira.
Increased buying of marks for French francs and lire "is basically putting a lid on the dollar," said Paul Farrell, vice president at Chase Manhattan Bank. 
 An uncertain political outlook in both France and Italy were the primary catalysts behind the mark's steady rise. The mark, the currency of Europe's strongest economy, is typically a haven for currencies buffeted elsewhere on the Continent.
Speculation mounted yesterday that Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi of Italy might be forced to step down. Mr. Berlusconi is being investigated on corruption charges.
In France, the lack of a clear front-runner for the presidential elections next spring continued to plague the franc. Jacques Delors, who had been widely seen as the successor to President Francois Mitterrand, announced on Sunday that he would not be a candidate.
In New York trading late yesterday, the dollar fell to 1.5682 marks from 1.5730 marks on Tuesday. The dollar also slipped to 1.3265 Swiss francs from 1.3290 Swiss francs. But the United States currency edged up slightly against the Japanese yen and the British pound. The dollar was quoted at 100.30 yen, compared with 100.29 yen on Tuesday. The British pound fell to $1.5630 from $1.5730.
The selling of foreign currencies can at times weigh on the dollar because in shifting from lire or francs to German marks, traders have to reduce their holdings of dollars.
Traders said the dollar was also buffeted by a growing sense that the Federal Reserve would not raise short-term interest rates at its policy meeting next Tuesday. That view was reaffirmed after the Labor Department reported yesterday that consumer prices increased by three-tenths of 1 percent in November.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Yawns greet a warning about the burning fuse on entitlements.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
CONGRESS is required to look five years ahead when it creates the Federal budget. But nobody is obliged to look to 2025 and beyond, when the all the expensive chickens that have been promised to the huge baby-boom generation -- the free medical care, the comfortable pensions -- come home to roost as the last of the generation hits retirement.
Senators Bob Kerrey and John C. Danforth volunteered to deliver the unpleasant news, agreeing last year to head a group of assembled worthies called the Bipartisan Commission on Entitlement and Tax Reform. The idea, a concession to Mr. Kerrey on the eve of the vote on President Clinton's deficit-reduction package, was to sound a very public warning long before Washington faced the choice of breaking promises to tens of millions of retirees, taxing the socks off wage earners or abandoning the pretense of controlling the deficit. 
 But with deja-voodoo economics ascendant in the new Congress, Washington can no longer even summon the interest to shoot the messengers. "I'm afraid we are oscillating around a decidedly downward trend," lamented Henry Aaron, an economist with the Brookings Institution. It is a trend in which politicians find it ever more difficult to deny immediate gratification to the electorate.
The first act of what was intended to be a tightly scripted morality play was the publication of the commission's interim report in August. That report, in which the commission congratulated itself on coming to a near consensus, outlined the sober realities: by 2012, Medicare, Social Security, interest on the Federal debt and lesser automatic transfers would consume 100 percent of Federal revenues. By 2030, Social Security would be technically broke and, by conservative reckoning, Federal outlays would absorb 37 percent of national income.
The solution? Increase national savings, the commission said. Contain health care costs. Compensate for the explosive growth in the numbers of dependent retirees.
But how? The details were left for the commission's final report, due today. And only in the last few weeks have Mr. Kerrey and Mr. Danforth circulated some ideas -- what they apparently hoped would be a starting point for building the 60 percent plurality needed to deliver collective recommendations to the White House. Indeed, when they publicly offered the plan last week, they received virtually no support.
With hindsight, it is not hard to understand what went wrong. The Kerrey-Danforth plan would never have been an easy sell since it included sharp cuts in Social Security checks for future retirees, an increase in the retirement age to 70, a cap on the deductibility of employer-paid health insurance and means-testing for veterans benefits. And since the commission operated under strict sunshine laws, there was never an opportunity to fashion a compromise in private.
What's more, the plan veered off the straight and narrow path of entitlement containment by, in effect, advocating the privatization of a portion of Social Security. It would have cut the payroll tax by one and a half percentage points, but required workers to invest the difference in something akin to individual retirement accounts.
Such a change appeals to policy makers of the center and right, who are uneasy about the growing dependence on Uncle Sam for retirement income. But few commission members were ready to run with so novel an idea on just a few days' notice.
Last but hardly least, suggests Robert Reischauer, the head of the Congressional Budget Office, the plan demands crisis-style sacrifice in the absence of a crisis. "Entitlements don't explode," he noted, "the budget deteriorates gradually." And that leaves policy makers without a convenient moment to rise above interest-group politics in the name of the greater good. The only real whack ever taken at Social Security came a decade ago, when Congress hid behind the big white lie that the system was on the verge of bankruptcy.
Nonetheless, it is hard to interpret the thundering indifference to the Kerry-Danforth effort as anything less than a repudiation of conservative fiscal planning. No wonder: old-stripe conservatives have little sway over the Republican House that Newt built. And with the next Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, an all-but-declared candidate for the White House, it is hard to imagine that most pragmatic of politicians will challenge the entitlement lobbies.
The same is probably true for President Clinton. He took a tentative step along the high road before the elections, criticizing the Republicans' "Contract With America" as a budget-buster. But since the slaughter, he is showing every sign of joining the competition to promise middle-class swing voters the most gain with the least pain.
For worriers like Mr. Aaron, then, it is hard to spot a silver lining in the gathering fiscal clouds. He can react only with "disappointment and sorrow when intelligent people pander" to the idea that unpleasant fiscal decisions can always be put off to another day.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Lumber Prices Fall on Fears Of Decline in Housing Starts

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Lumber prices fell sharply yesterday on expectations that higher interest rates would cause housing demand to slow.
On other commodity markets, coffee fell for the second day, while gasoline rose. The Commodity Research Bureau index of 21 commodities rose 0.41 point, to 229.64. 
 Lumber prices fell as traders looked ahead to tomorrow's Commerce Department report on housing starts for November. Traders expect the report to show another decline, with mortgage rates running at their highest levels in more than three years.
On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, lumber for January delivery fell $10, to $298.50 for 1,000 board feet, the most the contract is permitted to move in one day. Lumber prices have fallen 15.5 percent in less than a month.
"We haven't seen a lot of hard data indicating the housing market has slowed yet," said Gary Leeper, sales manager for the commodity division of Timber Products Company, a lumber mill in Eugene, Ore. "But if you're a contractor, or a supplier for contractors, you get a little pessimistic."
Coffee plunged for a second day as traders said Brazil's crop was adequate to keep the market well supplied, even into next year.
The United States Department of Agriculture said on Monday that Brazil harvested about 26 million bags of coffee last year, more than its previous estimate of 23.5 million bags.
On the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York, coffee for December delivery fell 6.5 cents, to $1.4425 a pound, a new six-month low. The more active March coffee contract also fell 6.5 cents, to $1.471 a pound, its lowest since June 27, the day after the first frost. Coffee prices have tumbled 37.5 percent since Sept. 21.
Gasoline and heating oil rose as stockpiles fell, surprising traders who expected an increase.
Gasoline inventories dropped 1.3 percent, to 212.3 million barrels last week, the American Petroleum Institute said, while stocks of distillate fuels like home heating oil fell 2.1 percent.
Many traders had expected gasoline supplies to rise for a sixth consecutive week, reflecting record production rates as refiners push to turn out reformulated gasoline for sale next year.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, unleaded gasoline for January delivery rose 1.56 cents, to 52.65 cents a gallon, and January heating oil rose 1.06 cents, to 49.54 cents a gallon. January crude oil climbed 8 cents, to $16.99 a barrel.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
The Yankees Make a Deal for an Ace in McDowell

BYLINE: By JACK CURRY 

 BODY:
The Yankees made a stunning trade late last night that could stabilize their starting rotation next season and beyond when they made a deal for the former Cy Young Award winner Jack McDowell from the Chicago White Sox for Keith Heberling, a minor league pitcher, and a player to be named later.
Because of myriad uncertainties raised by the labor disagreement in baseball and the possibility of the owners' implementation of a salary cap today, McDowell is technically not a member of the Yankees and is still a free agent. 
 McDowell fell 52 days shy of being a six-year free agent after the strike began Aug. 12 and, if the owners do implement their new economic system, he would become a restricted free agent like all four- and five-year players. If that occurs, he could sign an offer sheet with any team, but the Yankees would have 10 days to match it. The qualifying offer to McDowell would be at least $5.83 million a season (110 percent of his $5.3 million salary in 1994).
But, if McDowell receives credit for his service time, the Yankees would have to compete for him as a free agent like any other team. Jim Abbott, the Yankee starter, is in a similar situation.
"We hope we can sign him," Yankee General Manager Gene Michael said last night of McDowell. "You have to take chances in this game. We think he's a good one to take a chance on."
Michael, who does not think McDowell will be granted the additional service time, said the Yankees had not yet made an offer to the right-hander because it was too early. Michael declined to discuss who the player to be named is or if the player would change depending on whether the Yankees sign McDowell.
Since the Yankees acquired a talented pitcher who has been one of the most consistent in the American League for the last five seasons, the player to be named must be a valuable commodity, too. Danny Tartabull, a high-priced power hitter with two years remaining on his five-year, $25.5 million contract, is someone the Yankees have tried to trade for the last two years.
McDowell, who turns 29 next month and has twice won 20 or more games in a season, would provide the Yanks with something they have not really had under Manager Buck Showalter: a workhorse. McDowell throws inning after inning and relishes completing games, as evidenced by his leading the league in that category in 1991 and 1992. He was 22-10 with a 3.37 earned run average and 10 complete games in 256 2/3 innings in 1993 and won the Cy Young.
"The first thing that jumps out at you is his competitiveness," Showalter said of the pitcher who averaged to throw 244 innings a season from 1990-93. "He likes to get out there and finish what he started.
Could the Yankees be concerned about Jimmy Key's off-season shoulder surgery? Could they be so concerned that they felt the need to obtain another expensive ace who could seriously escalate their payroll? Michael scoffed at the notion that the Yankees were worried about Key and insisted their payroll will be manageable, even if a salary cap is implemented. McDowell and Key would probably anchor a rotation that included Melido Perez, Sterling Hitchcock and Scott Kamieniecki. Michael sidestepped the issue, but Abbott's career as a Yankee is most likely over if McDowell signs with New York.
"Of course," said Michael, when asked if he would have made the deal if Key had not had surgery. "When you get a chance to get someone like this, you do it. We were only looking at the top pitchers. We think we got one."
After stumbling in the 1993 American League Championship Series with two losses and a 10.00 e.r.a. against Toronto, McDowell proceeded to have what was considered an erratic year for him with a 10-9 record, a 3.73 e.r.a., 6 complete games and 127 strikeouts in 181 innings. He criticized the White Sox throughout his career and was not expected to re-sign with them.
A first-round pick out of Stanford University in the 1987 draft, McDowell is 91-58 lifetime with a 3.50 e.r.a. in 191 starts, 52 of which he has completed. His repertory includes a 90 mile an hour fastball and a nasty split-finger pitch, and he is known for his intensity and for brushing hitters off the plate with inside stuff.
Heberling was 11-7 with a 2.92 e.r.a. at Class A Tampa last year. Who will join Heberling in leaving the Yankees remained the mystery.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Baseball's Best Remedy Is a Repeal

BYLINE: By DAVE ANDERSON 

 BODY:
THE newest advice in baseball is the oldest advice in politics: Write your Senators and Representatives.
If you're interested in seeing major league baseball the way it ought be instead of picket lines and replacement players, then you the people should inform Congress that the time has come for it to repeal baseball's antitrust exemption. 
 Throughout the labor dispute that has evolved into the likelihood that the club owners will impose a salary cap today, the union has indicated that, if the antitrust exemption is repealed, it would end the strike and litigate its problems.
But only Congress can end baseball's exemption from the antitrust laws.
When the Supreme Court rejected Curt Flood's bid for free agency in 1972, Justice Harry Blackmun described the exemption that was granted in 1922 by the Supreme Court as an "anomaly" and an "aberration."
"If there is any inconsistency or illogic in all this," Blackmun wrote in his opinion, "it is an inconsistency and illogic of long standing that is to be remedied by the Congress and not by this Court."
If ever a remedy were needed, it is now.
On behalf of Florida's sumptuous spring training economy, that state's two Senators, Connie Mack, a Republican, and Bob Graham, a Democrat, have asked Senator Orrin Hatch, Republican of Utah, for "speedy action on legislation applying the same laws of fair competition to baseball" that apply to pro football, pro basketball and pro hockey.
"It's not a level playing field, when owners have a remedy and the players do not have a comparable remedy enjoyed by other similarly situated athletes," Mack and Graham wrote in their letter to Hatch, who is expected to be chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee when Congress reconvenes early next month.
But much more than Florida's economy is at stake now. Major league baseball as we know it is at stake. If the impasse continues into the season, if some players cross a picket line and others don't, if the proposed United League becomes a reality, major league baseball might never be the same again.
And if the United League materializes, will it also inherit an antitrust exemption? If not, why not?
How the new Congress will react is hard to say. Some members will surely equate a repeal with an end to the strike. Others will surely not want to interfere in baseball's labor problems. Others will sneer, and rightly so, that Congress has many more important issues to consider than how baseball should be governed.
"Baseball's antitrust exemption should be done away with no matter what; baseball should be under the same laws as any other business," said Jim Bunning, a Republican from Kentucky who is Congress's only right-hander with a career 224-184 record. "At least its labor negotiations should be nonexempt from antitrust law."
Time is a factor. When the antitrust exemption was argued in Washington during the early weeks of the strike, there wasn't enough time to do much. And with spring training scheduled to open in the final week of February and the season to open on April 2, time is still short.
George Mitchell, Democrat of Maine, often mentioned as baseball's next commissioner once the labor dispute is resolved, did not seek re-election after having been the majority leader of the Senate since 1989. But as one of those who did not support the repeal, he could still influence the opinion of others in Congress.
Baseball lobbyists have argued that a repeal would damage the minor leagues, that if a major league club's control over a player were to be limited to four years instead of six years, it would lose its incentive to subsidize the minors. It's an argument that would charm legislators from almost every state.
"Major league teams spend a total of $130 million on their minor league operations," said Stanley Brand, the vice president of the minor leagues' governing body. "Without that investment, the economic forecast for the minor leagues would be dire. It would eliminate 120 teams in the Class A and Rookie leagues."
But decades ago there were dozens of Class B, C and D leagues. The minors have survived without them. And whatever the future of the minors, the future of the big leagues is what's at stake now. Write your Senators and Representatives.

HEADLINE: Family Resort in the Catskills Seeking to Survive

BYLINE: By BARBARA LLOYD 

 BODY:
When people plan a benefit -- a dinner, a dance, or maybe a walk-a-thon -- they are usually out to raise money for some charitable cause. But in the heart of the Catskills, the focus has been on a ski area.
The future of Belleayre Mountain in Highmount, N.Y., is at stake. Having survived extinction a decade ago, the midsize ski area is competing now in an industry of corporate giants. At Belleayre, a group of mostly volunteers is fighting against the inevitable wave of attrition. 
 The Coalition to Save Belleayre staged a formal dance last Friday in a lodge at the Belleayre Mountain Ski Center. The benefit was organized to raise money for the Belleayre Conservatory, a cultural adjunct of the ski area that stages summer concerts on the mountain. But summer or winter, it is all the same place, and its ultimate demise has raised concern.
"Belleayre is a family mountain," said Joe Kelly, a New York City securities executive who has skied there for 20 years. "Families who started to ski there go off to bigger areas, but then come back. That's really what Belleayre is all about -- kids, parents, grandparents."
There is reason for smaller ski resorts to be on the alert. According to a report last month in Snow Country magazine, more than 400 mostly small ski areas have gone out of business since 1977.
With survival in mind, Belleayre has decided to play the game of bigger is better. The ski center wants to acquire Highmount, the defunct resort that sits like a sleeping lamb on the backside of Belleayre Mountain. And it's also looking for an ally to develop a virgin area at the eastern end of the hill.
Recent announcements give weight to the trend toward consolidation. Sunday River, Me., now shares ownership with Attitash, N.H., and Sugarbush, Vt. Aspen and Snowmass have merged with their Colorado neighbor, Aspen Highlands. And owners of the Killington resort in Vermont have made Waterville Valley, N.H., their latest acquisition. The S-K-I Ltd. group also owns Mount Stowe and Haystack in Vermont, Bear Mountain in California and Sugarloaf in Maine.
Belleayre, an area with 33 trails and 9 lifts, has struggled for the last 10 years to keep up. As the only ski area wholly owned and operated by New York State, Belleayre cannot afford to go into the red. The state wouldn't like it, and neither would the locals. So far, revenues hold a slim lead over deficits.
"If we closed, 30 hotels would go out of business, plus another 30 restaurants or so," said Joan Bauer, director of marketing for Belleayre. "We're an essential economic catalyst to this region."
Highmount Ski Center, a privately owned operation, closed last winter. With five trails and five lifts, the area is anything but a skier's paradise. Yet the Belleayre Coalition, of which Kelly is chairman, sees Highmount as a "highly visible sore in an area that doesn't need it."
The asking price is $700,000, a cost that looks negotiable, Kelly said. Since New York City draws its water from the region, state officials look at tourism as a lesser of development evils. Kelly urges the purchase of Highmount as a call to action in a time when "attention is focused on the Catskills for its mother lode of water."
"You've got to improve to compete," he added.
In fact, the Belleayre Mountain Ski Center just finished a decade of capital improvements. The state agreed in 1984 to a $16 million subsidy at Belleayre. But a large state deficit is unlikely to loosen any more money from state funds.
Instead, Belleayre planners are trying to attract private investment. They also acknowledge that they would have to work out an agreement with state forest officials. But given the available terrain, they are determined.
Dean Gitter, executive director of the Central Catskill Planning Alliance, has reviewed a 1988 study from Snow Engineering, of Littleton, N.H. As a leading ski area planner, the engineering firm found Belleayre's untouched east side highly desirable for ski area expansion. With 600 feet of additional vertical drop, and the potential for 14 miles of new trails, there is room for adding advanced terrain to Belleayre.
It helps that Belleayre is situated within 140 miles of the New York City region.
"The ski industry is now concentrated in large and sophisticated hands," Gitter said. "But we also have the opportunity to have a first-class area close to a major metropolitan area. The mountain on the eastern end would keep most any demanding skier interested."

LENGTH: 250 words

HEADLINE: Farewell, National Prune Day

 BODY:
The 104th Congress has not yet begun. But the incoming class of 73 new Republican House members can already claim one small victory for common sense. Last week the Republican Conference approved a freshman-sponsored resolution to end the embarrassing Congressional tradition of honoring what is trivial and, thus, of trivializing what is honorable. It is this tradition that has given us empty commemorative events like National Tap Dance Day and Dairy Goat Awareness Week.
This inflationary exercise began innocently enough when Congress designated Mother's Day in 1918. But Congress's soft spot for commemoratives has since extended well beyond Mom to considering non-occasions like National Good Teen Day, Grapefruit Month and Random Acts of Kindness Week. 
 Most proposals die for lack of support from the required majority in both chambers. But each of the more than 300 commemorative bills submitted in the last Congress ate up the time and energy required to round up the necessary signatures.
The Republican resolution, which must still be approved when the new Congress convenes, would hand the chore of designating ersatz holidays to a Presidential commemorative commission.
For this modest step toward legislative sanity, the Republican freshmen deserve praise. Having stared down National Prune Day, they might now deploy the same zeal on weightier matters so far overlooked by Speaker-designate Newt Gingrich -- like, for starters, campaign finance and lobbying reform.

HEADLINE: Orange County's Fatal Error

 BODY:
The bankruptcy of Orange County, California -- the biggest municipal bankruptcy ever -- is turning chaotic. The county's investment fund, whose contributors include 60 school districts and 11 water districts, is no longer returning principal or interest to its participants. The cutoff forced the county to suspend highway repairs and tax refunds. Schools, which were legally required to invest in the fund, health clinics and social service providers may run out of money to pay salaries.
The fiasco raises two questions. What caused the bankruptcy? What can prevent similar episodes across the country? 
 The county fund lost money by buying complex, volatile securities known as derivatives, whose value rises and falls with the price of underlying bonds, stocks, currencies and interest rates. Many observers have leaped to the presumption that money-losing derivatives caused the bankruptcy.
The presumption is unwarranted. The fund's flagrant mistake was not which securities it bought, but its choice of an irresponsibly risky investment strategy. Robert Citron, the County Treasurer, brazenly borrowed billions of dollars at low short-term rates of interest in order to buy higher-yielding long-term bonds and other securities.
The strategy amounted to a risky gamble that interest rates would fall; if they did, Mr. Citron's borrowing costs would fall and the value of his long-term bonds would rise. For years he racked up fabulous gains, becoming a local hero by earning profits in excess of 7 percent when other county funds settled for half as much. Indeed, Mr. Citron was elected as a Democrat in a ferociously Republican county even though his opponent ridiculed Mr. Citron's risky strategy.
But this year the Federal Reserve has been jacking up interest rates to clamp down on inflation. The rates at which Mr. Citron was forced to borrow rose above the return the fund could earn on long-term securities. The rate hikes sent the value of Mr. Citron's long-term bonds on a downward spiral: a prescription for bankruptcy. The fund appears to have lost more than 25 percent of its value.
It is a matter of detail which securities -- derivatives or plain-vanilla stocks and bonds -- Mr. Citron chose to trade. The strategy, not the securities, proved fatal.
What, then, was needed to stop him? Some members of Congress have picked the wrong answer: prohibiting county funds from purchasing derivatives or borrowing to purchase securities. The danger with such blanket prohibitions is that they rule out the use of derivatives and borrowing to reduce investment risk. Mr. Citron's mistake was to make one-way bets on the direction of interest rates. But prudent investment managers use the same tactics to insulate funds from movements in interest rates in either direction.
What Orange County needed was oversight. Mr. Citron was seemingly left to run amok. Arthur Levitt, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, calls on state and local governments to monitor investment managers of taxpayer money. The primary objective of government funds must be safety and liquidity (the ability to convert investments into cash for emergencies), not profit. If fund managers were forced to assess and report risks, and government supervisors were responsible for overseeing the managers, then Orange County -- one of the wealthiest in America -- would not now be threatening to lay off teachers and nurses.

HEADLINE: Journal;
The Key to the City

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH 

 BODY:
On New Year's Eve, thousands of revelers, tourists and scoundrels will once again gather in Times Square to watch the ball drop, and millions more will watch on TV. Why? The ball is but a bauble, the neighborhood a has-been. Its gaudy signs aside, the intersection of Broadway and 42d Street has long been an urban blank, sparsely populated by fast-food and electronics outlets and the last remaining peep shows.
No matter. Crowds pour into the former crossroads of the world anyway, and not just on New Year's. Even in a coma, Times Square remains an alluring international symbol of the racing, racy Gotham pulse; those of us who work there still catch a whiff of that adrenaline along with the other odors greeting us at the subway exit each morning. 
 If people hunger to come to New York's defunct field of neon dreams now, imagine the results were someone actually to build something there. The whole city could be refueled, economically and spiritually, by a reborn Times Square. You need only stroll to David Letterman's marquee 11 blocks north to see how even a single glamorous new tenant in a dark theater can transform a dead Broadway neighborhood into a mini-Times Square of its own.
Incredibly enough, given the interminable history of stalled plans, a new 42d Street is at this moment closer to reality than ever before. The wind changed, as expected, right after Disney's February announcement of its desire to resurrect the New Amsterdam, the glorious Ziegfeld palace. Construction began soon after on a nonprofit youth theater long promised for the Victory across the street. Now virtually every 42d Street parcel has become the subject of active negotiation.
According to Rebecca Robertson, president of the 42d Street Development Project, and some of the potential tenants, the bright lights include:
* Madame Tussaud's, now a leader in theme-park high tech as well as waxworks, plans to pack the old Times Tower with interactive, Manhattan-centric displays from Andy Warhol's Factory to the top of the Chrysler Building. Outside, the news zipper will not only remain lit but will circle a rehabilitated facade.
* Combining three dark theaters, MTV will create a complex that could do for the rock network what the RCA Building long ago did for NBC. John Cannelli, the MTV point man, pictures a studio for "unplugged" concerts, an unorthodox tour allowing visitors to snake through the network's production facilities, and a flamboyant restaurant that he promises will in no way resemble the Hard Rock Cafe.
* The distinctive architectural details in three other theaters will be preserved by American Multi-Cinema as it builds a multiplex of at least 24 screens, with diverse programming designed to draw the traditional Times Square audience mix.
* Four companies, Disney among them, are competing to create a flamboyant hotel across from the Port Authority Terminal.
All these plans, wildly urban-eclectic rather than homogeneously suburban-mall, uphold Times Square's indelible identity as a cacophonous, edgy center of night life. The neighborhood's very first theater, Oscar Hammerstein I's Olympia of 1895, was a multi-stage complex with a glass-bubbled roof garden; the first 42d Street sex businesses were documented as early as 1901. Times Square was never meant to be the Rockefeller Center promised by the austere Johnson-Burgee office towers of the previous development scheme.
What could go wrong now? The crucial final negotiations happen to coincide with the changeover in Governors. Any uncertainties could make one major tenant turn skittish, prompting others to flee, too.
But to keep 42d Street on track, George Pataki need do nothing -- literally so. The best way to preserve the momentum and continuity of the deal-making at this crucial pass is to retain the current state employees, led by Ms. Robertson, who have gotten so close, know the history and command the other players' trust.
Does the Governor-elect really care about New York City? We'll get an early clue if he makes sure that Times Square's dazzling new development balls stay in the air even as the old ball welcoming 1995 descends.

HEADLINE: The Fed's Making War on the Business Cycle

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Greenspan Hints at Further Rises in Interest Rates" (front page, Dec. 8): Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, holds to the conviction that the price of increased economic activity is "inflation," that "inflation" is evil, and therefore it is imperative to abort increases in economic activity. It is depressing that those who so profess to honor "market theory" have forgotten how the market works. 
 It used to be that in a free-market society there was an endless rhythm of contraction and expansion. This was called the business cycle. It is not a new phenomenon.
What happened in a business cycle is that in bad times producers had to reduce their prices, and in good times producers could increase their prices. Whether you made steel or refined sugar, what you always hoped was that the time would come when you could raise your prices and thereby increase your return. Increasing your return used to be the essence of capitalism.
Even better, if you could lower your unit cost, you could even increase your return without raising your prices! Thus, producers of commodities -- iron and coal, sugar and spice -- could increase their prices and profits, while manufacturers and processors, by increasing productivity, could maintain their own prices and profits if they chose or, if the market permitted, even increase their prices and profits.
This was aptly called a recovery. What was being recovered was the opportunity to make a satisfactory return on capital. Making such a satisfactory return was what capitalism was all about.
Enter Mr. Greenspan. On Dec. 7, the day the Labor Department confirmed that in the 14 quarters of this recovery, output per number of hours worked (productivity) had risen a little more than 2 percent a year -- and in the third quarter, in particular, by 2.9 percent -- Mr. Greenspan reiterated to Congress his tired refrain. Any higher price must be called inflation. Inflation will cool off the economy. Cooling off the economy is bad. Therefore we must cool off the economy. Now.
Not when the market was ready, but when the Fed was ready.
In Mr. Greenspan's words, inflation ultimately leads to "subpar economic performance over time." So let's steer the economy to subpar performance now. Don't wait for the market to steer the economy to subpar performance later.
Wait a minute. I thought it was the bad old socialists who wanted a controlled economy. Now it is the inflation fighter at the Federal Reserve who wants a controlled economy.
Mr. Greenspan's war on the business cycle deserves examination in the public arena. The oil shocks were 20 years ago. Let's get back to business.
 
J. PETER FLEMMING
Brooklyn, Dec. 8, 1994

HEADLINE: The Fed's Making War on the Business Cycle;
Cost to Consumers

 BODY:
To the Editor:
To innoculate against inflation, the Federal Reserve is using counterproductive medicine. Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, is reported (front page, Dec. 8) as giving an unusually clear signal that the Federal Reserve will continue raising interest rates to forestall inflation. 
 "Avis Says Costs Force a Rental Rise" (Business Day, Dec. 8) says the rental car company cited interest rate increases as one of two reasons it was raising rental cost by as much as 6 percent. Businesses pass increased costs on to consumers. Increasing interest rates increases costs.
 
LAWRENCE HUGHES
New York, Dec. 13, 1994

HEADLINE: The Fed's Making War on the Business Cycle;
Misplaced Euphoria

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The euphoria over the November figure of 350,000 newly created jobs would be bullish if it were not for a small omission. New unemployment claims totaled a whopping 317,000, making the net gain a mere 33,000. 
 Adding to the distortion is that the gain has been in the service sector, with lower wages, than in manufacturing, where jobs are declining.
At the risk of playing Scrooge before Christmas, the first-quarter outlook is for exponential downsizing in all economic sectors, especially in government, where budgetary constraints will make it mandatory.
If the Federal Reserve continues its destructive course of raising interest rates for the seventh time, a mild recession is possible. Then look for market forces reversing the course of interest rates in the second quarter.
 
HERBERT BARCHOFF
New York, Dec. 8, 1994
 
The writer has served on the President's Council of Economic Advisers.

HEADLINE: Salomon Will Start Selling Orange County Debt Today

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
Orange County yesterday began the slow, hard work of rescuing itself from the largest municipal bankruptcy in American history. In one sign of that effort, Salomon Brothers prepared to auction off the first $1 billion of the bonds that remain in the Southern California county's ill-fated investment portfolio.
In another sign, a Federal bankruptcy judge approved resumption of normal banking services with the Bank of America, the county's commercial bank. The judge authorized the bank to maintain a $200 million loan agreement so that the county could meet its $16.4 million automatic payroll deposit tomorrow. 
 But more potential casualties of Orange County's trouble emerged. Kemper Financial Services said it would cover losses on $198 million of defaulted county bonds it had bought for six of its mutual funds.
The auction today by Salomon Brothers will be for $1 billion of bonds bought by Orange County from several Federal Government-sponsored agencies. At an unspecified future time, Salomon will auction the county's $4.7 billion in derivatives known as structured notes, the portfolio holdings that have been hardest hit by the rise in interest rates this year.
The county announced on Tuesday that it would sell the remaining $5 billion or so of assets in the investment pool, on which the loss has already totaled $2.02 billion, or 27 percent. The sale is expected to take 90 days, but the county's financial advisers indicated that they wanted to move quickly because each percentage-point increase in short-term interest rates would add $300 million to the losses.
The auctions today will be open both to brokerage firms and to investors, according to people familiar with the planning. A catalogue of about 20 different packages of bonds for sale will be distributed by Salomon this morning, and bids will be accepted later in the morning. There will probably be a minimum bid of about $5 million, though the details were being worked out last night. The county will have the right to withdraw any of the packages from sale if it thinks the top bid is too low.
People familiar with the auction said they expected the bidding to be vigorous because there were few other bonds being offered right now -- just before the Christmas holidays. Also, with an uncommonly flat yield curve now in the Treasury markets -- interest rates on shorter-term paper are nearly as high as on long-term bonds -- many investors are interested in the sort of shorter-term debt that Orange County is selling.
Traders said the structured-note investments may be more difficult for the county to sell. These bonds, also issued by Government-sponsored agencies, have interest payments tied to complex formulas that made them rise sharply in value if interest rates fell, but plummet if rates rose. Still, a number of large Wall Street firms were preparing to bid for those bonds, including Merrill Lynch, Bear Stearns, J. P. Morgan & Company, Chase Manhattan Bank and Lehman Brothers. Those companies will try to find ways to hedge the volatile bonds' risk and then sell them to investors seeking a bargain.
The creditors of Orange County and of the investment pool met in Los Angeles yesterday with the United States bankruptcy trustee, Marcy J. K. Tiffany, who is the United States Trustee for the Central District of California, to form two creditors' committees.
The 20 largest creditors of the county and the pool, which each filed for protection under Chapter 9 last week, were invited, but about 250 people showed up, according to Ms. Tiffany, who under the Federal bankruptcy code is charged with appointing creditors' committees.
At the end of the day, a seven-member committee for the pool had been appointed: the Orange County Transportation Authority, water district, sanitation district and transportation corridor, as well as the city of Irvine to represent cities in Orange County; the city of Mountain View, Calif., to represent those outside the county, and the Orange County Department of Education to represent the school districts.
A glaring omission from this creditors' committee was the Irvine Ranch Water District, the fourth-largest investor with $301 million in the pool. Several creditors are irritated with the district's withdrawal late in October of $100 million from the pool. "They should put that money back into the pot for equal distribution to all," Ms. Tiffany said.
The United States trustee program was created in 1987 to oversee the bankruptcy process, mainly in large metropolitan areas. It is responsible for monitoring the trustees appointed in cases, protecting creditors' rights and preventing fraud. Though the Federal bankruptcy judge often oversees the appointment of creditors' committees, the trustee program can also be engaged to do so at the request of several creditors.
Individual investors across the nation may be affected by the bankruptcy through taxable money market funds, which bought $600 million of taxable notes the county sold in July, Federal officials said. These funds can hold only debt they can sell quickly for 100 cents on the dollar.
Kemper Financial Services said yesterday that it held $198 million of those notes in five money market funds with about $13 billion in assets. To keep the notes liquid, Kemper has "arranged a facility that assures the funds' ability to sell the notes at par," said Steven A. Radis, a spokesman, adding that the Kemper Corporation would assume the risk.
The holders of the remaining notes did not step forward yesterday.
Kemper is the first mutual fund company to rescue taxable funds affected by Orange County, but several others -- including Alliance Capital Management, the Benham Group, the Calvert Group, Franklin Resources and Putnam Investments -- have taken steps to protect investors in their tax-exempt funds.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 17, 1994, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Thursday about the bankruptcy of Orange County, Calif., referred incorrectly to $198 million in the county's securities held by Kemper Financial Services' money market mutual funds. The securities have plunged in price, but they are not in default. In addition, the article misstated the number of Kemper money market funds holding the Orange County securities. It is five, not six.
