HEADLINE: Comeback Kid's Tightest Corner Yet

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14

 BODY:
President Clinton faces the most critical point in a Presidency as stuffed with crises as an old-time movie serial.
 In a speech on Thursday night, for the first time since the seismic election shock five weeks ago, he will tell the nation what he intends to do, especially in the scant year remaining until the political world is caught up in another Presidential campaign. 
He has been dangerously silent until now. He has left the initiative to Republicans, who have seized it, going so far today as to suggest what his speech ought to say. Their confidence and audacity has deepened the Democrats' demoralization; a Democratic Senator said this week, "It's hard to see how we escape from the wilderness."
 The mood is evident even abroad. A senior British minister said on Monday: "No point in trying to deal with the Administration any more. They've had the stuffing knocked out of them."
 The advance intelligence indicates that the President will propose middle-class tax cuts and the scaling down, if not the dismantling, of certain units of Government. The intent is twofold: to prove that he heard the message of hostility to big government and heavy spending that the electorate sent, and to seize as his own some of the most eye-catching Republican promises.
 Mr. Clinton has to do something. All of his advisers, those whom he chose and those who appointed themselves, agree on that. But there are tremendous risks in the move to the right, which has already begun with increases in military spending and agreement to talk about school prayer legislation.
 The first is me-tooism, as it used to be called in the Eisenhower Administration, when Republican moderates infuriated their conservative brethren by espousing a watery version of the New Deal and Fair Deal. Scaling back government is, at bottom, a Republican issue. If Mr. Clinton had wanted to make it his own, the time to do so was early in his term, when the Democrats controlled both houses of Congress as well as the White House.
 Instead, the President earned a reputation as a bureaucracy-builder with his health care proposals and the Republicans captured the Senate and the House of Representatives and started stressing a government of limits. Now, they are in a perfect position to one-up Mr. Clinton, no matter what he proposes.
 In their letter to the President, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas and Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, who will lead the Republicans on Capitol Hill next year, threw down the gauntlet this way: "We also intend to present you with a bold plan to downsize and restructure the Executive Branch, and we ask that you join us in this effort. The American people do not want half-measures; they want real change and real cuts."
 Furthermore, cowboys who pose as Indians are seldom very convincing, and many Democrats are uncomfortable trying to out-Republican the Republicans.
 Another pitfall confronting the President is the loss of his base. The government departments and programs that Mr. Clinton is talking about cutting back were the creation of Democratic Presidents and legislators, working in tandem with Democratic pressure groups, like the unions, the minorities and the disadvantaged, and they will not like seeing their handiwork undone.
 But he does not have a lot of choice, in the view of many experienced Democrats who wish him well.
 "It will give them heartburn," said Harry McPherson, a Washington lawyer who served as Lyndon B. Johnson's White House counsel. "If he goes too far, he loses the true believers, the people who run phone banks and lick stamps.
 "But the fact is that there's really no one out there carrying the flag for liberalism any more. The shock troops of the poverty program are gone -- unions smaller and less effective, same for the big civil rights groups. The old coalition isn't big enough to win anymore, so whatever base he risks alienating, he has no choice but to try to add to it by moving right."
 Mr. Clinton has fought his way out of a lot of blind alleys; his staff talks about that whenever he seems utterly forlorn and decisively beaten, as he does now. But doing so has cost him. He has emerged from his battles bearing grievous political scars that have sometimes been invisible at first.
 There seemed nowhere for him to turn, for example, when Gennifer Flowers made her accusations during the New Hampshire primary. He survived, christened himself the Comeback Kid, and went on to win the Presidency. But that episode crystallized the "character issue." It led many voters to wonder -- and to keep wondering -- whether he was was morally fit to lead the nation.
 As President, Mr. Clinton finally found a compromise on the question of homosexuals in the military. It seemed at the time to have been a sideshow to the bigger problems on the table. But across the country last fall, Republicans used the issue to great effect in their Congressional blitz, citing it as prima facie evidence that Democratic values clashed with the country's.
 More than anything else, though, Mr. Clinton has been damaged by the widespread belief that he has no core beliefs, that he is a New Democrat one day, an Old Democrat the next. As he has twisted and turned on viciously complicated issues like Bosnia and health care, searching for consensus and finding none, he has been denounced as a trimmer and a vacillator.
 In the process, he has received astonishingly little credit for important achievements, especially in the economic sphere, where he has presided over a solid business recovery. In the latest New York Times/CBS News poll, Mr. Clinton's overall approval rating is a dismal 38 percent, and his approval rating on economic issues is only marginally better at 41 percent.
 Deepening rather than erasing his image as a wishy-washy leader is perhaps the greatest peril of the course upon which the President appears to be embarking. If he merely echoes the Republicans, without putting forward at least a few distinctively Clintonian programs or ideas, he risks looking more rudderless and less convincingly Presidential than ever. And he cannot win re-election in 1996 without changing a lot of minds out beyond the Beltway.
 Just before he lost to Mr. Clinton two years ago, George Bush was in just about the same shape as his conqueror is now, with his approval rating at 37 percent.
 Comebacks can be made, even from such a nadir; Ronald Reagan's standing once sank to 41 percent. But that was in the trough of a recession in early 1983, with lots of room for improvement, and Mr. Reagan retained, even then, an electoral base and a gift for political persuasion that President Clinton can only envy.

HEADLINE: PARENT & CHILD;
Protecting Children Going to School

BYLINE: By RALPH GARDNER Jr. 

 BODY:
ON Dec. 5 at 8:15 A.M., a 14-year-old girl was walking to school on Third Avenue near 84th Street when a black sedan pulled up beside her. A man got out and told her to get in. When she refused, he tried to grab her. The girl threw her umbrella at him and ran the two blocks back to her home screaming for help.
"The guy chased her for at least a block," said Police Officer Judy Gawley, who responded to the police call. Officer Gawley noted that while the girl passed stores, apartment buildings with doormen and a man selling Christmas trees, nobody came to her aid. Fortunately, she made it home safely. "Her parents always told her to be careful, which is probably what helped her out on this occasion," the officer said. 
 While abductions are rare, crimes involving children on their way to and from school are common enough that the Police Department recently criticized its own policies on handling them. Commissioner William Bratton has tripled the number of youth officers -- those who deal exclusively with problems affecting children and adolescents -- in each of the city's 76 precincts. Interviews with law enforcement officials, parents, students and civic groups suggest that the most challenging part of getting an education in New York City may be getting to and from school safely.
"The violence level seems to be escalating a little, which is very scary, and the crimes seem to be more random," said Tamar Lynn, a member of the West Side Crime Prevention Program. "We as parents feel less in control."
The victims are primarily boys ages 12 to 15. Their assailants are usually a few years older and correspondingly bigger and stronger. The attacks usually occur after school, as hundreds of thousands of city children are heading home on buses and subways. The perpetrators' motives can range from a desire for easy money to mugging as a sort of after-school sport, either for the pleasure of intimidating weaker boys or to impress their own friends.
Here is a sampling of incidents that have occurred recently:
* In November, the police charged a 15-year-old truant from Louis D. Brandeis High School on the Upper West Side in connection with three robberies of children. The police think he may be responsible for up to 20 such robberies, mostly in the West 90's from Amsterdam Avenue to Central Park West. "Any kid who was around he tried to shake down for money," said Thomas Hilliard, a youth officer in the 24th Precinct.
* In late October, the police arrested seven students out of a group of about 15 from Robert F. Wagner Junior High School on the Upper East Side after they attacked a boy and took his jacket as he was walking home after school with two girls. "He was beaten up pretty bad," said Sgt. Paul Smith of the 19th Precinct on the Upper East Side. "I have no idea why. Sometimes these guys get a little brave, a little physical, when there's a group."
* Last year, the police arrested a group of boys after they committed robberies using a toy gun against children from several private schools. Their leader was all of 11 years old. He would slap the victims around while the others watched.
Statistics on the numbers of crimes involving children going to or coming from school are hard to come by for several reasons. Each year about 50,000 reports of petty crime involving juveniles are handled by the New Work City police, but the department doesn't categorize these incidents based on whether they happened outside schools.
A Police Department pamphlet published last April strongly criticized its own policy of not updating procedures to deal with the surge in youth crimes "in more than a generation." Among the findings: the names of offenders weren't entered into the computer files at the department's Youth Services division, so precinct personnel couldn't retrieve vital information. Among the steps Commissioner Bratton has announced is the creation of a data base to link information on youth violations of every kind. But so far that hasn't occurred. "There has been no allocation of resources yet," said Police Officer Scott Bloch, a Police Department spokesman.
Many public school principals haven't been eager to report incidents that happen outside their school gates for fear they will be held accountable. Consequently, the Board of Education hasn't been getting as much information as it should, said Zachary Tumin, director of the board's Office of School Safety.
In September, the board created a new reporting system that allows principals to report incidents outside the school without being blamed for them. But Mr. Tumin said he had not had a chance to judge the effectiveness of the new system.
Another part of the problem is that the victims themselves sometimes don't report the crimes, even to their own parents. Some fear that their independence will be curtailed by anxious mothers and fathers.
So in place of statistics, the police and parents rely heavily on anecdotal evidence. "I think it's a feeling and a feedback that we get," said Police Officer Bernard Gannon of the 19th Precinct.
David Tunick, an art dealer, says he worries about safety every day. His son, a student at the Dalton School, was mugged this fall and last year. "It's a thin line between fighting back and being submissive in order not to get hurt," Mr. Tunick said. "It's such a mixed message to give a kid."
Girls who attend private schools are rarely the victims of this kind of violence, because adolescents who attack their male counterparts apparently think unchivalrous to attack a girl. But public school girls are often victimized, sometimes by each other, often over a boy, said Gino Silvestri, the principal of Julia Richmond High School on East 67th Street. He said a girl might point out an enemy and get a surrogate to attack her after school. "You have people outside the school do it because they know it will be very tough for us to identify them," he added.
Cecilia Ford, a psychologist with a daughter in the sixth grade at the Spence School, moved nearby to ease her concerns about her child's safety. "I figured the fewer blocks she had to go, the less likelihood something would happen," Mrs. Ford said.
Parents are finding other ways to reduce the risks. "I think people are becoming more and more aware that the police can't do it by themselves," said Ann Goldsmith, the safety coordinator for the Parents League, an organization of independent schools. "More has to be done by individuals to protect their children."
Following are some of the programs set up to protect children.
Safe havens. This is a rapidly expanding network of stores that offer shelter to children when they are in danger. There are now 400 Safe Havens on the Upper East Side, another 250 on the Upper West Side, and efforts are under way to establish the program in the Riverdale section of the Bronx and in neighborhoods in Brooklyn and Queens. The stores display yellow stickers that let children know that when they walk in and say "safe haven," they can find protection. "It happens every couple of months," said Philip Krumholtz, an owner of Morris Brothers, a clothing store at Broadway and 84th Street.
Mr. Krumholtz recently sheltered several boys after a gang of adolescents tried to steal their knapsacks. "The kids stayed here for an hour or so," he said. "I chased the other kids away, put the kids in a cab and sent them home."
Safety patrols. Each day at dismissal time at 25 private schools, parents patrol the area, wearing bright orange vests to identify themselves and carrying walkie-talkies and whistles, and sometimes cellular phones. While their value is primarily as a deterrent, in October, a mother on safety patrol at the Chapin School, on East End Avenue and 84th Street, helped the police catch a man she saw loitering near the school. Based on her description, he was later arrested after breaking into a car.
Ann Goldsmith of the Parents League said public schools didn't participate in the safety patrol program because its effectiveness depends on sending out the patrols every day of the school year and public schools can't compel parents to participate, as private schools do. to
Business district initiatives. Businesses are also joining the effort to protect children who attend schools in their neighborhoods. Perhaps the most dramatic example is at Worldwide Plaza, an office and residential complex on Eighth Avenue at 50th Street. Last February, its security force teamed up with the police, the Board of Education and the Times Square Business Improvement District after a series of gang-related incidents involving students at two nearby schools, the High School of Graphic Communication Arts and Park West, escalated from two a month to two a week, said Michael Johnson, the plaza's security director.
He deployedhis security officers with the police to make the most of their visibility. Since then, "We've had a very significant drop in incidents," Mr. Johnson said. "I've been told the arrest rate of the students has dropped 30 percent to 50 percent."
Safe corridors. These are routes primarily running from public schools to the nearest bus or subway station that are heavily patrolled by the police at dismissal time. Every precinct in the city has at least one of these routes, but some, like the 19th, have as many as six. "On the 8-to-4 shift, this is our highest priority," said George J. Kelly, the 19th Precinct's commanding officer, referring to student safety.
Safe passage. This Transit Police program puts an officer on each of 100 trains serving 85 key schools at dismissal time, from 1:30 to 4 P.M., when children are most volatile. The police ride one of the last three cars.
City buses, the public transportation system's weakest link in terms of safety, don't have police officers assigned to them on a regular basis. But the Transit Police will receive $2.1 million from the Federal government to hire 28 officers for their Surface Crime Unit. "Very likely they'll be involved in buses that serve students," said Al O'Leary, a Transit Police spokesman.
Public and private school activities. To foster friendship between private school children and those who attend public schools (and, police say, are often the assailants), the 19th Precinct's Community Council and the Stanley Isaacs Neighborhood Center run a weekend hockey league for 150 adolescents from across the social and economic spectrum. "It's an approach we're using to bridge the differences," said Howard Knoll, the center's youth director.
But it is the youth officers who are the linchpins in the Police Department's effort to curb violence against children. They try to make regular visits to every public and private school in their precinct and develop relationships with school administrators, who know better than anyone else who the troublemakers are. "The key is to break the anonymity that shields wrongdoers," Mr. Tumin said.
But Thomas Marino, a youth officer in the 19th Precinct, said his help was generally, but not always, warmly received. "Some private schools don't treat us with open arms like public schools do," he said. "Some don't think it's a good thing for a police officer to be around the school. I don't know whether they think it's a bad thing for parents to see there's trouble there."
Recently, three boys were charged with trying to rob a Dalton student around the corner from the school, in part for what they perceived as the privileges of the well-to-do. "Those preppie kids get a different amount of rights," claimed a 15-year-old, one of those charged. "If I put my hand on his shoulder, I'd be arrested." The arrests in that case came as a result of the new priority the police are giving such crimes. As soon as the boys surrounded the student, they were captured by a Dalton security guard and plainclothes officers from the 19th precinct on the lookout for such incidents.
Then, the victim agreed to prosecute. "He was very bright, had a very good memory, and was very articulate about what happened to him," said Ileane Spinner, a prosecutor for the Family Court. "He practically drafted the case for us." On Monday, two of the boys were found guilty of attempted robbery. They face up to two years probation or a year and a half at an institution for juvenile offenders.
 
 
Before Your Child Sets Off
 HERE are some suggestions from parent's groups and the police to help children reduce the risk of being mugged.
Ask children to look alert and always take note of the people around them. Daydreamers make better victims.
Remind children to walk with purpose, but not to strut or act macho. A child looking to prove himself to his friends might take such behavior as a challenge.
Suggest that children travel to and from school with a classmate whenever possible. Predators often have friends along to provide physical as well as moral support. So should other children.
Help them select streets where there is a lot of pedestrian traffic rather than deserted side streets.
Remind them to seek doormen if they think they are in danger. Many doormen are now equipped with walkie-talkies and can contact the police.
If concerned about subway safety, check with the Transit Police Department to see which trains have officers regularly assigned to them as part of the Safe Passage program. Information: (718) 330-3098. If children are traveling by bus, suggest that they sit near the drivers. For information about the Safe Corridors program near your child's school, call your local police precinct.
Remind children not to flash money or possessions, and to keep bus or subway passes in their pockets until they're ready to use them. If they are threatened, tell them to give up their possessions.
Find the Safe Havens along their route and introduce children to the merchants involved. For the location of Safe Havens, call the Parents League at (212) 737-7385.
To reduce risks, private school children should leave school blazers in their lockers.
If they become victims of a crime, call the police immediately; minutes count. But even if the call is made the next day or several days later, it's not too late. The police may arrest an assailant later for another crime and connect him or her to your child's case based on the description provided. Furthermore, the police assign officers where they think the need is greatest. If you don't report a crime, the police say, it may as well have never happened. RALPH GARDNER Jr.

HEADLINE: THE CLINTON TAX PLAN: THE OVERVIEW;
Clinton Outlines a Plan for Tax Breaks

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15

 BODY:
Bracing for battle with a Republican Congress and striving to win back a disgruntled electorate, President Clinton tonight sketched a blueprint of middle-class tax breaks, smaller government and new incentives for education and training for the second half of his term.
In a 10-minute televised address to the nation from the Oval Office, the President returned to the winning themes of his 1992 campaign, presenting himself as the champion of hard-working ordinary Americans. He sounded what amounted to the opening notes of his 1996 re-election effort in remarks aimed as much at reshaping himself as the Government he wants to continue to lead. 
 Mr. Clinton summoned Congress and the country to support a package of tax breaks intended to help middle-class families care for young children, send them to college or technical school, and plan for retirement and life's biggest and most important expenses, like buying a first home. [Transcript, page A36.]
In a move to cast himself as the fiscally responsible defender of the elderly -- which could severely limit his options -- Mr. Clinton challenged Congress to pass his program "without adding to the deficit and without any new cuts" in Social Security or Medicare. He said he would finance his tax package, which aides said amounted to about $60 billion over five years, by shrinking and reorganizing Government departments in ways that he left mostly unspecified.
"Fifty years ago, an American President proposed a G.I. bill of rights to help returning veterans from World War II go on to college, buy a home and raise their children," said Mr. Clinton, who, in a speech by turns bookish and personally upbeat, recalled his own youth as the son of a widowed mother who fought to make a better life. "That built this country. Tonight, I propose a middle-class bill of rights."
As he strove to assure a hearing for proposals that the Republican Congress could well ignore, Mr. Clinton embraced such traditionally Republican notions as smaller, less intrusive government and lower taxes. But he put the debate in his own terms by suggesting his actions were a fulfillment of his 1992 campaign pledge to cut the tax burden of the middle class and invest in education and training to prepare the nation for the 21st century -- ideas also long supported by the moderate Democrats who have recently accused him of forsaking them.
The President's plan would offer an annual income tax credit of up to $500 for each child under age 13 to families with adjusted gross incomes of up to $75,000, and up to $10,000 in annual deductions for any kind of post-high school education for families earning no more than $120,000.
Mr. Clinton also proposed expanding eligibility for tax-deductible contributions to Individual Retirement Accounts to families earning up to $100,000, from $50,000 now. He would permit tax-free withdrawals before retirement age to pay for education, catastrophic illness, care of an elderly parent or the purchase of a first home.
The President also proposed to consolidate 60 Federal job training programs into a single system that would give vouchers of between $2,000 and $3,000 to those who qualify for training in private employment programs.
Speaking from his desk with a flag and bright red poinsettias behind him, the President went out of his way to seem above partisan bickering, insisting: "This is not about politics as usual. As I have said for years, it is not about moving left or right, but moving forward. It is not about Government being bad or good, but about what kind of Government will best enable us to fulfill our God-given potential.
"And it's not about the next election, either. That's in your hands. Meanwhile, I'm going to do what I think is right. My rule for the next two years will be country first, and politics as usual dead last. I hope the new Congress will follow the same rule. And I hope you will, too."
But Republicans were swift and sharp in their response. Representative Jim Leach of Iowa, the new chairman of the Banking Committee and Mr. Clinton's chief Congressional critic on the Whitewater affair, accused the President of blatant accommodation to the new Republican realities.
"In a pretense of leadership, the President has strapped on the seat belt in the caboose of the freight train engineered by the new Speaker of the House," Mr. Leach said, "and made a leaner-government theme the centerpiece of both political parties."
In the Republicans' official televised reply to the President's speech, the newly elected Senator Fred D. Thompson of Tennessee vowed that his party would renew efforts to slash the size of Government, reshape Congress and set the country on a new path.
"We campaigned on these principles, and now we are going to do something that has become all too unusual in American politics," Mr. Thompson said. "We are going to do exactly what we said we were going to do during the campaign."
Officials said the President intended to pay for his plan with a sweeping mix of consolidation and cost cutting in five Federal agencies -- the Departments of Energy, Transportation, and Housing and Urban Development, as well as the General Services Administration (the Government's real estate management arm) and the Office of Personnel Management -- and by continuing existing caps on spending for discretionary programs into 2000.
Discretionary programs are the part of the Federal budget that must be approved each year and have a specific, limited budget. They do not include Social Security, Medicare, Medicaid or other "entitlements" on which the Government spends as much as necessary to cover all those who are eligible.
The Administration's approach postpones, at least until after the 1996 elections, hard decisions about just which programs would have to be cut to pay for the tax cuts. The White House deliberately deferred any detailed discussion of the rest of the budget until Mr. Clinton's State of the Union and budget messages next month, though the President tonight pledged a top-to-bottom review of spending in the coming weeks.
The new Republican majority in Congress has already proposed a broader, deeper range of tax and spending cuts, so even Presidential proposals that otherwise might be broadly popular with voters now face at best uphill fights and uncertain coalitions on Capitol Hill -- and quite likely will simply be declared dead on arrival in Congress.
Since the election, Mr. Clinton has struggled, first simply to absorb the Democrats' sweeping defeat, and then to respond to it, and he has been buffeted not only by bold pledges from the triumphant Republicans but also by harsh criticism and lukewarm support from many fellow Democrats. Indeed, the strongest statement that the new Senate Democratic leader, Tom Daschle of South Dakota, made for Mr. Clinton tonight was that his "proposal appears to be a good one."
For the last 10 days, Mr. Clinton and his top advisers have reviewed scores of options, and aides said Mr. Clinton was still tinkering with the final version of his address until early this evening, striving to communicate both his vision for the future, and his resolve to pursue it.
"He lived the American dream," one senior aide said in a White House briefing before the speech. "He's going to say that to the American people, and he wants others to believe it again as well."
Mr. Clinton himself stressed that theme in one passage of his speech, explaining his desire to make the tax code work to support worthy social goals. "Just as we made mortgage interest tax deductible because we want people to own homes, we should make college tuition tax deductible because we want people to go to college," the remarks read.
The President repeated a line from his inaugural speech, saying "I still believe deeply that there is nothing wrong with America that can't be fixed by what's right with America." He also echoed the second inaugural address of Abraham Lincoln, saying that the country needed "less malice and more charity."
The proposed tax cuts would take effect on Jan. 1, 1996, but senior officials acknowledged that their full effect was likely to be phased in over time, which would diminish the initial benefit.
Officials said about $24 billion in savings necessary to finance the tax breaks would come from restructuring Government agencies and farming out some functions to the private sector, though no cabinet department would be eliminated. It appears that the bulk of such savings would come from the Department of Energy. Another $52 billion in savings would come from continuing in force the caps on discretionary spending initially adopted as part of the 1990 budget accord through the turn of the century.

"HIGHLIGHTS: The President's Proposal"
 Highlights of the President's proposed package of tax and spending cuts as outlined by White House aides.
 
TAX CUTS: $60 BILLION OVER FIVE YEARS
 Children -- Create tax credit of $500 for each child under 13. Applies fully for families with incomes of less than $60,000; phased out at $75,000.
 Education -- Allow deduction of up to $10,000 for post-secondary education. Applies fully to families with incomes of up to $100,000; phased out at $120,000.
 Individual Retirement Accounts -- Raise cutoff for full IRA deduction for people not covered by retirement plan (up to $2,000 per wage earner) to family incomes of $80,000, up from current limit of $40,000. Phased out at $100,000, up from current $50,000.
 Allow penalty-free early withdrawal of IRA funds for to pay for education, illness or illness of a parent or purchase of first home.
 
SPENDING CUTS: $76 BILLION OVER FIVE YEARS
 Cuts and management changes at Departments of Transportation, Energy and Housing and Urban Development and other agencies -- $ 24 billion.
 Extension of freeze on discretionary spending -- $ 52 billion.
 Spending cuts would be used both to cover cost of tax changes and to reduce the deficit by $16 billion over five years. (pg. A36)

HEADLINE: Yeltsin Extends His Deadline for Rebels' Surrender

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Dec. 15

 BODY:
With Russian troops surrounding the capital of a Caucasus region and secessionists there threatening an all-out war, President Boris N. Yeltsin backed off tonight and extended his deadline for the rebels' surrender by two days.
In a statement addressed to the people of the secessionist region, Chechnya, Mr. Yeltsin said he would set aside his deadline and give forces loyal to the local leader, Dzhokhar M. Dudayev, until midnight Saturday to disarm. He also offered to send a higher-level delegation to resume failed cease-fire talks, on the condition that Mr. Dudayev led the Chechens' delegation. 
 Whatever the fate of peace talks, the delay in an all-out war was as much a reprieve for Mr. Yeltsin as it was for his opponent. Russian troops have met with fierce resistance in Chechnya's capital, Grozny, and their advances toward the city today were impeded by thick fog. It was not even clear that the military was capable of seizing Grozny after the original deadline elapsed.
Mr. Yeltsin's decision came during a visit by Vice President Al Gore, who is in Russia for three days to discuss economic issues and technical cooperation with Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin.
Defense Secretary William J. Perry was also in Moscow today, for talks on economic and military cooperation. By extending the deadline for a Chechen surrender, Mr. Yeltsin spared both American officials the awkwardness of being present during a full-scale Russian military attack on a city of 400,000 people.
Earlier today, the Chechen government had tried to get the United States involved by asking Mr. Gore to act as a mediator between Chechen and Russian negotiators. Washington has stayed out of the fray, insisting that it views the secession as an internal Russian affair.
Shortly before Mr. Yeltsin's statement, Mr. Dudayev also called for high-level talks to resolve the conflict over the oil-rich, mainly Muslim region. But at a news conference in Grozny, Mr. Dudayev suggested that Russian soldiers would have to withdraw from Chechen territory before such talks could begin. It was that condition that caused earlier negotiations to come to a standstill.
Mr. Yeltsin also seemed to be clinging to his preference that Chechen forces disarm before a Russian withdrawal. Saying he would view a voluntary cease-fire as "a manifestation of good will," he added, "It is essential that heavy guns fall silent and then be surrendered within the set time limit."
The new deadline also seems to offer the Russian President a personal respite. Since Mr. Yeltsin sent hundreds of tanks and thousands of troops on Sunday to bring the republic to heel, he has appeared to be in a political free fall, attacked from nearly all sides for driving the country to the brink of crisis and accused of establishing a pretense for the creation of a neo-authoritarian regime.
"The Constitution does not arrive in tanks," read a front-page headline in Literaturnaya Gazeta, a liberal weekly newspaper.
Even some Russian soldiers were openly complaining about their assignment. The newspaper Izvestia quoted a Russian officer at the front who angrily invited Mr. Yeltsin to take a first-hand look at war. "Let him and all his comrades-in-arms come down here and spend a couple of days in the trenches," the officer said. "Maybe then he'll come up with a normal way out of this mess more quickly."
Russian and Chechen forces continued to clash today around Grozny, with Russian troops positioned about six miles from the capital. At least 15 Russian servicemen have been killed since the invasion began.
In his statement, Mr. Yeltsin stressed his desire to avoid further bloodshed -- and his desire for more public support. "At this crucial hour for the Chechen people's fate," he said, "I hope that all citizens will understand my position."
Mr. Yeltsin, who is recovering from minor surgery on his nose, had copies of his statement released to news agencies rather than delivering it on television.
Throughout the crisis, in fact, he has been far from public view.
Just before sending the troops into Chechnya, he checked into the hospital for the operation. Many commentators in the Russian press are convinced that Mr. Yeltsin wanted to keep some distance from the military action and has a poor hold on his own circle of fractious political advisers.
There have been unflattering comparisons with his Soviet predecessor, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who lost the confidence of liberals and reformers when his Government attacked protesters in Georgia, Azerbaijan and Lithuania. But Mr. Gorbachev has not been particularly supportive. He described Mr. Yeltsin's tough line in Chechnya as "a big mistake, and I would say it smells of adventurism."
One of Mr. Yeltsin's closest political allies, his former Prime Minister, Yegor T. Gaidar, has joined right-wing politicians in criticizing the military deployment. Mr. Gaidar said that for the first time in two years he has not even been able to reach Mr. Yeltsin by telephone. Two of the leading figures in the Russian military, Gen. Boris V. Gramov and Lieut. Gen. Aleksandr I. Lebed, have spoken out against the invasion.
Pavel Felgenhauer, a military expert for the newspaper Segodnya, said he believed that the decision to extend the deadline was an effort to make a virtue out of a necessity.
"The Russian forces have yet to finish the stage of operation necessary to blockade the city," he said. "They weren't ready to storm. They figured, 'Why not make some good public relations and gain more time?' "

GRAPHIC: Photos: Chechen women crying and praying on the road near Russian positions 28 miles west of Grozny. Russia extended its deadline for surrender of secessionist forces by two days as the rebels threatened an all-out war. (Agence France-Presse); President Boris N. Yeltsin has spared Vice President Al Gore the awkwardness of a Russian attack on a secessionist city during his visit to Moscow. Mr. Gore and his wife, Tipper, danced around a Christmas tree with children yesterday at the GUM shopping center in Moscow. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: THE CLINTON TAX PLAN;
Text of Clinton Speech Proposing Series of Tax Breaks for the Middle Class

 BODY:
Following is a transcript of President Clinton's speech in Washington last night, as recorded by The New York Times:
My fellow Americans, ours is a great country with a lot to be proud of. But at this holiday season everybody knows that all is not well with America, that millions of Americans are hurting, frustrated, disappointed, even angry. 
 In this time of enormous change our challenge is both political and personal. It involves Government all right, but it goes way beyond Government to the very core of what matters most to us. The question is what are we going to do about it.
Let's start with the economic situation.
I ran for President to restore the American dream and to prepare the American people to compete and win in the new American economy. For too long too many Americans have worked longer for stagnant wages and less security. For two years, we pursued an economic strategy that has helped to produce over five million new jobs.
But even though the economic statistics are moving up, most of our living standards aren't. It's almost as if some Americans are being punished for their productivity in this new economy.
We've got to change that. More jobs aren't enough, we have to raise incomes.
Fifty years ago, an American President proposed the G.I. Bill of Rights to help returning veterans from World War II go to college, buy a home and raise their children. That built this country.
Tonight, I propose a middle-class bill of rights.
There are four central ideas in this bill of rights. First, college tuition should be tax deductible. Just as we make mortgage interest tax deductible because we want people to own their own homes, we should make college tuition deductible because we want people to go to college. Specifically, I propose that all tuition for college -- community college, graduate school, professional school, vocational education or worker retraining after high school -- be fully deductible, phased up to $10,000 a year for families making up to $120,000 a year.
Education, after all, has a bigger impact on earnings and job security than ever before. So let's invest the fruits of today's recovery into tomorrow's opportunity.
Second, bringing up a child is a tough job in this economy. So we should help middle-class families raise their children.
We made a good start last year by passing the Family Leave Law, making college loans more affordable and by giving 15 million American families with incomes of $25,000 a year or less an average tax cut of more than $1,000 a year.
Now, I want to cut taxes for each child under 13, phased up to $500 per child. This tax cut would be available to any family whose income is less than $75,000.
Third, we should help middle-income people save money by allowing every American family earning under $100,000 to put $2,000 a year tax-free in an I.R.A., an individual retirement account.
But I want you to be able to use the money to live on, not just retire on. You'll be able to withdraw from this fund tax-free money for education, medical expenses, the purchase of a first home, the care of an elderly parent.
Fourth, since every American needs the skills necessary to prosper in the new economy, and most of you will change jobs from time to time, we should take the billions of dollars the Government now spends on dozens of different training programs and give it directly to you to pay for training if you lose your job or want a better one.
We can pay for this middle-class bill of rights by continuing to reduce Government spending, including subsidies to powerful interests based more on influence than need. We can sell off entire operations the Government no longer needs to run and turn dozens of programs over to states and communities that know best how to solve their own problems.
My plan will save billions of dollars from the Energy Department, cut down the Transportation Department and shrink 60 programs into 4 at the Department of Housing and Urban Development.
Our reinventing Government initiative, led by Vice President Gore, already has helped to shrink bureaucracy and free up money to pay down the deficit and invest in our people. Already we've passed budgets to reduce the Federal Government to its smallest size in 30 years and to cut the deficit by $700 billion.
That's over $10,000 for every American family.
In the next few days, we'll unveil more of our proposals. And I've instructed the Vice President to review every single Government department and program for further reductions.
We've worked hard to get control of this deficit after the Government debt increased four times over in the 12 years before I took office. That's a big burden on you.
About 5 percent of your income tax goes to pay for welfare and foreign aid, but 28 percent of it goes to pay for interest on the debt run up between 1981 and the day I was inaugurated President.
I challenge the new Congress to work with me to enact a middle-class bill of rights without adding to the deficit and without any new cuts in Social Security or Medicare.
I know some people just want to cut the Government blindly, and I know that's popular now, but I won't do it. I want a leaner, not a meaner, Government that's back on the side of hardworking Americans, a new Government for the new economy, creative, flexible, high quality, low cost, service oriented, just like our most innovative private companies.
I'll work with the new Republican majority and my fellow Democrats in Congress to build a new American economy and to restore the American dream. It won't be easy. Believe you me, the special interests have not gone into hiding just because there was an election in November. As a matter of fact, they're up here stronger than ever. And that's why more than ever we need lobby reform, campaign-finance reform and reform to make Congress live by the laws it puts on other people.
Together we can pass welfare reform and health care reform that work.
I'll say more about what I'll do to work with the new Congress in the State of the Union address in January.
But here's what I won't do.
I won't support ideas that sound good but aren't paid for, ideas that weaken the progress we've made in the previous two years for working families, ideas that hurt poor people who are doing their dead-level best to raise their kids and work their way into the middle class, ideas that undermine our fight against crime or for a clean environment or for better schools or for the strength and well-being of our armed forces and foreign policy.
In other words, we must be straight with the American people about the real consequences of all budgetary decisions.
My test will be: Does an idea expand middle-class incomes and opportunities? Does it promote values like family, work, responsibility and community? Does it contribute to strengthening the new economy?
If it does, I'll be for it, no matter who proposes it.
And I hope Congress will treat my ideas the same way.
Let's worry about making progress, not taking credit.
But our work in Washington won't be enough.
And that's where you come in.
This all starts with you.
Oh, we can cut taxes and expand opportunities, but governments can't raise your children, go to school for you, give your employees who've earned it a raise or solve problems in your neighborhood that require your personal commitment.
In short, government can't exercise your citizenship. It works the other way around.
The problems of this new world are complicated, and we've all got a lot to learn. That means citizens have to listen as well as talk. We need less hot rhetoric and more open conversation, less malice and more charity. We need to put aside the politics of personal destruction and demonization that have dominated too much of our debate.
Most of us are good people trying to do better, and if we all treated each other that way we would do better. We have got to be a community again.
Yes, some people do take advantage of the rest of us, by breaking the law, abusing the welfare system and flaunting our immigration laws. That's wrong, and I'm working to stop it. But the truth is that most people in this country, without regard to their race, their religion, their income, their position on divisive issues, most Americans get up every day, go to work, obey the law, pay their taxes and raise their kids the best they can.
And most of us share the same real challenges in this new economy.
We'll do a lot better job of meeting those challenges if we work together and find unity and strength in our diversity. We do have more in common, more uniting us than dividing us. And if we start acting like it, we can face the future with confidence. I still believe deeply that there's nothing wrong with America that can't be fixed by what's right with America.
This is not about politics as usual. As I've said for years, it's not about moving left or right, but moving forward. Not about Government being bad or good, but about what kind of Government will best enable us to fulfill our God-given potential. And it's not about the next election either. That's in your hands.
Meanwhile, I'm going to do what I think is right.
My rule for the next two years will be country first, and politics as usual dead last.
I hope the new Congress will follow the same rule. And I hope you will, too.
This country works best when it works together. For decades after World War II, we gave more and more Americans the chance to live out their dreams. I know; I'm blessed to be one of them.
I was born to a widowed mother at a time when my state's income was barely half the national average. The first person in my family to finish college, thanks to money my parents couldn't really afford, scholarships, loans and a half-a-dozen jobs.
It breaks my heart to see people with their own dreams for themselves and their children shattered, and I'm going to do all I can to turn it around. But I need your help. We can do it.
With all of our problems this is still the greatest country in the world, standing not in the twilight but at the dawn of our greatest days.
We still have a lot to be thankful for. Let's all remember that.
Happy holidays, and God bless America.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Stocks Advance on Signs of Little Inflation

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
In the fourth advance of five sessions, the stock market rose again yesterday in unusually heavy trading, helped by further signs of a moderately growing economy with little inflation.
Computer networking stocks especially benefited because they are seen as thriving in an economy where business executives, prime customers for computers, do not fear inflation. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 19.18 points, to 3,765.47, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 0.38 point, to 455.35. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index climbed 5.01 points, to 730.68.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was above normal, with 337.1 million shares changing hands, about 16 percent above this year's daily average of 290 million shares.
The market may also have been helped by technical factors like stock purchases in advance of the so-called triple-witching expiration today of stock options, index futures, and options on futures.
For the most part, though, potentially troublesome economic reports, like the Consumer Price Index and the Producer Price Index earlier this week, have encouraged stock traders because the reports showed the price increases were still moderate. But the good news was not enough to change the expectation that the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates again, either when its policy-making committee meets next week, or early next year.
Traders' concerns about how a slowing economy would affect corporate earnings prompted falls for two of the three major long-distance telephone carriers. MCI Communications, the No. 2 carrier after AT&T, set a 52-week low of 17 1/4, before closing at 17 7/8, down 5/8.
MCI's fall was prompted by Sprint's announcement that long-distance revenue growth is expected to be flat in the fourth quarter. Sprint shares also set a 52-week low of 26 1/8, before closing at 26 7/8, down 3 7/8.
AT&T, though, closed unchanged at 51. The company said on Wednesday that it had signed up 300,000 customers in November, triple its average monthly gain. Analysts see AT&T continuing to win market share at the expense of MCI and Sprint.
MCI, at 9.1 million shares, and Sprint, at 6.9 million shares, were among the day's most active stocks.
The most active issue, at 12.3 million shares, was the American depository receipts of Hanson P.L.C., but its stock is often traded heavily around the time of its ex-dividend date, which is today. On the ex-dividend date, a current purchaser of the stock does not receive a dividend. Hanson's A.D.R.'s lost 1/8, to 18 1/8.
Stocks of companies that tie together large numbers of personal computers, printers and other gear rose sharply. 3Com, which makes equipment for such computer networks, established a 52-week high of 48 3/8 and closed at that price, up 6 1/4. Alantec, which rose 4 3/8, to 25 5/8, established a 52-week high of 26 1/4.
Morgan Stanley declined 3/8, to 61, after it and S. G. Warburg announced the halt of their merger talks for the two investment houses. Bankers Trust dropped 1 3/8, to 57 7/8, after The Washington Post reported that Federal regulators were negotiating with the concern to settle lawsuits prompted by the sale of derivatives. Bankers Trust specializes in derivatives, securities whose performance is based on the action of simpler, underlying securities.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 0.63 point, to 248.96, with advancing stocks outnumbering declining issues by 1,499 to 815. The American Stock Exchange market value index rose 2.95 points, to 426.02.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Companies
 Morgan Stanley and S. G. Warburg broke off merger talks after a deal could not be reached with Warburg's independently run fund-management subsidiary. The dashed deal is a big setback for Warburg of Britain, which had sought an American partner to elevate it to the ranks of global banking powers. [Page D1.] 
 Dime Savings Bank is being investigated by Federal officials for possible fraud in its home-mortgage business. [D1.]
 While declining to disqualify Weil, Gotshal & Manges, a Federal bankruptcy judge ruled that the law firm damaged its client, Leslie Fay, by not disclosing potential conflicts of interest. [D1.]
 The S.E.C. is expected to accuse Bankers Trust of fraud in the sales of derivatives to Gibson Greetings. [D5.]
 Shares of Sprint tumbled in heavy trading after the company said that fourth-quarter earnings would be lower than expected. [D5.]
 A plan to rescue the Manville asbestos trust was approved by a Federal judge in Brooklyn, who said it would insure that all those filing claims were compensated to some degree. [D5.]
 3Com led a rally in computer-networking stocks. The company reported strong sales of switching equipment. [D5.]
 Metrocall sweetened its offer for two rival paging companies, USA Mobile and Premiere Page, to more than $400 million. [D5.]
 Gannett looked ahead to expansion, appointing a new editor at its flagship newspaper, USA Today, and receiving support from Warren Buffett, who acquired a 4.9 percent stake. [D18.]
 
The Economy
 The surge in sales this year of a new crop of home computers has created a boom in software for the home, as well. One result: The best Christmas ever for children's software. [D1.]
 A push for natural-gas cars and trucks faces a big setback. The E.P.A. is expected announce soon that it will retreat on car-emission rules for the Northeast, eliminating one of the remaining incentives for converting vehicles to natural gas. [D1.]

HEADLINE: Economic Slowdown May Become Wider

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15

 BODY:
A slowdown caused by higher interest rates may be about to spread from the home-building industry to manufacturing in general, new reports suggested today.
The Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia said the manufacturing growth rate in its region was poised to slow from current high levels. 
 The Philadelphia Fed's December index of general economic activity fell to 28.9 in December from 30.5 last month, while its index of future economic activity fell more sharply, to 17 -- its lowest level since January 1991 -- from 30.6. "Firms expect growth will continue, but at a slower pace," the report said.
In a separate report, the National Association of Home Builders said today that builders were less optimistic about sales of new homes in the next six months than at any time since the recent recession.
"Housing activity tends to lead everything else both on the upside and downside," said Raymond Stone, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates in Princeton, N.J. "This survey is giving a sour look."
New-home building is slumping because six increases in interest rates this year by the Federal Reserve have also raised mortgage rates.
Until now, though, there were relatively few signs that the weakness was spreading outside the housing industry. Today, for example, the Commerce Department reported that American businesses, in preparation for holiday sales, increased their inventories by four-tenths of 1 percent in October -- the seventh consecutive monthly gain.
"Retail sales were gangbusters in November, so businesses were making good judgments in October," said Gene Sherman, director of research at M. A. Schapiro & Company, an investment firm in New York. "They stocked up but didn't burden themselves."
And the Labor Department said the number of Americans applying for unemployment benefits fell last week by 1,000, to a seasonally adjusted 323,000. In the previous workweek, jobless claims dropped by a revised 8,000.
In the Commerce Department report, retailers, wholesalers and manufacturers all reported inventory increases for October. In September, total business inventories rose five-tenths of 1 percent. Compared with October 1993, total inventories advanced 5.6 percent.

HEADLINE: Smith College Makes History In Naming Its Next President

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

 BODY:
Smith College, known as one of the more conservative of the top women's colleges, and as the alma mater of Nancy Reagan and Barbara Bush, yesterday became the first of the nation's prestigious Northeastern institutions to name a black educator as its president.
The moment was not lost on the president-to-be, Ruth Simmons, a Harvard University graduate and the youngest of 12 children of a Texas sharecropper, who is now vice provost of Princeton University. Before accepting the post at Smith, she repeatedly and bluntly asked the trustees, "Is Smith ready for this?" 
 Dr. Simmons said she had thought it more likely that Oberlin College in Ohio, which has a long history of liberalism, would be the first of the top-rated colleges to name a black president. In fact, she was one of two finalists last spring when the Oberlin trustees narrowed their search for a new president.
"But it's Smith that accepted me!" she said, adding "I don't believe that conservative people will reject all African-Americans." Besides, said Dr. Simmons, who also has been provost at Spelman College in Atlanta, America's oldest black women's college, "All schools have some conservative alumnae, even Spelman."
At Smith, which is in Northampton, Mass., Dr. Simmons, 49, will become the ninth president on July 1, 1995. She will succeed Mary Maples Dunn, who is stepping down after 10 years.
In an interview yesterday, Dr. Simmons said she did not feel she was "a pioneer."
But she made it clear that she had questioned members of the Smith College search committee and trustees about the possibility of a backlash against her appointment.
"I pushed them hard," she said. "I was feeling somewhat tentative. They persuaded me. They responded that they thought there would be a tremendous positive response, and that the appointment would be accepted by the alumnae." Smith, which has admitted black women since the 1920's, currently has 86 black students out of 2,700.
Kate Webster, chairwoman of Smith's board and a member of the search committee, said that race became an issue after Dr. Simmons became the leading candidate.
"The unanimous belief was that, given an opportunity to show who she is, what she can do and the style with which she can accomplish things, she will allay any concerns," Ms. Webster said.
Dr. Simmons attended Dillard University in New Orleans, from which she graduated summa cum laude. She studied in France on a Fulbright scholarship and earned a master's degree and a doctorate in romance languages from Harvard University.
Her ties to Princeton go back to 1983, when she was director of studies at Princeton's Butler College and later was acting director of the black studies department. After holding several administrative positions, she was named vice provost in 1992.
Dr. Simmons speaks vigorously in favor of women's colleges.
"It's not true that all barriers to women have come down," she said. "We all imagine that some day we will live in a society that does not impede women. But will that happen in my lifetime? I doubt it. And so for now, the best way to deal with it is to separate women so that they can achieve -- especially in fields like physics, chemistry and economics."
Smith College was criticized last month when an article in The Boston Globe used it as an example of the difficulties faced by women's colleges today. The article asserted that the S.A.T. scores of recent entering freshmen at Smith were declining.
Ms. Dunn responded in a letter to the newspaper, arguing that S.A.T. scores are not the best predictors of a student's ability.
Yesterday, Stacey Schmeidel, a spokeswoman for the college, said applications for admission to Smith were at an all-time high.
Dr. Simmons's apppointment was hailed by many black educators. Henry Louis Gates Jr., chairman of Harvard University's department of Afro-American studies and director of the W.E.B. Du Bois Institute for Afro-American Research, said that the appointment of a black educator to such a position was long overdue.
"She understands the poetry of administration and luxuriates in it," he said.
Frank L. Matthews, publisher of Black Issues in Higher Education, said he thought it was significant that Dr. Simmons had worked not only at an elite institution like Princeton but at a historically black school like Spelman.
"At Spelman," Mr. Matthews said, "her role model was Johnnetta Cole, the president of Spelman, and from her she learned the practice of tough love -- nurturing students with a realistic view of the problems that confront the black community."
"She believes that you get educated to serve the community," he continued. "If she can convey that religion, then Smith will run circles around the other Ivy League schools."
Dr. Simmons agreed that her experience at Spelman had been formative but also said the same of her years at Harvard.
"My involvement in both white and black institutions provides a kind of example of how we must move through these artificial barriers that separate higher education," she said.

HEADLINE: U.S. and California Sign Water Accord

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15

 BODY:
California and the Federal Government signed an agreement today on how to protect the water and the wildlife of the San Francisco Bay and its vast inland delta, resolving stubborn conflicts that for years had divided the region's farmers, city dwellers and conservationists.
Concluding a year of negotiations that had continued right up to a final court-ordered deadline, the two sides produced a far-reaching pact and turned a confrontation between a recalcitrant state and a determined Federal overseer into a compromise embraced by all sides. 
 The agreement is intended to preserve a vast but ecologically fragile estuary that holds the aquatic lifeblood of central California. If it succeeds in halting the watershed's prolonged environmental decline, it may prove to be a notable achievement in the Clinton Administration's effort to manage whole ecosystems rather than regulate one industry and one species at a time.
The arrangement establishes limits on how much fresh water can be diverted from the estuary to agriculture and cities, an effort to protect endangered fish species by insuring that the young fish survive their migrations and that their breeding grounds do not become too salty for survival.
Although both farmers and cities are expected to give up significant amounts of water under the plan, the agreement does not set forth exactly how much water, within the limits set today, will flow to which users. That kind of detail will be left to state and local officials to work out later.
Farmers will face the greatest costs year in and year out, while cities will feel the effects in mostly dry years, officials said. Commercial and recreational fisheries, they said, stand to gain economically.
Unlike plans for other ecosystems, like the old-growth forests of the Pacific Northwest or the Everglades in South Florida, which have met with widespread hostility, the plan for the California estuary was praised today by state officials and by representatives of the region's business, agricultural and environmental groups.
"I think that this is a model for the country," Carol M. Browner, the Federal Environmental Protection Administrator, said at the signing ceremony in Sacramento. "You can do it. It took a lot of patience, a lot of listening and a lot of communication."
Gov. Pete Wilson, who criticized the Clinton Administration last year over its initial plan for the estuary, heaped praise on the agreement, calling it "a major victory of consensus over confrontation." Flanked by Administration officers, state and local officials, environmentalists and agricultural representatives, he joked, "We are lacking only Yasir Arafat and Yitzhak Rabin."
At issue is a watershed so thick with man-made plumbing that it can supply two-thirds of the state's water needs, the aqueducts running hundreds of miles to the region's farms and cities.
The delta is the source of drinking water for 20 million people. It also irrigates 200 different crops, including 45 percent of the nation's fruits and vegetables.
But in addition it harbors more than 120 species of fish. And when fresh water running toward the bay is diverted to cities and farms, salt water invades the 1,600-square-mile estuary, which extends east from the bay nearly to Sacramento. Some fish species have been brought to the brink of extinction as the water quality has declined, and efforts to resolve the problem have been paralyzed by fights over the precious water among interest groups.
A year ago, under legal pressure from environmental groups complaining that the state had failed to enforce the Federal Clean Water Act, four Federal agencies stepped in and said they would impose a water quality plan on the whole region. They spelled out their proposal and said it would take effect no later than today.
But urban water managers and rural agricultural interests both believed that the initial Federal plan would set aside too much water for the estuary, worsening what the farmers call a "regulatory drought."
Resistance also came from the State of California.
Usually the states routinely set water quality standards for Federal approval under the Clean Water Act. But Governor Wilson had balked at doing so, citing problems posed by another Federal law, the Endangered Species Act, that he said made the task impossible.
But in the last 12 months Federal and state officials re-negotiated the initial plan, with the Administration agreeing to reduce the water reserved for environmental reasons. In the end, they whittled down that amount by about a fifth, from 500,000 to 400,000 acre feet in a year with normal rainfall. An acre foot is about 326,000 gallons, enough to keep two typical households supplied for a year.
The negotiators managed to make the reduction by asking scientists to come up with a new approach for calculating how much fresh water would be needed to reach the desired salinity. The new measure, based on monthly measurements instead of rough annual estimates, is more accurate and more flexible, an official said.
They also agreed on ways of protecting fish other than increasing the flow of fresh water, for instance operating pumps differently at times of the year when the young fish are most vulnerable.

HEADLINE: U.S. Signs Agreement to Help Haiti Revitalize Its Economy

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Dec. 14

 BODY:
Haiti's Government signed an agreement with the United States today as part of a Clinton Administration plan to revitalize the Haitian economy.
Under an initiative announced on Wednesday by the White House, the United States will provide technical and financial aid to Haiti so businesses can return to the Caribbean nation. 
 The measures are intended to improve telecommunications, energy and transportation, as well as clear the way for Haiti to borrow money from international financial institutions. To that end, the United States has pledged nearly $25 million to Haiti to clear past-due payments on loans, the White House said.
Today, officials of the Haitian Finance Ministry and the United States Department of Commerce signed a memorandum of understanding to create a joint Business Development Council, which will clude representatives from the private sector and both Governments, to stimulate economic growth in Haiti.
The Haitian Government will do its part to encourage trade and investment by providing incentives to business, President Jean-Bertrand Aristide said. They will include tax breaks for companies that establish operations in Haiti by July 1, 1995. President Aristide also said that by the end of this year he planned to introduce legislation to Parliament that would lower import tariffs, especially those on food.
"Our challenge is great, but our will to succeed is greater," he said at a meeting sponsored by Caribbean/ Latin American Action, a nonprofit corporation. "Haiti is back in business and ready to go,"
The immediate focus of the Clinton Administration initiative will be on the assembly and handicrafts industries, which could provide jobs for tens of thousands of Haitians who had few ways to make money under an embargo imposed against the military leaders who overthrew President Aristide in 1991. The plan includes a $12 million project by the Agency for International Development to support small Haitian businesses.

HEADLINE: Star Fades for Natural Gas Autos

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

 BODY:
What ever happened to natural gas vehicles?
After the oil crises of the 1970's and the clean air laws of the 1980's, the consensus among environmentalists, petroleum executives and state and Federal officials was that the United States would reap economic and environmental rewards from converting millions of vehicles to natural gas. 
 But conversion to natural gas has never caught on, and another setback could come as soon as today. A ruling on clean-car standards is expected from the Environmental Protection Agency today or early next week, and many experts expect it to eliminate one of the remaining incentives for building and driving natural gas cars and trucks.
Natural gas once seemed like such a good idea. Compared with solar power, electric cars and other energy exotica, it appeared to be a simple solution. Natural gas is clean and has a higher octane than race-car gasoline, the nation has abundant reserves of the fuel and using it requires hardly any new technology. What's more, in terms of cost-per-mile, natural gas is up to 40 percent less expensive than gasoline.
But not many have embraced the technology, with fewer than 33,000 vehicles in the nation running on natural gas, according to Federal estimates. Operators of large fleets of cars or trucks, including New York City, have found that drivers prefer vehicles powered by gasoline.
The Big Three auto makers have shown limited enthusiasm, and General Motors said earlier this year that it would suspend production of its natural-gas vehicles at least through 1996 and recall all 2,500 it had already sold. G.M. made that decision after fuel tanks ruptured and exploded in two different trucks, causing minor injuries.
Another big setback for the natural gas movement could lie in the impending E.P.A. ruling. The agency has been considering a request by New York and 11 other Northeastern states to have the Government impose strict car-emission rules for the region from Maine to Virginia. The rules would be the same as those adopted by California, and the natural gas industry believes that imposing them in the Northeast would result in the use of tens of thousands of natural gas vehicles.
But the auto makers have proposed a compromise that would require them simply to make cleaner-burning gasoline vehicles, which would be sold in all 49 states besides California. The E.P.A. has expressed interest in the auto makers' proposal. And the Big Three have vowed that no matter what is required, they will try hard to do it with gasoline and nothing more exotic.
With the prospects increasingly gloomy for natural gas vehicles, even the advocates say that instead of the millions of such cars and trucks that they once hoped for, the numbers could be much lower.
"Any reasonable projection should include zero" as a possibility, said James S. Cannon, the author of "Paving the Way to Natural Gas Vehicles," published by the New York environmental group Inform.
Not surprisingly, a main proponent of natural gas vehicles has always been the natural gas utility companies that sell the fuel. Because the United States produces 30 percent more natural gas from its petroleum fields than it does oil, there is an adequate supply and a national distribution system that already delivers the fuel to 50 million homes.
Converting cars to use natural gas requires some special equipment -- a high-pressure tank, fuel-pressure regulators and modifications to the fuel-injection system -- but none of this is very complicated.
Natural gas has an octane of 110 to 130, compared with an octane of 93 or less for the gasoline sold at filling stations, which should mean that natural gas delivers much higher power. But most vehicles converted to natural gas -- typically at a cost of several thousand dollars -- retain the ability to run on gasoline, too.
Using both fuels enables the vehicles to range beyond the limited number of fueling stations with natural gas pumps. As a result, the engines must be tuned to gasoline specifications, meaning that natural gas loses its power edge and the engine often performs worse and runs dirtier than with gasoline.
The experience of New York City is instructive. Hoping to help clean the air, reduce fuel costs and set an example for the private sector, the city government in the last few years has converted hundreds of cars and light trucks. The conversions were done largely at the expense of two local gas utilities, Consolidated Edison and Brooklyn Union Gas, and the city signed contracts with them that guaranteed certain minimum purchase levels of natural gas.
But the city has incurred penalty fees on those contracts because it is using only about two-thirds as much natural gas as it agreed to buy. City officials, seeking the reasons, say that many of the cars may still be running on gasoline or that some drivers may see them as lemons and are not driving them at all.
In fact, some of the conversions could leave that impression. For example, Joe Olive, the assistant deputy chief of operations for technical services at the city's Parks Department, recalls being stuck in traffic on a hot summer day in a 1989 Ford Bronco running on natural gas, and telling the driver that when they returned to the shop, they would have to have the air-conditioner fixed.
But the driver, Kurt Schroer, simply reached down and threw a switch that converted the Bronco back to gasoline, and the air-conditioner began working fine, Mr. Olive said.
In Texas and other places where local gas utilities have been aggressive, some fleet operators are converting. In Atlanta, for example, the city housing authority converted 18 Ford Rangers to natural gas. But officials found that converting them was one thing, and getting them to run on the new fuel was another.
Scott A. Massie, the facilities and fleet equipment manager for the Atlanta housing authority, said, "When you give people a choice, they usually go with gasoline, because it's more familiar, I guess."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Natural gas is available at only one station in Manhattan, at West 46th Street and the West Side Highway, where Joe Torres filled up. (Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
S.E.C. Begins to Investigate Orange County Board's Role

BYLINE: By SALLIE HOFMEISTER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 15

 BODY:
The Securities and Exchange Commission's investigation into the Orange County, Calif., bankruptcy has shifted to the county's elected board of supervisors, even as the agency's chairman suggested that voters should throw the five-member board out of office.
The S.E.C., late on Wednesday, subpoenaed records of the supervisors that relate to the sale of bonds by the county. But county officials said today that a letter to the board from the S.E.C. assured them that the request for documents "should not be construed as an indication by the commission that any violations of the law have occurred." 
 The widening of the S.E.C.'s investigation came hours after Arthur Levitt Jr., the S.E.C.'s chairman, rebuked the five-member board for not challenging the investment strategy pursued by the former treasurer, Robert L. Citron, that forced the county to file for bankruptcy. As a result of Mr. Citron's heavy borrowing and ill-timed bets that interest rates would fall this year, Orange County is expected to lose more than $2 billion of the $7.5 billion invested by 187 local governments, school districts and other county institutions.
Mr. Levitt's speech, made with little advance notice, went unreported when it was delivered here on Wednesday. In remarks at a luncheon sponsored by the Town Hall, a speaker's forum whose members are mostly business leaders, Mr. Levitt said: "If your supervisors are so lax that they allow you the unique power, without oversight, to make that kind of speculation, I think the voters of that community should throw the whole bunch out of office."
In recent days, several Orange County residents have attended county board meetings to ask board members and other top county officials to resign. Next week, Gaddi Vasquez will take over as chairman of the Orange County Board of Supervisors from Thomas Riley, who is retiring, as is Harriett M. Wieder. Two newly elected supervisors, James Silva and Marian Bergeson, will take the vacant spots on Jan. 2.
The initial focus of the S.E.C. inquiry was on the brokerage houses that sold Orange County bonds to the public. At least two firms have been subpoenaed by the S.E.C.: Merrill Lynch & Company, which sold $600 million in county bonds in the summer, and Rauscher Pierce Refsnes Inc., a Dallas firm that had been retained to sell a coming issue.
The S.E.C. would not comment on its overall investigation. Lawyers close to the case, however, said the regulators were looking at whether the firms sold bonds to investors knowing that the Orange County investment pool faced losses and without disclosing that information.
Regulators are also reviewing the relationship between the county and Merrill Lynch, which has received millions of dollars in fees from selling the county's bonds. One question is whether county officials improperly steered business to Merrill Lynch because of campaign contributions or any other gifts made by brokers. Merrill has denied any wrongdoing in its relationship with Orange County.
The county succeeded today in its first attempts to sell off the portfolio. Salomon Brothers, which has been retained by the county to convert the assets into safer, more liquid instruments, sold the first batch for $483 million, taking in nearly 100 bids that totaled $7.5 billion.
"I'm pleased with the amount of interest and generally pleased with the spreads," said James A. Forese, managing director of Salomon and head of the bond syndication desk. "But tomorrow's a new day and we may not have as much response."
He would not disclose the number of winning bids. The Federal National Mortgage Association, which issued some of the bonds sold today, said that it had tried to buy back some of those bonds but that other bidders offered higher prices.
On Friday, Salomon expects to sell an additional $500 million in bonds, While today's sale was mostly of Treasury and Fannie Mae bonds with durations of three to four years, Friday's offering is expected to include bonds with longer maturities. Mr. Forese said the firm had divided the auction into two parts to avoid swamping the market.
The real test for the county is not so much the outcome of the sale of these relatively easy-to-sell conventional securities as its ability to sell its larger supply of structured notes, which are more complex instruments whose performance is tied to declining interest rates. Salomon Brothers would not discuss when or how these securities would be sold.
