HEADLINE: Arrest of Financier, Accused of Stealing, Shakes Barcelona

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BARCELONA, Spain

 BODY:
People in Barcelona were accustomed to seeing Javier de la Rosa, a maverick financier, met by investment bankers, Middle Eastern sheiks and Government ministers as he stepped from his Mercedes-Benz limousine. But on Oct. 18, he stepped into the arms of the police, who arrested him on suspicion of stealing the assets of his company.
The arrest shook the labyrinthine streets and grand boulevards of Barcelona. Mr. de la Rosa's rise was intertwined with that of this city of 1.7 million. 
 After 1985, when Spain entered the European Community, this bustling port city attracted billions of dollars in investments. In 1992, when the Olympic Games were staged here, fortunes were made.
The political stock of Catalonia, the region of which Barcelona is the capital, has also risen. As head of the Catalan government, a de la Rosa associate named Jordi Pujol made it possible for the Socialist Prime Minister of Spain, Felipe Gonzalez, to return to power at the head of a minority Government in June 1993. Mr. Pujol agreed to throw his regional party's support to Mr. Gonzalez in exchange for favors for Catalonia.
Mr. Pujol also supported Mr. de la Rosa and his company, Grand Tibidabo, a real estate development enterprise with many other interests. The company collapsed when the local real estate bubble burst after the 1992 Olympics, and Mr. de la Rosa is accused of stripping it of $80 million in assets.
Mr. de la Rosa's supporters say he is the victim of political intrigues against Mr. Pujol, and through him, the Prime Minister.
But even during the years when he appeared to be most successful, Mr. de La Rosa's record was not all sunshine. In 1986, a Catalan bank that he had steered into heady expansion with agriculture investments, Banco Garriga Nogues, collapsed under $300 million in bad loans, and his management was widely criticized.
At the same time, Mr. de La Rosa was making contact with Kuwaiti investors, who eventually plowed $5 billion into real estate, chemical and food companies through a corporation of his called Grupo Torras.
When Spain's boom turned to bust, as the recession of the early 1990's hit, Grupo Torras went into receivership. Mr. de la Rosa and dozens of other businessmen are under investigation into how the bulk of the $5 billion was squandered.
After the Kuwaiti venture failed, Mr. de la Rosa fostered a plan for Tibidabo to develop a theme park south of Barcelona called Tibigardens, in partnership with the American beer company Anheuser-Busch.
Much fog surrounds what happened to the project, but in the end Mr. de la Rosa was forced from Tibidabo, and minority shareholders are suing to regain the vanished assets. The project is to be built by other companies.
Jose Maria Mena, the investigating judge, who is plowing through 600 volumes of documents, denied there is a political vendetta.
"In no case are we interested in persecuting any person," he said. "There is no personal desire for triumph."
But Alfredo Fraile, whose Agencia A public relations company has worked for Mr. de la Rosa for six years, contended that in the inflated world of real estate during the 1980's, many fortunes were owed to Mr. de la Rosa.
"How many people bought shares in his companies, and when the prices went up, sold at huge profits?" he said. "And where are they now? We're in a situation in Spain where they're looking for scandal, with a political component."

HEADLINE: Prosecutor Rejects Rape Cases Brought by Male Van Drivers

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
After a 21-month investigation, District Attorney Richard A. Brown of Queens issued a report yesterday concluding that seven immigrant van drivers working in the Rockaways had falsely accused a male police officer of raping them. Mr. Brown said Officer Reggie Rivera would not be prosecuted because the rapes never took place.
The drivers, all of whom are black immigrants working in the illicit van trade on the Rockaway peninsula, had a strong motive to defame Officer Rivera because he had issued thousands of tickets to van drivers and represented a direct threat to their livelihood, the report said. 
 At a news conference, Mr. Brown stopped short of saying the accusers had deliberately conspired to fabricate the charges, which have led to months of protest marches by black community activists. But Police Commissioner William J. Bratton did not hesitate in calling them liars.
"In no uncertain terms, backed up by a very lengthy report, the District Attorney of Queens County has made it clear that there are not seven rape victims in this case, there are only two: New York City Police Officer Reggie Rivera, and the citizens of New York City who were raped by this rat pack," Mr. Bratton said.
The accusers and their lawyers, the Commissioner said, had maliciously concocted the rape stories in order to intimidate the police from enforcing the law against the van industry.
Leon Greenberg, a lawyer for the accusers -- who was personally accused by Mr. Brown of hindering the investigation -- said the report was "a carefully crafted scheme" to cover up the truth of the allegations and protect the City of New York from a huge financial liability. He said investigators from the District Attorney's office and the police were biased against the accusers, and had fabricated evidence to make the charges appear to be a conspiracy.
And in a brief telephone interview, one of the seven accusers denied that he or the others had lied about the rapes.
"There is nothing made up in this story," said the accuser, who spoke on condition of anonymity because a civil suit is being pursued. "They are trying to cover up. We thought if we went to the D.A., this would never happen to us again. But now I feel so disappointed and sick."
The case began in April 1993, when an African-born livery-van driver from Rockaway Beach accused Officer Rivera of having sodomized him at gunpoint three months earlier. In October and December 1993, three other van drivers and a mechanic who had been test-driving a van charged that Officer Rivera had raped them. And yesterday's report disclosed for the first time that two other drivers had stepped forward earlier this year to say they had been raped, beginning in 1989.
Because the District Attorney took so long to decide whether to present the case to a grand jury for prosecution, many politicians and community leaders had begun calling for a special prosecutor in the case. Several black newspapers and clergy members rallied to the drivers' cause, saying their case was being ignored because they were black immigrants operating in an underground economy on the margins of society.
But Mr. Brown said the nature of the charges produced the most exhaustive investigation in the history of his office, including hundreds of interviews, hours of surveillance, the review of 4,000 traffic tickets, and the use of an independent expert in sexual assaults.
John M. Ryan, the senior executive assistant district attorney who headed the investigation, said there was no single piece of evidence that conclusively proved the accusers had concocted their charge. But taken as a whole, he said, there was no physical or medical evidence of rape and there was a good deal of evidence to show that Officer Rivera could not have raped the men in the manner they claimed.
The report said Officer Rivera was usually writing traffic tickets during the times that the accusers said the rapes took place. The van in which the first accuser said he was raped was ticketed in a different location at the same time the rape was said to have occurred, the report said. It also said some of the physical details of the rape descriptions provided by the accusers were implausible.
Most importantly, Mr. Ryan and Mr. Brown said, the accusers had a strong motive to get rid of Officer Rivera. Their report describes the officer as a "ticket-writing machine," issuing up to 200 tickets a day to drivers in the thriving unlicensed van industry, who illegally pick up passengers for less than the cost of public transportation and take them to subway stops or shopping malls.
The first accuser, described in the report as an industry leader, was so angry about being repeatedly ticketed by Officer Rivera that he organized an August 1992 meeting of Rockaway van drivers in a public library to urge them to file citizen complaints against the officer, the report said.
When those complaints failed to get the officer transferred, Mr. Ryan said, the accusers began their charges of rape. He added that he did not know if any of the accusers except the first were present at the library meeting.
The accusers' other motive was financial, Mr. Ryan said, noting that they have filed a $120 million civil damage suit against the city. Mr. Greenberg said his clients would not drop the suit.
The report also says that at least five of the seven had at one point lived in the same apartment complex on Seagirt Boulevard in Far Rockaway. The accusers have said throughout the investigation that only two of them knew each other, and yesterday, Mr. Greenberg continued to make the same point.
Asked if he planned to prosecute the accusers for making a false report, Mr. Brown said he did not, pointing out that such an action was a Class B misdemeanor, the lowest class of criminal conduct. He said building such a case would require an extensive effort for such a small charge and might deter legitimate sexual-assault victims from coming forward in other cases.
Many of the findings in the case represented a battle of experts. The accusers had hired Nat Laurendi, a retired New York City police detective who was formerly chief polygraph operator for the Manhattan District Attorney's office, who conducted lie-detector tests that he said showed they were telling the truth about the rapes. But Mr. Brown's in-house polygraph operator, as well as the F.B.I.'s chief lie-detector expert, reviewed Mr. Laurendi's tests and concluded that the accusers were actually lying.
Similarly, both sides hired experts in rape trauma syndrome to determine whether the accusers appeared to exhibit the normal characteristics of rape victims, and the two experts disagreed. The report does not address whether, because the accusers come from Africa and the Caribbean, there may have been language and cultural barriers that produced behavior patterns different from the norms. But Mr. Ryan said his office's expert on the subject has a background in the cultural differences among victims of sexual assault.
Officer Rivera declined to comment yesterday, but his lawyer, James Lysaght, chief counsel for the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, said his client was still upset at having "become the object of public scorn on the basis of such despicable calumny."
As a result of a court-approved agreement in the civil case, the officer remains restricted from entering the Rockaways except to go to the bank once a week. Hearings in the civil case are scheduled to resume on Dec. 27.
The officer was transferred last spring from the Rockaways to the 107th Precinct in Fresh Meadows, Queens, where he is on active duty. Commissioner Bratton said he had not determined Officer Rivera's future assignment.
 
Two Views, Both Accusatory
 "There are not seven rape victims in this case, there are only two: New York City Police Officer Reggie Rivera, and the citizens of New York City who were raped by this rat pack." -- POLICE COMMISSIONER WILLIAM J. BRATTON
 "There is nothing made up in this story. They are trying to cover up. We thought if we went to the D.A., this would never happen to use again. But now I feel so disappointed and sick." -- ONE OF THE ACCUSERS

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Mixed Day For Treasury Securities

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Treasury notes and bills rallied and bonds fell yesterday after a report suggested that higher interest rates were beginning to create a slowdown in manufacturing.
The report, a survey of regional manufacturing conditions by the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia, eased concerns about any acceleration in inflation and helped to confirm expectations that the Federal Reserve would not raise short-term interest rates on Tuesday, when its policy-making committee meets. 
 The Philadelphia Fed's index of general economic activity fell to 28.9 in December from 30.5 last month.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 1/8, to 9523/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 7.87 percent, from 7.86 percent on Wednesday. The price of the two-year note rose 1/8, to 9917/32 , for a yield of 7.51 percent, down from 7.58 percent on Wednesday and nearly 20 basis points below Tuesday's yield of 7.69 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percent.
Yields on the three-month bill dropped as much as 15 basis points.
The Philadelphia Fed report, coming after Labor Department reports on producer and consumer prices this week, meant "the three-year area looks most attractive," said Jim Somers, who runs a $5 million hedge fund in Radnor, Pa. "You can sell the one-year bill and buy the three-year and pick up 52 basis points."
Speculators who sold bills on a bet that the Fed would make them less valuable by raising short-term rates, reversed that bet after this week's inflation reports, traders said.
Yield spreads between benchmark mortgage securities and Treasury bonds reached their narrowest in three weeks as investors speculated that a shortage of new mortgages would insure better returns.
Municipal bonds were little changed as some investors sought to sell securities to record tax losses before the end of the year, traders said. The average yield to maturity in the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal issues was unchanged at 6.98 percent.
Orange County, Calif., began selling the debt remaining in its loss-plagued investment portfolio yesterday.
Salomon Brothers Inc., manager of the auction, took bids on nine pools of the fund's Government agency securities issued by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board; the Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae, and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, or Freddie Mac.
Demand for the securities was strong, as traders expected, with $7.5 billion of bids received by Salomon.
Differences in yield, or spreads, between agency bonds and Treasuries widened by as much as 20 basis points last week after Orange County filed for Chapter 9 bankruptcy because investment banks sold about $11.4 billion of agency notes that were held as collateral for Orange County's derivative investments.
The agency sales "cheapened up the agency area," attracting buyers, said Jerry Paul, who helps manage about $3 billion at the Invesco Trust Company in Denver.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Firmer Against Mark In Generally Quiet Trading

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar ended little changed against most leading currencies yesterday, with many participants sidelined ahead of the year-end holidays.
"There is very little activity and very little volume," David Durst, vice president at Bear, Stearns & Company, said. "The silence is deafening. People are just in the process of squaring up for the year end." 
 The dollar was bolstered somewhat after the German mark eased from recent highs against the Italian lira and the French franc in early trading in Europe.
The dollar had been been weighed down earlier in the week by the strength of the mark, as traders shifted out of the Italian and French currencies and into the mark. In many cases, dealers bought dollars for lire and francs and then sold dollars for marks, considered the anchor currency in Europe.
But dealers in Europe began selling marks at its higher levels yesterday to book profits and that helped to relieve some pressure on the dollar.
In New York trading, the dollar eased after the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia said its industry activity survey showed a slightly slower pace of growth in December.
Susan Stearns, vice president at Harris Trust New York, said the milder-than-expected data "dashed speculation of any short-term interest rate hike that the Federal Reserve might do next week."
In New York trading late yesterday, the dollar rose to 1.5710 marks from 1.5682 marks on Wednesday. The dollar edged up to 100.37 yen, from 100.30 yen on Wednesday.
 Some dealers had expected the Fed to raise rates for the seventh time since February next Tuesday, when its policy-making Federal Open Market Committee meets. Higher interest rates tend to benefit the dollar by attracting investors drawn by a higher return on investments denominated in the currency.
In other currency trading yesterday, the Australian dollar rose to 78 United States cents, its highest since December 1991, a day after the Reserve Board of Australia, the country's central bank, raised short-term interest rates a full percentage point, to 7.5 percent. In New York, the Australian dollar settled at 77.80 United States cents.

HEADLINE: On Stage, and Off

BYLINE: By Donald G. McNeil Jr. 

 BODY:

'What's Wrong'? Too Much
"What's Wrong With This Picture?" has its answer: the critics didn't like the Jewish mother ghost story starring Faith Prince, and the public didn't buy tickets. It opened on Broadway on Dec. 8; it closes on Sunday.
"We decided that the best thing to do was return the 25 percent that's left of the capitalization to the investors," said David Stone, the lead producer, whose first production, "Family Secrets," has run for 15 months off Broadway. 
 He raised $1.25 million for "What's Wrong" and will give back $325,000. "We don't think the box office warrants spending our reserve to try building an audience," he added. "I'm sorry it didn't work out better, but I couldn't be prouder to have tried. We brush ourselves off and go on."
Getting in her "I told you so's" is Ruth Kalkstein, who had an option on the play from 1990 to 1993 but never found investors. She had a tiny share of this production, but she and Mr. Stone fell out after she criticized his casting and his decision to go to Broadway. So although he gave her tickets to previews, he disinvited her from opening night. "I regret that now," Mr. Stone said this week. "It probably wasn't a kind thing to have done. My mother raised me better than that."
 
A Public Goodbye
 Another pink slip has been handed out at the Joseph Papp Public Theater as George C. Wolfe consolidates his control. Jason Steven Cohen, the managing director who began there 22 years ago as a stage manager, will leave next month.
There was no falling-out, said Mr. Cohen, 48. "But after helping chart a course through tumultuous times, with the promised land of economic and artistic stability in sight, I'm hugely disappointed not to be a part of it."
As Papp's last No. 2, Mr. Cohen negotiated the Public's 99-year lease, arrangements for the now-defunct Festival Latino and exchanges with the Royal Court Theater in London.
What will he do? "Good question," he said. "I'll think about working in films or TV. Maybe I'll teach, and give back what I've learned. Maybe I'll work in somebody's orchard."
Mr. Wolfe has recently hired other administrators, including Joey Parnes as general manager, but wouldn't say what the new hierarchy will be. "I'm not being coy," he said. "I'm still assessing the structure of the institution."
 
A Polygram Goodbye
 Another theater figure left more abruptly: John Scher, a promoter of megaconcerts (including Woodstock '94) who was also the first president of Polygram Diversified Entertainment, resigned last week. Polygram is one of the few conglomerates, with Disney and Capital Cities/ ABC, that are powers on Broadway; it backed "Jelly's Last Jam," "Damn Yankees" and the long-delayed "Victor/Victoria" and owns 30 percent of Andrew Lloyd Webber's Really Useful production company.
Mr. Scher and Polygram said he left because the company's chief executive, Alain Levy, resisted Mr. Scher's plans to expand the division. He still sees "extraordinary opportunities" on Broadway, especially if more pop musicians like Pete Townshend of "Tommy" will write shows.
 
Teapot Dome-Jack the Ripper Link
 "Camping With Henry and Tom" opens with a Model T hitting a deer. The stranded men -- Henry Ford, Thomas Edison and Warren G. Harding -- are joined by a Secret Service colonel reluctant to let the President wander the woods. The play, based on a real camp-out, is coming to the Lucille Lortel Theater in February. It begins rehearsals on Jan. 10, a lucky date for the playwright, Mark St. Germain. On the same day, rehearsals are also to begin for a Playwrights Horizons production of his musical "Jack's Holiday." The incident that inspired this one was uglier. After Jack the Ripper disemboweled several London prostitutes, New York's chief of police, Thomas Byrnes, boasted that he would have had the Ripper collared within 36 hours. In 1891, a prostitute was killed Ripper-style on Manhattan's waterfront, and the challenge was on.
Mr. St. Germain and his composer, Randy Courts, also wrote "Johnny Pye and the Fool Killer."
 
 
Confessing a Theft
 Sometimes it's hard to tell whether a producer is driven more by the need for publicity or the need for absolution. Which could have been stronger when James Freydberg called to confess, "I'm doing something I always hated when movie producers did it to me"?
His sin: With Khalil Kain two weeks into rehearsals for the revival of "Zooman and the Sign," now being mounted by Second Stage Theater, Mr. Freydberg stole him for the title role in his television movie "Zooman," now shooting in Los Angeles. He agonized about it, and auditioned other actors, but ultimately went ahead.
In this 1980 play by Charles Fuller, a stray bullet from Zooman's gun kills a girl on her porch during a drug turf battle. The neighbors are silent. Her father raises a sign attacking their cowardice, and infuriates Zooman.
Before the opening on Sunday, Carole Rothman, the artistic director of Second Stage, spoke of Mr. Freydberg in pleasant tones but unprintable terms, adding: "If he felt that badly about it, he wouldn't have done it. He's got to live with himself. We've found someone I think will be even better, Larry Gilliard Jr."
The reviews say Mr. Gilliard has worked out fine. Mr. Freydberg is glad.
 
Footlights
 *Glenn Close will be on vacation from "Sunset Boulevard" from March 7 through March 19. Her standby, Karen Mason, will play the role. If you insist, box offices exchange tickets.
*Paul Ronan knows what he wants for Christmas. In Kenneth Branagh's "Public Enemy" at the Irish Arts Center, he plays a Belfast hoodlum who thinks he's Jimmy Cagney. Ten days ago, there was a slip-up in a fight scene with Neal Jones, who plays his straight-arrow brother, and Mr. Ronan's two front teeth were knocked out.
*Because tourists at the TKTS booth are nervous about out-of-the-way theaters, "Inside Out," the group-therapy musical at the Cherry Lane, is experimenting. Next week, a free shuttle bus will run from Times Square to the theater, at 38 Commerce Street, Greenwich Village.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Phils Spend While Clubs Poor-Mouth

BYLINE: By GEORGE VECSEY 

 BODY:
WE don't know if there will be reputable baseball in April but the owners are playing games in December. The most insulting thing the owners are doing goes far beyond threatening a salary cap at the players and then backing off for a week, as they did yesterday afternoon in Chicago.
The delay might even turn out to be statesmanlike, if you can imagine that from this bunch. In the meantime, the really despicable thing the owners are doing is conducting business as usual. They are bleating that they must have an artificial limit on salaries, but on Wednesday the Philadelphia Phillies had the nerve, the gall, the chutzpah, to sign Gregg Jefferies for $20 million for four years. 
 Have they no sense of shame? Paying $5 million a year for a good hitter who's never proven he's a winning player is not out of sight, considering the ludicrous salaries tossed around by the owners. A month ago, Houston re-signed Jeff Bagwell for $27 million for four years. But the Jefferies timing is contemptuous to the public.
The Phillies will say they are lucky to be able to afford Gregg Jefferies, that baseball never meant to stop being competitive for top players. In the most recent proposals for a tax on payrolls, the Phillies were listed as "haves" by both the owners' and the players' economists. They sell tickets, they're in a major television market, they do fine. But isn't this charade all about rich owners showing some solidarity with their poor cousins?
Legally, of course, the owners cannot afford to have an official policy of not signing free agents. They've been down this collusion path before. They clumsily avoided signing free agents like Tim Raines and lived to pay the price in damages. But the Phillies could have declined to sign Jefferies. Who made them? It was their own choice. And that's the point.
Just about every one of these owners made money in some other field, then got into baseball because they were convinced they could outsmart all those other clodhopper owners. Hobnob with the players. Win the World Series. Impress the guys at the club. So they tossed around money for players who turned out to be busts. Every town has its stories.
The owners are embarrassed at having spent like fools and being beaten by the players association for the past two decades. The owners are still threatening to get even by imposing new labor rules on the players, which would send this business into the courts and the Congress. It has come to this because the owners failed to impress the self-centered, short-sighted athletes there is any kind of financial urgency. The way the owners hide their profits, I don't believe their poor-mouthing, either.
The owners don't even have the character to close shop while they bluster. The Yankees traded for Jack McDowell Wednesday night and signed Tony Fernandez yesterday. Will Steinbrenner try to force either of them to break the picket line on opening day? That's going to this winter's version of the old Hot Stove League. Who's got the most scabs?
I wouldn't put it past the owners. They talk as if they would be performing a public service by dragging up the culls and rejects and palming them off as baseball players. Bud Selig tries to sound like Santa Claus when he says he'd personally cut ticket prices if he had to field bush leaguers.
Meanwhile, the sad-sack fans try to make sense of this. Some of them were calling in to sports radio yesterday babbling about the Yankees' pitching rotation with Jack McDowell. More likely, the Yankee pitching rotation will be names you have not yet heard. How grubby.
Not only that, Steinbrenner wants you to underwrite it. The clubs are still selling tickets for next year. At going rates. The poor fans are signing up because they don't want to lose their good locations. To see what -- the return of Jim Coates and Duke Carmel?
It's time for the fans to be offended. No more idealism. The only weapon the fans have is not to buy tickets. Lend money to Steinbrenner and Doubleday and Wilpon and Selig and The Chicago Tribune and Ted Turner and Jerry Reinsdorf? Lend money to the Philadelphia Phillies as a down payment for $20 million for Gregg Jefferies?
Let them settle this thing first. They think you're fools. Prove you're not. Never lend money to baseball owners. What a clean, pure way to start the new year.

HEADLINE: THE CLINTON TAX PLAN: NEWS ANALYSIS;
About-Face by Clinton

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15

 BODY:
For the first two years of his Presidency, Bill Clinton insisted that reducing the Federal budget deficit was his highest calling. Tonight, he reversed course.
What is most important is not the details of what he proposed: a variety of tax breaks designed mostly for political appeal and a seemingly pain-free method of raising the revenue to pay for them. The Republican Congress is no more likely to adopt this President's budget offerings than Democratic Congresses were likely to accept President George Bush's. 
 Much more significant is what the measures say about how the President is positioning himself ideologically for his next two years in office and his race for re-election.
Rather than try to persuade the public that the deficit is a corrosive force that must be brought under control to keep it from eating away at the country's economic roots, a view held by most economists but relatively few politicians, Mr. Clinton has opted for the course Republicans have followed for years. For him, as well as for his political opponents, lowering the deficit will play second fiddle to lowering taxes.
The Republicans who will be controlling Congress beginning next year have promised to pass a Constitutional amendment requiring a balanced budget by early in the next century, but they have given no indication whatsoever how they intend to accomplish that. Instead, they have emphasized the handsome tax breaks in their script.
Mr. Clinton's tax proposals are not so generous, but for better or worse, he is on the same stage.
The President's advisers dispute the notion that he has flip-flopped on this issue the way he did, for example, on policies regarding Haiti and Bosnia. The advisers say that Mr. Clinton has always wanted a middle-class tax cut -- after all, he proposed one during his election campaign -- but that reducing the deficit had to come first.
For three straight fiscal years, the deficit has fallen. In part, that is because of the budget Mr. Clinton pushed through Congress last year. The deficit is expected to begin to rise once more in the fiscal year that begins next October unless taxes are increased or spending is reduced further. The President ignored that in his speech tonight.
Presidential assistants who spoke to reporters tonight on the condition that they not be identified insisted that the tax cuts Mr. Clinton was offering would be fully offset by spending reductions.
Maybe so. But the proposed tax breaks were described tonight with considerable specificity. The spending cuts were described only in the most general terms. A White House spokesman said the Administration would describe the tax measures in even greater detail on Friday but would not deal publicly with the specifics of the spending reductions until next week.
No mention was made tonight of reducing the deficit further in any significant way or of steps to keep it from rising beginning in 1996.
The most unpleasant part of the President's tax proposals -- that they will be gradually introduced over a period of years rather than becoming effective immediately -- was not discussed publicly tonight.
Furthermore, most of the savings in spending -- $52 billion out of a total of $76 billion -- would be accomplished without immediate political pain by extending the freeze on discretionary spending programs through the year 2000. (Discretionary spending includes items ranging from battleships to ballpoint pens -- everything the Government puts up money for except entitlements like Social Security and Medicare, under which benefits are paid to the people who meet the eligibility requirements regardless of the total cost to the Government.)
The freeze has been in effect since 1991 and was to have expired in 1998. It has indeed held down spending. But the Administration is not saying which programs are in line for cuts in 1999 and 2000 to maintain the freeze, whether they would be in the military or social programs or what. Since no one knows who would take the hit, there is no current political cost to the President.
Only a few specific program cuts were divulged tonight, but some of them are likely to generate considerable political opposition.
For example, the Administration intends to sell dams, power stations and other assets connected to hydroelectric plants the Government owns in Western states. This would doubtless result in higher electricity costs in those states and is likely to be opposed by, among others, Senator Mark O. Hatfield of Oregon, who will be the new chairman of the Appropriations Committee, and his fellow Republican from Oregon, Senator Bob Packwood, who will be chairman of the Finance Committee.
Similar proposals have arisen in the past, but they were blocked by Representative Thomas S. Foley, the Washington Democrat who was Speaker of the House.
Money would also be saved by turning over the air-traffic control system to private operators. Opponents of this step include the general aviation industry. Most of the American-built planes flown by private pilots are made by companies with headquarters in Kansas. Senator Bob Dole of Kansas will be the new Republican majority leader.
The tax breaks Mr. Clinton wants would be helpful to middle-income families but would by no means be a windfall. The White House a family with two small children and an income of $50,000 would save $1,000 a year in taxes, or less than $20 a week. A comparable family with a college tuition bill of more than $10,000 would save $1,500 a year.
The Clinton proposal faces stiff competition on Capitol Hill. Republicans in the House have offered a $500 tax credit for all dependent children in families with incomes below $200,000. Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the Democratic leader in the House, has offered lower taxes for all families with incomes below $75,000.
Today, Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, put his oar in the water with a proposal to double the personal exemption parents can take for each dependent child to $5,000 from $2,500. This would save a middle-income family in the 15 percent tax bracket $375 per child in taxes. It would save an affluent family in the 36 percent bracket $900 for each child.
An Administration official who worked on the Clinton election campaign and who disagrees with the new policies announced tonight said Mr. Clinton's decision to back away from the hard-choices stance he took in his first two years in office resulted from a lesson he learned in the Democratic primaries in 1992. Then, Paul E.. Tsongas won the New Hampshire primary with a campaign grounded in making tough, potentially unpopular budget decisions. Mr. Clinton quickly eclipsed Mr. Tsongas in the later primaries by denouncing the bitter medicine his opponent was advocating and sugar-coating his own campaign.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Lean and Very Mean

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
They were born in a land where work and hope were rights, not dreams, and for the rest of their lives it gave them a spring in their walk. They did not claim the earth, just that part of it they could earn with their muscle and brain.
They believed good steady work, wages moving up, was their part ownership in their own society. They believed that next year would be better than this one, if not always for them, then for sure for their children. Generally they turned out right, so the children believed it too, generation after generation. 
 American optimism -- for two centuries you could touch it, believe in it, as it built a great nation. No other country in history had an inspiration, a system, a concept, a mixture of people, a gift of God, a heritage -- American optimism grew out of all of them -- that worked as well, created so much for so many.
In times when despair did descend, on the nation or parts of it, America discovered the leadership it needed -- a Lincoln, a Franklin D. Roosevelt, a King. What were Dr. King's dreams but the reaching out for a right to believe in American optimism?
Now it is withering. If it expires, the epitaph will be: "Dead of lean and mean."
If you are looking for basic meaning in the last election, it is that Americans are beginning to understand that the unwritten contract between them and their society is being torn up. The understanding was that in bad times everybody would hurt but that if the boss was doing well so would the workers -- better wages to take home, more job security to build on.
Unemployment is low -- well, if you don't want to count young black men. Inflation is under control, foreign trade growing, corporate profits generally up, productivity rising. But nobody sings and dances.
Instead Americans are edgy. They look for targets -- sometimes immigrants, the press, and in the last election the party in power.
They are mad and should be madder. The surprise is that Americans are so passive while the foundations of their working lives and nation-building optimism are destroyed.
They all know what is going on -- that often it takes a husband and wife to earn what the husband once earned, that in a time that should be prosperity thousands of Americans are fired by companies showing nice profits, that if the unemployed do find a job it is at lower wages, and lower dignity, and that their kids will be lucky to get that much.
Politicians and journalists use new terms for millions of American workers and their children -- the losing class, the anxious class. Yesterday's people.
If Americans were not anxious they would be fools. First they lost the right to public security, now that of job or pride. Companies that once built links with employees now build headquarters designed to keep them away; no personal desks, please.
It is no tragedy when either party is thrown out; that is what elections do. The sorrow is that Republicans and Democrats think the solution is to throw the middle and working class a pizza or two -- which is what tax cuts will get them.
Is that what American conservatism and liberalism have come down to -- not steady jobs at better wages but a choice of toppings on the cheese? As a conservative liberal and bleeding-heart conservative I hate to believe it.
Despite the President's tax-cut speech, the real comeback chance is with the Republicans; but so far they are not even approaching it.
I cling precariously to the hope that some Republican of courage -- maybe Jack Kemp, maybe Bill Bennett -- will campaign for the party to call in its chips to convince business executives that firing thousands in good times or shifting full-time workers to temporary help without benefits is not good business sense but a disaster in the oven.
Give private industry the billions wasted so far on government "retraining" programs. But tax the money back if business does not then show job results.
If leanness-meanness goes on too long and American optimism finally dies, workers may one day fill the streets again. There will be no F.D.R. to rescue capitalism. A new counterculture can grow, this one not besotted by drugs and narcissism. American business will find out how very mean life can get.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

LENGTH: 279 words

HEADLINE: Republican Rome Inspires Republicans

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Peter Passell notes (Economic Scene, Dec. 8) that official poverty rates are based on the assumption that an income three times as large as the basic food budget would put people above the poverty line. This criterion is interesting compared with that used by Cato the Censor in the second century B.C. 
 Relying on Cato's estimates, F. R. Cowell, in "Cicero and the Roman Republic," calculated the annual budget of a minimum-wage free laborer and his wife during this period: food, 52 percent; clothing, 8 percent; rent and extras, 40 percent.
Food consisted of whole-wheat porridge, some vegetables, oil, salt, and watered-down wine.
In the cooler climate of the United States, clothing's share would grow and food's decline. It seems reasonable to conclude that Republican Rome's definition of the poverty line as a multiple of food needs is similar to Republican America's.
If the Roman worker's wage fell below the poverty line, he would have to give up his apartment. If his wages went higher, he would be replaced by a slave. To protect themselves, laborers rioted to extract subsidies from the authorities. This state of affairs lasted in Europe until the late 19th century, when modern welfare systems were developed.
Although slavery may now be gone, labor-replacing technology exists, and we may expect Roman-like behavior from the urban poor of the United States if welfare systems are dismantled.
After tiring of putting down disturbances, Republican America could reinstitute the welfare system. Things really don't change much.
 
JEREMIAH SULLIVAN
Professor of Business
University of Washington
Seattle, Dec. 9, 1994

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1339 words

HEADLINE: Giuliani Plans Inducements To Revive Wall Street Area

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani proposed tax breaks and zoning changes yesterday to bolster the sagging real estate market of Wall Street and the rest of lower Manhattan.
The inducements are intended to encourage new housing and offices in the area and stop any further exodus of businesses. Despite the fame of Wall Street and high-profile sites like the World Trade Center, lower Manhattan's vitality has been drained by outdated office buildings and a lack of housing that leaves streets barren after dark. 
Besides the tax and zoning proposals, the plan calls for other quick actions, like new bus service and express taxicab lanes to improve transportation to the area.
The proposal also envisions more long-term, and tentative, steps to spur development, like express commuter trains from Grand Central Terminal and the Long Island Rail Road Terminal in Brooklyn. Those proposals are most likely to hinge on large public investments, and Mr. Giuliani did not identify new capital financing for them.
His aides said the tax breaks would pay for themselves through increased economic activity and the revenue that it would produce.
The plan is potentially the city's largest development proposal in more than 10 years. It is being announced at a time when lower Manhattan is buffeted by high vacancy rates, falling rents and intense efforts by real estate executives and urban planners to find ways to revitalize the entire area south of Chambers Street.
Mr. Giuliani called for sharp five-year reductions in property taxes and the commercial-rent tax, an unusual tax that business leaders have widely criticized. The cuts would apply to businesses that move to the area and companies that renew leases there, provided that they are in buildings constructed before 1975.
Commercial-rent taxes, 6 percent of a building's total rent, are almost always passed on to tenants. They would be eliminated for qualifying tenants for the first three years of the program. The taxes would then be phased in over the next two years.
Real estate taxes would be halved for the first three years and gradually returned to 100 percent over the next two years.
Mr. Giuliani also proposed easing restrictions on the height and bulk of new buildings, to spur construction.
Although lower Manhattan has been the site of some of the largest and most acclaimed real estate ventures in the nation in recent decades -- complexes like the World Trade Center, the World Financial Center, Battery Park City and the South Street Seaport -- experts say its problems are deeply rooted in the age and architecture of narrow and poorly equipped buildings, most built before World War II.
With little housing, the neighborhood becomes an urban ghost town in the evening, after office workers clear its teeming streets. Even the financial lifeblood -- the investment banks and brokerage houses -- have reduced their presence over 20 years, scattering departments elsewhere in Manhattan and computer operations to offices in Brooklyn and New Jersey.
"The plan is to make lower Manhattan precisely what it used to be, a generator of jobs," said Mr. Giuliani, who was applauded repeatedly as he described his proposals yesterday at a meeting at the Vista International Hotel in the World Trade Center. The meeting was held by the Association for a Better New York, a group made up mostly of real estate executives.
Many aspects of the proposal, including the tax and zoning incentives, would require votes by the City Council and State Legislature. John S. Dyson, Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, said he hoped that both bodies would approve the plan by March.
But approval is by no means certain, particularly because the plan would require the city to forgo anticipated tax revenues at a time it faces major budget gaps.
Mr. Giuliani said the zoning and tax incentives, if approved, would be offered beginning next year. The deputy mayor for planning and community relations, Fran Reiter, estimated that the cost to the city in lost revenues from the commercial-rent and real estate taxes would be $234 million for the first three years.
But in a city analysis that assumed that the program would also retain 3,000 jobs that would otherwise move out of the city, the administration contended that the tax breaks would be offset by $346 million in new city revenues that would be mainly raised through personal and corporate income taxes.
Because the proposal is being announced when the state and city are struggling to resolve huge budget gaps, any possibility of lower tax revenues is very likely to prompt at least some political opposition.
"It's difficult for 51 Council members to agree on anything when only perhaps one-fifth of the membership would benefit," a spokeswoman for the Council, Moronke Oshin, said. She added that any hope of obtaining formal approval by March was "pretty optimistic."
The plan received mixed reviews from Borough Presidents Howard Golden of Brooklyn and Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan. "I would not want to see to see lower Manhattan's problems solved at the expense of downtown Brooklyn," Mr. Golden wrote in a letter to the Mayor. Mr. Golden said City Hall should consider offering the same incentives in downtown Brooklyn.
Ms. Messinger, who has often criticized tax abatements, called the proposal a "well thought-out blueprint" to "help stimulate all aspects of the local economy."
The plan, most of which the real estate industry widely anticipated, is being proposed as business people are struggling to find ways to revitalize lower Manhattan. Property owners there have formed the nation's largest Business Improvement District, a private organization to which they have agreed to pay $8.6 million a year to upgrade sidewalks, improve transportation and attract a variety of stores, offices and housing.
Real estate executives say there is no alternative to extensive government intervention to encourage renovation or replacement of many outdated buildings. Many, built from 1900 to 1940, have floors that are considered too small for modern offices, ceilings that are too low for labyrinths of computer wires and a lack of sufficient interior light and ventilation to be converted easily to apartments.
"The Mayor's plan recognizes the economics of obsolescence," said Richard Kennedy, associate director of Cushman & Wakefield, the real estate concern, who headed a committee of business people that advised the officials who prepared the plan.
Despite the problems in the neighborhood, Mr. Giuliani said, lower Manhattan remains the third largest business district in the nation, based on its commercial real estate, after midtown Manhattan and downtown Chicago. But because of its weak market and increasing vacancies, the assessed value of lower Manhattan real estate has declined 28 percent, from $5.9 billion to $4.2 billion, since 1991.
Under the plan, developers who renovate old office buildings for offices or apartments would receive exemptions for 10 years from increased property assessments based on the improvements.
To stimulate construction further, the plan calls for creating a special zoning district covering all of lower Manhattan. Any existing zoning prohibitions on residential development would be removed. Developers would also not be required to abide by certain restrictions on building heights and setbacks from the street.
Mr. Giuliani also said about 20 buildings should be designated for landmark status and protected from alteration.
Transportation, long a serious aggravation to commuters, would be improved by creating an express taxicab corridor on an unspecified avenue between lower Manhattan and 34th Street.
The most ambitious transportation improvement would be express commuter trains linking lower Manhattan to Grand Central and the L.I.R.R. Atlantic Terminal in Brooklyn. Ms. Reiter said the Metropolitan Transportation Authority had agreed to study the proposal, and would report to the city by the summer.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 21, 1994, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Friday about efforts to attract development to lower Manhattan referred incorrectly to the city's estimate of lost revenue from proposed reductions in commercial rent and real estate taxes. The city said the projected reduction, of $234 million, would occur over 12 years, not 3.
The Guide to New York Dining in the City section on Sunday misstated the telephone number for Maison Caribe on East 85th Street. It is (212) 744-1227.

HEADLINE: Fake Bank Set Up by U.S. Agents Snares Drug-Money Launderers

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16

 BODY:
The Federal authorities said today that a fake bank they created in the Caribbean had crippled major money-laundering schemes used by the Cali drug cartel of Colombia and organized crime groups in Italy.
As the first financial institution ever created and operated by Federal agencies in a criminal investigation, the bank produced what the American and Italian authorities said was the strongest evidence yet of direct financial links between the cartel and Italian groups that distributed their drugs. The ploy allowed the authorities to seize almost $40 million in cash as well as paintings by Picasso and Rubens. 
 So far, more than 90 people have been arrested, including three New York residents who were picked up Thursday night in Montreal. They were identified as Benjamin Marcovitch, 60, an American citizen born in Ukraine; his wife Betty Rios-Marcovitch, 36, a Colombian-born American, and Gregory Kaminer, 46, a Canadian born in Ukraine.
Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney, said in New York that the New York suspects tried to hide at least $3 million for the cartel, using commercial banks in upstate New York, New Jersey and a New York City company, Privat Capital Inc., run by the Marcovitches.
The two-year investigation was begun by the Drug Enforcement Administration and ultimately involved the Internal Revenue Service, the Federal Bureau of Investigation and law-enforcement agencies in four states and four other countries. The bank operated for six months as the final stage of the investigation and was closed down this month, to avert suspicion.
Appearing at a news conference at the drug agency's headquarters in Arlington, Va., to announce the success of the operation, Thomas A. Constantine, the administrator of the agency, said that the suspects arrested included 60 Americans and Pasquale Locatelli, an Italian who was described as the head of a major criminal organization operating across Europe and Canada. Mr. Locatelli, who escaped from a French jail by helicopter in a wild shoot-out five years ago, was captured three months ago in Spain.
More arrests are expected, Mr. Constantine said.
For the last several years, law-enforcement agencies have been piecing together the relationship between the cartel and organized crime in Italy. Officials involved in the latest investigation, called Operation Dinero, said they had documented the cartel's transactions with two Italian crime groups after they created a private bank licensed on Anguilla, a British territory in the Caribbean, in an effort to attract drug traffickers to convert their assets.
The bank, which was actually run out of the drug agency's Atlanta office, enabled the authorities in the United States, France, Italy, Canada and Spain to identify not only traffickers in Colombia but people they used around the world to broker their deals, collect their money and deliver their products.
In addition to the arrests, Mr. Constantine said the authorities had seized nine tons of cocaine and $52 million in assets that included $39 million in cash and three valuable paintings that a Colombian trafficker wanted sold, with instructions to bank "officials" that they they fetch at least $10 million for them.
The paintings, which were confiscated Wednesday night at Miami International Airport after a courier brought them from Colombia, included a 1904 watercolor by Pablo Picasso from his blue period, called "Head of the Beggar"; a painting of St. Paul by the 17th century Flemish master, Peter Paul Rubens; and a work of an unknown subject by the 18th century English portrait artist Sir Joshua Reynolds. One drug agent said an informer had told the authorities that at least one of the paintings had been stolen in France, but the agent said the authorities had not yet determined if that was true.
"We are most proud of the fact we could probe the underground economy of drug traffickers," said William Malarney, a drug agent who worked on the operation. "We were able to get into their board rooms and see what was happening with their financial transactions. They have spent years establishing corporations and boilerplates to protect their wealth from its true source, narcotics trafficking."
The idea to create a bank to attract profits from drug dealers came from a casual conversation with an informer several years ago, Mr. Malarney said. By that time, American undercover agents had begun infiltrating drug trafficking networks by providing money pickup services for the dealers.
But the informer told the agents that what the Colombians really needed was the convenience and respectability of a bank to handle their profits, or to exchange dollars for, say, pesos.
With help from the British Government, American agents picked Anguilla as the fake bank headquarters because of the island's laws protecting the identity of customers. "Headquarters" was an electronic address for moving money rather than a actual building, but officials said they were careful to use stationery and business cards of sizes more commonly found in Europe and made certain that any "bank official" who spoke to a money launderer used perfect French or Spanish.
"After all," Mr. Malarney said with a laugh, "we were bankers."
Once the bank was in place, officials said, undercover drug agents began promoting its services to criminal contacts in Colombia and elsewhere. Then through transactions involving loans, cashiers' checks, wire transfers and currency exchange, officials said they were able to trace the money from Colombia and then to sources the brokers were using around in the United States, Europe and South America.
Mr. Malarney and William Bruton, an agent of the Internal Revenue Service who worked on the case, said that several times, drug dealers discussed airplanes, freighters and other major purchases with people they believed to be officers of the bank.
In one instance, Mr. Constantine said, "they indicated they had $500 million they wished us to launder."
By the time the operation ended, Mr. Constantine said, the bank had created 41 corporate accounts for drug traffickers and handled 92 cash transactions totaling $8.9 million and 291 noncash transactions. Federal agents also handled another $39.5 million before the bank was functioning.
While no one in Colombia was arrested in the operation, officials said that Italy was a huge beneficiary because of the arrests of Mr. Locatelli, who had been serving a 20-year term on drug charges before his escape, and Roberto Severa, who was described as a member of the Rome crime organization called Banda Della Malgliana.
Officials said the Locatelli organization used a fleet of nine ships, including an 85-foot yacht, to smuggle drugs from Colombia and that one was recently intercepted by NATO forces, investigating whether the crew was smuggling arms into Bosnia, in violation of a United Nations embargo. After seizing the ship, the Italian military authorities found two containers on the ship filled with small weapons and ammunition.
"Locatelli is at the top of something that is not from traditional organized crime," Gianni De Gennaro, deputy chief of the Italian national police, said at the news conference. "He is a new figure. I don't know if this means traditional organized crime is weaker or we have to study this case to understand what is a new story of organized crime in Italy."

HEADLINE: PRESIDENT INSISTS HIS TAX CUTS KEEP DEFICIT IN CHECK

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16

 BODY:
The White House set out today to sell President Clinton's proposed tax breaks in the face of far grander Republican promises, saying the political test was whether such proposals could be paid for without worsening the deficit -- and insisting that its cuts could be.
But senior officials withheld virtually all specifics about what Government programs they would cut in five agencies to help finance the $60 billion package over five years. And they acknowledged that the President's proposed tax credits for children and new deductions for education would have to be phased in, starting at perhaps half their eventual value, before savings would be available to finance them in full. 
 "We're talking about having a responsible program, a paid-for program, and not one penny of increase in that deficit," Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said. "We've come too far in this budget-deficit cutting to let the next Congress turn back and start cooking the books. The President wants to make things fair without cooking those books, and that's the way to do it."
The reaction of the Congressional Republicans who will control the fate of any tax plan ranged from tepid praise for the President's ideas to brisk vows to press on further and faster, though they have generally offered even fewer specifics of how they would finance their ideas.
The Administration is committed to producing $76 billion in savings to pay for its plan and to allow further deficit reduction by the turn of the century, when the deficit would otherwise begin rising again. It has identified about $24 billion from reorganizing agencies, about half of it from changes in the Department of Energy, and is reviewing still deeper cuts.
But the bulk of the money, $52 billion, would come from extending through the year 2000 caps on discretionary spending that had been set to expire in 1998 -- meaning that the money would not materialize until 1999.
As a result, senior officials said, Mr. Clinton's proposed tax credit of up to $500 per child for families with adjusted gross incomes up to $75,000 might initially be worth just $250 per child in 1996. Similarly, his plan for deductions for college or technical training of up to $10,000 a year for families earning no more than $120,000 would probably be phased in at $5,000.
"We are going to phase in our tax relief to match our spending cuts, so that in fact we don't have up-front tax relief by down-the-road spending cuts," Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, told a breakfast briefing for reporters.
Ms. Tyson, Mr. Bentsen, Leon E. Panetta, the White House chief of staff, and other officials today repeatedly emphasized the tonic of tax cuts and training efforts, deferring discussion of medicinal spending cuts until Monday, when Vice President Al Gore is to outline many of them in the context of his efforts, already under way, to "re-invent government."
Mr. Panetta did say that the President would offer more details on the effects of continuing the freeze on discretionary spending -- that is, for all programs except those like Medicare, Social Security and others in which spending automatically increases to cover eligible recipients -- in his full budget message early next year.
"We will specify, as we have always had to specify when it comes to that kind of hard freeze, exactly how those savings will be achieved in the budget that we present to the Congress," he said. "We've had to do that the last two years. We will do that with regards to specifics here for '99 and 2000 as well."
Administration officials said an aggressive search was under way for more money in corners of the bureaucracy, an exercise that could eventually produce $22 billion over five years in the Energy Department alone, for example.
About half of that could come from selling government-owned power authorities, administrative entities like the Bonneville Power Administration, to the private sector. They already charge customers for electricity, and thus operate at relatively low cost, so selling them would bring a big one-time infusion of cash, rather than continuing savings.
Officials said other proposed cuts included $4 billion from delaying cleanup of pollution at some nuclear production sites. Other options for savings include cuts in research programs; turning over management of the Naval Petroleum Reserve, where oil bought by the Government is stored underground for use in emergencies, to the private sector, and closing one of the national laboratories that conducts high-technology research, though the site has not been chosen.
The officials said such savings could be used for even deeper deficit cutting, or to let the tax breaks take full effect immediately.
"This is not a budget document, and we shouldn't yet be held to that level of detail," a senior Presidential aide said.
In fact, the President was pressed into specifics about the tax breaks in part to win live television time for a Thursday night speech that aides initially said Mr. Clinton envisioned as a philosophical statement of direction for the next two years, in the wake of last month's elections. In the end, Mr. Clinton's 10-minute talk, which he dictated into a tape recorder and then reworked, was part wish-list for the future and part revival of winning themes from his past.
The President was cheered enough by the address that he, his wife, Hillary, and Mr. Panetta gathered the staff on the South Lawn for a brief meeting today, to thank the troops, bid them happy holidays and rally them on.
Top aides went out of their way to portray Mr. Clinton's tax proposals as consistent with longstanding priorities, like education, and his 1992 campaign promise of middle-class tax relief, which he dropped in favor of deeper deficit reduction, the success of which they said had now made tax breaks possible. But the language they chose implied a new tack.
"He is getting back to the core principles and dreams on which he ran," said Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich.
The President would consolidate 60 existing Federal job training programs into a system of "skill grants," in which qualified individuals could get vouchers of $2,000 to $3,000 for use in private job training programs.
In addition, Mr. Reich noted, Mr. Clinton's proposed tax deduction for education would apply not only to parents sending their children to college but also for anyone who sought more schooling later in life.
At a White House briefing, Secretary Bentsen pointed to charts showing the growing share to median family income consumed by the annual cost of college, now 15 percent for families with children in public colleges, up from 11 percent in 1980, and 40 percent for those with children in private colleges, up from 26 percent.
Mr. Reich, Ms. Tyson and Mr. Bentsen said the President had not ruled out a cut in capital gains taxes, one of the Republicans' chief ideas. But they said he would not support one that benefited only upper-income taxpayers, and declined to discuss how such a reduction might be made more broadly applicable.
The Treasury Department also released charts to buttress the Administration's assertion that it was the true friend of the middle class, by showing that just 13 percent of the President's proposed tax breaks would go to families with incomes over $100,000, compared with 54 percent of the proposals in the House Republicans' "Contract With America."

HEADLINE: Russian General Halts His Tanks As Qualms Over Rebellion Grow

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Dec. 16

 BODY:
In an extraordinary sign of the Russian military's unhappiness with its mission in the rebellious republic of Chechnya, the commander of a tank division halted his advance about 20 miles from the rebel capital today and promised local villagers that he would not go any further.
The officer, Maj. Gen. Ivan Babichev, told weeping Chechen women: "It is forbidden to use the army against peaceful civilians. It is forbidden to shoot at the people." 
 There were other signs today in Moscow and Grozny, the Chechen capital, that both sides are under heavy pressure to find a peaceful way out of the conflict.
In what he described as a good-will gesture, the leader of the secessionist Chechen republic, Dzhokhar M. Dudayev, said he had ordered his troops to withdraw one kilometer from the front line, or about half a mile, and to stop firing at Russian troops.
And the Russian Prime Minister, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, said he would lead negotiators to resolve the conflict, promising to meet Mr. Dudayev "anywhere, anytime."
Deputy Prime Minister Nikolai N. Yegorov, President Boris N. Yeltsin's representative at the military command post in Mozdok, in North Ossetia, was recalled to Moscow tonight to attend an emergency meeting of the National Security Council to examine the crisis.
Mr. Yeltsin's decision on Sunday to send hundreds of tanks and tens of thousands of troops to bring Chechyna to heel was not a popular one, particularly in the Defense Ministry. Two leading military figures, Gen. Boris V. Gromov and Lieut. Gen. Aleksandr I. Lebed, have spoken out against the invasion.
Dissension among officers involved in ground operations spilled out in public today. In a remarkable display of compassion -- and possible insubordination -- General Babichev hugged weeping Chechen women in the village of Novo-Shurvoi, about 20 miles from Grozny, and assured them that he would not advance on the capital or fire upon their sons.
General Babichev had stopped his column's advance in the area after unarmed civilians blocked his tanks. Today, as a Reuters TV crew filmed the scene, the officer said he did not think he was disobeying orders. "Why should I be fired?" he asked. "Article 5 of the President's decree says that we shouldn't shoot at civilians or send our tanks against civilians."
Next to him a colonel was equally moved by the appeals of pleading villagers, who said, "Please don't kill our sons."
The colonel replied: "It is not our fault we are here. We are not going to attack people with our tanks. Let us solve this together."
In Moscow, Defense Ministry spokesmen said they were aware of the officers' comments, but declined to make any of their own.
The Kremlin, unhappy about the unflattering press coverage of the Chechen conflict, complained about "unreliable" news reports by Russian and Western journalists and threatened to withdraw the license of the independent television news channel NTV, whose broadcasts from Chechnya have angered high-ranking Yeltsin officials. In the last few days, Interior Ministry troops have fired warning shots at reporters and camera crews seeking to enter Chechnya.
Even after Mr. Yeltsin decided to postpone a final assault on Grozny on Dec. 15, the date he had set as the deadline for Chechen forces to lay down their arms, criticism of the President did not abate.
In the upper house of Parliament, a member of the Russia's Choice party returned from a visit to Grozny today and chastised the Kremlin for bombing apartment buildings in the capital, causing what he angrily described as "mass killings of civilians."
Mr. Yeltsin received a small boost from Vice President Al Gore, who is in Moscow to discuss economic issues, and who repeated that Washington looked upon Chechnya as an "internal Russian affair."
"We hope it can be resolved through negotiations, as all involved in it do," Mr. Gore added.
Defense Secretary William J. Perry, who was also in Moscow today, said Russian military officials had told him that they want to solve the crisis in Chechnya with as little bloodshed as possible.
"That's what they are trying to do," Mr. Perry told reporters on his aircraft. "But in terms of how they are going to do that, and what tactics and approaches they use, that I don't feel free to discuss."
Some American officials, however, expressed some serious concerns over the Russian position in Chechnya. "It is disturbing, because there seems no real consensus on what you do to get out and declare success," one official said. He said the idea of storming Grozny was hardly attractive, since military firepower is not much use in a crowded city.
To the visitors from Washington, Chechnya seemed part of a preoccupation in the Kremlin about the erosion of central Government authority in a country where taxes are not paid, organized crime is rampant and Mr. Yeltsin's decrees are often ignored. "They're looking for ways to regain that kind of authority," the official said.
There is little love for Chechnya among most Russians, many of whom view Chechens as mobsters and petty criminals. But the invasion and the Chechen resistance have for the moment recast Chechens as the underdog fighting for independence against Russian neo-imperialism.
To combat that trend, Mr. Yeltsin's office issued a statement today labeling the rebel territory a "powerful crime-breeding zone" and "one of the most sinister centers not only of Russian but also of world crime."
Mr. Yeltsin, who has been out of sight since the invasion began recovering from minor surgery on his nose, met with Mr. Gore in his hospital suite today. He was also intercepted by a reporter from the weekly newspaper Argumenti I Fakti while walking from a treatment room to his hospital room.
"A big war won't start," Mr. Yeltsin told the reporter. "The conflict is not extending beyond Chechnya so far."
But even a presidential adviser, Emil Pain, warned that the widening breach between Mr. Yeltsin and his former allies imperiled Russian democracy.
"There are two Chechen conflicts in Russia," he told reporters this week. "One in the North Caucasus, the other in Moscow. The one is Moscow is even more dangerous."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Companies
Maurice Saatchi was forced out of Saatchi & Saatchi, which he and his brother built into a global advertising power. Mr. Saatchi stepped down after the board sided with shareholders angry about his pay package and his role in internal squabbles. The board also said it would change the name of the British company. [Page 39.]
Lockheed won a $1.3 billion order to supply Britain with 25 military transport planes. The choice of an American company came over protests that the Royal Air Force should wait for the development of a European military freighter. [39.]
U.S. Shoe has reopened talks with Nine West Group, which has offered to buy the company's footwear division in a $627 million deal. U.S. Shoe's rejection of an earlier $425 million offer from Nine West had set off loud protests from some shareholders. [39.]
Shares of General Electric jumped in heavy trading after the company increased its quarterly stock dividend by 14 percent and said it would buy back as much as $5 billion worth of stock. [39.]
Hoffritz, an old name in knives, has a second chance at survival. Last week, a group of investors injected $500,000 into the company, which was forced into bankruptcy in August. [39.]
Steinhardt Management and Caxton agreed to pay a total of $76 million to settle charges that they had cornered the market in an issue of two-year Treasury notes in 1991. [48.]
Philip Morris named new heads for its food and tobacco divisions. The appointments were seen as a further sign that the company was unlikely to split up its businesses. [41.]
In an effort to set a standard in movie compact disks, Sony and Phillips introduced a joint design for a digital videodisk. [41.]
American Eagle shut down its Chicago commuter service after a pilots union complained of inadequate training. [A1.]
The chairman of USX was arrested and charged with carrying a gun without a license. [41.]
Kiwi International Airlines reached an agreement with the F.A.A. that will allow the carrier to resume service. [30.]
 
Markets
Stocks surged in the busiest trading day since the 1987 crash. The expiration of options accounted for much of the activity. The Dow rose 41.72 points, and the S.& P. 500 gained 3.45 points [39.]
Treasury prices were mixed. Bonds rose, and notes fell. [48.]
Coffee prices jumped after a report showed a steep drop in supply in the United States. Sugar prices also rose sharply. [49.]
The dollar was little changed in quiet trading. The Canadian dollar weakened after Quebec's debt rating was lowered. [49.]
 
The Economy
Starts on new houses rose 6.9 percent in November, the most rapid rate for residential construction in nearly a year. [48.]
Orange County, Calif., sold the rest of the $1 billion in Government-sponsored notes in its troubled investment portfolio. [48.]
 
Your Money
Taking the self-employed route requires caution and planning. Replacing the corporate safety net of insurance, pension and other benefits may be put off for a while, but it must be reckoned with eventually to achieve some degree of financial security. [37.]
The bankruptcy of Orange County, Calif., points to the need for municipal bond investors to guard against risk. But securing too much safety can be wasteful, experts say. [37.]
Families intent on getting the most in college aid need to make adjustments two years before their student enters college. [38.]

HEADLINE: Gore Upbeat After Talks With Top Russian Leaders

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Dec. 16

 BODY:
After 10 days of fevered speculation about the state of relations between the United States and a more nationalist Russia, American officials said today that "a lot of air has been cleared" and that "the relationship is in pretty good shape."
Vice President Al Gore, after three days of talks with the Russian Prime Minister and a morning meeting with President Boris N. Yeltsin, was upbeat. 
 "My impression is there is no 'cold peace,' but instead a warm relationship that's very much on track," he said.
Mr. Gore was referring to a harsh speech in Budapest by Mr. Yeltsin, who warned the United States in the presence of President Clinton not to try to manage the "destinies of the world community," and said, "Europe is in danger of plunging into a cold peace."
Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin was also positive in public remarks today. "Despite some inevitable frictions, our partnership is an active one," he said. "This is a partnership needed by both countries in equal measure."
Mr. Chernomyrdin praised the work of the Joint Commission on Economic and Technical Cooperation, which he and Mr. Gore direct. The panel has focused the work of the two Governments on issues from defense conversion to environmental protection and now public health.
Asked about vows by Republicans in Congress to cut foreign aid, Mr. Chernomyrdin expressed confidence that the Clinton Administration "will deal with your Congress, and we will deal with ours."
Significant hard feelings remain on the American side, the officials acknowledged. Mr. Yeltsin embarrassed and angered President Clinton by blindsiding him in public, the officials said, only days after Foreign Minister Andrei V. Kozyrev stunned American officials by suddenly refusing to join in NATO's "Partnership for Peace," an affiliation intended to lead eventually to full NATO membership.
The Russians then vetoed a minor intensification of sanctions against their Serbian allies in the former Yugoslavia that was proposed in the United Nations Security Council, and blocked statements at the Budapest meeting assigning any guilt to the Serbs in the Bosnian war.
In a busy exchange of communications, senior American officials said, "it was made clear to Mr. Yeltsin that you don't embarrass your friends in public." But it also became clear, they said, that the Russians had misunderstood American intentions about the pace of NATO expansion.
"The Russian reaction was in part for domestic political consumption," a senior official said. "But they also made an assumption, which was wrong, that there had been some sudden decision to accelerate NATO expansion, which they understood as a threat to isolate them from Europe."
Russian officials expressed the concern that any such decision would imply that the Americans had given up on Russian democracy, the American official continued, "and writ large and personal, it meant that Bill Clinton had given up on Boris Yeltsin."
Separate Russian conversations with European officials within NATO apparently fed the Russian concern, American officials said.
The result was the Yeltsin-Kozyrev shower of cold water and deep American annoyance and embarrassment, the officials said. "But it was also a shot across the bow," one official said, addressed to a number of audiences: the Clinton Administration, the new Republican Congress, the East Europeans and domestic Russian nationalists.
"And the message was heard," the official said. The Russian message, he said, was clear: "We're in Europe whether you like it or not."
The Russian broadside may also help clarify an internal Clinton Administration problem: officials have been trying to give two different messages about NATO expansion.
They imply that it is inevitable and will be relatively quick, to pacify Eastern European countries like Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic while encouraging Ukraine and making a nod toward Congressional Republicans. That was why the North Atlantic Council, in a statement, spoke of a study in 1995 of the process of "gradual" NATO enlargement -- apparently the beginning of Moscow's misunderstanding.
At the same time, the Americans are trying to reassure the Russians that NATO's expansion will be a "gradual and open process," with no hidden messages and no desire to isolate Moscow.
" 'Gradual' carries some ambiguity," a senior American official said. "Ambiguity can be your friend, but it can also be your enemy."
It is in the contradiction between those two messages, American officials admit, that the Russian misunderstanding could arise, providing Moscow an opportunity to raise its voice and profile. They said Mr. Gore had spent a good part of his time with Mr. Yeltsin explaining that NATO had not supported rapid expansion, but only decided to study it. "The Russians don't always believe what we tell them, of course," one official said.
The contradiction is somewhat absurd, the officials say, since it will take at least four or five years for the first East European countries to qualify for NATO membership, and current European members have no desire to expand their defense pact to the Russian border or beyond.
Mr. Gore was the first foreign official to see Mr. Yeltsin, who has been in the hospital for minor surgery, and he said the Russian President appeared healthy and fit, "hale and hearty and in good spirits." He said the signs of Mr. Yeltsin's operation, on a deviated nasal septum, were almost gone.
