HEADLINE: A Plan That Tries to Please

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16

 BODY:
The blueprint for tax cuts that President Clinton unveiled on Thursday night was not only an appeal to disgruntled middle-class voters. It was also directed at the nation's nervous financial markets, which may ultimately hold the veto power over the best-laid budget plans of either Democrats or Republicans.
While it may have been fear of more middle-class wrath that forced Mr. Clinton to move at all, more than two years after his campaign promise to cut taxes for ordinary working Americans, fear of the markets also kept the proposal limited in scope. Although $60 billion over five years is a lot of money, it is still a drop in the stream of an economy rushing along at $6 trillion annually. 
 Anything much bigger, economists said today, would create doubts that either party could pay for the tax cuts they are championing with equivalent spending reductions. And even the first hint that the Administration might be weakening in its commitment to pay for any tax reduction would almost certainly lead investors to drive up already-rising interest rates, undercutting the same home buyers and university students that Mr. Clinton says he is dedicated to helping.
This counterbalancing is just the most recent illustration of how little room the President, or his opponents, have to maneuver, at least if they stick to the commitment not to make new cuts in the biggest entitlement programs -- Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid.
And the markets are imposing a vague sort of discipline on the notoriously flexible budget process.
"The bond market will sniff out any flimflam in the cuts," said Allen Sinai, chief economist at Lehman Brothers. "And if that pressure is felt by both political parties, the result could be that Washington really will be forced to drastically cut the least productive segment of the economy -- the Government itself."
The Administration's constraints were acknowledged by Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen in remarks today and in an interview in his office earlier this week. Mr. Bentsen, a deficit hawk whose resignation takes effect next week, said there would be "not one penny of increase" in the budget deficit as a result of the tax cuts.
"I made that mistake in 1981," he said, speaking of the time in the Senate when he voted for President Ronald Reagan's tax cuts, which began the huge increase in the Federal deficit, "and I don't need to learn that lesson twice."
But as he was packing up to return to Texas, Mr. Bentsen expressed concern that the result of the President's initiative, on this and a range of other issues, would be to force the Republicans to make even more dramatic gestures. "Whatever the President comes up with," he said, "the Republicans will move to the right."
"I'm not very optimistic about bipartisan cooperation," he said, particularly on issues like the overhauling of the nation's welfare system.
It is just that scenario that could spook the bond markets, which are hypersensitive to any suggestion that the Federal deficit will worsen, after several years of successful reductions. In fact, the markets are looking for Mr. Clinton to accelerate budget cutting, because under the current plan, the deficit reduction peters out starting in 1996, as entitlement benefits continue to rise.
This morning, the chairwoman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, said she had little fear that a bidding war between Congress and the White House would spin out of control, and send the deficit soaring again.
"It is not the case that we in Washington can freely act to do things which are fiscally irresponsible, because the result of that will be not just in domestic financial markets, but in global financial markets," she said.
"Two constraints will provide discipline -- the discipline of the voter, and the discipline of the market."
That is not to say that analysts and investors are driving every detail. If economists, for instance, had their choice, Mr. Clinton's tax cut would take a very different turn. With the economy growing at such a fast clip, few want to spur demand, which is exactly what Mr. Clinton's proposal would do if it freed up more family income now devoted to college tuition or child care. Instead, many economists would prefer to increase savings and production capacity, and perhaps cut capital gains taxes, in hopes such a cut would increase manufacturing capacity.
But economists do not run for re-election. And Mr. Clinton's aides feel considerable pressure, after a month of intense focus on bolstering free trade in Asia and Latin America, to show that they can prepare American workers for the heightened competitive pressure they will face because of more open markets around the world.
"There is still a lot of feeling in the middle of the country that free trade is a death warrant for many blue-collar workers," one of Mr. Clinton's close advisers said last weekend during the summit of Latin American nations in Miami. "Over the next year, we have to show the other side of the coin -- the retraining, the stress on college educations."
Mr. Clinton's plan comes out of that mold. Rather than just reduce tax rates or grant blanket tax credits, as some other Democrats and a raft of Republicans have proposed, this tax cut is carved from the favorite hobby horses of this Administration. There is a deduction of up to $10,000 a year for retraining or university tuition, a tax credit of up to $500 for each child under the age of 13 in families earning no more than $75,000, and a loosening of the rules on I.R.A.'s to allow deductions for catastrophic illness or buying a first home. "Clearly, we are investing in human capital," Ms. Tyson said.
But no matter how well it is clothed, a tax cut is a tax cut, and taxpayers will spend the money as they see fit. That is the central contradiction: Economic theory dictates that tax cuts are for times of economic downturn, and enacting one now spends a bullet that might otherwise be saved for the next recession.
And then, of course, there is the deficit. Mr. Clinton's own cabinet members have said time and again over the past few weeks that if they were not paying interest on the Federal deficit, the Government's budget would be in surplus this year. Rather than cut taxes, Mr. Clinton could simply declare that he would use the savings from shrinking Government to shrink Government debt -- figuring that $60 billion would do more good there than spread over millions of taxpayers, most of whom would see only a few extra dollars a week in their pockets. Some voters, Mr. Clinton's aides suggested before the election, would rather see more aggressive deficit reduction than what one termed "a fairly meaningless tax cut."
But that was October. No one in the White House was talking about that option today.

HEADLINE: Dow Up 41.72 in Heaviest Trading Since '87

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Stock traders ignored another signal of a possibly overheating economy and bid up stock prices higher yesterday during the biggest trading day since the 1987 stock market crash.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 41.72 points, to 3,807.19, as trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange hit 483.2 million shares. That was the third-heaviest volume after the record 608 million shares set on Oct. 20, 1987, just after the stock market plunge of Oct. 19, when 604 million shares were traded. 
 The broader Standard & Poor's 500 index rose 3.45 points, to 458.80. But the smaller-company Nasdaq composite index fell 1.61 points, to 729.07.
Traders reacted only mildly to a report that the housing industry continued to demonstrate unexpected strength, which in other sessions would have been interpreted as bad for stocks. Housing starts rose 6.9 percent in November, the biggest increase since March. [Page 48.]
And a dividend increase and big stock buyback plan by General Electric gave skittish investors a reason to invest in stocks, traders said.
Blue-chip stocks have recovered more than two-thirds of the ground they have lost since mid-November. The Dow has now advanced for five of the last six sessions, regaining some 121 points after a 171-point selloff over five sessions starting Nov. 17.
Under the peculiar logic of the financial markets this year, good news about the economy has often led to bad news for stock and bond prices because traders worry that the economy will threaten to become inflationary months from now and thus prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates as a pre-emptive move.
But the housing news came on a day when traders were scrambling to cope with the so-called triple witching expiration yesterday. Trading volume shoots up on triple witching days because traders must decide whether to "use it or lose it" for a wide variety of stock options, index futures, and options on futures.
Harrison Roth, senior options strategist for Cowen & Company, noted that most of the options activity was concentrated in large stocks like AT&T, Exxon and Coca-Cola. That may account for the weakness in the Nasdaq index, he said. The Russell 2,000 index of stocks, representing the bottom 2,000 companies of the largest 3,000 United States stocks, fell 0.20 point, to 241, Mr. Roth said.
But both the bond and international currency markets, which did not have the distorting effect of triple witching stock trading, also seemed to react mildly to the housing news. The dollar closed mixed against major currencies and bonds were basically unchanged. The yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond fell to 7.85 percent from 7.87 percent.
Matthew F. Alexy, government trading strategist of CS First Boston, said bond prices fell after the housing report but recovered quickly because the fine print was more encouraging. Permits for future construction fell 1 percent, he said.
More important, Mr. Alexy said, 75 percent of the housing starts were for apartments, rather than single-family homes. Homes, with their large initial outlay for mortgages, furniture and other expenses, are a better barometer of consumer spending than rental apartments, he said.
Moreover, the market climate has changed, he said. The sentiment among bond traders has shifted toward a later increase in interest rates by the Fed, perhaps a rise of three-quarters of a percentage point as late as February.
"Early in the week, maybe 50 percent of traders were betting on some early tightening by the Fed," Mr. Alexy said. "Now 80 percent, 90 percent of traders are betting the Fed won't tighten now, but wait until January and probably February."
Trading of General Electric stock, at 7.9 million shares, was the heaviest of the year for G.E. and the third-heaviest of any stock for the day. G.E. rose 1 1/4, to 50 1/4.
Almost 40 percent of G.E.'s volume came from a single trade of 3,004,700 shares at the beginning of the session. The identity of the trader was not immediately known. G.E. yesterday raised its dividend 14 percent and authorized the repurchase of as much as $5 billion of G.E. stock over the next two years.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 1.58 points, to 250.54, with advancing stocks outnumbering declining stocks by 1,364 to 938. The American Stock Exchange market value index rose 0.21, to 426.23.
Of the 30 component stocks that make up the Dow industrials, 25 stocks rose, led by Alcoa, which gained 1 7/8, to 83 1/2. Of the 500 component stocks that make up the S.& P. 500, 316 rose, led by G.E and Exxon, which rose 1 1/8, to 61 3/4.
The most active stock, at 10.7 million shares, was Intel, which rose 7/8, to 59 1/2.

HEADLINE: Cuomo Makes His Last Speech as an Official, in a Hurry

BYLINE: By MELINDA HENNEBERGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo began what he said would be his last speech as a public official by excusing himself for talking so fast. There was so much, he said, that he wanted to say.
 In a 35-minute goodbye at the National Press Club, Mr. Cuomo said he did not expect to become a Supreme Court justice and does not intend to become commissioner of baseball. ("If you did want to give a political opinion from time to time, you couldn't do it.") 
 He also said he did not want to become chairman of the Democratic National Committee, adding that there are already a number of capable people in line for that job.
 Instead, he is negotiating with universities, where he wants to lecture on an occasional basis rather than teach full-time. He is entertaining offers from the kind of white-shoe law firms that once rejected the Queens-born son of a grocer who for years lived behind his father's store. And he has hired James M. Griffin of the William Morris Agency to help sort through a stack of book, television, radio and lecture offers.
 Of yesterday's speech, Mr. Cuomo said it was so short that it left out "a lot of the good stuff." In it, he was wholly unapologetic and combative as ever, calling Republican proposals to simultaneously cut taxes, boost military spending and balance the budget "deja voodoo." After his formal remarks, he repeated the contention that Governor-elect George E. Pataki won by counting on anti-incumbent backlash without taking on the issues.
 "I said his tax cut was so large he'd never do it, and he never will," the Governor said. "And that was the end of it. They waited until the end and brought it back. But he didn't argue with me about criminal justice. There were no issues. He just thought, 'He will be defeated because he's been there so long.' And I was."
 Lightheartedly, but often enough to suggest he wasn't entirely kidding, he suggested that he'd been fighting a funk since losing his bid for a fourth term last month. "The temptation, you know, is to whine, you know, at least a little bit," he said. "Why not? You served 12 years, you're entitled.
 "And I caught myself doing that. I began pointing out to people that ever since the Republican landslide on Nov. 8th, it's been getting dark outside a little earlier every day. You notice that?"
 Aides say Governor Cuomo has not taken the loss particularly well, spending some days obsessing about the election and others looking forward to the future. Indeed, it should come as little surprise that the complicated brooder who has so frequently been compared to Hamlet would not easily shrug off such a loss. But friends say that Mr. Cuomo is resilient.
 "I'm disappointed," the Governor said, when asked about his frame of mind following his defeat. "I'm sorry." He said he wanted a fourth term "more than I wanted the first three because I think this is a more important moment."
 "So I regret it," he said, "but it certainly in no way diminishes my gratitude to the people of the state."
 And he is by no means the "unemployed, homeless" unfortunate he jokingly called himself in his speech. He recently bought a three-bedroom Sutton Place co-op with a terrace, a river view and 24-carat gold on the bathroom fixtures.
 Much of yesterday's speech was vintage Cuomo: he blasted Republicans for pitting the middle class against the even less fortunate, saying: "In the end, behind nearly every one of the Republican proposals lurks the same harshness and negativity. And I think we need better from our leaders than to have them distill our worst instincts and then bottle the bitter juices and offer them back to us as a magic elixir."
 He also exhorted his own party to stick to its principles. "We'd rather preserve a family than build an orphanage," he said. "We believe that we're too good as a people to seek solutions by hurting the weakest among us -- especially our children. And at our wisest, we believe that we are all in this together."
 Representative Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn said the Democratic Party hopes, perhaps, to tap Mr. Cuomoas the kind of spokesman who could "counter the Limbaughs."
 And, of course, he will continue to give speeches, saying that he has lost, learned, forgotten nothing and is eager to share his experiences. He continues to wrestle with the existential questions that follow him around, saying that his parents, a priest, and a lot of good books had taught him to expect a lot of disappointment and occasional moments of joy.
 "In the end, you've got to find some raison d'etre,"he said.

HEADLINE: U.S. Bonds Gain While Notes Drop

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Treasury bonds posted their first gain in three days and notes fell yesterday as the market looked ahead to a Federal Reserve meeting and a new supply of notes next week.
The price of the 30-year bond rose 7/32 of a percentage point, to 95. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 7.85 percent, from 7.87 percent on Thursday. The price of the two-year note, meanwhile, fell for the first time in four days, pushing its yield up to 7.56 percent from 7.51 percent. 
 The spread between the two-year note and the 30-year bond was 29 basis points, 7 basis points narrower than Thursday and down from 47 basis points two weeks ago. A narrowing spread suggests increasing investor expectations the Federal Reserve will soon raise rates. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
But many traders expect the Fed will put off an increase in short-term interest rates when its policy-making committee meets on Tuesday and will wait until its next scheduled meeting, a two-day session beginning on Jan. 31, to act. The Fed has raised short-term rates six times since February in an effort to prevent inflation from accelerating. Reports on producer and consumer prices this week indicated that the pickup in inflation the Fed had warned about has yet to appear.
"The Fed has won," said Jane Wyatt, chief investment officer at Voyageur Asset Management in Minneapolis, which has $6.2 billion in bonds. "We have a moderate economy and moderate to low inflation."
A report showing a strong rise in November housing starts failed to shake the market's expectations for the Fed. The Commerce Department reported that builders increased new construction on homes by 6.9 percent last month, in the sharpest advance since March.
The report at first prompted some selling, but prices recovered as traders attributed the increase in housing starts in part to last month's mild weather. The market also focused on a decline in permits for future construction, suggesting that housing was due for a slowdown in coming months.
If the Fed does surprise traders and investors by raising rates next week, Treasury notes and bills with maturities of five years or less are more vulnerable than the long end of the market. Another rate increase "will hurt the short end, but it won't hurt the bond because it will slow the economy," said Terrence Crowe, a trader at Nikko Securities.
The prospect of a supply of new notes from Treasury auctions next week pushed the prices of three- and five-year notes lower yesterday, traders said. The Treasury plans to auction $17.25 billion of two-year notes Wednesday and $11 billion of five-year notes Thursday.
Municipal bonds were little changed yesterday amid concern that selling by bond funds may increase following a resumption in investor redemptions, traders said.
Investors resumed withdrawing funds from mutual funds this week after Orange County, Calif., filed for bankruptcy and as the yields on individual bonds became more attractive.
"Funds are net sellers," said Mike Bauer, a trader at Starr Securities. Some investors are "afraid they will get year-end redemptions" and are selling bonds to raise cash.
The average yield to maturity in the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal issues edged up to 6.99 percent, from 6.98 percent on Thursday.
